webTitle: New coach due by Christmas

fields.headline: New coach due by Christmas
fields.standfirst: Business gurus assess England's plight
fields.trailText: The FA hope to have a new coach in place by Christmas, and chief executive Adam Crozier has said that the choice will be his alone. But just how qualified are the people who are will advise him in the coming weeks?
fields.body:
Adam Crozier, the FA chief executive, says he is hopeful of having a new England coach in place by Christmas. If the shambles of the past few days is anything to go by, the new man will be looking forward to the festive season as eagerly as one of Bernard Matthews' turkeys.

Crozier has already assembled what he believes are his wise men to advise him on his choice and he has doubled the traditional Christmas quota of three. They are not, he stressed, a selection panel, merely a team of "top-class people with real opinions".

Opinionated they might be, but those who crave real change at the top of the England football hierarchy are unlikely to share the view that they are top-class, let alone the right men to confer on who should receive the poisoned chalice of England coach.

Few would oppose the Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale and Arsenal's vice-chairman David Dein. But the remaining voices belong to Dave Richards, the Premier League chairman who has presided over a disastrous few years at Sheffield Wednesday; Howard Wilkinson, the FA technical director and caretaker England coach; the international committee chairman Noel White; and the executive director David Davies.

Crozier said we must "stop appointing a new England manager every 18 months". He wants, he says, a coach who can take the team forward over the next five to 10 years, seeming to suggest that the new man might bring his own successor(s) with him to provide the sort of continuity invented by the Germans and successfully imitated by the French. But many of the men who are to advise him are not only linked to past mistakes, in some cases they are synonymous with them.

White of Liverpool is the kingmaker who not only appointed Graham Taylor to the England stewardship but refused to remove him after the disastrous European championship of 1992, leading to England failing to qualify for the 1994 World Cup finals. He also ensured that Terry Venables' spell was not extended.

Richards' Wednesday are in free fall, which led to protests by fans at last night's volatile annual general meeting. As part of a board that has been unable to supervise the selection of a suitable club manager, how on earth can he be trusted to help choose one at international level?

Wilkinson, who already wields an unhealthy amount of power for most people's liking, is seen as the dead hand preventing the modernising of the English game. It is not clear yet whether he wants the job himself, either. If he does he should not be sitting as an adviser, and if he does not, how easy will he find it to help select someone who may bring in a coach in his place?

And on what grounds is Davies, a non-football man who ushered Kevin Keegan into the job with unseemly haste after playing a huge part in the demise of Glenn Hoddle by ghosting his infamous diaries, included?

Crozier was asked to explain his qualifications for the task in hand, particularly as he has made it clear he alone will select the new manager and he alone will interview candidates. The best he could offer was that he represents the calm in the eye of the storm. In other words, he is likely to be deeply reliant on his six advisers. Mostly men whose decisions have already proven to be deeply flawed and who represent the same old vested interests that have brought England's national team to the present parlous state. How quickly the new dawn fades.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Wenger given touchline ban

fields.headline: Wenger given touchline ban
fields.standfirst: New coach due by Christmas
fields.trailText: So much for Arsène Wenger being an ideal candidate for the England job. The FA last night banned him from the touchline for 12 matches for his behaviour at Sunderland on the opening day of the season.
fields.body:
If the Football Association is hoping to land Arsène Wenger as England coach it went about the job in an unusual fashion last night by banning the Arsenal manager from the touchline for 12 matches and fining him four weeks' wages.

The punishment relates to an incident in the tunnel after Arsenal's defeat at Sunderland on the opening day of the season. Given that the ban applies only to domestic matches, perhaps the FA hopes Wenger will soon be pining so much for the dug-out that he will agree to succeed Kevin Keegan.

Arsenal announced immediately after yesterday's hearing at Lancaster Gate that they will appeal. Wenger had pleaded not guilty to using "threatening behaviour and physical intimidation" towards the fourth official, Paul Taylor. If the appeal fails and Wenger repeats the offence of jostling or intimidating officials, he faces a minimum one-year touchline ban under the FA's new disciplinary regulations.

"Mr Wenger insisted to the commission his behaviour was aimed at preventing a far worse incident involving the Sunderland player [Darren Williams] and Arsenal's Thierry Henry," said the FA's executive director David Davies.

Tensions were high after Patrick Vieira's dismissal in the last minute of Arsenal's 1-0 defeat for a retaliatory strike at Williams. His team-mates seemed to feel Williams had cheated and Wenger later said of what followed in the tunnel: "It was a minor incident. I was trying to separate two players."

However, the FA apparently decided the evidence presented at the hearing by Taylor and Williams was more persuasive. Davies said Wenger had questioned "several points" in their stories.

"Mr Wenger's sentence is in line with the minimum punishment contained in the new disciplinary guidelines introduced this season and agreed by the FA Premier League, the Football League and the FA board of directors," Davies added. "The Professional Footballers' Association and League Managers' Association also supported the guidelines."

Wenger's four years at Highbury have been peppered with disciplinary problems. His players have been shown 31 red cards in that time, with Vieira responsible for six of them.

Wenger's suspension begins on October 30 and could keep him off the bench until the new year. For his first match watching from the stands, against Ipswich in the Worthington Cup, he will be without Gilles Grimandi, who has been banned for one match for stamping on Gary McAllister's hand against Liverpool at Highbury in August.

Middlesbrough's Paul Ince was fined £15,000 and warned about his future conduct after being found guilty of misconduct and use of abusive language against Derby in September, while Swindon's manager Colin Todd was fined £2,500 for misconduct towards referees and using foul and abusive language. Carlisle's manager Ian Atkin was fined £1,000 and given a 28-day touchline ban for a similar charge.

Claudio Ranieri has made his first signing for Chelsea by completing a £1.7m deal for the Yugoslavia midfielder Slavisa Jokanovic from the Spanish champions Deportivo La Coruna. The 32-year-old has signed a two-year deal.

Chelsea have abandoned hope of signing the Brazilian winger Savio but one South American heading for the Premiership is Sacundo Bonvin, a 19-year-old Argentine winger who has joined Newcastle on loan for the rest of the season from Boca Juniors.

In another loan move Fulham have taken Nicolas Sahnoun, a 20-year-old defensive midfielder, from Bordeaux for a year. Middlesbrough's manager Bryan Robson has pulled out of a £4.5m move for the centre-back Lucien Mettomo and instead hopes to sign the Australian Simon Colosimo.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Halifax at war with big four

fields.headline: Halifax at war with big four
fields.standfirst:
Crack team to take the sting out of transferring current accounts
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Halifax prompted expectations of a war for banking customers yesterday by pledging to break the stranglehold the "big four" clearing banks have over 30m current accounts.
fields.body:
Halifax prompted expectations of a war for banking customers yesterday by pledging to break the stranglehold the "big four" clearing banks have over 30m current accounts.

The bank said it would set a 100-strong "crack switching team" on the customers of Lloyds TSB, HBSC, NatWest and Barclays which would take the pain out of transferring accounts by handling direct debit transfers.

To lure customers, Halifax pledged to pay a 4% rate of interest on deposits and charge 10% on authorised overdrafts, beating the rates offered by its four rivals who between them control 80% of the market.

The planned assault prompted sharp falls in bank stocks, their second successive day of jitters as dealers reported profit-taking in the sector. Banks were the worse performing in the FTSE 100 index, with some falling as much as 8%.

Halifax claimed that if the big four decided to match its rates it would cost them a combined £1bn in profits.

James Crosby, chief executive of Halifax, said: "The battle for customers starts today. The perception about inertia [among customers] is very strong. It will become a myth very quickly."

The move, intended to double its 5% share of the current account market, will cost the bank £50m initially. It intends to spend £100m in total to take a share of the markets held by the four banks, attacking credit cards, personal loans and the small business banking next. The plan follows the Cruickshank report which highlighted the difficulty associated in moving current accounts, now being tackled by the industry.

While there was some confusion among rivals about how its Halifax-branded accounts would compete with its new telephone-cum-internet operation Intelligent Finance, Mr Crosby insisted they were aiming for different customers.

The new Halifax rates are aimed at customers who want to continue to use branches, which the bank said a poll showed 75% of the population would prefer to use.

Countering statistics that people are more likely to divorce than move their current account, Halifax said an NOP poll had found 15m current account customers would consider changing banks if they could find better interest rates.

But a senior banker at one of Halifax's rivals cast doubt on the statistics about interest rates being a factor. He said the biggest win for Halifax would be if it could reactivate the current accounts held by 2m of its customers, which he said were not their primary account.

Halifax will pay the interest rates to customers who pay in salaries of more than £1,000 a month.

Best rate

How they compare

First figure: Credit interest (gross) Second figure: Authorised overdraft rate

Halifax: 4% :10%

Barclays: 0.1%: 18.8%

HSBC: 0.1%: 16.9%

Lloyds TSB: 0.1%: 18.8%

NatWest: 0.1%: 18.38%

Source: Halifax

webTitle: Working Lives: The way we work

fields.headline: Why boys and girls don't go out to play
fields.standfirst:
The way we work: Richard Reeves

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The way we work: Richard Reeves
fields.body:
'W e don't need no education, We don't need no thought control.' Pink Floyd's social comment is an ironic anthem for the schooled classes; the bars of Oxbridge colleges still reverberate to its beat.

The message was ahead of its time. The needs of the economy have changed dramatically, but the education system is stuck in the past. While employers cry out for post-industrial workers, schools are run on strictly industrial lines. Children are sorted into clear hierarchies, the teacher is indisputably the boss, progress is relentlessly quantified and time is divided into equal shifts, signalled by loud bells. Few of us now file through factory gates in the morning, but we still push our kids through the school gates into institutions designed for another age.

Trends in education policy are making things worse. The national curriculum, so inflexibly enforced, is like an unreasonable edict from head office. The testing virus is out of control and emphasis is given to "proper" subjects such as maths and science, while art, music and drama are further downgraded.

Perversely, many of the changes in schooling are made in the name of better equipping children for the world of work. Vocationalisation of education is the order of the day. Children and young people have got the message: the numbers studying economics and philosophy A-levels are falling as ever more plump for business studies and law. Research by Ann Sherman, from Nottingham University, found that, just one term into primary school, five-year-olds know they are there to "get a job" and that "work" is something imposed, while "play" is what they choose.

This is scary stuff: primary school as the first step on the career ladder. It might just be tolerable if there were any evidence that the education system is, in fact, preparing us for work. But it is not. Employers are sceptical of exam grades and are looking for other skills. Post-industrial workers need to be self-confident team players, networkers, innovators. They need to be able to teach themselves new skills and the quirkier they are, the better. Given the needs of today's firms, who could argue that playing in a school band or football team is not going to be more valuable than sitting in a silent classroom cracking algebra questions?

But those activities are not scored and ranked, so schools cannot focus on them. Precisely the activities that do equip young people for the new world of work are being squeezed out by a misplaced emphasis on "core" skills.

New Yorker John Taylor Gatto, winner of the US Teacher of the Year award three years running, blows apart the "three Rs" myth in Changing Schools, a groundbreaking report from the Scottish Council Foundation. "The truth is that reading, writing and arithmetic only take about 100 hours to transmit, as long as the audience is eager and willing to learn ... The continuing cry for 'basic skills' is a smoke screen behind which schools pre-empt the time of children for twelve years."

The education system's failure to adapt cannot be blamed on teachers. Rising class sizes and bales of bureaucratic paperwork are preventing teachers from doing what they do best. In his book My Ishmael, the novelist Daniel Quinn writes: "Teachers for the most part would be delighted to awaken young minds, but the system within which they must work fundamentally frustrates that desire by insisting that all minds must be opened in the same order, using the same tools, and at the same pace, on a certain schedule."

Of course we need better teachers - but we also need to free the teachers we have got right now. It is time to deindustrialise schooling, ditch the obsession with exams, allow children to follow their own intellectual passions and stop constantly scoring, ranking and tabling those activities "experts" from the department for education decide are the important ones.

Unless we rethink schooling, education will serve to reinforce the class divide in the workplace. Employers are much more likely to complain that a potential recruit can't talk to customers with confidence than that they can't add up. These "soft" skills - communication, presentation - are provided with mother's milk in middle-class households. If schools don't nurture these non-academic skills, the life-chances of children from disadvantaged backgrounds will be worse than ever and the divide between rich and poor will grow.

 Richard Reeves is director of futures at the Industrial Society. You can contact him at rreeves@indsoc.co.uk.

webTitle: Theatre review: The Red Shoes

fields.headline: The Red Shoes
fields.standfirst:
The Red Shoes
BAC, London ****
fields.trailText: Most people remember the Powell and Pressburger film starring Moira Shearer about a dancer who becomes a slave to her art and her ballet shoes; fewer recall that it was inspired by a seriously unpleasant Hans Christian Andersen fairy tale.
fields.body:
Most people remember the Powell and Pressburger film starring Moira Shearer about a dancer who becomes a slave to her art and her ballet shoes; fewer recall that it was inspired by a seriously unpleasant Hans Christian Andersen fairy tale.

Kneehigh Theatre return to the original, about a young orphan punished for her vanity in wearing red shoes to church: she is condemned to dance in them until she turns red raw and her skin clings to her bones. The result is delirious: witty, macabre, with a light tone that still gets to the dark heart of this tale of temptation, obsession and the fatal lure of red.

The initial few minutes of this production - part of the British Festival of Visual Theatre - suggest that a feyness of tone might mar the evening. Like so much of Kneehigh's work, which caters to a wide range of people, there is a tendency to treat the audience as if it is a couple of pairs short of a shoe shop. But that is turned to advantage as the simpleness of the theatrics collides with the story's inherent melodrama. Like the best fairy tales, it works on the unconscious, ensnaring and ultimately freeing us.

The story is told by hollow-eyed travelling players clad in grubby underwear who transform themselves like greedy children raiding the dressing-up box. A point of a finger, a pair of clogs, a flash of diamante, a pair of goggles and they become sinister gender-bending storytellers or angels disguised as world war one aviators.

One of the best things about the show is the way it subverts theatrical convention. There is no attempt to suspend disbelief. Everything is paste but, like the shoes themselves, that knowledge actually increases the show's glittering allure.

Writer and director Emma Rice makes subtle reference to women's experience and 20th-century society's expectations of them, but at the heart of the story is its metaphorical meaning. We all have a pair of red dancing shoes hidden somewhere. The question is whether we give into temptation and join the dance.

 The BFVT runs until October 21. Details: 020-7223 2223.

webTitle: Working Lives: Unprofessional odours

fields.headline: When the wind blows
fields.standfirst:
Anita Chaudhuri on unprofessional odours

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Anita Chaudhuri on unprofessional odours.
fields.body:
Spare a thought for Paula Levins. She was busy getting on with her career as an accountant with a firm in Ireland when she was forced to share an office with a man who thought it was quite the thing - to put it bluntly - to fart his way through the working day. The smell apparently became so unpleasant that Levins was forced to work beside an open window, even when it was bitterly cold outside.

Alas, her bosses did not take her complaint seriously, so she resigned and launched a claim for constructive dismissal. This week, the firm has agreed to settle out of court, which is probably just as well for the man concerned. After all, any tribunal would surely have caused him serious embarrassment. ("And how many times a day did he break wind?" Shocked murmuring in court. "When you say bad smell, how bad?")

Yet, despite the potential cringe-factor, more of these types of cases are ending up in court. Last year Ian White, a journalist with the Kidderminster Shuttle, was sacked because of apparent poor personal hygiene and took his case to tribunal. Despite arguing that his problems stemmed from depression, White lost his case. The tribunal ruled his dismissal was "a reasonable response from a reasonable employer".

Anyone who has ever worked in a cramped, overpopulated office will know that the personal habits of co-workers can be a major source of stress and discomfort. It needn't be a question of poor hygiene: I have been driven to despair by a boss singing Blues Brothers songs, loudly and tunelessly, a colleague bringing in noxious egg sandwiches for lunch and another who asphyxiated us all with regular spritzes of Poison.

The most familiar dilemma, though, does concern body odour: do you tell the colleague to their face or leave a can of RightGuard on their desk anonymously?

"Don't do the deodorant trick," advises workplace psychologist Sarah Lewis. "That's passive-aggressive, and it won't achieve anything." She advises that, whatever the problem, it is best taken to someone at a more senior level. "A good manager should ask the person making the complaint to keep an accurate record for evidence purposes."

So Levins should have kept a log of wind patterns? "Well, that's what it takes. Otherwise, when the subject is broached, the person might say: 'Well, everyone farts, it's a bodily function.' Then you can say: 'Not 25 times a day!' The same goes for any personal hygiene problem."

Lewis suggests, though, that managers should be careful about how such issues are handled. "It's important you stress from the outset that it is not the person's work that is at issue. You should also stress what a valuable member of the team they are and how you want to help them."

webTitle: Working Lives: Office romance

fields.headline: The end of the affair
fields.standfirst:
You spend more time with them than with friends or family - but woe betide you if you fall for a colleague. Dave Hill reports on new moves to put the squeeze on office romance

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: You spend more time with them than with friends or family - but woe betide you if you fall for a colleague. Dave Hill reports on new moves to put the squeeze on office romance.
fields.body:
Their eyes met across the carpet tiles. His fingers caressed the keyboard and his message flew to her screen.

Her response was immediate. Chancing another glance, he smouldered under the same gaze that had set him on fire the night before. But suddenly he felt a chilling hand upon his shoulder - the hand of the most feared enforcer in Human Resources. "Mating games belong in fields," he growled, placing a P45 casually on the desk. "When will you people learn? Passion is for playtime. This here is a place of work."

Could it actually happen? Could employers really believe that workplace liaisons are so terribly dangereuses that they would make them a sacking offence? According to recent reports, some already do. Or, to be precise, the argument has been made that certain clauses in some firms' codes of employee conduct effectively amount to a ban on romance on the shop or office floor. Those cited include an allegedly growing number of civil service departments and some major high street names.

These, it has been claimed, are just the high-profile tip of a growing iceberg as employers in general become more nervous about the possible implications of libidinal interactions among their personnel. Coupled with the prospect of the government giving bosses the formal right to monitor employees' emails without their knowledge or consent, it seems fears about managers controlling the personal lives of subordinates more tightly than ever may be justified.

So what exactly is going on? Marks & Spencer - mentioned in a dispatch from The Director magazine as being one of those with "stated policies that govern office romance" - firmly denies any ban on relationships exists. But increasingly companies do appear to be feeling the need to take a tougher stance on certain connections between employees that might deflect them from their duties.

HSBC is one of a number of banks whose employee handbook includes the requirement that personal relationships should not be allowed to impair efficiency or breach customer confidentiality. Such relationships, though, include not only lovers, but also long-term partners, siblings, parents, uncles and so on. A spokeswoman explains that, yes, HSBC employment contracts do require staff to abide by the guidance in the handbook, but insists it is absurd to suggest this amounts to a back-door ban on entanglements: "We categorically refute the charge that it is an attempt to control people's love lives."

Talk of personnel departments deploying hard-faced sex police to outlaw love- or lustlorn workers might be overdone: indeed, it is difficult to see how desire could be outlawed effectively in practice. With more and more women going out to work, and British workers toiling for more hours per week than those anywhere else in Europe, it is hardly surprising that so many of us meet our partners during our labouring hours rather than in our leisure time.

Nonetheless, it is clear that employers are growing increasingly preoccupied by sexualised behaviour in the ranks, thanks to the substantial rise in the number of legal cases brought for sexual harassment. In the US it is now commonplace for companies to encourage or cajole employees in sexual relationships to sign "love contracts". Also known as consensual relationship agreements, they typically require the signatories to pledge that their arrangement has been entered into willingly and to promise that if and when it all goes horribly wrong, neither party will sue the firm's directors on grounds of sexual harassment or discrimination.

The aim is to provide protection against the fallout from an affair. A jilted subordinate may claim she was pressured into having sex by the senior figure who has since dumped her. People may argue they were passed over because they were sleeping with someone at an adjoining desk, or claim their working life became unbearable because the company failed to act when somebody they used to be involved with wouldn't leave them alone. And so on.

Could it catch on here? Judi James, management consultant and author of Sex At Work: A Survivor's Guide, published by the Industrial Society, thinks it unlikely. "There's an element of scaremongering about it," she says. "Some company lawyers like to stir it up, but I can't see it working in Britain." James doubts if people here would put up with such intrusion. "It seems to me you're effectively asking someone not to object if they are sexually harassed by a certain person. To me, that is signing your rights away."

It is unclear, she says, how US-style "love contracts" would hold up legally. Indeed, Bill Clinton's weasel definition of "sexual relations" during the Monica Lewinsky saga shows just what a quagmire of definitions may await. When exactly is a relationship deemed to be taking place? Would it have to have been pursued on the company premises or would it also incur action if only conducted elsewhere? Does penetration have to have occurred?

Where sexual grievances are concerned, James strongly advocates that companies establish proper complaints procedures, rather than trying to insulate themselves against future litigation in individual cases. This is obviously better for employees and if an employer does find itself on the wrong end of a tribunal, it will do no harm to be able to demonstrate that it takes such matters seriously.

As for the broader issues - the love match blossoming amid the VDUs, the jitterbugging of pheromones in the canteen - draconian suppression across the board looks unworkable, not to mention heartless and counterproductive. As work comes to dominate our waking hours, surveys have found around 40% of employees have been intimate to some degree with workmates at some time.

Charles Cochrane, secretary of the Council of Civil Service Unions, says that the civil service - also named last week as operating a "love ban", though this was news to the major civil servants' professional organisations - has rules about harassment and bullying. But he would be very concerned at any attempt to snuff out mutual attraction. "We would want to know what evidence there was that this was a problem," he says. "There could be serious implications. Our Newcastle central office employs so many people that if you banned relationships there, I doubt if anyone would have a social life at all."

webTitle: Pop review: Julian Cope

fields.headline: Julian Cope
fields.standfirst:
Julian Cope
City Varieties, Leeds ****
fields.trailText: Julian Cope has nothing to promote. No new book; there hasn't been a new album for four years. He's touring, he tells us, because people at his sporadic book-signing sessions said he should. On one hand, this sums up the eco-warrior author's now seemingly irreversible marginalisation as a pop performer. But almost three marvellous hours in his company demonstrate that Cope's unlikely success is something far more cherishable.
fields.body:
Julian Cope has nothing to promote. No new book; there hasn't been a new album for four years. He's touring, he tells us, because people at his sporadic book-signing sessions said he should. On one hand, this sums up the eco-warrior author's now seemingly irreversible marginalisation as a pop performer. But almost three marvellous hours in his company demonstrate that Cope's unlikely success is something far more cherishable.

He doesn't even have a record company, never mind kowtow to one, but creates an intimate, magical antidote to rock's current sterile, corporate excesses. Cope has spent the past 20 years trying to convince us that he's weird, but seems to have finally accepted that he's just extremely funny.

This year's model wears stack heel boots (which render him 8ft tall), ladies' tights, a camouflage jacket, make-up and about three tons of matted hair. With his neck dyed blue, he looks like a neanderthal man reincarnated as a larger-than-life glam rocker. His appearance may well render this show unsuitable for small children (who would certainly run away), but at least it's impossible to look elsewhere.

Half the show is aided by Donald Ross Skinner on bass/ keys and normal haircut; the rest is just Cope, a guitar, a synthesised drone and wit. The stripped-down, ghostly voices lean towards Cope's Fried period, and there are few hits - but plenty of visits to the back catalogue's political wing.

Like Frank Zappa, Cope appears to have realised that the best way to deliver a serious message is with humour. Promised Land, he says, was designed to get rid of Thatcher. "It didn't work," he sighs. "I needed two or three other songs."

Sunspots is mauled, Me Singing is spellbinding, but there aren't any new songs. Three years in the making, his Citizen Caned album remains uncompleted. However, for the moment it is enough for Cope to remind us that he "rocks" (as he puts it). Thus, for Sleeping Gas, he crawls Iggy-like on his belly, clambers over the theatre's seats, and finally stands precariously aloft on two chairs. "I'll be back next time with bigger boots!" he howls. And he probably will.

webTitle: £2.25-plus hint on pensions

fields.headline: £2.25-plus hint on pensions
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
Special report: welfare reform
fields.trailText: Ministers last night raised pensioners' expectations dangerously high when they promised an inflation-busting increase in the basic state pension to repair the political damage inflicted by last year's paltry 75p a week rise.
fields.body:
Ministers last night raised pensioners' expectations dangerously high when they promised an inflation-busting increase in the basic state pension to repair the political damage inflicted by last year's paltry 75p a week rise.

Although the announcement of stronger than expected inflation in September - used as a benchmark for the annual uprating of benefits - guaranteed the elderly an extra £2.25 next year, both the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and social security secretary, Alistair Darling, signalled a much bigger increase was in the pipeline.

"We want to do more, much more for poor pensioners," Mr Darling told the Guardian. "We will make sure that all pensioners share in the rising prosperity of the country."

Pensioner groups and Labour MPs leapt on his words as proof that the government will make amends for last winter's gaffe ahead of the expected May election when "grey" votes will be important.

With unions and pensioner lobbies demanding the restoration of the pre-1979 link between pensions and earnings, some experts are urging Mr Brown to use a less costly option by tying pensions to the growth in gross domestic product (GDP). Either option would mean up to £7bn in extra taxes to pay for it by 2010.

Whitehall discourages speculation that Mr Brown will adopt the GDP formula, but refuses to provide any further hints as to how the Treasury will distribute the extra money. That was the crucial misjudgment last year which ruined what Mr Brown hoped would be seen as generosity.

Then he targeted the poorest and the very old who got free TV licences, as well as increasing the winter fuel allowance to £150 for all. But it flopped politically.

In his speech to the Labour conference two weeks ago Mr Brown promised help for pensioners beyond the annual upgrading of the state pension in his pre-budget report, due late this month or early in November, when fuel protesters are also looking for generosity.

Based on yesterday's inflation figures, when higher fuel prices helped push the monthly increase from 3% in August to 3.3%, the basic state pension would rise from £67.50 to £69.75 - nearly three times last year's increase. The married couple's pension would go up by £3.60 from £107.90 to £111.50.

Treasury sources said next year's above-inflation in creases would be designed to tide pensioners over until the introduction of a new pensioners' credit in 2003.

There is speculation that these measures will produce an increase of £5 for single pensioners and £8 for couples.

Help the Aged's spokesman, Mervyn Kohler, said: "Today's announcement of a £2.25 a week increase is more welcome news than this year's derisory 75p increase. However, this is still not going to lift anyone out of poverty. The government has to do more than give pensioners an increase which will barely buy them the pint to celebrate."

The unexpectedly strong increase in the annual rate of inflation was driven by higher oil and petrol prices but the national statistics office said there was also pressure from household goods, especially from furniture and furnishings, as prices continued to recover from big summer sales.

The sharper than expected rise rekindled fears that the bank's lending rate - currently at 6% - could rise again.

webTitle: Art review: Sonictraps

fields.headline: Sonictraps
fields.standfirst:
Sonictraps
Angel Row Gallery, Nottingham ****
fields.trailText: Since the early 1990s, Aaron Williamson has been building a reputation as one of Britain's most engaging performance artists. Reading from his books A Holythroat Symposium and Cathedral Lung, he added the sounds and gestures of primal theatre to fragments of texts. Lately, though, he has found his rightful place with gallery installations.
fields.body:
Since the early 1990s, Aaron Williamson has been building a reputation as one of Britain's most engaging performance artists. Reading from his books A Holythroat Symposium and Cathedral Lung, he added the sounds and gestures of primal theatre to fragments of texts. Lately, though, he has found his rightful place with gallery installations.

Williamson's struggle with deafness has made him deeply aware of the inaccuracies and ambiguities of language. With the Sonictraps installation, he takes as his subject the involuntary head sounds that are experienced as much through bodily nerves and muscles as through hearing. Teeth chatterings, yawns, sighs, sneezes, hiccups and groans are translated into sculptural assemblages scattered throughout the gallery.

A small bell rendered soundless by being embedded into a block of wax is entitled Sob. A single suede shoe abandoned on a doormat bears the inscription: "Now the (yawn) is in the gaping mouth of a left-footed shoe whose tongue has been yanked out..."

Williamson has escaped the relative obscurity of the experimental literary world for the more publicly controversial, but less intellectually rigorous, arena of fine art. Yet it's when he brings the necessarily tentative scores to life in performance that one really gets a sense of what he is up to.

In the first of three scheduled performances, the artist stuck his head into a bowl of pepper, whittled away at an old chair leg with a blunt knife, embossed text into his bare arm and foot, struck up a mock classical pose while having a good old yawn, then padded across the gallery on tiptoe like a bewildered spook.

The event predictably attracted a distinctive audience. One rather suspect-looking character with scissors down his sock circled around, as did a pair of twins dressed in black from head to toe.

Peculiar stuff - but certainly for real.

 Until November 11. Aaron Williamson will give performances in the gallery on October 20 and November 10. Details: 0115-915 2869.

webTitle: Theatre review: Daryl Hannah's seven-year tease

fields.headline: Daryl Hannah's seven-year tease
fields.standfirst:
The Seven Year Itch
Queen's Theatre, London
fields.trailText: Memorable for the movie version, in which Marilyn Monroe experienced difficulty with her skirt, The Seven Year Itch began as a play in 1953. It remains fixed in that decade in its psychology, humour, stagecraft, and, most of all, in Michael Radford's polished but dreary production. Radford's idea of a joke is not to recreate the notorious skirt-raising scene, but to have Daryl Hannah's Girl undo her top and lean against a fan. Like everything else in this production, it is just a tease.

Like everything else in this production, it is just a tease.

The story is as 1950s as cherry pie. Richard, a New York publishing executive anxious about looming middle age, waves goodbye to his wife and son. Then a tomato plant from the upstairs duplex falls on his terrace, narrowly missing him.

Instead of getting mad with the culprit, Richard falls for her - hardly surprising when she turns out to be Daryl Hannah. But Richard is consumed by guilt and keeps going into fantasy mode (cue a light change) in which he imagines his wife being unfaithful, himself being unfaithful, his wife shooting him and then herself. I fear the only genuine concern is that the audience might prove unfaithful and leave before the end, pausing only to shoot the cast.

This isn't so much a star vehicle as a star zimmer frame. This is a pity, because although Hannah is very much a 21st-century sex goddess - twice the height of Monroe, half the width and a quarter of the charisma - she does exhibit the odd spark. Given a decent play, she might be good at comedy.

Just as The Blue Room was about Nicole Kidman without her clothes, and The Graduate is about Jerry Hall in the buff, The Seven Year Itch is entirely about being able to gawp at Hannah's legs that reach upwards spectacularly. The gimmick is that she isn't naked. There are entire scenes where she wears a complete stitch. That's a new one for Shaftesbury Avenue, although this tired evening is further evidence that the West End has lost the will to do theatre, and now only does celebrity.

 Until December 9. Box office: 020-7494 5040. This review appeared in some editions of yesterday's paper.

webTitle: IT specialists celebrate as court orders tax review

fields.headline: IT specialists celebrate as court orders tax review
fields.standfirst:
Professionals say policy causes a brain drain
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Computer contractors were celebrating last night after the high court ordered a judicial review into IR35, the government policy which prevents consultants claiming self-employed tax privileges while working for just one company.
fields.body:
Computer contractors were celebrating last night after the high court ordered a judicial review into IR35, the government policy which prevents consultants claiming self-employed tax privileges while working for just one company.

Mr Justice Gibbs ruled in favour of the Professional Contractors Group, set up to lobby on behalf of IT specialists, which used European Union law to argue it discriminated against small firms and was causing a brain drain.

The case will now proceed to a full trial which is expected to be heard in February. Gareth Williams, chairman of the PCG, said he was "over the moon" about the decision but called on ministers to rethink the entire policy.

The introduction of IR35 last April, he claimed, was forcing thousands of experienced consultants to move overseas and making a mockery of Tony Blair's aim to fuel the growth of e-business in Britain.

"People with a decade of experience are being driven abroad," he said. "If we don't succeed and the tax bills starting landing on the door mats, the real exodus will start. This is clearly going to slow [internet-related development] down and will allow other countries to take the lead. We will be left behind and it's going to be difficult to catch up."

Most of the defecting consultants are believed to be setting up in Germany, Holland, Ireland and the United States.

The PCG says its members will be subject to unfair taxation - including the loss of deductible expenses enjoyed by larger companies.

Mr Justice Gibbs said its case was arguable on three grounds: the greater tax burden was effectively state aid to large contractors; it restricted the movement of workers across the European community as it was commercially unviable for small contractors to operate in the UK and represented interference with the property rights of small companies.

Despite yesterday's ruling, the government has no plans to back down from its stance. It insists the old tax regime allowed employees to quit their jobs and return the following day, as a consultant, doing exactly the same work but paying far less tax.

A spokeswoman for the inland revenue said: "The government is confident that the full hearing at the court will decide that the legislation is fair, proportionate and compatible with all the UK's obligations under EU law."

The outcome of the judicial review, which can be appealed, is expected to be made public by next April.

webTitle: Pop review: Will the real Robbie Williams please stand up?

fields.headline: Will the real Robbie Williams please stand up?
fields.standfirst:
Robbie Williams
NEC, Birmingham ***
fields.trailText: Robbie Williams might as well have swaggered onstage polishing his big metal testicles. Orff's Carmina Burana, reworked around the singer's name, thundered round the NEC on this first night of a 21-date, five-city tour as a prelude to Robbie's emergence; meanwhile "public announcements" counted down the minutes to lift-off. The anticipation, like the hype, is palpable. That he starts his set with Let Me Entertain You - as much a plea as an offer - and then confesses "I'm shitting myself" demonstrates the contradiction at Williams's heart.
fields.body:
Robbie Williams might as well have swaggered onstage polishing his big metal testicles. Orff's Carmina Burana, reworked around the singer's name, thundered round the NEC on this first night of a 21-date, five-city tour as a prelude to Robbie's emergence; meanwhile "public announcements" counted down the minutes to lift-off. The anticipation, like the hype, is palpable. That he starts his set with Let Me Entertain You - as much a plea as an offer - and then confesses "I'm shitting myself" demonstrates the contradiction at Williams's heart.

The nation's favourite cheeky chappie is a neurotic superstar who needs his audience as much as they worship him. He may dress up his showmanship with raised eyebrows and camp glances - as if it's all a bit of a larf - but, for Williams, pleasing the crowd is a serious business. It is almost a compulsion.

Not that he needs to worry: the audience was more than willing to bless him with their affection. As well as what was once Williams's core audience - teenage girls in capri pants with carnal thoughts beyond their years - the crowd was swollen with adolescent boys flushed with testosterone and in search of a role model, burly blokes in their 20s in much the same predicament, and more burly blokes in their 40s who probably also had tickets to see Tom Jones.

Middle-aged women ("Let me entertain you, Robbie," one shouted lustily after Karma Killer) completed the smorgasbord of the Great British public, all hollering along to Strong, No Regrets and the latest single - Kids, his duet with Kylie - with unfettered enthusiasm. This audience certainly lends weight to the notion that if there's a cultural icon that unifies Britain right now, it isn't the Royal Family or Coronation Street, it's Williams. Once an underdog, he's now the mutt's nuts.

Still he frets, though, protesting too much with his ironic, devil-may-care attitude. Williams's tongue remains so firmly in his cheek for so long that, if the wind changes, he may stay that way. And that would be a shame, since the bloke from Stoke is at his best when he is most genuine - a heartfelt rendition of She's the One is one of the night's highlights.

All his cowboy-punk-Elvis posturing dangerously obscures Williams's formidable vocal talents, not to mention the excellent songwriting for which he and writing partner Guy Chambers are responsible. They are undoubtedly two of the most important British music writers since Lennon and McCartney - and, live, Williams and his band (including Chambers on keyboards) do their songs every justice, adding rather than obscuring nuance and subtlety. Indeed, this was the first time I considered No Regrets could be about Williams's relationship with his estranged father, not simply a tormented love song.

Yet Williams's first encore once more betrayed the karaoke king as he burst into My Way before segueing into his own singalong classics, Millennium and Angels, which the crowd crooned nearly by themselves. Williams was well chuffed. There's another song that Williams might consider for next time, instead of Carmina Burana. It's called Manic Superstar.

 Robbie Williams is at the NEC, Birmingham (0121-780 4133), from tomorrow until Saturday, then tours.

webTitle: Pop review: Shea Seger's strange brew

fields.headline: Shea Seger's strange brew
fields.standfirst:
Shea Seger
Borderline, London ***
fields.trailText: Some people make it so difficult for themselves. Only when 20-year-old Shea Seger and her five accomplices have actually finished the nine songs which comprise her London debut, and her fifth show ever, does the realisation strike: apart from a barely audible thank you at the climax of the closing song May Street (from her exhilarating first album The May Street Project), she has not uttered a single word between songs.
fields.body:
Some people make it so difficult for themselves. Only when 20-year-old Shea Seger and her five accomplices have actually finished the nine songs which comprise her London debut, and her fifth show ever, does the realisation strike: apart from a barely audible thank you at the climax of the closing song May Street (from her exhilarating first album The May Street Project), she has not uttered a single word between songs.

Her body language suggests similar aloofness. Hidden behind comedy sunglasses, she sings with her hands in the pockets of a pair of grubby trousers in which she may well have spent the afternoon gardening. Former performing arts student or not, Seger is not one for projecting. Thus, from the back of the tiny Borderline club, Seger is drowned out by conversation and clinking glasses. If she cannot be bothered to perform, the crowd cannot be bothered to listen.

Move closer, though, and the situation turns on its head. These songs - the single Last Time, Isn't it Good Tonight, Shatterwall - are excellent: tight, trip-hoppy beats, overlaid with the vocal catch and pop sensibility of Sheryl Crow. It's a strange brew, but it works. More crucially, Seger, neither beautiful nor plain, has a wonderfully expressive face which, despite those sunglasses, tells her distinctly adult tales as vividly as her voice.

Twisted is all bitter recrimination and Walk on Rainbows all unbridled optimism, but May Street itself, titled after her childhood address, is the most heart-stopping. She even takes both hands out of her pockets during the verses. It's an angry, wistful, moving trawl through her Texas upbringing (she moved to London in 1998) told with the same elegiac air Van Morrison applies to his stream-of-consciousness Belfast childhood stories. Those behind the first five rows remained indifferent, but the rest were shellshocked by the mesmeric intensity of what they have just experienced. Playing arenas may be a long way off, but if Shea Seger played in your front room, your life would never be the same again.

webTitle: Art review: Picasso has second thoughts

fields.headline: Picasso has second thoughts
fields.standfirst:
Picasso Linocuts
British Museum, London ****
fields.trailText: Creativity itself was the theme of Picasso's art in the last two decades of his life, when he was living in the south of France, married to a young wife, Jacqueline, and feasting his eyes and imagination on the Mediterranean and its myths. In the 1950s and 60s, he experimented with a bewildering variety of media, decorating plates, drawing in ball-point pen, always with intense energy.
fields.body:
Creativity itself was the theme of Picasso's art in the last two decades of his life, when he was living in the south of France, married to a young wife, Jacqueline, and feasting his eyes and imagination on the Mediterranean and its myths. In the 1950s and 60s, he experimented with a bewildering variety of media, decorating plates, drawing in ball-point pen, always with intense energy.

It's easy to reduce this to the biographical cliche of an old, angry man raging against the dying of the light, but Picasso's last metamorphoses were about more than that. No artist responded as acutely to the violence of the 20th century: after the second world war, when he reached back for classical imagery, Picasso was asking if art still had a purpose.

This small but fascinating exhibition of linocut prints executed between 1959 and 1962 gives the answer: yes. These red, caramel and black prints evoke some of the oldest European art of all, and the most joyful: the red and black ceramics of classical Greece with their strutting satyrs, dancing nymphs and flowing wine.

Picasso re-created the colours of ancient ceramics using the unglamorous modern material of linoleum. The conventional method, using several blocks of lino, one for each colour, was too dull for him, so he used the same block and kept recutting it. The results - demonstrated in the British Museum's complete collection of working proofs for his print Femme nue à la source - are multiple reinventions of the same image, second thoughts, second looks, that mock the idea of a final state.

The "final state" of a print is the one the artist releases; although you can look at Picasso's successive takes on La femme nue à la source - a big-breasted, long-haired woman bending down to a fresh spring full of goldfish -as a progress towards the version he published in an edition of 50, you can hardly see the earlier states as sketches.

Each one is confident, complete - another way things could go. The relativism that Picasso introduced into western art before the first world war still informs these late works as the woman mutates from a lithographic outline into a muscular woodcut-like body, and finally into the richly reddened published version which resembles a Greek vase.

Picasso reveals mythic forms in the block; a faun playing the flute, nymphs entangled in a bacchanalian scene, a frenzied, ecstatic woman dancer.

But most of all there's a fascination with the form and its mutation, the classical ideal and its comic vulnerability. Picasso does not believe for one minute in a pure classic idyll. He believes in an art that turns to the world around it for refreshment, absorbing and enjoying each moment, tasting the water - like the woman bending down to the renewing fresh spring, the source.

 Until January 7. Details: 020-7636 1555.

webTitle: Hussain sees Klusener as benchmark

fields.headline: Hussain sees Klusener as benchmark
fields.standfirst: South Africa's big hitter will examine England's 'bottle' today
fields.trailText: Nasser Hussain believes taday's quarter-final against South Africa will be an accurate gauge of his team's chances of success this winter as England attempt to cope with big-hitting Lance Klusener.
fields.body:
After a comprehensive but expected win over Bangladesh, some runs at last for the captain and a week of nets, things get serious now for England. South Africa, their quarter-final opponents today at the Gymkhana Club, have more than success in the ICC Knockout Trophy on their minds.

The whole credibility of their cricket is under scrutiny. This is the first time England have played them since the shaming of Hansie Cronje, and his successor as captain Shaun Pollock has stressed that the only route to restoring trust and pride is through impressive performances on the field. So expect South Africa's senior players such as Pollock, Lance Klusener, Allan Donald and Jacques Kallis to be motivated.

England's captain Nasser Hussain will be especially interested in his bowlers' reaction if Klusener, voted player of the tournament in last year's World Cup, starts connecting with the railway sleeper he calls a bat. Hussain believes the way his bowlers handle Klusener will be an accurate gauge of their chances of success in Kenya and on the tours of Pakistan and Sri Lanka.

"If Klusener starts attacking our bowlers, we'll find out about their bottle," Hussain said. "The pitch here is good, the ground is small and so far in this tournament the ball has been disappearing all over the place. There's a lot of pressure on bowlers and they must remain cool and patient. I think the secret of trying to keep Klusener quiet is to bowl straight in order to restrict his room to play shots.

"We've played a lot of cricket against South Africa in the past couple of years and I believe we've improved since we toured there last winter."

He added: "When the ball peppers the boundary so much, life is difficult for a captain. In comparison, last summer's triangular tournament was quite straightforward because the ball was moving around and batsmen were always under pressure. But here even a good over can go for 10 runs, because a few feet either side of a fielder and it is four. A captain must keep his wits about him and will come off drained after 50 overs.

"Before our game against Bangladesh I told our bowlers to keep calm even if the ball keeps going for four. And the message will be the same against South Africa. It is a stern examination."

"Bottle" has been a theme of Hussain's pre-match analysis and he believes his Essex team-mate Paul Grayson has sufficient mental resolve not to crumble on the big occasion. Grayson was yesterday brought into the 14-man squad officially for the first time at the expense of the injured Ashley Giles. It is clear evidence that the management are considering playing the all-rounder against South Africa, only five days after he was driving to a pub in Romford hoping to sell the landlord some beer.

"Paul has plenty of bottle when batsmen give him the charge in the closing overs of one-day games," said Hussain. "He keeps his calm; I've seen that at Essex. We must decide whether we need a specialist spinner in addition to Graeme Hick's off-breaks on such a small ground."

Giles will remain with the England party - he will be involved in all the cricket in Pakistan and Sri Lanka - but he cannot now play in the remainder of this tournament even if he does recover from problems with his left calf.

England (probable): Trescothick, Stewart, *Hussain, Hick, Thorpe, Flintoff, White, Ealham, Grayson, Caddick, Gough.

South Africa (from): *Pollock, Kirsten, McKenzie, Kallis, Hall, Rhodes, Klusener, Boucher, Boje, Ntini, Donald, Telemachus.

webTitle: Twose sends Kiwis into the last four

fields.headline: Twose sends Kiwis into the last four
fields.standfirst:
New Zealand 265
Zimbabwe 201
New Zealand won by 64 runs
fields.trailText: Warwickshire's Roger Twose scored 85 to help New Zealand set up a semi-final against Pakistan on Wednesday.
fields.body:
Roger Twose, the Torquay-born batsman who slipped through the England net, again provided the cornerstone of a New Zealand innings yesterday as they set up a semi-final meeting with Pakistan tomorrow in the ICC Knockout Trophy in Nairobi.

"We have nothing to lose against Pakistan, the pressure will be on them," said the former Warwickshire left-hander, who scored 85 to claim the man-of-the-match award. New Zealand made 265 for seven after being asked to bat first, with Twose's runs coming off 111 balls with four fours and a six. Zimbabwe were then seen off by 64 runs.

After Nathan Astle went for a duck, a 53-run partnership between Stephen Fleming and Craig Spearman steadied the innings before Henry Olonga claimed his second victim when Heath Streak snapped up Spearman.

Fleming shared a half-century third-wicket stand with Twose before he was run out by Guy Whittall's throw from cover point. Craig McMillan then provided the impetus in a key partnership of 95, with 52 off 51 deliveries.

The Kiwis wound up their innings with a cameo performance by the wicketkeeper Adam Parore, who hit 20 off only eight balls including two huge sixes off Olonga in the 49th over. Olonga's three wickets from nine overs cost 58 runs.

Zimbabwe's only batsmen to make an impact were the opener Alistair Campbell, who scored 47 before being trapped lbw by Chris Harris, and Stuart Carlisle with 67 before being caught off Paul Wiseman, who claimed four for 45.

 The Pakistan Cricket Board has formally asked the nation's president Mohammad Rafiq Tarar to order a judicial inquiry into the allegations of match-fixing against Pakistan in the 1999 World Cup when they lost to Bangladesh by 62 runs and to India by 47 runs. "Allegations against the Pakistani umpire Javed Akhtar's biased umpiring during the England-South Africa Test in 1998" will also form part of the inquiry.

webTitle: Nurseries planned in deprived areas

fields.headline: Nurseries planned in deprived areas
fields.standfirst:
Ministers want to create 1m extra care places to help lone parents
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The creation of 900 new nurseries in deprived communities was pledged by the government yesterday in a drive to create 1m extra childcare places.
fields.body:
The creation of 900 new nurseries in deprived communities was pledged by the government yesterday in a drive to create 1m extra childcare places.

The junior employment minister, Margaret Hodge, said ministers wanted to provide a childcare place for every lone parent in a disadvantaged area by 2004.

By then the government is committed to spending £200m on 1.6m childcare places, compared with £66m on 600,000 places now.

In five areas - Cornwall, Ealing, Kirklees, Lancashire and York - the idea of providing early education and childcare on one site throughout the day will be tested.

"It is something that a lot of mums and dads prefer. If they are working its easier for them to be looked after following their nursery session," a spokeswoman for the Department for Education and Employment said.

The department has encouraged such schemes in the past but now is starting its own pilots, to begin this year and run until March 2003.

Mrs Hodge said: "We are witnessing a revolution in childcare for families up and down the country. Never before has a government attempted to deliver so many new childcare places.

"It is not acceptable that, with over half of all women with young children now working, thousands of lone parents and low income families still feel that their childcare commitments stop them from working."

Labour is already committed to providing free nursery places for all three-year-olds whose parents want them by 2004. The 900 new or expanded nurs eries will each provide places for about 50 children.

Gordon Brown, the chancellor, on a visit to Southville, Bristol, said Labour wanted a "sea change" in opportunities available to lone parents. He said: "We want to give lone parents real choices, enable them to move from welfare to work, and get them and their children out of poverty." He is promising a new £1.5bn children's tax credit to benefit up to 5m families.

In a speech in London, Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, accused the Tories of failing to back with action their claims to care about the poor. "In the 1980s there were those who said that self-interest was socially acceptable and that exclusion was economically inevitable.

"Today the same people talk about the need for compassion and inclusion. But compassionate talk alone will never lift children out of poverty. That will only happen if governments are prepared to act.

"I believe that one of the key battlegrounds in the future will be between those who want to see government again withdraw and to leave it to chance and those of us who believe that we cannot afford to exclude a whole generation."

Anne Longfield, chief executive of Kids' Clubs Network which represents after and pre-school clubs, said her organisation had long argued that start up grants for childcare in areas of disadvantage were not enough. "The government has responded with greater investment for those who need it most".

But she warned that the government would find it a challenge to recruit 80,000 childcare workers by 2003. So far a hotline for the government's childcare recruitment campaign, launched in July, has taken 40,000 calls.

webTitle: Women: Web lines

fields.headline: Web lines
fields.body:
Coinciding with breast cancer awareness month, the UK Breast Cancer Coalition (www.ukbcc.org.uk) has gone online to extend its campaigning work. Aimed at empowering patients to lobby government and health professionals for improved access to treatment, the project invites people to log on to a campaigns website where they can email a ready-prepared letter to their local MP or health authority, find out about local campaigns or give feedback on consultation documents.

 Over the hill and out of touch? Grandma's Guide to the Internet (published by Willow Island) could be for you. Designed for silver surfers who still think of the net "as something you wear at night to keep your perm in place", this not-at-all patronising guide is full of gems to get older women gripped. One section on browsing suggests typing in "knitting" as a typical topic. Real pearls of wisdom.

 The wonders of Wap and other telecoms developments are the subject of the next meeting of HighTech Women, a mentoring group for women in technology-related jobs. Taking place in London on November 1, the evening event will examine the changing face of the telecoms industry, from mobile internet access to broadband technology. Founded by Lucy Marcus, recently named by Business Age magazine as one of the top 10 women leading new media developments in the UK, the group aims to support hi-tech women with networking and partnering. Details: www.hightech-women.com.

webTitle: Comment: If you really want to help the homeless, don't get out your purse, just get involved

fields.headline: Brother, spare the dime
fields.standfirst: If you really want to help the homeless, don't get out your purse, just get involved
fields.trailText: We have come to accept in this country the daily sight of people at cashpoints, in train stations, outside pubs and clubs, with their hands out begging for money. The public face a real dilemma in this situation. Is this person homeless, in desperate need and begging simply to get by? Or do they have somewhere to live? Are they claiming benefits and begging for drink or drugs?
fields.body:
We have come to accept in this country the daily sight of people at cashpoints, in train stations, outside pubs and clubs, with their hands out begging for money.

The public face a real dilemma in this situation. Is this person homeless, in desperate need and begging simply to get by? Or do they have somewhere to live? Are they claiming benefits and begging for drink or drugs?

No one really knows the answer and no one will ever really know. What we do know is that there are more people out on the streets during the day than there are sleeping rough overnight.

So what do you do? Walk on by, stop and talk, give some money or buy some food?

The government thinks that if people want to be really sure that their money is helping someone, not trapping them in a dangerous situation, they should think twice about giving handouts on the street.

We are not, as some would have you believe, dictating that people should not give to beggars. That choice must be an individual one.

But people need to be aware of the issues in order to make an informed choice. What we do know is that drugs are a major issue for people on the street - we cannot be sure that the pound given will not go towards the fiver needed for the next heroin hit.

The police know that drug dealers in many parts of the country prey on vulnerable people who are on the street - they have sophisticated marketing strategies in place to hook vulnerable people into a life of self-destruction and crime.

In Nottingham the police believe that up to 90% of people who beg are doing so to sustain drug addictions. In Brighton almost half of those begging have told the police that they use their income to sustain an addiction to heroin. We must do everything in our power to help people combat their addictions and that includes asking people if the pound that they give is really the best way to help. I would not be doing my job if I did not ask this question.

Nearly every person in this country wants to help those less fortunate than themselves. The easy option is to toss a pound coin into someone's hand. The truth is that the easiest things are not always the right things to do.

Some of the help given to people on the streets, however well-meaning, is misplaced. We need to provide long-term answers to difficult problems - complex problems require complex solutions.

The more difficult, but better option is to help people who are homeless by giving time, goods or money to a registered charity designed to help them in the longterm.

We now have solutions in place for the most vulnerable, socially excluded people, those who have spent many years sleeping rough on the nation's streets.

The solutions to people sleeping out on our streets in the early hours of the morning with drug, alcohol and mental health problems are not cheap, not basic and not easy. And frankly, they are more than a cup of soup or a pound coin.

But everyone has a part to play. Every member of the public has it in their hands to help change a person's life.

That is why the government is launching a public awareness campaign designed to encourage the public to get involved in their community and help people who are homeless, or who have been, rebuild their lives away from the streets.

Many charities working with homeless people desperately need volunteers. As well as helping to run services, people need help to reintegrate back into the community when they've got a roof over their head. It is a tragedy when someone overcomes their problems and succeeds in finding a decent place to live, only to return to the street because they are lonely or because they have little to fill their day.

Day centres and hostels all over the country need support from their communities, not just cash but food and furniture too.

This summer, the government's rough sleepers unit published our progress report that indicated the numbers of people sleeping rough on our streets have dropped. But the thousand that are still there are a thousand too many. We have made major progress across government to help people leaving care and the armed forces. We've also put in place schemes to break people out of the cycle of offending and homelessness.

Our strategy is not only to spend £200m on organisations, from national ones such as Shelter to little-known self-help projects, but to encourage the public to play their part as well.

And if we are called Scrooges for this, then our purpose has been misunderstood. We are not asking people to stop giving help. In fact, it is quite the opposite. We want more people to help, but to think about the ways in which they help.

Getting it right means facing up to difficult dilemmas. For a government simply to throw money at any problem would be wrong. For the public simply to throw money at beggars would also be wrong.

 Louise Casey is director of the Rough Sleepers' Unit

webTitle: Supermarkets escape 'rip-off' charge

fields.headline: Supermarkets escape 'rip-off' charge
fields.standfirst: Read the Competition Commission report
fields.trailText: Britain's top five supermarkets have escaped largely unscathed from a 16-month long competition probe, after the Competition Commission cleared the retailers of charging overall excessive prices and making excessive profits.
fields.body:
Britain's top five supermarkets have escaped largely unscathed from a 16-month long competition probe, after the Competition Commission cleared the retailers of charging overall excessive prices and making excessive profits.

But they have been ordered to draw up a legally binding code of practice to ensure fair competition.

Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers made the demand after the Competition Commission published a report which found that the big chains operated in some ways which "distorted" a fair market.

The long awaited report said excessive prices were not being charged and the industry was broadly competitive, essentially turning the government's "Rip-Off Britain" crusade into an embarrassing damp squib.

But the commission's long-awaited report, which followed a year-long inquiry, highlighted three areas in which supermarkets were operating against open competition.

These were the relationship between supermarkets and farmers, persistent selling of goods below cost and a limited choice of supermarkets in some areas.

My Byers said: "I agree that a code of practice should be introduced. Like the commission, I do not believe that a voluntary code would be adequate.

"The relevant supermarkets will have to give legally binding undertakings to comply with the remedies."

Mr Byers said he was asking the Director General of Fair Trading (DGFT) to approach those supermarket chains with 8 per cent or more of the market (currently Asda, Safeway, Sainsbury, Somerfield and Tesco) to agree a code, which would meet the concerns identified by the Competition Commission.

The Trade Secretary added: "I want this matter resolved quickly and have asked the DGFT to report back to me in three months time."

The report has been described by analysts as "benign" with some questioning why the investigation was launched in the first place.

"It is nearly two years of wasted time and they have come up with absolutely nothing as we knew they would," said Philip Dorgan of WestLB Panmure.

Those thoughts were echoed by another leading food retail analyst who asked not to be named.

"It seems the Commission's report has come up short even as a face-saving exercise," he said. "It didn't say an awful lot, the government has found it can't do a lot -- it is completely toothless."

webTitle: Hague shelves new drug policy

fields.headline: Hague shelves new drug policy
fields.standfirst:
Special report: drugs in Britain
Special report: tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary, last night admitted her political reputation had been hurt after William Hague shelved her five-day-old policy of zero tolerance of cannabis possession.
fields.body:
Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary, last night admitted her political reputation had been hurt after William Hague shelved her five-day-old policy of zero tolerance of cannabis possession.

Miss Widdecombe, following a brief and friendly meeting with the Tory leader yesterday morning, said she would still try to retain her proposal of fixed penalty fines for possession, but she would allow the police to keep the present option of a formal caution. She said she had always intended that the police would retain the option of an informal verbal warning.

Miss Widdecombe said the episode "has absolutely not helped me, but I will come through it. I have been here before".

Mr Hague was forced to backtrack after the party's flagship conference announcement was met with widespread criticism. The policy became untenable when seven shadow cabinet members admitted they had smoked cannabis in their youth.

Mr Hague said yesterday: "The plans remain on the table, but need further consultation, discussion and debate.

"We realise there are concerns about some of the proposals we have made and so we are going to go to the police, to the medical profession, to drug rehabilitation workers, to teachers and to parents around the country and have this honest debate."

He ruled out decriminalisation, saying soft drugs led to hard drugs. Despite the political embarrassment - it is the second time he has had to drop a flagship policy - he expressed his "150%" confidence in Miss Widdecombe, whose political career has always been turbulent.

She had not urged Mr Hague to stick with the policy. "William is quite right. If we cannot carry the argument at first flush, we have to debate it.

"I am a practical politician. We needed to cool things down and get some rational debate. I am still keen to have a proper drugs policy and you cannot have a drugs policy that only looks at supply. Demand fuels supply.

"My aim was to give the police some teeth in dealing with class B drugs like cannabis without being excessive. That is why I thought the £100 fine, replacing the caution, was so beauteous and simple because it did not involve court appearances, shanghaiing people into prison and blighting their lives for evermore. It involves something quick and easy for the police."

webTitle: Business schools extend agenda

fields.headline: Ethics on the march
fields.standfirst: Human rights, environment and the social factor are only now moving up the agenda in UK business schools, says  Eileen Sheridan
fields.trailText: Human rights, environment and the social factor are only now moving up the agenda in UK business schools, says Eileen Sheridan
fields.body:
Companies in the 21st century have to be aware of a triple bottom line - profit, society and the environment. And naturally young managers are now demanding their MBA courses cover issues like ethics, environmental sustainability and social concerns.

This year the Association of Business Schools officially recognised the importance of ethical business practice with the introduction of a special Business and Society section in its annual Business Schools Awards, sponsored by Clerical Medical and supported by the Guardian.

The winners, Alex Nicholls and Charlotte Opal, who were Masters of Business Administration at the Said Business School, University of Oxford, impressed with a project to establish a fair trade wine in the UK, which they are promoting themselves with independent wine retailers as outlets.

Their MBA included several subjects relevant to ethical trading. The Global and Comparative Business course included a detailed analysis of the stakeholder model of operating a company, which takes account of workers and local communities.

"We looked at business philosophies, comparing the Anglo-American shareholder model to the German Japanese stakeholder model in which workers have interests in the company," explains Opal, a Rhodes Scholar.

The aim of fair trade is to make sure that people in developing countries earn a living wage and that the production process is environmentally sustainable.

Nicholls and Opal made a research trip to South Africa to investigate social and ethical concerns such as the lack of labour rights protection for vineyard workers and the illegal practice of paying workers in wine. These aspects - and the monopolistic power of multi-national wine exporters in Mexico - had to influence their business plan. But the problem for businesses that wish to be ethical and for consumers is the complicated nature of third world economics. While the developed world, for example, views child labour as undesirable, a child's earnings may be essential to its family, so the issue of business ethics becomes complicated.

"Consumers want to do the right thing," says Opal, "but they don't necessarily know what the right thing is and so have to trust the trader."

British business schools are only just introducing ethics in business to their MBAs. Warwick University set up its corporate citizenship unit two years ago but it is the only one in the UK.

Professor Malcolm McIntosh explains that the world is changing and that organisations need to have values. "They have to understand the different forms of capital, not just financial capital but relationship and social capital."

It was young managers themselves who wanted social accountability in business to be part of their MBA courses. Now, he says, businesses have to take responsibility for such matters as human rights, environmental and social impact.

"Business does not operate in a vacuum. The rules of the game are such now that we have to be aware of all stakeholders, customers, staff and the communities in which companies operate. You can't make money unless you understand people's values."

Companies have to be aware of the triple bottom line - profit, society and the environment. Professor McIntosh believes a cluster of British companies, including Shell and BP, are leading the way in this sea change.

At Strathclyde School of Business, ethics has also become a core part of the MBA. "The aim is not to judge but to be a way of making students aware of the wider range of factors which will affect the environment they work in," says Professor George Cairns.

They have to consider the political, legal, environmental and social framework and look at the various ethical considerations in different countries.

Students can go further into the moral minefield with two electives, one that looks at business ethics in more detail and a course in Power and Organisations. Apart from looking at power structures inside organisations, this elective looks at the power of organisations on a macro level and considers how people exercise power, says Prof Cairns.

Using TV documentaries of the Union Carbide disaster at Bhopal and its consequences over a decade, tutors encourage students to consider the issues involved.

Halfway through the case study, students are asked to put themselves into the positions of the stakeholders and think about how the problem is unfolding from their point of view.

"I think it works," says Prof Cairns. "I hope the students go out with the capacity to look at things from different perspectives."
