webTitle: Wilko names Sheringham and Heskey for Finland game

fields.headline: Wilko names Sheringham and Heskey for Finland game
fields.trailText: England caretaker manager Howard Wilkinson has included Teddy Sheringham and Emile Heskey in his team to face Finland in tomorrow night's World Cup qualifier in Helsinki.
fields.body:
England caretaker manager Howard Wilkinson has included Teddy Sheringham and Emile Heskey in his team to face Finland in tomorrow night's World Cup qualifier in Helsinki.

Sheringham was handed a late call-up to the squad by Wilkinson on Sunday night after several players were forced out of the trip to Finland because of injury.

Wilkinson, in charge of the team following the shock resignation of Kevin Keegan following the 1-0 defeat by Germany at Wembley on Saturday, will field a three-pronged attack with Andy Cole and Emile Heskey also in the team.

Defender Gary Neville, who has been struggling with a toe injury, is out while striker Robbie Fowler has been allowed to return to Liverpool after not being selected in the starting line-up by Wilkinson.

Sheringham is one of six changes to the line-up which lost to Germany. He greeted his return to the international arena by claiming "you never give up hope".

The veteran United striker, 34, said: "It's a lovely moment for me. When you are playing at the highest level, you always have a chance and I have been doing that with Manchester United.

"I've read over the last few months that my career is over but it isn't.

"I still want to play at the top level and do myself justice and that's what I want to do on Wednesday night."

Wilkinson added: "We had a meeting this morning to discuss the events past and the events in the future. I told them what I thought and marked one or two cards. At the end of the day I made sure they understood.

"But the only two problems we can deal with are Finland and ourselves. The first question is, can we beat Finland? The second is can we deal with ourselves professionally?

"Of course it has been a crisis. A manager has left, people have dropped out, and we've got to get back on track.

"But history tells us this is not an impossible task. But the crisis is behind us. We are now faced with what we would be like to be faced with, which is a football match.

"It's a game where first and foremost we have to perform. It's not a cup tie where if we lose we are out.

"We have to perform how we can perform. They (the players) can play a lot better than they did in that first half against Germany.

"If we get the performance then you've got to take the result. If we get the performance - a nine out of 10 - then you've got to take the result.

"But the players are as well prepared as they can be given the circumstances. We've got another 24 hours between now and tomorrow. One of the big factors was getting the debris of the weekend out of the way.

"They've got a million excuses to go out and fail if they (the players) want them. A lot of people will be looking at them thinking we are a dying animal ready to pick off the bones. But they are going to be in for a big surprise."

England team to face Finland in World Cup qualifier in Helsinki: Seaman, Parlour, Southgate, Keown, Barry, P Neville, Wise, Scholes, Sheringham, Heskey, Cole

At the end of the day I made sure they understood. "But the only two problems we can deal with are Finland and ourselves. The first question is, can we beat Finland? The second is can we deal with ourselves professionally? "Of course it has been a crisis. A manager has left, people have dropped out, and we've got to get back on track. "But history tells us this is not an impossible task. But the crisis is behind us. We are now faced with what we would be like to be faced with, which is a football match. "It's a game where first and foremost we have to perform. It's not a cup tie where if we lose we are out. "We have to perform how we can perform. They (the players) can play a lot better than they did in that first half against Germany. "If we get the performance then you've got to take the result. If we get the performance - a nine out of 10 - then you've got to take the result. "But the players are as well prepared as they can be given the circumstances. We've got another 24 hours between now and tomorrow. One of the big factors was getting the debris of the weekend out of the way. "They've got a million excuses to go out and fail if they (the players) want them. A lot of people will be looking at them thinking we are a dying animal ready to pick off the bones. But they are going to be in for a big surprise." webTitle: Crisis in the Middle East: what the papers say

fields.headline: Crisis in the Middle East: what the papers say
fields.trailText: There is no mistaking the mood of real crisis in the region, after 12 days of   bloody clashes between Israeli forces and Palestinians. Nor is there much   evidence of a willingness to compromise, with each side looking for the other   to blink first.
fields.body:
There is no mistaking the mood of real crisis in the region, after 12 days of bloody clashes between Israeli forces and Palestinians. Nor is there much evidence of a willingness to compromise, with each side looking for the other to blink first.

The Jerusalem Post, among the more hawkish of Israeli papers, is indignant about the UN condemnation of Israel's massive military response to the rioting. Its editorial sarcastically comments: "An innocent observer reading the resolution might reasonably conclude the Palestinians were quietly minding their own business when, out of the blue, Israeli forces decided to throw seven years of talks out the window and attack their negotiating partners. The opposite is the case. After weeks of official Palestinian broadcasts encouraging violence and lionizing martyrs, and after attacks against Israelis in which both soldiers and civilians were killed, Yasser Arafat took advantage of Likud leader Ariel Sharon's visit to the Temple Mount to turn the flames on full burner."

The far-right Sharon is cold-shouldered by the more liberal Ha'aretz daily, which rejects suggestions that he be brought into a government of national unity. The paper comments: "Sharon's past teaches us that his temperament and personality do not tend toward level-headed thinking or restrained suggestions during times of crisis or war. Military measures taken under his command or with his permission have more than once taken on much greater proportions than initially intended. Israel is better off without a man with these kinds of tendencies in the government."

The few Palestinian websites which offer English translations are woefully behind the times. Even the excellent Jerusalem Media and Communication Centre - a boon to many correspondents in the region - is somewhat behind the times, though the outrage of Palestinians is forcefully expressed.

The Palestine Times, a monthly English-language digest, devotes virtually its entire web edition to the latest bloodletting, though it is already slipping behind the news.

The Palestinian National Authority too is struggling to keep pace with events, and is hampered by the leaden bureaucratic prose favoured by the Ministry of Information. Here is its statement on last week's attacks on religious sites: "While the PNA expressed its indignation towards the irresponsible act that caused damage to the Joseph Tomb in Nablus, and noting the subsequent instructions issued by President Arafat to begin restoration works on the site, after which the relevant authorities began its restoration works immediately, the PNA view with contempt and extreme anger the actions of Israeli gangs who this morning burned in full view of the Israeli police the mosque in Tiberias and attempted to burn another mosque in the Sheikh Jarrah neighborhood in Jerusalem."

The ministry also offers a brief summary of headlines from the local papers, all seething with outrage against the Israelis.

In the wider Arab world, there is growing concern that the conflict could infect the region. The Jordan Times, not given to scaremongering, wonders whether the proposed Arab summit will help. The paper is not optimistic, but its editorial notes: "we believe that the summit could be considered somewhat successful if it manages to achieve a unified Arab position, and if such position translates into firm and effective support for Palestinian President Yasser Arafat."

In the United Arab Emirates, the Khaleej Times reports the scathing condemnation of Israel by the government: "The cabinet condemned the barbaric massacre of defenceless Palestinians by Israeli occupation forces and held the government of Israel responsible of the provocation which has led to deaths of a large number of Palestinians and resulted in severe violations of the human rights of the Palestinians and has posed a threat to the Middle East peace process and the security and stability of the region as a whole."

webTitle: Books - one-parent families

fields.headline: Books - one-parent families
fields.trailText: Books about lone-parent situations aren't all grim "issue" books on divorce and bereavement, many simply show a single-parent situation as the "normal" back-drop to a good story
fields.body:
By 2010, it is estimated that more children will be living in one-parent/ step families than with both parents. Children's books are starting to reflect these changes. Books about lone-parent situations aren't all grim "issue" books on divorce and bereavement, either; many simply show a single-parent situation as the "normal" back-drop to a good story.

The following books are taken from a new guide to such books ("Families Just Like Us") to be published next month by Book Trust and the National Council for One Parent Families (020-7428 5400) or Book Trust (020-8516 2993).

Flour Babies (Anne Fine, Puffin, £4.99, 9-13yrs)

Simon and each of his classmates are given a "flour baby" to look after for three weeks. As Simon becomes unusually attached to his "baby", he also begins to appreciate the work involved in being a parent - particularly a single parent like his mother.

Playing With Mum (Carla Dijs, Child's Play, £5.99, 1-4 years).

Books featuring just mum or just dad are becoming far more common now. This volume celebrates the mother-child relationship, as a small piglet plays exuberantly at being a range of different animals in this pop-up book.

Why? (Lindsay Camp and Tony Ross, HB Andersen Press,£9.99, 4-7 yrs)

Many parents will be familiar with the cry "why?" from young lips. Here Lily's constant barrage of questions is driving her father to distraction in a delightful interpretation of a father- daughter relationship.

We're Going On A Bear Hunt (Michael Rosen and Helen Oxenbury, Walker Books, £4.99, 2-6 yrs)

This has rapidly become a firm favourite for the age group. A father takes his party of children on a bear hunt, encountering grasslands, rivers and snowstorms en route. The rhythmic text has a musical charm that lends itself well to reading aloud.

My Dad is ... My Mum (Ali Ives and Georgie Birkett Macdonald, Young Books, £8.50, 5-8 yrs)

Although 25%of children live with one parent, this can still be a sensitive subject, especially at school. It's very difficult for Becky when she has to write an essay on the theme My Dad is ... But she finds the perfect solution.

Two of Everything (Babette Cole, Random House, £4.99, 6-9 yrs)

This story shows how miserable it can be living with two parents who hate each other. Then the children come up with the inspirational idea of "un-marrying" them, and the festivities begin . An original and effective book about divorce, laced with great humour.

Stone Cold (Robert Swindells, Puffin, £4.99, 12+ yrs)

The arrival of an unfriendly stepfather causes "Link" to leave home and live on the streets. His story is interwoven with that of an ex-soldier, set upon ridding the streets of "vermin" by enticing the homeless back to his house and murdering them. A gripping yet disturbing read.

webTitle: Adams and Trimble criticise Panorama

fields.headline: Trimble and Adams attack Panorama broadcast
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: Northern Ireland's first minister, David Trimble, and Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams have criticised last night's BBC Panorama programme, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Northern Ireland's first minister, David Trimble, and Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams have criticised the BBC Panorama programme, which last night named four men questioned by police investigating the Omagh bombing.

Mr Trimble said he had grave doubts about the wisdom of the programme and hoped "it would not prejudice any future trial".

He said: "It's the case with regard to so many terrorist atrocities in Northern Ireland that identities are known. Is it wise to broadcast that? I would like to think the programme-makers were after something other than sensationalism."

Mr Adams, MP for West Belfast, admitted he did not see the programme but said he was against the naming of people involved. He added: "Not least because those who were involved in the killings on Bloody Sunday are remaining anonymous in the courts. And those involved in the Dublin and Monaghan bomb attacks have had a shroud of secrecy over their involvement."

The Irish Republic's Taoiseach, Bertie Ahern, and the shadow Northern Ireland secretary, Andrew Mackay, also criticised the broadcast.

But Panorama was defended by the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, speaking on BBC Radio 4's The World at One. Mr Mandelson said: "I thought it was very powerful, a very professional piece of work, which above all never lost sight of the people who should be most in our thoughts today; that is the victims and their families.

"We have to act within that law and I hope that as a result of the programme, people will be able to come forward with that last piece of evidence we need that will clinch a conviction."

Last night's programme left the victims' families bitterly divided, with some claiming the gang responsible for the single worst terrorist atrocity in Northern Ireland might never be brought to justice.

The programme only went ahead after a High Court ruling rejected legal attempts to block it by the Northern Ireland Human Rights Commission and Lawrence Rush, whose wife was among the 29 people killed in the explosion in August 1998.

webTitle: Media diary

fields.headline: The BBC on drugs and LastminuteMonkey
fields.trailText:
Pot boiler
And again, Monkey prints a BBC memo without the need for further comment. THIS CIRCULATED TO ALL BBC STAFF AND REGIONS: Request from London Newsdesk: "Could any outlets speaking to government ministers in the course of the day ask if they have ever used cannabis."
fields.body:
Pot boiler
And again, Monkey prints a BBC memo without the need for further comment. THIS CIRCULATED TO ALL BBC STAFF AND REGIONS: Request from London Newsdesk: "Could any outlets speaking to government ministers in the course of the day ask if they have ever used cannabis."

Monkey's uncle at Lastminute
It's official. Monkey mania is sweeping the internet world. Monkey's family has never been so busy - at the moment we're the de rigeur accessory for any website and we've got work coming out of our ears. While Monkey is quite happy tarting it around medialand, my family keep cropping up in all guises. Uncle Harry, last seen at webmonkey.com, appears to have been doing a spot of moonlighting and has been spotted doing "essential maintenance work" on version 2 of Lastminute.com's website - v2.lastminute.com. Note the family resemblance with the rolling eyes? If you're very lucky, Uncle Harry lets you through to look at the development version.

Below-the-belt campaign
PR Week reports on a fascinating new development at the People's Bank, which has launched a new affinity card with the Vegetarian Society. Journalists were reportedly lured to the press conference using that age-old trick, the promise of a freebie. So what did the People's Bank use to tempt busy journalists away from their desks? A branded apron, which, according to PR Week, "they were encouraged to wear at home while cooking". How could anyone resist?

Readers' wives online
While checking to see which of its flagship magazines Northern & Shell has registered the domain names of, Monkey was amused to find that a certain webmeister, the one and only Richard Evans, is the proud registrar of readerswives.com. Intrigued, Monkey checked out the website only to find it defaults to Object1, the digital agency where Richard works. For a brief second, Monkey thought Richard may have devoted an entire site to his missus, the delectable Tarnya Norse from Mediasurface. Phew, what a relief.

What a bummer
Does somebody at the BBC have it in for arsetastic Granada TV sitcom The Royle Family? We only ask because, following on from the BBC's Montreux Royle Family triumph - when the show's chances of bagging a Golden Rose were scuppered because some dozy BBC minion sent a tape of the wrong episode for the judges to watch - the comedy has been hit by another tape-sending cock-up. Queue much bemused scratching of heads in newspaper preview offices across medialand, as the BBC's awesomely efficient publicity machine sent out tapes of the fifth episode of the new run of The Royle Family, masquerading as the series opener. As Jim Royle would say, "BBC publicity - my arse".

Dot.conservatives
The Monkey heartily applauds the Conservative Party's latest brave stand against the shocking political bias of that commie-pinko-shirtlifting collective that masquerades as the nation's public service broadcaster. Obviously wanting to do our bit to help expose the hordes of subversive degenerates hiding under beds at the BBC, we feel duty bound to draw Central Office's attention to seethru.co.uk, the so-like-a-real-website-its-incredible website for BBC2 dot.com drama Attachments. Said site contains a thinly veiled attack on the shadow home secretary's brave stand against that hardcore criminal element, cannabis smokers, under the headline "Widdecombe you hilarious clown". This is an outrageous misrepresentation of the facts and a clear example of political bias - La Widdecombe has never been funny in her life.


Barely believable
Kevin Brown, founding partner of Soul and a successful and no doubt wealthy ad man, is simply unable to resist starring in his own ads. However, friends of his have this week admitted he's now taken things too far by stripping down to the short and curlies - something he appears to have plenty of - for the sake of the Daily Star's "MegaStar" campaign. The poster features a nude - and rather flushed - Mr Brown covering (just) his modesty with a board advertising the site. Mark Cranmer, chief executive at Starcom Motive and a dear friend of his, said: "Kevin has a long history of exhibiting himself. He's done ads promoting gambling, alcohol and now blatant sex. I feel he should have asked for his legs to be retouched, though, because he seems to be suffering from the skinny legs/fat gut syndrome that comes to all men as they get older. I love Kevin, but he is mad." Even one of Kevin's co-founders is advising people to turn a blind eye to the stunt. "I wouldn't look at it if I were you - you might find it offensive," he said. You're not wrong, Duncan.

Caught out on a techie point
Programmers panning TV shows? Geeks up in arms about TV stars? What the heck is going on? Anyone would think the BBC had made a show about a dot.com start-up. TV audiences may be unimpressed by This Life 2, the one set in a new media start-up and called Attachments, but those whose lives BBC2 is trying to mimic are even more unimpressed. True, World Productions may have done some homework, but those finicky techies are taking umbrage at any slight faux pas - such as transferring files by throwing floppy disks across the office and talking about downloads and demos as a revenue model. Those that haven't vented their spleen already are invited to do so at Everyonehatesattachments.com. But be careful, these hardcore new media types don't take prisoners.

Invaluable sentiment
Granada Media chairman Charles Allen began his first address to troops of his newly acquired United News & Media by declaring how much his company values programme-makers. Not such a surprising sentiment, you'd imagine, coming from the boss of a company with a significant TV production arm - but the jaws of senior United TV execs hit the floor all the same. Apparently the only word they were used to hearing from former boss Clive Hollick in the same sentence as "value" is "shareholder".

When the caption fits...
Sir Christopher Bland got a morning grilling from the delectable Sophie Raworth (isn't Jeremy looking fetching too with his matching purple tie?) on BBC breakfast news today. Pity about the caption though, which read: "Fiona Mannion: mini owner".

expectingcomplaints.com
Monkey apologies for allowing a cad like Danny Kelly to blatantly pull the wool over readers' eyes in Monday's edition of the Media Guardian. Asked about his favourite websites, Kelly named expectingrain.com and woolyrockstars.com. Pernickety readers, i.e. those that go through absolutely everything with a fine-tooth comb, immediately pointed out that the latter website does not in fact exist. More importantly neither the .com or the .co.uk domain names for Woolyrockstars have been registered. Was Kelly making a mockery of us all or was he merely pointing out a new market niche? Kelly says neither: "I'm very much afraid this thing does exist. The url, however, is woollyrockers.com. Check it out!!" Duh! Monkey did and fell in love with the Bee Gees doll. Could Kelly have created a monster?

Minutes matter
What's this? The BBC's famously impartial news reporting standards slipping over its own 10pm news bulletin announcement? The Monkey has got its paws on an internal email from BBC Online producer James Thornet that was sent round after the news broke to BBC online hacks out in the sticks. He draws his colleagues' attention to the fact that the switch to 10pm means the regional bulletin tacked on at the end of the proper, grown-up news will be extended to a massive six-and-a-half minutes. "We must put this story at the top of online news stories asap," says the excitable Thornett. Is he worried viewers in the regions wouldn't notice the difference otherwise?


Sticky gimmicks
Monkey was amused to discover an overflowing pot of honey in the post today. The honey pot subsequently attacked all surrounding computers and made everything in the office sticky. Eugh. The penny finally dropped when Monkey found the attached (and at this point very sticky) note, saying that eBay was stickier than QXL. Point taken. But did it really have to destroy my workspace to tell me that?


Email the Media Monkey at monkey@mediatheguardian.com

webTitle: England crash out

fields.headline: England crash out
fields.trailText: Match scorecard
fields.body:
Match scorecard

England are out of the ICC Knockout Trophy. They were thrashed by South Africa in the quarter-finals in Kenya by eight wickets after a dismal batting performance in which they lost their last six wickets for 28 and were dismissed for 182 with 35 balls remaining. It left South Africa needing to score at just 3.66 an over to secure a semi-final clash with India on Friday, and, despite a slight wobble at 52 for 2, they did it with ease as Jacques Kallis hit a controlled 78 and Boeta Dippenaar a more adventurous 65.

England's bowlers needed to save runs and take early wickets if they were to disrupt one of the world's longest batting line-ups. Neither happened. Andy Caddick did begin with a maiden, but Darren Gough undid the good work by conceding nine in his first over as Gary Kirsten worked one ball through square-leg and cut another for four. In the next over he chopped a no-ball to the third-man boundary and guided Caddick through point for four more.

South Africa lost Andrew Hall to Gough as a cut shot flew into Graeme Hick's bucket-like hands at second slip for 1 (19 for 1), but Kallis was immediately into his stride. He stood up on his toes to force Caddick for four through the covers on the up, and hit sweetly through mid-on in Caddick's next over. Kirsten, playing with untypical aggression, flicked Gough powerfully over square-leg, then creamed a no-ball to the long-on boundary.

After eight overs South Africa were cruising at 43 for 1. England, at the same stage, had been 5 for 0. England's opening bowlers were poor. Gough overstepped four times, while Caddick had one of those days when he seems too easily dispirited.

And it took a bowling change to change England's fortunes. With his second ball Craig White snared Kirsten for 32 as Hick held on brilliantly to a fierce cut with his left-hand (usually his weaker side) to leave South Africa 52 for 2.

But that was about as good as it got. Kallis worked White's slower ball through midwicket for four in the same over, and the runs began to flow again. Kallis was particularly merciless against anything pitched even fractionally short outside off, while Dippenaar grew in confidence, off- and on-driving Caddick for four in the same over.

The 100 came up in the 21st over as Kallis drove White through the covers, and Kallis moved to 50 soon after, having taken just 59 balls. Paul Grayson made some amends for his first-baller and a couple of misfields with some tidy overs of left-arm spin (five overs for 20), but by this stage the batsmen were in cruise control, picking off the singles at three an over and hammering the odd loose ball to the boundary. With the required run-rate never a problem, Kallis was able to play his normal game as Dippenaar accelerated. And when he ended the game with a straight six off White, South Africa had won with more than ten overs to spare.

Earlier England batted with a death wish: four batsmen (Alec Stewart, Graham Thorpe, Andy Flintoff and Graeme Hick) holed out at deep square leg and two (Craig White and Andy Caddick) were run out by direct hits. Another, Grayson, lunged weakly outside off and fell to his first ball in international cricket. It was grim stuff from a side that can still collapse with the worst of them.

But at 154 for 4 in the 37th over, with Hick striking the ball cleanly and Flintoff lending solid support, England were on course for 240. Then Flintoff pulled Shaun Pollock straight to Lance Klusener in the deep for 25 and things went quickly downhill. White set off for a single to the right of Jonty Rhodes, prowling at point, and paid the price (160 for 6), and when Hick's pull flew unerringly to Andrew Hall on the legside boundary in the next over, England were in deep trouble at 167 for 7. Hick, on, 65, was their last hope for some sort of score.

Grayson groped at his first ball and edged to first slip (168 for 8), and Caddick chose the wrong moment to forget how to run a quick single as Boje hit the stumps from point (174 for 9). The rout was complete with almost six overs to spare when Mark Ealham fended Pollock to Mark Boucher.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

webTitle: Language resources: Peru's president resigns

fields.headline: Testigo - Peru
fields.standfirst: Aldo Gil Crisóstomo talks about the effect of the resignation of Peru's President Fujimori
fields.trailText: Aldo Gil Crisóstomo talks about the effect of the resignation of Peru's President Fujimori
fields.body:
E l día que Alberto Fujimori anunció en televisión su dimisión y la convocatoria de elecciones, una multitud salió a la calle. En Lima la gente se concentró de forma espontánea y pacífica en la Plaza Mayor. Fue una fiesta hasta altas horas de la madrugada para celebrar la caída de la dictadura.

Eran las nueve y media de la noche y yo estaba en casa con mi familia. Mi primera reacción fue de estupefacción y escepticismo. A medida que pasaban los minutos empezó la algarabía. Amigos y familiares empezaron a llamar por teléfono. Se solidarizaban conmigo y me decían que mi sacrificio no fue en vano. Me llamaban porque el día 28 de julio fui brutalmente atacado por la policía cuando participaba en una marcha pacífica. Entonces una bomba lacrimógena impactó en mi cara y me rompió el maxilar en ocho partes y perdí el ojo derecho. Hoy me siento orgulloso de haber puesto un pequeño grano de arena en la lucha de mi pueblo contra la dictadura.

Ahora, el gobierno sigue manipulando la situación y el país está totalmente movilizado para acabar con la dictadura. Cómo evitar un nuevo fraude electoral si el poder sigue en manos del mismo presidente?

Este es el debate. Mientras, Vladimiro Montesinos, el asesor del presidente Fujimori, está fuera del país. Un vídeo que mostraba sus sobornos a diputados fue lo que desencadenó la actual crisis. Huyó a Panamá y provocó protestas en este país. Ellos no quieren convertirse en el basurero de Latinoamérica. La justicia tarda pero llega. La impunidad es algo que nuestro pueblo no va a aceptar jamás.

Aldo Gil Crisóstomo was speaking to Eulàlia Furriol.

una bomba lacrimógena tear-gas bomb

poner un grano de arena to do one's bit

orgulloso de proud of

un soborno bribe

webTitle: World's first female prime minister dies

fields.headline: World's first female prime minister dies
fields.standfirst: Obituary: Sirima Bandaranaike
fields.trailText: Sirimavo Bandaranaike, the world's first female prime minister, died of a heart attack today after voting in  Sri Lanka's parliamentary elections. Bandaranaike, the widow of another former prime minister of the Indian Ocean island, died aged 84 on her 60th wedding anniversary.
fields.body:
Sirimavo Bandaranaike, the world's first female prime minister, died of a heart attack today after voting in Sri Lanka's parliamentary elections. Bandaranaike, the widow of another former prime minister of the Indian Ocean island, died aged 84 on her 60th wedding anniversary.

Bandaranaike stood down in August to let her daughter, President Chandrika Kumaratunga, appoint a hardliner in a bid to boost the government's 17-year fight against Tamil separatists ahead of today's elections.

Bandaranaike had gone to her hometown, Gampaha, 22 miles east of Colombo, to vote. She suffered a heart attack in her car on her way home after casting her ballot, and was pronounced dead after being taken to a nursing home, government spokeswoman Kusum Rodrigo said. "I think the entire nation has lost its mother," said Alavi Mowlana, a government minister for local affairs. "I cannot believe that she is no more."

Bandaranaike retired on August 10, suffering from diabetes and other ailments. She said that her daughter needed someone more capable of pushing proposals to end the civil war, which has claimed 63,000 lives since 1983. "I believe it is time for me to quietly withdraw from the humdrum of busy political life, to a more tranquil and quiet environment," Bandaranaike wrote as she ended a 40-year political career. She was elected the first woman head of government on July 20, 1960, six years before Indira Gandhi became India's first woman prime minister.

Born Sirimavo Ratwatte on April 17, 1916, Bandaranaike was a member of one of the island's wealthiest families. In 1940, she married Soloman Dias Bandaranaike, a senior politician in the United National party, which was governing what was then called Ceylon.

Her husband later broke away to form his own Sri Lanka Freedom party and was elected prime minister in 1956. A Buddhist monk assassinated him three years later.

Bandaranaike was transformed from shy housewife into a political dynamo. She campaigned for her husband's party in the 1960 elections and became its leader, winning elections later that year.

Her election was so unusual that newspapers were unsure what to call her. "There will be need for a new word. Presumably, we shall have to call her a stateswoman," one British newspaper wrote. "This is the suffragette's dream come true."

In September 1961 at the Neutral Summit Talks in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, she made history by being the first leader to say she was speaking "as a woman and a mother". She governed until 1965, lost the next elections, then regained power in 1970.

Shifting toward the left, Bandaranaike ordered the US peace corps out in 1970 and closed the Israeli embassy. In May 1972, she made the country a republic and changed its name to Sri Lanka, and during her second term, she nationalised private companies and banned imports. She used the military to crush a 1971 insurrection by Marxist rebels, and up to 20,000 were believed to have died.

Parliament expelled her in 1980, accusing her of misusing power, and banning her from office for seven years. Her civic rights were restored in 1986, and she narrowly lost the election for the new, more powerful post of president in 1988.

Suffering from diabetes and a knee problem that put her in a wheelchair, Bandaranaike reduced her political activities.

In 1993, Ms Kumaratunga took over the party's leadership and, when elected president a year later, she appointed her mother prime minister, a position that has become largely ceremonial.

webTitle: Autonomy to list on London Stock Exchange

fields.headline: Autonomy to list on London Stock Exchange
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Technology company Autonomy Corporation is coming home after announcing plans to list on the London Stock Exchange. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Technology company Autonomy Corporation is coming home after announcing plans to list on the London Stock Exchange.

The Cambridge-based company, one of the brightest stars of the "silicon fen" phenomenon, is listed on the Easdaq and Nasdaq exchanges in the US. It hopes to enter the FTSE 100 by December 6, with Deutsche Bank acting as co-ordinator for the offering.

Autonomy's chief executive, Michael Lynch, said: "This is a natural step in the evolution of our company."

The company is best known for its web solutions, which can produce advanced search engines and scan audio tracks on the internet.

Autonomy's stock market debut will spark interest in the City, as last month it was voted Easdaq share of the year.

The company recently announced first-half revenues of $26.3m (£18m) - a threefold increase on the $8.7m (£5.9m) figure for the same period last year.

webTitle: Casting couch

fields.headline: Casting couch
fields.trailText: Tom Cruise marches into the Philippine jungles, John Malkovich confirmed as the Green Goblin, and Robin Williams goes into kiddie-TV land
fields.body:
 Tom Cruise (pictured) looks set to star in Fertig, a WW2 drama penned by Gladiator scriptwriter William Nicholson. The film will be set in the jungles of the Far East and, says Nicholson, "I have reason to believe Tom Cruise will be doing it and he would be fabulous. It is a real hero's story about an extraordinary guy at the time of the greatest military disaster in American history - the surrender of 80,000 American soldiers to the Japanese in the Philippines during World War II."

 Spiderman director Sam Raimi has confirmed that John Malkovich will be playing the movie's villain, the Green Goblin. The Tobey Maguire-starring film is scheduled for release in 2002.

 Robin Williams is to star in Death to Smoochie, in which the schmaltz-loving star will play a children's TV star fired and replaced by the clean-cut Smoochie, a blue rhinoceros. Williams is Rainbow Raindolph, the sacked kiddies' favourite, and Edward Norton may don the rhino suit. Danny DeVito directs.

webTitle: Today's stories from the papers

fields.headline: Today's stories from the papers
fields.trailText:
THE GUARDIAN

The BBC last night succeeded in naming the four men accused of the Omagh bombing. Mr Justice Kerr, at the Belfast High Court, threw out the injunction with just 90 minutes to transmission. Acting on the advice of its lawyers, the Guardian declines to name the suspects. p1)
Just hours after the launch of Voices, a publication by the Government's women's unit produced by former Good Housekeeping editor Pat Roberts-Cairns in the NatMags stable, public health minister Yvette Cooper was defending Labour from accusations that the government's Its OK to be a Virgin campaign is a further example of the nanny state. (p9)
The man behind Victor Meldrew, Richard Wilson, is so sick of the catchphrase "I don't believe it", that he is charging fans to hear it, according to the Radio Times. (p12)
Hans Snook, chief executive of the mobile phone company Orange, is to stand down to make way for a French executive appointed by the company's new owner France Telecom. (p23)
Carlton Communications has made an offer, predicted yesterday in the press, of £400m for the rights to British horseracing. (p23)
Eidos' talks with potential buyer Infogrammes have collapsed. (p24)
Amazon.com founder Jeff Bezos has said in an interview that he predicts that Europe could overtake the US as the world's most important online marketplace. (p24)
As BSkyB shares bucked the trend yesterday in world financial markets, speculation increases that Rupert Murdoch could integrate BSkyB further into the Sky Global Networks holding company, possibly as part of a share swap with Vivendi. (p26)

webTitle: BSE 'could still be in food chain'

fields.headline: BSE 'could still be in food chain'
fields.standfirst: Food standards chairman fears farmers may still be sending infected meat to market
fields.trailText: Food standards chairman fears farmers may still be sending infected meat to market.
fields.body:
Sir John Krebs, head of the Food Standards Agency, today voiced new concerns that meat infected with BSE could still be finding its way into the food chain.

Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Farming Today, Mr Krebs warned that, under existing rules, beef can be exempt from strict BSE inspection controls if the animal is slaughtered at unlicensed premises for private consumption by the owner. But there are no checks to ensure that such meat is not sold on privately.

"The concern is perhaps some of this meat is being passed on or sold on for wider consumption," he said, adding that cattle aged over 30 months are deemed unfit for human consumption but that does not apply to meat from a private kill. And there was no way of ensuring parts such as brains and spinal tissues - feared to be the most dangerous part of an infected animal - had been properly removed, he said.

Jill Newt, the chair of the Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons advisory committee, said there was no doubt meat from private kills was entering the food chain. "I think consumers should be aware that anyone offering them cheap meat should get a second look at where that animal was killed and where that meat was cut up," she told Farming Today.

Peter Scott, a director of the British Meat Federation which represents abattoirs, called for the end of the exemptions for privately killed animals: "This is a problem for the Food Standards Agency and it's a dilemma which they, and before them Maff [the Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Fisheries], have faced for a number of years," he said.

webTitle: Sirima Bandaranaike

fields.headline: Sirima Bandaranaike
fields.standfirst:
The world's first female prime minister led Sri Lanka to independence but presided over the oppression of the Tamils

World's first female prime minister dies
fields.trailText: The world's first female prime minister led Sri Lanka to independence but presided over the oppression of the Tamils.
fields.body:
Sirima Bandaranaike, who has died aged 84, became the world's first woman prime minister, leading her country's government three times. One of the third world's best-known leaders, she made Ceylon a republic and changed its name to Sri Lanka.

Bandaranaike was the daughter of a prominent Sinhalese family in the Kandyan hill country - a perfect match for the wealthy low-country Bandaranaike with his driving political ambition. Like many similar families, the Bandaranaikes were thoroughly anglicised and held prominent positions in the colonial regime.

Sirima, the eldest of six children, was sent at the age of eight to an English-language convent boarding-school in Colombo. But her parents ensured that she remained a devout Buddhist and spoke Sinhala as fluently as English. After leaving school she threw herself into social welfare work, walking miles through jungles and over mountains to distribute food and medicines, organise clinics and develop village industries. She became a great favourite of the Sinhalese peasantry, acquiring a reputation which proved politically invaluable.

In 1940 she married Solomon West Ridgeway Dias Bandaranaike, an Oxford-educated minister in the colonial government. Both were from the top goyigama caste of landowners.

Sirima was a valued confidante to her husband, persuading him to resign from the government and the ruling United National party (UNP) in 1951. Two months later he formed the Sri Lankan Freedom party (SLFP) with democratic socialism and Sinhalese resurgence at its heart.

In general elections the following year she helped her husband win the biggest majority of any seat won by his party. She campaigned in his constituency while he concentrated on the rest of the country. At the next elections in 1956, Bandaranaike won by a landslide and formed a leftwing coalition government. He had promised to replace English with Sinhala as the island's sole official language, a watershed in the country's history. This was aimed against the dominance of the English-speaking elite, but also sowed the seeds of bitter conflicts with the Tamils. Bandaranaike used Sinhalese chauvinism to gain power, but could not control it.

His prejudice also played a part in his murder in 1959 by a Buddhist monk. Mrs Bandaranaike was given little time to grieve in peace. The following year she succumbed to the SLFP's pleas to assume the party leadership, and led it to victory on a wave of sympathy.

Over the next four years, the world's first woman prime minister forged ahead with her husband's socialist reform programme. The island was thrust into the emerging Non-Aligned Movement; foreign oil companies were nationalised and all government business was transferred from foreign banks to the state-owned Bank of Ceylon and the new People's Bank, bringing an end to US aid. Soviet aid was sought for industrialisation projects and education was reformed in favour of the Buddhist Sinhalese.

But under pressure from rightwing Buddhist leaders, some SLFP MPs crossed the floor and the government collapsed at the end of 1964. She lost the next year's elections, but was herself elected to parliament for the first time.

In 1970 the United Left Front led by the SLFP won a two-thirds majority in parliament. But in 1971 the leftwing People's Liberation Front launched an insurrection in protest against unemployment. This rebellion was swiftly crushed, though at the cost of an estimated 1,000 lives. More than 10,000 were jailed, but most were later released. Deeply shaken, the government pressed on with land reform, the nationalisation of the tea estates and a new republican constitution, which changed Ceylon's name to Sri Lanka and made Buddhism the state religion - to the dismay of the mainly Hindu Tamils.

Mrs Bandaranaike also imposed rigid state control over the economy. Under the impact of soaring oil prices, living standards collapsed in a welter of rationing, bureaucracy and corruption. Her SLFP was routed in the 1977 elections. The UNP, led by JR Jayawardene, secured a 75% majority, which he used to tighten the authoritarian regime Mrs Bandaranaike had imposed in her second term. He revised the 1972 constitution and had himself elected executive president. In 1980 he had her civic rights suspended for seven years for abuse of power.

With Mrs Bandaranaike unable to play any public role, the SLFP was riven by discord. In the difficult years ahead her main task was to hold the party together. Succession to the party leadership became a bone of contention between her son Anura, who was moving to the right, and her daughter Chandrika, who formed her own leftwing party with her popular film star husband Vijaya Kumaranatunga. One of the new party's main aims was to seek a rapprochement with the Tamils.

With her civic rights restored in 1985, Mrs Bandaranaike recovered her place as unchallenged leader and the SLFP's fortunes rose again. After Kumaranatunga's assassination in 1988, Chandrika rejoined the SLFP and secured the party leadership in 1994 at the expense of Anura, who crossed over to the UNP.

These were years of mounting violence, often initiated by the government or the ruling UNP. After the nationwide pogrom in 1983, the Tamils took to armed resistance and in 1987 India sent in troops to impose a peace settlement. It failed, but Mrs Bandaranaike, once India's greatest ally on the island, hotly opposed the intervention.

Without influence in Delhi or among the Tamils, she could not prevent rising violence in the south. In 1989 the JVP was again crushed by the UNP government. Estimates of the number slaughtered vary from 30,000 to 70,000.

Her last bid for power was in the presidential elections of 1988 and the parliamentary polls of 1989. The UNP lost its two-thirds majority in parliament, its chief weapon in manipulating the constitution.

Mrs Bandaranaike stepped down just before the parliamentary elections in 1994. When Chandrika also won the presidential elections three months later, she appointed her mother prime minister.

The Bandaranaikes, husband and widow, broke the stifling colonial ethos of the English-speaking elite, and restored dignity and a rightful place to the Sinhalese. But it was largely at the expense of the Tamils. Mrs Bandaranaike, like most Sinhalese, had little concept of the island as a multi-ethnic whole.

Sirima Bandaranaike, nee Ratwatte, born April 17 1916, died October 10 2000.

webTitle: Sister Julia can't you spare a dime?

fields.headline: Sister Julia can't you spare a dime?
fields.trailText: Toothsome Julia Roberts, Hollywood's newly-crowned most bankable star, has had to fend off accusations of meanness and lack of talent - from her own straight-to-video brother, Eric
fields.body:
Hollywood's newly-crowned most bankable star Julia Roberts has had to fend off accusations of meanness and lack of talent - from her own straight-to-video brother, Eric.

Eric, who hit the big time with Runaway Train back in 1985 and rapidly slipped back into oblivion, says: "Julia could help me and she hasn't. I helped her, and when she was in a situation to help me she wanted nothing to do with me."

Of sister's success in the legal drama Erin Brockovich, grumpy bro adds, "Everyone's going on about how great she was in it but what did she do? Wear some push-up bras. It wasn't great acting."

The toothsome actress was recently raised to the top of Hollywood's annual star power chart, the first woman to be identified as the industry's most bankable star (see our earlier story).

According to the list, compiled by former Premiere magazine columnist James Ulmer, the Notting Hill star beat off competition from Tom Hanks (who's number two) as well as 80s throwbacks Tom Cruise, Mel Gibson and Bruce Willis (third, fourth and fifth respectively). The only other woman in the top ten is Meg Ryan, whose impending role as porn star Linda Lovelace may endanger future appearances on the chart. Top Brit, at number twenty, is Sean Connery. The younger generation is represented by Leo DiCaprio at nine and Will Smith at ten.

Speaking about her giddying success - her last five films grossed over $100 million - Roberts purred, "In every piece of work I do, working hard is what enables me to get the next job."

webTitle: Language resources: the French fuel problem

fields.headline: La France en manque
fields.standfirst: The French government has cut diesel, but not petrol, prices following the recent protests.  Zoé Eisenstein finds out what people think
fields.trailText: The French government has cut diesel, but not petrol, prices following the recent protests.  Zo* Eisenstein finds out what people think
fields.body:
Mauvaise nouvelle pour la fin des vacances : le prix de l'essence augmente. Les camionneurs, les chauffeurs de taxi, les pêcheurs sont mécontents et ils protestent. Il y a la grève des taxis, le blocage des routes par les camionneurs et celui des ports par les pêcheurs. Leurs protestations ont le soutien de la majorité du public. C'est le plus gros coup dur pour Lionel Jospin depuis son élection.

Il n'y a même plus d'essence dans les stations-service. Les automobilistes qui veulent faire le plein doivent faire la queue pendant des heures ou passer par l'Allemagne ou la Belgique. C'est la pagaille !

Ça a duré pendant quinze jours et le gouvernement a fini par céder plus qu'il ne le voulait. Mais le problème pour les automobilistes en France n'a pas changé : le prix à la pompe continue à augmenter.

Qu'en pensent les Français ?

Majid, chauffeur de taxi : Si j'ai fait grève, c'est surtout pour protester contre l'augmentation du prix du gazole. Grosso modo, on peut dire qu'en un an et demi, le prix est passé de quatre francs à six francs le litre. Pour ceux qui utilisent le gazole comme matière première, comme les taxis, c'est énorme. On a protesté à la tour Eiffel. C'était une mobilisation rapide, mais qui a rassemblé quand m me la plupart des taxis parisiens. On veut simplement améliorer certaines conditions de travail, vivre tranquillement, avoir des conditions qui nous permettent d'avoir un peu de temps libre et de gagner notre vie correctement.

Finalement, le gouvernement nous a fait une proposition, qui n'a pas encore été mise à l'épreuve. Ils ont dit qu'il y aurait une augmentation au niveau des tarifications et je crois que dans un premier temps, c'est déjà pas mal.

Quel effet a eu la grève sur toi ?

Philippe: D'abord on n'a pas pu sortir parce qu'il n'y avait pas d'essence. Chaque fois qu'il fallait remplir la voiture, c'était la course pour trouver une station-service qui était ouverte. Les stations parisiennes, ça allait à peu près, mais en province, c'était mission impossible .

Anaïs: À l'époque de la grève, je suis partie en weekend en province et j'ai pas eu de problème personnellement. Mais c'était une ambiance de panique, de psychose, d'avant-guerre; tout le monde avait peur de ne pas avoir assez d'essence pour partir, pour revenir.

Fred: J'étais pas du tout solidaire par rapport à leur cause mais par contre, j'avais très envie que le mouvement dure pour qu'il n'y ait plus de bagnoles dans Paris !

Que penses-tu des accords entre le gouvernement et les grévistes?

Philippe: L'accord est peut-être une bonne nouvelle pour les camionneurs ou pour les taxis mais pour les automobilistes privés, ça n'a absolument rien donné. On paye de plus en plus cher notre essence. Et le gouvernement se fait de l'argent sur notre dos.

Anaïs: Je ne sais pas vraiment ce qui s'est passé. Mais en tout cas, pour les particuliers, le fait d'avoir supprimé la vignette, je trouve ça ridicule. Les vignettes les plus chères étaient attribuées aux voitures les plus luxueuses. Les supprimer va favoriser les gens qui ont plus de moyens.

Fred: Ça ne me concerne pas. Moi j'utilise le vélo. De mon point de vue personnel, l'essence n'est jamais assez chère.

Quel effet cette histoire va-t-elle avoir sur la popularité de Jospin?

Philippe: Si on payait le prix brut du pétrole, on paierait un ou deux francs le litre. Là, le gouvernement encaisse la grande partie. Si le premier ministre n'annonce pas une bonne nouvelle pour les automobilistes, sa popularité ne risque pas d'augmenter.

Anaïs: Je suis sûre que son image est déjà dégradée. Dans un moment où elle avait besoin d'ûtre renforcée.

Fred: Elle en a déjà pris un coup. Mais je ne pense pas que ce soit un truc qui lui nuise trop personnellement.

Est-ce qu'il serait temps de penser à de nouveaux moyens de transport?

Philippe: Ça ne marchera pas à mon avis. On sait déjà que le diesel est très polluant et les écologistes sont contre. De toute façon, eux, ils sont pour l'augmentation du prix du pétrole parce que ça décourage les gens de rouler en bagnole.

Anaïs: Tout à fait : les transports en commun, le Météor qui ne consomme rien, les bus qui fonctionnent au colza au lieu du pétrole.

Fred: Évidemment. Il y a le transport fluvial par exemple qui a été pratiquement abandonné. C'est du pétrole aussi, mais ça consomme beaucoup moins que les camions. Mais pour moi, le vélo en ville, c'est le moyen de transport royal !

webTitle: Piety overshadows rites of unrepentant showman

fields.headline: Piety overshadows rites of unrepentant showman
fields.trailText: Ever since the schedule for Paris fashion week was published, there have been unhappy mutterings about the fact that yesterday, the third day of shows, coincided with Yom Kippur, one of the most important holy days in the Jewish calendar and one on which adherents are forbidden to work. The American designer Marc Jacobs put his show for Louis Vuitton back one day, while prominent Jewish fashion journalists and buyers made it known that they would not be attending shows.
fields.body:
Ever since the schedule for Paris fashion week was published, there have been unhappy mutterings about the fact that yesterday, the third day of shows, coincided with Yom Kippur, one of the most important holy days in the Jewish calendar and one on which adherents are forbidden to work. The American designer Marc Jacobs put his show for Louis Vuitton back one day, while prominent Jewish fashion journalists and buyers made it known that they would not be attending shows.

But among the designers who went ahead with shows was French designer Gaspard Yurkievich. This was the sixth collection from the 28-year-old Parisian whose sculptural shapes have earned him a cult following.

Entitled 'Parade', yesterday's show was based around an exaggerated hourglass shape, with necklines wide enough to fall off the shoulders, waists de fined, and skirts and trousers flaring out from hip level. Fabrics included this season's ubiquitous jersey, as well as PVC and elegant sheer black lace. Customised denim, a collaboration with Levi's Red, the jean giant's most exclusive, high-end line, included faded jeans and skirts weighted with brass upholstery studs.

A recurring motif in Yurkievich's collections is a stiff fan of pleated fabric worn as an armband at the shoulder. In the collection on sale these are pointed, to look like angel wings. In the collection shown yesterday, which will be available for spring/summer 2001, they are circular, and appear in leather at the shoulders of sleeveless jersey T-shirts and dresses in raspberry and mustard.

webTitle: Rumours Unlimited

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours have been offered £2m a year to stay at Highbury
fields.trailText: Arsene Wenger was approached by the FA to take charge of England for one game in the wake of Kevin Keegan's resignation, according to the Sun. The Arsenal boss turned the offer down, of course, leaving Howard Wilkinson in control for the crucial Finland game.
fields.body:
Arsene Wenger was approached by the FA to take charge of England for one game in the wake of Kevin Keegan's resignation, according to the Sun. The Arsenal boss turned the offer down, of course, leaving Howard Wilkinson in control for the crucial Finland game.

Marcello Lippi is interested in the job, though. "I hear my name is mentioned it is very gratifying to be in the frame for such a prestigious position," he said.

Meanwhile, Southampton are ready to equal the club record £2m they paid for David Hirst by signing Tottenham goalkeeper Ian Walker.

Poland goalkeeper Jerzy Dudek is on the verge of joining Arsenal in a £4m deal, according to the Daily Mail.

Christian Dailly could be on his way back to Derby after losing his place at Blackburn. But Jim Smith is not prepared to meet the £4m asking price for the Scottish international, who left Derby for Blackburn in a £5.3m deal in 1998. Celtic and Newcastle are keeping tabs on the situation.

AC Milan midfielder Zvonimir Boban has turned down a £4m move to Chelsea.

Bordeaux's 20-year-old striker Nicolas Sahnoun will spend a year on loan at Fulham.

Luton are about to sign defender Jose Jorge Saavedra, according to Planet Football. The 22-year-old Spaniard, who plays for Primera Liga side Real Oviedo, will join Ricky Hill's men early next week.

webTitle: Putting paid to Lippi service

fields.headline: Putting paid to Lippi service
fields.standfirst: Football Italia presenter James Richardson joins Football Unlimited today. In his first column, he takes a long hard look at the latest new dawn for Internazionale
fields.trailText: October is a revolting month, as Lenin once observed, and the dull thud of Keegan and Milosevic falling with the autumn leaves confirms this year is no exception.
fields.body:
October is a revolting month, as Lenin once observed, and the dull thud of Keegan and Milosevic falling with the autumn leaves confirms this year is no exception.

Here in Italy, of course, we've had a top dog dismissal of our own to chew over - Marcello Lippi, manager of Internazionale. Lippi's sacking came just three days into a new championship, which post-Keegan looks positively pedestrian but still left Italians open mouthed like a bowl of steaming linguini.

Why the surprise? Until arriving at Inter, Lippi had the most impressive CV in the Italian game. A cigar-puffing Paul Newman lookalike, at previous clubs Napoli and Juventus he'd brought extraordinary results including three Italian titles at Juve in his first four seasons. Naturally, his move to the nerazzurri a year ago was supposed to herald the start of a glorious new era, but as usual what had worked elsewhere here went hideously wrong.

Call it the Inter jinx. For years, after all, this club has relentlessly bought up the world's top talents only to watch them break up or fail. Take Dennis Bergkamp, Ronaldo and Christian Vieri - all three hanging ten on the wave of success until they met the cold hard beach of Inter. Lippi was no exception. A few months in Inter's heart of darkness were enough to turn Serie A's most intelligent, charismatic and flexible manager into an arrogant ball of nerves.

Not surprisingly, his debut season was not successful, with Marcello upsetting the players and ending cupless. In May, to clear the air, he offered his resignation but the club declined. This season, then, Inter began afresh with two targets: the Champions League and the Italian championship.

The first they exited in the preliminary round, and when the second began with an away defeat to Reggina, Lippi borrowed a page from Artie Fufkin: "If it were up to me," he informed a puzzled post-game press conference, "I'd fire the manager, put all the players against the wall and kick their backsides." Inter dismissed him two days later.

Those of us who love Serie A for the silly surnames now have only Totti to fall back on, but the news isn't all bad. Firstly, Lippi's plea for post-game spankings was plainly a cry for help - the time off and the check to his rampant pride should do him good. Secondly, as their performance at Reggina made all too clear, the team sure won't miss him.

Meanwhile, Inter's directors get to do what they enjoy most: start afresh. This Wednesday, thus, the club that's seen more disasters than George Kennedy unveiled their latest manager, Marco Tardelli. Last time many of us saw Tardelli, he was tearing his way across the Bernabeu turf yelling his head off, having put Italy on course for the '82 World Cup. Eighteen years later, he arrives worryingly fresh from success with Italy's Under-21 side.

Under his management this summer, they won the European championship with a side featuring many of Inter's younger players - now his task is to bring a little humility and cohesion to the Nerazzurri's multi-ethnic squad. Hopes are high as always.

webTitle: TV websites more popular

fields.headline: TV websites ride high in popularity stakes
fields.trailText: 11.15am:TV stations' websites are attracting four times the number of visitors than they were a year ago, according to research from MMXI Europe, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Websites for TV stations are attracting four times the number of visitors than they were a year ago, according to research from MMXI Europe.

Buoyed by the success of Big Brother, Channel4.com increased its audience by 390% from 271,000 in March 99 to 1.3m unique visitors in August. BBC.co.uk has consistently been one of the most popular UK websites, with the number of unique visitors to the site increasing by 33% from last October to 1.5m in August this year.

French TV channel TF1's website, TF1.fr, increased its number of unique visitors from 137,000 in October 1999 to 267,000 in August this year.

Arielle Dinard, managing director of Jupiter MMXI, said: "By extending their brand to the internet, TV channels can offer more value to their audiences whilst at the same time strengthen their brand."

webTitle: CanalWeb launches in UK

fields.headline: CanalWeb joins forces with H2P for UK launch
fields.trailText: 11am: CanalWeb has launched a UK operation with H2P, Amy Vickers reports.
fields.body:
French webcaster CanalWeb has launched a UK operation in partnership with H2P, the streaming media company set up by the former Victoria Real director, Fred Hasson, and Mathew Horsman, research director at Investec Henderson Crosthwaite.

CanalWeb, which was launched in France at the start of 1999, is positioning itself as the largest European TV internet operator, having already launched an operation in Spain.

In the UK, H2P and CanalWeb UK will develop British programmes to be screened via its website. Viewers will be encouraged to interact with the programmes and chat with other internet viewers.

CanalWeb claims to have more than 400,000 viewers per month, watching 60 hours of live webcasts every week, and more than 5,000 hours of on-demand content. In the next four years CanalWeb says it will develop 1,000 programmes, equivalent to around 75,000 hours of webcasting.

CanalWeb plans to IPO on the Paris Bourse in the first half of next year. In addition to moving into new European markets, the company is negotiating with broadcasters, such as Canal-Satellite and TPS, to broadcast its content on their digital services.

webTitle: Granada achieves status upgrade

fields.headline: Granada achieves status upgrade
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Granada received some rare good news from the City this morning, following the issuing of a positive analyst's note, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Granada received some rare good news from the City this morning, following the issuing of a positive analyst's note.

SG Securities upgraded the media giant's status from "hold" to "buy", with a target price of 468p. Granada's shares recently received two downgrades in 10 days from Merrill Lynch, due to concerns over falling advertising revenue and the cost of rolling out digital services.

SG media analyst Anthony De Larrinaga said Granada was now trading at a bargain 15% discount, and that the bad news about ads and digital services was more than covered by the lower price.

"The shares have fallen too far, and the market hates to catch falling knives. The market was focusing too much on short-term earnings momentum, and it loves to run after a short-term bad news story," said Mr De Larrinaga.

However, Granada's shares were down 3.5p to 394.5p in early trading.

webTitle: H Bauer hits back at WH Smith in distribution row

fields.headline: H Bauer hits back at WH Smith in distribution row
fields.trailText: 10am: H Bauer is threatening legal action against WH Smith after it issued edicts to three companies ordering them to move onto its national distribution network, Jessica Hodgson writes.
fields.body:
H Bauer is threatening legal action against WH Smith after the newsagent issued edicts to three companies ordering them to move onto its national distribution network.

WH Smith has informed publishers H Bauer and DC Thomson and distributor MMC that they must source magazines through its wholesale distribution business on a national basis. H Bauer is objecting on the grounds that it has several exclusive, regionally-based contracts which it cannot simply override.

John Menzies, which has a distribution relationship with H Bauer, had threatened to instigate legal action against H Bauer for breach of contract if the publisher was forced to drop its relationship with the company. But a spokesman for John Menzies said the companies were now in agreement and H Bauer would continue to honour its relationship.

Max Beddard, H Bauer's chief financial officer, said legal proceedings had yet to be instigated, but confirmed that the company was on the point of suing. He told MediaGuardian: "The wholesale network works differently in different geographical areas. By forcing us into a national distribution network, they are putting us in breach of contract with other distributors."

WH Smith's supply chain controller, David Taylor, said that H Bauer did not have a contract which allowed it to use different distributors in different areas. He admitted "there are a number of contracts which preclude us moving [other publishers] onto national distribution". But he claimed that DC Thomson and MMC were "willing" to follow WH Smith's wishes to go onto national distribution. webTitle: US actors' unions call for advertiser boycott

fields.headline: US actors' unions call for advertiser boycott
fields.trailText: 10.30am: The US actors' strike today steps up a gear as unions call for a boycott of Procter & Gamble's products, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The US actors' strike will today step up a gear when trade unions hold a protest at the annual general meeting of Procter & Gamble and call for a mass boycott of the company's products.

In a statement the unions said they were calling for a boycott because Procter & Gamble, the world's biggest advertiser, had used non-union actors to continue to make commercials during the five-month actors' strike.

The actors will officially kick off their protests at Procter & Gamble's AGM in Cincinnatti today. Further demonstrations will take place in New York, where actors Julia Roberts, Susan Sarandon and Tim Robbins are expected to call on the US public to boycott P&G brands including Tide detergent and Crest toothpaste.

Talks between the actors' unions and advertiser representatives broke down at the end of last month. They are due to restart on October 19, but appear to be no closer to reaching an agreement. Indeed, there are signs that the strike may be spreading after member of the New York branch of the International Association of Theatrical Employees, which includes grips and electricians, joined in. Members refused to work on the set of a commercial being shot for P&G's Physique hair care brand in New York.

The dispute began when advertisers said they were planning to change the way they pay actors, proposing a single upfront fee. Until now, actors have been paid according to how often the ad is broadcast

webTitle: NatMags editor defends Voices against 'propaganda' claims

fields.headline: NatMags editor defends Voices against 'propaganda' claims
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Good Housekeeping's editor, Lindsay Nicholson, has defended Voices magazine against accusations that it is "blatant propaganda", writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The editor of Good Housekeeping, Lindsay Nicholson, has defended Voices magazine against accusations that it is "blatant propaganda".

Ms Nicholson said that the National Magazine Company was simply providing a "contract publishing" function for the government in its decision to publish the magazine, edited by former GH editor Pat Roberts-Cairns, for the government's Women's Unit.

She said: "Good Housekeeping has always had strong links with the government of the day. It's got nothing to do with the Labour party."

Ms Nicholson pointed out that during the second world war, GH was one of the few magazines authorised by the government to publish magazines despite rationing. She added that GH would publish a magazine for the Conservatives if it asked them to and if it was in keeping with the magazine's ethos.

Labour has come under fire in the past for targeting women's magazines to spread its message. Before joining Natmags last year as communications chief, Siobhan Kenny worked at the Downing Street communications unit and Tony Blair last year gave an exclusive interview with Prima. Press reports have since accused the prime minister of using women's magazines for "soft target" propaganda, a strategy that backfired spectacularly when he was heckled by the Women's Institute earlier this year.

webTitle: NUJ seeks guarantees on BBC news bulletins

fields.headline: NUJ seeks guarantees on longer BBC news bulletins
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: Regional heads of NUJ chapels are meeting today to discuss the BBC's decision to lengthen regional bulletins, Jessica Hodgson reports.
fields.body:
Regional heads of NUJ chapels are meeting today to discuss the impact of the BBC's decision to lengthen the regional bulletins that follow the main national news and the later time of the bulletins.

The BBC will lengthen its bulletins from their current time of three minutes 15 seconds to six minutes, and the bulletins will now follow the main national news at 10pm from October 16. The BBC has indicated that it wants to make life as easy as possible for staff moving onto later shifts, providing for later working and rostering shifts to suit staff.

But an NUJ spokesman says the union may want an increase in staffing in certain regions and guarantees that staff will be given greater flexibility on shifts.

webTitle: The Omagh Panorama

fields.headline: Panorama pulls no punches
fields.standfirst: It's being sidelined to Sunday, but Monday's Panorama on the Omagh bombing showed that current affairs still has a place at the heart of peak time. Matt Wells on the making of a classic investigation.
fields.trailText: Monday's Panorama on the Omagh bombing shows that current affairs still has a place at the heart of peak time. Matt Wells on the making of a classic investigation.
fields.body:
The Panorama programme that named four men allegedly involved in the Omagh bombing did not just defy the critics in Northern Ireland, it also stuck two fingers up to the BBC mandarins who shunted the series to the graveyard slot on Sunday night.

John Ware's emotion-filled report - the last to be shown in the usual Monday night 10pm slot - demonstrated that the BBC's flagship current affairs series still has the capacity to tell a cracking story in a gripping style, as well as stirring up enough fuss to get itself onto the front pages His report was not only important politically, it demonstrated to figures such as the BBC director of television, Mark Thompson - understood to be behind the decision to shift Panorama following the move of the Nine O'clock News to 10pm - that hard-hitting current affairs can justify its place at the heart of the peak-time schedule

The programme mixed typical BBC authority, Roger Cook-style confrontations with suspects and emotional interviews with victims' families to produce an effective and memorable piece of television. Undeniably, the evidence was thin - Mr Ware only had mobile phone records to go on - but the programme did not name the suspects as the "Omagh bombers". It simply stated that they had questions to answer.

Some relatives of the Omagh dead felt that the programme would prejudice any future trial. The high court in Belfast disagreed, dismissing an application for an injunction 90 minutes before Panorama went on air. But there are other concerns. Clearly, Mr Ware relied heavily on the police for information. There were also hints that police were involved in protecting Mr Ware and his team when they visited the houses of those he named. At one point, he revealed that "local police" told him that associates of one man had turned up at one location a few minutes after Panorama's departure.

So why were the police so happy to associate themselves with Panorama and John Ware? The Omagh investigation has reached an impasse. Police know who carried out the atrocity, but they do not have enough evidence to bring them to trial. They need people to testify in court. Appeals by the RUC are unlikely to cut much ice with nationalists and republicans, but Mr Ware has, in the past, questioned security service involvement in the deaths of prominent Catholics. He is a figure with independent credentials.

But by aligning himself with the police, did Mr Ware allow himself to be manipulated? He would strongly deny such a charge. The programme had the blessing of many, if not all, of the victims' relatives. Mr Ware also put himself in a great deal of personal danger, and decided to shoulder most of the risk - note that the programme did not end with the usual production team credits. It is also undeniable that the four men named by Panorama have serious questions to answer.

Panorama, in one of its most memorable programmes of recent years, has returned to form.

webTitle: ITC relaxes rules on programme sponsorship

fields.headline: ITC relaxes rules on programme sponsorship
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Advertisers have been given the right to visually feature their products across TV sponsorship for the first time, following an ITC decision to relax its rules on programme sponsorship.
fields.body:
Advertisers have been given the right to visually feature their products across TV sponsorship for the first time today, following the independent television commission's decision to relax its rules on programme sponsorship.

From now on credits may also include contact details such as telephone numbers and website addresses, provided they are not part of an explicit encouragement to purchase or contact the sponsor.

The move will be welcomed by advertisers and their agencies as technology increasingly enables viewers to skip advertising content. It will bring sponsorship much closer to advertising and will inevitably make it much more attractive to advertisers as a medium.

While the ITC aims to provide a streamlined and more user-friendly regulatory approach to sponsorship, advertisers will still be asked to ensure that sponsorship credits are clearly differentiated from spot advertising and make a clear link between the sponsor and the programme. These regulations will act to prevent sponsor credits being used as extra advertising minutage and programmes being distorted for commercial purposes.

The rules that prohibit the sponsorship of news programmes, current affairs programmes and consumer advice programmes will continue to prevent advertisers influencing editorial content. The sponsorship of business and finance programming will no longer be specifically prohibited but they may be unsponsorable if they fall into a news category.

Martin Hart, the ITC's head of sponsorship said: "The new ITC sponsorship code represents a real step forward in terms of simplifying regulation whilst preserving the core principles which protect viewers' enjoyment of programmes."

fields.headline: Bertelsmann joins Lycos for music download venture
fields.trailText: Bertelsmann, the German media conglomerate, has linked up with US portal Lycos to sell music downloads over the net, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Bertelsmann, the German media conglomerate, has linked up with US portal Lycos to sell music downloads over the net.

The Lycos Music Internet site will sell digital downloads of records from Bertelsmann's BMG record label. BMG artists include veteran rocker Santana and Christina Aguilera, arch-rival of Britney Spears.

The move is the latest attempt by Bertelsmann to take the initiative in online retailing. The company already sells music, books and videos through its Bol.com operation and is a major shareholder in internet bookseller Barnesandnoble.com.

webTitle: Editors seek clarity on Human Rights Act

fields.headline: Editors seek clarity on Human Rights Act
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: The Society of Editors is asking any editors who may have encountered problems with the new Human Rights Act to contact it, Jessica Hodgson writes.
fields.body:
The Society of Editors is asking any editors who may have encountered problems with the new Human Rights Act, which came into force on October 2, to contact it.

The move follows reports that a police force had told a local newspaper it can no longer release the names and addresses of people who have been charged before they have appeared in court. The Society of Editors would not reveal the name of the police force.

The society's director, Bob Satchwell, said that on the whole he "cautiously welcomed" the Human Rights Act, believing that it would ultimately mean greater freedom of information. He pointed out that the act emphasises that Article 10 - protecting the freedom of the press - should be given precedence over Article eight, which protects the right to privacy. "A lot of senior government law officers are saying that its going to be beneficial for the media," he said.

Mr Satchwell said he was talking to the police force in question in an attempt to put the situation right. He added: "What we are concerned about is that there are lots of organisations around the country who are going to have to be educated about what the act means."

Last week the commissioner of the Metropolitan Police, Sir John Stevens, said that he wanted police forces across the country to co-operate with the media to counteract a growing "suspicion" between the two.

webTitle: Incepta chief quits as profits surge

fields.headline: Incepta chief quits as profits surge
fields.trailText: 9.15am: Bob Morton, chairman of marketing group Incepta, has announced he is to step down, on the day his company posted bumper profits, says Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Bob Morton, chairman of marketing group Incepta, has announced he is to step down, on the day his company posted bumper profits.

Mr Morton, who is also chairman of troubled internet firm Freecom.net and has been in charge of Incepta since 1992, said he will leave before the end of the financial year.

"As I look ahead, I believe the time is now right to plan to handover as chairman of the group," he said.

Meanwhile, Incepta doubled its first-half pre-tax profits on the back of a boom in its overseas operations, from £7m to £14.2m. Turnover rose from £76.7m to £113.4m.

The group, which is best known for owning financial PR firm Citigate Dewe Rogerson and its US counterpart Sard Verbinnen, said non-UK revenue rose from £11.9m to £29.3m, with UK earnings climbing from £25m to £34.7m.

Public relations remains the group's biggest earner by far, with revenue nearly doubling to £32.5m, with advertising coming next, on £17.7m

The past six months have seen the group make several acquisitions in the global market, including Cunningham Communication in the US and Finex - a Milan-based financial services company.

David Wright, chief executive of Incepta, said: "The group has had an excellent first half, with results that further strengthen our position as one of the world's fastest-growing marketing and communication groups."
