webTitle: Paul Jackson quits BBC

fields.headline: Jackson quits BBC for Granada Media Australia
fields.trailText: 10.45am: The BBC controller of entertainment, Paul Jackson, is quitting to become managing director of Granada Media Australia and chief executive of Red Heart Productions, Jason Deans reports.
fields.body:
The BBC controller of entertainment, Paul Jackson, is leaving the corporation to become managing director of Granada Media Australia and chief executive of Red Heart Productions, Granada's Australian production joint venture with Seven Network.

Mr Jackson will take up the Sydney-based role by the end of the month, overseeing a 400-hour-plus Red Heart production slate including the dramas Home & Away and SeaChange. He will report to Red Heart's chairman, Steve Vizard, following chief executive David Champtaloup's recent departure.

He said: "I am a programme-maker through and through and I will be doing what I love best - working with talented people on both sides of the screen."

Chris Pye, Granada Creative commercial director and executive vice-president international production, said: "Paul Jackson has unrivalled experience in producing, commissioning and managing innovative and exciting new shows which makes him the perfect appointment to capitalise on the continual international growth of the Australian market."

Mr Jackson, whose long and distinguished track record in comedy and entertainment programming includes The Young Ones and Three of a Kind, has been head of the BBC entertainment department for nearly four years.

He was a sometimes outspoken critic of former BBC director general Sir John Birt's regime. There has been speculation about his future at the BBC since the new director general, Greg Dyke, introduced a new management structure in April and Mr Jackson's department became part of Alan Yentob's drama, entertainment and children's production division.

webTitle: ITV counters BBC criticism of sports coverage

fields.headline: ITV counters BBC criticism of sports coverage
fields.standfirst: BBC lambasts ITV in row over rugby rights
fields.trailText:
9.45am: ITV has defended its sports output following BBC criticism of its FA Cup, Formula One and Rugby World Cup coverage. By Jason Deans.
BBC lambasts ITV in row over rugby rights
fields.body:
ITV has defended its sports output following BBC criticism of the broadcaster's FA Cup, Formula One and Rugby World Cup coverage.

An ITV spokesman said the channel's sports output was stronger than it had ever been, with an increased commitment and investment in the "golden trio" of Champions' League football, Formula One motor racing and the recently acquired Premiership highlights for next season, which are currently shown on the BBC's Match of the Day.

The spokesman was responding to BBC claims that ITV only announced it was not bidding for the 2003 Rugby World Cup because it was unlikely to win the rights. He said: "The BBC is now reduced to congratulating itself for winning rights against no competition. That says it all about the state of BBC Sport."

ITV recently devoted five hours of coverage to the Japanese Formula One Grand Prix, the ITV spokesman added, and was named international broadcaster of the year by the Formula One Association.

He said this year's FA Cup ratings were poor because the match between Chelsea and Aston Villa was poor.

webTitle: Web agency launches Uni-Lateral

fields.headline: Web agency kicks off expansion drive
fields.trailText: 8am:Web agency Lateral has taken its first step towards developing its much-talked-about network infrastructure, Uni-Lateral, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Web agency Lateral has taken its first step towards developing its much-talked-about network infrastructure, tentatively called Uni-Lateral.

The first agency within the network has been named as lshift, which will concentrate on back-end technology solutions. Lateral is believed to have invested around £150,000 in the project in return for a 20% stake and a seat on the board. Other agencies that cover media, PR, strategy, creative and technology are also being mooted.

The thinking behind the the expansion strategy is that Lateral will be able to tap into talent across the network without taking the agency past its self-imposed limit of 30 staff.

Andy Wilson, chief executive and co-founder of lshift, said: "Talent in this industry is being vastly underused. The idea of lshift is to create an environment where geeks want to work and where people want to stick together."

webTitle: Future has seen the past and it is exaggerated

fields.headline: Future has seen the past and it is exaggerated
fields.trailText: Magazine publisher Future Networks has discovered an apparent black hole in the accounts of its French subsidiary, leading to a 24% slump in its stock market value yesterday, writes David Teather.
fields.body:
Magazine publisher Future Networks has discovered an apparent black hole in the accounts of its French subsidiary, leading to a 24% slump in its stock market value yesterday.

The company, which owns the internet magazine Business 2.0, said discrepancies had been identified by management in its French operation at the end of last week. Initial findings suggest that sales of certain titles have been overstated by £3.2m over three years.

The discovery compounded an already tough couple of months for Future which has watched its share price fall from 900p at the start of August. Yesterday the price fell 140p to 445p.

Greg Ingham, Future's chief executive, said the situation was frustrating, but main tained that it had no effect on the underlying business. "This is obviously a significant hit but it shouldn't fundamentally alter our story." he said. "The real value in our business is the future potential for growth and the ability to come up with good ideas."

Accountancy firm Deloitte & Touche was brought in at the end of last week to verify the findings and will continue a fuller investigation. The company has not suspended any staff over the affair and Mr Ingham said there appeared no cause to notify the police.

"We are still trying to fully understand what has happened here, to collate and analyse all the necessary information. It seems to be an issue of competence as opposed to malice or fraud," he said.

Initial checks have been carried out in other parts of the business to make sure that similar problems do not exist elsewhere. France contributed 10% of revenues in the most recent set of figures issued by the company and 5% of operating profits.

One analyst conceded that the amount was small in the context of a company which last year recorded revenues of £174m but said it had depressed sentiment around the company. Operating profits last year were £23m.

Future is closely identified with the hi-tech sector through many of its best selling titles and has weathered many of the same negative changes in investor attitude.

Mr Ingham said measures were being taken to ensure there would be no repeat of the problem. Extra financial managers are being employed.

Future bought the French business, then known as Edicorp, in spring 1998.

webTitle: BSkyB stands out from herd

fields.headline: BSkyB stands out from herd
fields.trailText: On a day when nearly everything in the technology, media and telecoms world was moving sharply lower, the solid performance of BSkyB yesterday was remarkable. By Neil Hume.
fields.body:
On a day when nearly everything in the technology, media and telecommunications world was moving sharply lower, the solid performance of BSkyB was remarkable.

Against the weak trend of the sector, shares in the satellite broadcaster fell just 2p to 970p as the market's shrewder players examined the possibility of a takeover.

Traders reckon the buyer is likely to be Sky Global Networks, the company which is at present being groomed for market flotation by Rupert Murdoch's News Corp.

Sky Global Networks is to become the holding company for all Mr Murdoch's digital broadcasting operations - ranging from Star TV in Asia to its controlling 37.5% stake in the British satellite broadcasting platform, BSkyB.

The plan is to incorporate all these assets into Sky Global Networks and then float the company on the Nasdaq exchange later this year.

The flotation promises to be the biggest in media history, with the company being valued at anything up to $40bn.

Sky Global Networks already has its first strategic investor in the shape of John Malone, the American cable pioneer. Recently Mr Murdoch has been signalling his desire to bring on board another strategic investor.

The name being mentioned is Vivendi, the French media group which already owns a 21% in BSkyB.

At a recent dinner Tony Ball, the chief executive of BSkyB, is said to have told investors that it is extremely likely Vivendi will join.

If Vivendi is invited to join Sky Global Networks it is likely to exchange its BSkyB stakeholding for a minority holding in Sky Global Networks. In the event that Vivendi does so, a full takoever bid for BSkyB might be triggered automatically because - according to dealers - Sky Global's stake in the satellite broadcaster will have reached 58%.

Takeover panel rules state clearly that should the owner of a 30-50% stake increase its holding it is required to launch a takeover bid.

However, the panel tends to look such events on a case by case basis - allowing a so-called whitewash if it thinks a bid unnecessary - so nothing can be taken for granted.

Moreover, Mr Murdoch's relationship with his opposite number at Vivendi, Jean-Marie Messier, has been troubled, to say the least.

Yet this did not stop analysts advising their clients to pile into the stock yesterday. Paul Reynolds, an analyst at Deutsche Bank, was telling his clients that holders of BSkyB shares at the time of such a deal are likely to receive a decent price. BSkyB, however, refused to comment.

After last week's respite, London's blue chips reverted to their downward trend. Once again the culprit was Nasdaq, where a truly dismal performance on Friday - the Nasdaq posted a three-figure decline - was followed by another yesterday.

The FTSE 100 closed down 126.4 points at 6,264.8, wiping out all of last week's 97-point gain. However, turnover in blue chip stocks was only 630m - the lowest since late August - suggesting that the day's move was more of a mark down than a genuine sell-off.

Elsewhere, the FTSE 250 eased 92.7 to 6,576.7 and the Techmark fell 135.5 to 3,593.12.

Hi-tech and telecoms stocks bore the brunt, with the worst hit being internet security group Baltimore , down 55p to 605p, chip designer ARM Holdings , off 53p to 672p, and cable company Telewest , 11p weaker at 127p.

Reckitt Benckiser managed to buck the trend, rising by some 28p to 881p. The household goods company has been seeing investors in the run-up to third quarter figures. Home shopping group GUS was another riser, up 2p to 439p ahead of an expected trading statement on Thursday.

Lower down the market it was more of the same, with technology stocks sinking. Online directory group Scoot.com fell 15.5p to 100p and Psion shed 65p to 630p.

Over on AIM, Sportscard Group made a solid debut. Against an issue price of 42p, the shares closed at 47.5p.

webTitle: Petrol crisis fuels inflation

fields.headline: Petrol crisis fuels inflation
fields.trailText: Rising prices at the petrol pumps led to a sharp pick up in inflation last month, according to official figures published today.
fields.body:
Rising prices at the petrol pumps led to a sharp pick up in inflation last month, according to official figures published today.

The Office for National Statistics reported that the headline rate of inflation in September rose to 3.3% from 3.0% the previous month.

The key underlying inflation rate - which excludes mortgage interest payments and is used by the Bank of England when setting interest rates - was also up, from 1.9% to 2.2%. But it remained below the government's 2.5% target.

The ONS said the increase was due largely to rising petrol prices - reflecting the rising cost of crude oil - which partly reversed the price falls of the previous month.

Normally, state pensions and other benefits would be uprated next year in line with the September headline inflation figure.

The 3.3% rate of growth would give an increase of around £2.25p a week on the single person's basic state pension. But the chancellor, Gordon Brown, has signalled that next year's up-rating would be above inflation.

His announcement followed an outcry over this year's 75p pension increase, which was based on the September 1999 figures, when inflation was at a 36-year low at just 1.1%. Mr Brown is expected to give details of the increase when he delivers his annual pre-Budget report in the next few weeks.

webTitle: Hizbullah resurgent and ready to fight

fields.headline: Hizbullah resurgent and ready to fight
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor in the Lebanese town of Baalbek finds the Hizbullah enjoying renewed confidence
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor in the Lebanese town of Baalbek finds the Hizbullah enjoying renewed confidence.
fields.body:
Anyone driving towards the Lebanese town of Baalbek begins to notice a change in the landscape. Army checkpoints become more frequent. Posters and signs, once bilingual, are written only in Arabic. Most alarmingly for many European visitors, red and yellow flags depicting an upthrust arm gripping an AK47 start to appear.

It shouldn't shock us, perhaps: elsewhere in the Middle East, Israeli men and women on military service have a habit of carrying their army-issue guns everywhere (even Tel Aviv nightclubs) because the penalty for losing them is so high. Nonetheless, it still comes as a surprise that eight years after the civil war - and seven years since they released British journalist John McCarthy - the militant Islamic faction of Hizbullah is still in remarkably good shape.

Hizbullah is more than just a guerrilla faction. It is a political party in its own right, with seats in the Lebanese parliament, and the Bekaa valley and south Lebanon are its strongholds. It was in Baalbek, the organisation's headquarters, that the western hostages spent part of their captivity and, perversely, it is Baalbek that attracts the majority of visitors to Lebanon.

They don't come to inspect the large Hizbullah barracks perched on the eastern slopes of the town, or to watch the organisation's local television channel, Baalbek TV. They come to gaze at the vast complex of ruined Roman temples which overlooks the town.

Perhaps the organisation thought that Israeli air forces might think twice before destroying the tallest temples ever built by the Romans. More likely, they realised its strategic importance. Baalbek lies close to the border with friendly Syria, and its position allows Hizbullah forces to get to the Israeli border in the south easily, bypassing Beirut and the crowded coastal towns of Lebanon.

And they are ready to fight. Invigorated by Israel's withdrawal from the 'occupied zone' of south Lebanon in May, Hizbullah has turned its attention to the dispossessed Palestinian Muslims in Israel and Chebaa, a piece of land seized by Israel from Syria in 1967.

Writing a postcard on the steps of the Temple of Jupiter a fortnight ago, days before violence broke out on the West Bank, I was surprised to hear the sound of gunfire coming from the Hizbullah camp on the hill. Soon afterwards, we heard the deeper boom of tank guns being fired. This practice session continued well into the evening and attracted not the slightest attention from the Lebanese tourists photographing the ruins or the Syrian soldiers smoking in the Temple of Bacchus on their day off.

Far from mollifying the party, Israel's pullout gave Hizbullah a new credibility. Until May, they dared not approach the Israeli border; now they have deployed troops only a few hundred metres away from it. This move infuriated Israelis, who would like to see Lebanon's president, Emile Lahoud, crack down on the paramilitaries.

Given that it is Syrian troops who are largely responsible for keeping the peace in Lebanon - despised by some Lebanese Christians, welcomed by most Muslims - wiping Hizbullah from the landscape of Lebanon would be not only undemocratic, but virtually impossible.

We drove back to Beirut through a road dotted with Bedouin tents, many of them made of old sugar sacks sent by the EU. Palestinian refugees sat cross-legged at junctions and watched the traffic go by. Occasionally an improvised wall of earth and sandbags tried to conceal a stash of tanks (some of them fake) from the road.

The stereotypical face of Hizbullah - an armed, sinister figure in sunglasses, military fatigues and headscarf - was nowhere to be seen. Yet Hizbullah was everywhere: in the flags draped from car repair shops, in the insignia sprayed on walls, as much a feature of Baalbek as its ancient temples. If Israel bombs its neighbour again, the government may not strike back. But Hizbullah will.

webTitle: Near enough is good enough in the US courts

fields.headline: Near enough is good enough in the US courts
fields.standfirst: The assertion in the US that no innocent prisoners are executed looks increasingly unlikely, writes Julian Borger in Washington
fields.trailText: The assertion in the US that no innocent prisoners are executed looks increasingly unlikely, writes Julian Borger in Washington
fields.body:
Just when you think you have heard the worst from the chamber of horrors that passes for the capital punishment system in the US, yet another chilling tale of wrongful conviction emerges from death row.

The latest such story comes from Virginia, where Earl Washington, a man with the mental age of a young teenager, has spent 17 years in prison for a murder and rape he did not commit, once coming within five days of execution.

DNA tests that proved conclusively that he was innocent of the crime finally led to a pardon last week. When his lawyer told him, he said: "Whew, I told everybody I didn't do that. I guess I'm freed now."

His lawyer had to tell him that he was not free. He still had to serve the rest of a 30-year sentence for another crime - hitting a neighbour over the head with a chair and stealing three dollars.

"Well, I've learned not to build my hopes and I'll just wait," Washington said. His lawyers are still fighting to get him out. He is now 39 years old. Washington's legal team had the exculpatory DNA evidence years ago. But in Virginia, if you cannot present evidence of innocence within 21 days of conviction, it is inadmissible.

If you have DNA evidence, eyewitness testimony, even a confession from the real killer, and you arrive 22 days after a death sentence has been pronounced, you have no recourse in the normal appeal court system. A handful of other states have similar laws, but Virginia's time limit is the shortest.

DNA testing has so far cleared 76 prisoners, including nine former death row inmates, of their crimes, but it is far from universally accepted. In some states, the criminal justice system jealously guards its convictions and is loathe to reopen cases.You cannot just keep the courts tied up indefinitely with old convictions, the prosecutors and the police often argue.

Just before the DNA evidence proved Washington innocent, the local police chief, CB Jones, told journalists: "It has been proved that he was guilty by a court of law and we keep trying the same case. Where is the end?"

In Texas two years ago, the appeal court refused to grant Roy Criner a new trial, even after DNA tests demonstrated that he was not responsible for the rape and murder he had been convicted of. His DNA did not match the semen found in the body. It was possible, the judges argued, that Criner had indeed committed the rape and used a condom.

He was only freed in August after tests matched DNA from cigarette butts found at the scene to the semen. After another man was exonerated of a rape charge with DNA evidence, the local Texas county destroyed forensic evidence from 50 other cases. Just tidying up, county officials said.

For some, of course, DNA testing comes too late. The family of Joe O'Dell is still fighting to prove his innocence of a rape and murder conviction more than two years after he was executed in Virginia. They wanted a DNA test, but were told that court officials had tossed the forensic evidence into an incinerator.

Even if they had not, it has been hitherto impossible to convince a US court to order posthumous DNA tests after an execution. There is almost certainly a connection between this policy and the argument advanced by death penalty supporters that no one in recent years has been proved to have been wrongfully executed.

webTitle: Acuna agent in the cold at Newcastle

fields.headline: Acuna agent in the cold at Newcastle
fields.trailText: Newcastle United may be reported to Fifa by the disgruntled agent of their latest signing, Clarence Acuna, after he was allegedly cut out of recent transfer dealings.
fields.body:
Newcastle United may be reported to Fifa by the disgruntled agent of their latest signing.

The Chile midfielder Clarence Acuna was on Tyneside yesterday undergoing a medical, and will complete his £1m move from Universidad de Chile once he has been granted a work permit. But the 25-year-old's agent Ronen Katzav has accused Newcastle of cutting him out of the transfer talks and is threatening to complain to football's world governing body.

The United chairman Freddy Shepherd and the general manager Russell Cushing flew to Buenos Aires last week to talk directly with Acuna and his club president, Pedro Gardenras. Earlier this season the Newcastle manager Bobby Robson criticised Duncan Ferguson's agent Dennis Roach when the striker's move to Everton appeared to collapse.

The former Newcastle striker Paul Robinson has joined Burnley from Wimbledon on a month's loan. The 21-year-old moved to Selhurst Park only this summer but has struggled to settle in the south since his £1.5m switch.

Aston Villa's England Under-21 striker Darius Vassell has signed a new four-year contract that ties him to Villa Park until the summer of 2004.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: £lm for 16 weeks a year - the job that nobody wants

fields.headline: £lm for 16 weeks a year - the job that nobody wants
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: The salary is £1m a year, you choose your own staff and even in a good year - an increasingly rare event - you work just 16 weeks out of 52. In the real world there would be no shortage of candidates for the job of England manager.
fields.body:
The salary is £1m a year, you choose your own staff and even in a good year - an increasingly rare event - you work just 16 weeks out of 52. In the real world there would be no shortage of candidates for the job of England manager.

English football, however, does not count as the real world at present and yesterday, as the Football Association began the task of finding a replacement for Kevin Keegan, who quit after England's shambolic 1-0 defeat by Germany, the leading candidates lined up to rule themselves out.

Speculation about such a high profile post always moves quickly but this was record-breaking; by the end of the day six potential applicants had declared themselves unavailable, leaving just Terry Venables, who walked out on the job in 1996, and Howard Wilkinson, who takes charge of the side in Finland tomorrow, with their CVs in the in-tray.

First to offer a firm "non" was Aimé Jacquet, manager of the side that captured the World Cup in 1998. "At the French federation I lead and I am pursuing passionate work with the coaches. That is fully sufficient for me," he said.

First of the English candidates to pull out was Peter Taylor of Leicester, a former coach of England's under-21s.

"To be mentioned is an honour and very very nice, but it is not for me at the moment," he said, perhaps recalling the chorus of abuse that greeted Keegan as he departed Wembley on Saturday.

It is a measure of the FA's desparation that Taylor, whose top-flight career amounts to eight games in which time he has taken Leicester to the top of the Premiership, should be a leading candidate.

Next to withdraw were Peter Reid of Sunderland and Bryan Robson of Middlesbrough, stalwarts as players but not renowned for tactical genius; both have seen their clubs from the Premiership. Another former England manager, Sir Bobby Robson of Newcastle, was barred from leaving his post by his chairman and another Frenchman, Gerard Houlier of Liverpool, declined to put his name forward.

One man remains non-committal, Arsène Wenger of Arsenal. An anglophile with an outstanding record in the Premiership, he would be a popular and progressive choice. But the Arsenal chairman, Peter Hill Wood, feels the Frenchman lacks one essential quality: "He is not crazy," he said.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Wilko's new arrivals slink through the back door

fields.headline: Wilko's new arrivals slink through the back door
fields.standfirst:
Keown leads depleted England

Litmanen test could leave England blue
fields.trailText: David Beckham did not travel here with England yesterday, a shame because he and Posh would have loved the completely unnecessary celebrity subterfuge arranged by security to throw non-existent fans off the scent.
fields.body:
David Beckham did not travel here with England yesterday, a shame because he and Posh would have loved the completely unnecessary celebrity subterfuge arranged by security to throw non-existent fans off the scent.

The team's Britannia Airways flight, which did not waft them here from paradise but, given Saturday's dreadful display against Germany, the more fittingly mundane Luton Airport, did not officially exist according to the arrival screens. And no one at Vantaa airport would confirm that a plane load of footballers were due to arrive for tomorrow's match.

The England plane was, in fact, diverted some two miles from the main international arrivals area to the business centre, usually reserved for private planes, and so much mystery surrounded the arrival of BLX 806A under the cover of darkness that for one exciting moment, as the plane door opened, one half expected Slobodan Milosevic to walk down the steps.

Sadly the first recognisable figure was Gareth Southgate, the man whose selection against Germany proved to be the beginning of the end for the coach Kevin Keegan. He looked as downcast as the squad members who scurried behind him and into a coach which carried the wholly inappropriate logo of "Sunny Buses".

English teams used to arrive in places such as this like conquering heroes, happy to sign autographs and confident of rattling up a huge win. This time, as they left under police escort, only the blankets over their heads were missing.

England would have touched down captain-less if the caretaker coach Howard Wilkinson had not informed Martin Keown in mid-flight that he would inherit the armband from his missing club-mate, Tony Adams.

They were also Paul Ince-less, which might normally have been a cause for celebration but for the fact that England are so short of players capable of playing a holding role in midfield.

His decision to stay at home with his heavily pregnant wife, who is due to be induced today, at first appeared to be the triumph of a caring husband over a sometimes reckless footballer. But it emerged that he made his choice only after ascertaining whether he had a definite starting place, Wilkinson admitting: "I was faced with an either or choice."

It may signal the end of Ince's international career and if so it would be a symbolic finish. He flew out to make his England debut under Graham Taylor in 1992 only after being promised that he would be in the side to face Spain.

Now he has refused to join the cause, which brings his career full circle while the rest of the squad just seem to be going around in them. Wilkinson said: "I have to stress that the agreement with Ince was an amicable one", though it did not say much for the morale in a squad that can rarely have been lower.

webTitle: Should England opt for a foreign manager?

fields.headline: Should England opt for a foreign manager?
fields.standfirst: Jacquet off as FA's shortlist thins out
fields.trailText: Rachel Anderson
fields.body:
Rachel Anderson

Football agent

Having an English manager would probably help on the patriotism stakes. I don't think a German could have the same effect on the players. That's my only reservation.

Choice: Peter Taylor, he's ideal

David Elleray

Premiership referee

I want the FA to appoint somebody and get the best out of the players. I wouldn't have any objections to that person being foreign; nationality does not come into it.

Choice: No one springs to mind

Lord Hattersley

Lifelong Sheffield Wednesday fan

I'd keep it in England because of the damage it would do the morale of our supporters and players if we said no one here was up to it. We need a tough, ideally northern, Englishman.

Choice: Step forward Bobby Robson

Yvonne Fletcher

LutonTown director

I see absolutely no reason why not if that is the best person for the job. Maybe if we had someone who wasn't English it would cut down on the xenophobia of some of the supporters

Choice: Arsène Wenger

John McCririck

TV racing expert and Newcastle fan

We cannot have all that xenophobic nonsense about not having a foreigner. That is from the Dark Ages.

Choice: Sir Alex Ferguson or Bobby Robson (and allow them to carry on with their club management as well)

Jonathan Pearce

Radio and TV commentator

People like Arsène Wenger and Gérard Houllier have brought something special into our game. But you would have to have someone English working alongside them

Choice: Terry Venables

Walter Winterbottom

England manager 1946-62

The problem is there is a shortage of English managers to do the job. So in that respect there is nothing wrong with having a foreign coach.But I'd prefer to see an English manager in charge.

Choice: At 87, I'm ruling myself out

Bryan Robson

Middlesbrough manager and former England captain

They should not appoint a foreigner. Terry Venables should never have been allowed to leave. If the FA have any sense they will put him in charge.

Choice: Terry Venables

Paul Parker

Former England international

The FA must realise that we should be building towards 2006 now rather than 2002. We should look at it as a development, rather than ridiculously thinking we are still a major force

Choice: Peter Taylor

The candidates

Terry Venables 5-2 fav

Howard Wilkinson 6-1

Ruled out

Aimé Jacquet 7-1

Peter Reid 10-1

Peter Taylor 12-1

Gérard Houllier 25-1

Bobby Robson 16-1

Bryan Robson 10-1

Walter Winterbottom 100-1

Non-committal

Arsène Wenger 7-1

Fabio Capello 16-1

Marcelo Lippi 20-1

Martin O'Neill 16-1

webTitle: Litmanen test could leave England blue

fields.headline: Litmanen test could leave England blue
fields.standfirst:
Finland's most famous player has a knack of spoiling other people's parties
Keown leads depleted England
fields.trailText: Chris Taylor profiles Jari Litmanen, Finland's most famous player, who, although currently languishing in the Barcelona reserves, is emminently capable of turning a game.
fields.body:
David Beckham may be on the cover of most of the magazines at your local newsagent, Tony Adams may be TV's most ubiquitous deodorant salesman, but for real sporting-icon status Jari Litmanen knocks the pair of them into a cocked hat. For Finland's playmaker enjoys the rare distinction of being immortalised on a postage stamp. Having your back licked by a million Finns may not be everyone's idea of celebrity but in a country where football lags a long way behind winter sports and motor racing in popularity it is about as good as it gets.

The fact that Finland's most famous footballing son is currently languishing in Barcelona's reserves will not fool England's caretaker manager Howard Wilkinson into thinking it will be an easy ride in Helsinki tomorrow night. For a start, unlike Beckham and Adams, Litmanen will actually be playing.

Wilkinson will naturally be hoping to start the post-Keegan era with a good result - which might under the circumstances be a draw - but Litmanen knows all about raining on other people's parades. When Wales wanted to open Cardiff's Millennium stadium in style last March they left nothing to chance. Ryan Giggs was persuaded to play his first international friendly in living memory and as opponents the Welsh FA picked Finland, one of the few teams they could reasonably entertain hopes of beating. But they reckoned without Litmanen, who popped up in the penalty area after 21 minutes, as he so often does, to sidefoot the first goal of Finland's 2-1 victory.

Scoring goals is Litmanen's stock-in-trade. And setting them up. And, in fact, everything else you could ask for in an attacking midfielder. In the great Ajax side of the 90s he scored 91 goals in 159 league games and his record in the European Cup is an equally impressive 18 in 32.

Like Giggs, who also scored in that match, Litmanen has long had to shoulder the burden of being by far the best player in an otherwise undistinguished international side. But after 11 years in the Finnish squad he feels that the time is ripe for the team to raise their station as their Scandinavian neighbours Sweden, Denmark and Norway have done in recent years. "This is the best team we have had in our history," he says.

Although only 29, Litmanen is such a veteran that he played against Graham Taylor's England eight years ago in a friendly and was brought down for the penalty that brought Finland's goal in a 2-1 defeat. The only England survivor from that game, Martin Keown, may again find himself chasing Finland's No10, who will claim one of the three forward positions in a 4-3-3.

Both his father and mother played football and Litmanen followed in dad's footsteps into his local team Reipas Lahti after turning his back on ice hockey. A move to HJK Helsinki was followed by a brief stint at MyPa before Ajax came in with a £66,000 bid, a Finnish record at the time.

He arrived at Ajax in 1992 and for his first season largely had to bide his time as Dennis Bergkamp monopolised the No10 shirt. But after Bergkamp's departure for Internazionale he quickly became a favourite with the Amsterdam crowd, who to this day mourn his departure to Spain last year.

Finland's best player he may be but this season he cannot get a kick at club level. He had followed Louis van Gaal to Barcelona last summer as part of the Dutchman's effort to recreate his Ajax team in Catalonia. Litmanen was one of six members of Ajax's 1995 European Cup-winning side - the other five were all Dutch - to join Barca under Van Gaal. Unfortunately, with Van Gaal's departure from the Camp Nou this summer, having seven years at Ajax on your cv is not the recommendation it once was, as Winston Bogarde has already found. The new coach, Llorenc Serra Ferrer, has shunted Litmanen on to the transfer list. He might be forgiven for asking, Ali G-style, "Is it because I is Dutch?"

Litmanen has vowed to stick it out at Barcelona but it is unthinkable that a player of his quality should sit out the remaining two seasons on his contract in the reserves. He has been linked with a number of clubs, including Bayer Leverkusen, managed by Germany's troubled coach-presumptive Christoph Daum, and Liverpool, the club he followed as a boy and who are captained by his international team-mate Sami Hyypia.

Litmanen got Finland's World Cup campaign off to a solid start with the first goal in their 2-1 win over Albania. And in a group where the Finns think all teams will drop points, hopes will be high that he can lead them to victory and a six-point cushion over England.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Keown leads depleted England

fields.headline: Keown leads depleted England
fields.standfirst: Litmanen test could leave England blue
fields.trailText: Martin Keown was proclaimed the third England captain in four games last night as Howard Wilkinson, resuming his role as caretaker-coach following the resignation of Kevin Keegan, strove to preserve an element of rationale following Saturday's 1-0 defeat by Germany at Wembley in the nation's opening World Cup qualifier.
fields.body:
Martin Keown was proclaimed the third England captain in four games last night as Howard Wilkinson, resuming his role as caretaker-coach following the resignation of Kevin Keegan, strove to preserve an element of rationale following Saturday's 1-0 defeat by Germany at Wembley in the nation's opening World Cup qualifier.

Keown gets the armband against Finland here tomorrow night because Tony Adams, England's best player against the Germans and fit on Sunday night, broke down in training yesterday with a recurrence of a back injury which, according to Wilkinson, "is going to be the bane of his life".

Keown made the usual right noises about being proud to lead his country and felt that if everybody pulled together England would get the right result. Since they have won here on six of their previous seven visits there is little doubt about what that result should be.

In the immediate aftermath of Keegan's resignation Adam Crozier, the Football Association's chief executive, declared it was an exciting time to be an England coach. An odd remark, the logic of which depends on what one means by exciting.

Maybe Crozier meant to say eventful. For instance, when Crazy Horse closed in for the kill, General Armstrong Custer would have doubted that it was an exciting moment to be commanding the Seventh Cavalry, but the old warhorse could not have denied that the day was turning out to be eventful.

Events are already catching up with up Wilkinson for whom, like Custer, his latest caretakership of the England team is likely to be brief and to the point. In fact with players dropping out all around him Wilkinson may end up being grateful for a point in the Olympic Stadium tomorrow.

The loss of Adams has further reduced England's defensive options despite Wilkinson's decision to call up Manchester United's Wes Brown from the Under-21s as cover. Already without Sol Campbell, he would appear to have no other choice but to play Gareth Southgate alongside Keown at centre-back.

Graeme Le Saux was another withdrawal yesterday, having failed to recover from the calf injury which eventually saw him substituted on Saturday. Gareth Barry, who replaced him for the last 13 minutes, looks like keeping the position on the left of the defence and England could profit from the opportunity Keegan gave the 19-year-old Aston Villa defender in Paris last month.

Barry was one of the most impressive performers as England held the world and European champions to 1-1. In the unlikely event of Wilkinson switching to a back three tomorrow night he could still stay in the side since left centre-back is his normal position for Villa.

Paul Ince has also missed the trip, though not through injury. After Wilkinson told him he would not be actively involved here Ince was allowed to return home to be with his wife, who is about to have a baby.

With David Beckham and Steven Gerrard dropping out on Sunday, Wilkinson's choice in midfield is looking even thinner than his alternatives at the back. Paul Scholes, who is carrying a foot injury, did not train yesterday but the England coach is hoping he will recover in time. Assuming Scholes is fit, Wilkinson could pair him in central midfield with Dennis Wise or Ray Parlour and use Kieron Dyer and Nick Barmby in the wide positions.

Wilkinson was impressed by the difference Dyer made on Saturday when he replaced the struggling Gary Neville after half-time as Keegan changed to a five-man midfield. Whether or not Wilkinson decides to play a 3-5-2 formation will depend on who he considers are the best players available to him. Not that any system will work if a team gives a passable imitation of zombies, as England did in the first half against Germany.

The caretaker coach's recall of Teddy Sheringham suggests that Wilkinson is thinking of using the 34-year-old to support his Manchester United colleague, Andy Cole, in the hope that the pair can continue their successful, if silent, partnership.

That would mean leaving out Michael Owen, whose omission from the starting line-up against France brought Keegan much grief from the media, especially when Owen scored England's late equaliser after coming off the bench for the last 12 minutes.

Last night it was put to Wilkinson that the situation under Keegan had become shambolic.

"Maybe you're right," Wilkinson replied, briefly dropping his guard. All he can do now is restore order out of chaos. Three points tomorrow would be a start.

England (probable 4-4-2)
Seaman; G Neville, Keown, Southgate, Barry; Dyer, Wise or Parlour, Scholes, Barmby; Sheringham, Cole.

Graeme Le Saux was another withdrawal yesterday, having failed to recover from the calf injury which eventually saw him substituted on Saturday. Gareth Barry, who replaced him for the last 13 minutes, looks like keeping the position on the left of the defence and England could profit from the opportunity Keegan gave the 19-year-old Aston Villa defender in Paris last month. Barry was one of the most impressive performers as England held the world and European champions to 1-1. In the unlikely event of Wilkinson switching to a back three tomorrow night he could still stay in the side since left centre-back is his normal position for Villa. Paul Ince has also missed the trip, though not through injury. After Wilkinson told him he would not be actively involved here Ince was allowed to return home to be with his wife, who is about to have a baby. With David Beckham and Steven Gerrard dropping out on Sunday, Wilkinson's choice in midfield is looking even thinner than his alternatives at the back. Paul Scholes, who is carrying a foot injury, did not train yesterday but the England coach is hoping he will recover in time. Assuming Scholes is fit, Wilkinson could pair him in central midfield with Dennis Wise or Ray Parlour and use Kieron Dyer and Nick Barmby in the wide positions. Wilkinson was impressed by the difference Dyer made on Saturday when he replaced the struggling Gary Neville after half-time as Keegan changed to a five-man midfield. Whether or not Wilkinson decides to play a 3-5-2 formation will depend on who he considers are the best players available to him. Not that any system will work if a team gives a passable imitation of zombies, as England did in the first half against Germany. The caretaker coach's recall of Teddy Sheringham suggests that Wilkinson is thinking of using the 34-year-old to support his Manchester United colleague, Andy Cole, in the hope that the pair can continue their successful, if silent, partnership. That would mean leaving out Michael Owen, whose omission from the starting line-up against France brought Keegan much grief from the media, especially when Owen scored England's late equaliser after coming off the bench for the last 12 minutes. Last night it was put to Wilkinson that the situation under Keegan had become shambolic. "Maybe you're right," Wilkinson replied, briefly dropping his guard. All he can do now is restore order out of chaos. Three points tomorrow would be a start. webTitle: FA's managerial shortlist thins out

fields.headline: Jacquet off as FA's shortlist thins out
fields.standfirst: Should England opt for a foreign manager?
fields.trailText: Aimé Jacquet, Peter Taylor, Peter Reid, Bryan Robson and Bobby Robson were yesterday ruled out of contention for the England job.
fields.body:
The already skinny list of candidates to succeed Kevin Keegan was pruned by five yesterday when Aimé Jacquet, Peter Taylor, Peter Reid, Bryan Robson and Bobby Robson were ruled out of contention for the England job.

And Arsenal's chairman Peter Hill-Wood invited the Football Association to approach Arsène Wenger but said: "I can tell them he wouldn't say yes to the job".

The bookmakers immediately slashed the odds on their favourite Terry Venables to 2-1, even though the former England coach has several detractors at the Football Association.

Jacquet, who won the 1998 World Cup with France, is now the national technical director for the French football federation. But he said: "I have no intention to return to the playing field in high-level soccer in England or elsewhere."

Bryan Robson, the Middlesbrough manager, said: "My name is not in the hat. If I get offered or would like the job of England manager I want to have good experience behind me as a league manager and, hopefully, success."

Taylor, the former England Under-21 coach, also declined. "It is not for me at the moment. One day I would love to manage England but I would have to have earned it. I have only been at Leicester four months and this is too early for me."

Sunderland's chairman Bob Murray said of Reid: "Peter is an established and respected Premiership manager and only wants to continue to devote his future to Sunderland."

Freddy Shepherd, the Newcastle chairman, similarly insisted Bobby Robson was staying. "We could not contemplate his release, neither in the short nor long term."

Aston Villa's John Gregory has not really done enough to warrant consideration, the same goes for David O'Leary at Leeds, and Martin O'Neill has only just moved to his beloved Celtic. Meanwhile Sir Alex Ferguson has pledged himself to Manchester United for another full season before retiring.

The leading foreign candidate is the Roma coach Fabio Capello, who turned Milan into a major power in the 90s and is the FA technical director Howard Wilkinson's choice. Another Italian being touted is the former Internazionale coach Marcello Lippi, but he does not speak English.

More plausible is the Rangers manager Dick Advocaat. He lifted the Dutch title with PSV, has won five trophies in 2 years at Ibrox, has managed Holland and has only a year left on his current contract.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Harry Pearson on the England's managerial crisis

fields.headline: Madness in the methods of a modern manager
fields.trailText: The Dressingroomistas are on the back foot, having lost one of their own. For now, the England game belongs to the Structuralists, and their guru Howard Wilkinson.
fields.body:
When it comes to the stewardship of their national football team, Argentines are said to fall into one of two camps. There are those that want a man who embraces the philosophy of the gaunt, lank-haired, chain-smoking Cesar Luis Menotti, the mastermind of Argentina's victory in the 1978 World Cup, and those who believe the leader must be somebody like Carlos Bilardo, the belligerent arm-waver with the toucanesque profile who repeated the feat in Mexico eight years later.

There are complicated socio-economic and political theories about how these divergent schools of thought came to surround the pair and what they both represent, but basically it is a battle between romance and pragmatism. If Menotti looks like the sort of careworn boulevardier you might stumble across singing Jacques Brel songs in a Hamburg cabaret, Bilardo is the merchant sailor who would jump on stage, knock him down and do a tap dance on his windpipe.

In the wake of Kevin Keegan's resignation it is clear that England, like Argentina, now has a couple of radically opposed football philosophies. In Buenos Aires the opposition groups converged on two men, in London they have rallied round the edifices they regard as the core of future success.

On the right side were those individualists who believe in the supreme importance of the spirit, motivation, mood and Max Wall impressions of The Dressing Room, and on the left those who are convinced success can only be found within the altogether less nebulous and more modern confines of The Structure, a vast homogenous tactical pyramid that should allow players to move from one place to the next without noticing they are anywhere different (a role currently carried out by the TGI Friday's chain).

The Dressingroomistas were clearly on the back foot on Saturday night. Keegan, fittingly elected by the people in a psychic plebiscite carried out by the People, was one of their own. And now he had gone, apparently admitting that, in the modern game, being able to organise a sweepstake on how many times Andy Cole will use the phrase "As I say" in a TV interview is no substitute for being able to organise a midfield.

The apparent betrayal left those who believe in the power of The Dressing Room reeling. A stunned Lawrie McMenemy spoke for many of his creed when with a mixture of incredulity, sadness and defiance he commented: "The dressing room, which no matter what anyone says is the most important part of it, was welded together". (Outsiders may have thought the former Southampton supremo was speaking figuratively at this point. Inspection of the home dressing room at Wembley indicated otherwise. In a bid to inspire some devil-may-care spirit in his squad the England boss had indeed welded all the doors shut, ensuring that the players had to jump in and out through the windows, just like those latter-day Robin Hoods, Bo and Luke Duke, getting into their automobile General Lee in the popular 70s TV show The Dukes of Hazzard).

Another man who must have been hurt by Keegan's sudden departure was the FA chief executive Adam Crozier. The plausible Scot is a confirmed Structuralist but saw the need to broker a compromise. Through Keegan he was hoping that the mystic philosophy of The Dressing Room could somehow be shoehorned into The Structure.

For a while at least the Dressingroomistas will have to retreat to their tiled and steamy fastnesses, lick their wounds and practise their tea-cup throwing. The field now belongs to the FA technical director Howard Wilkinson, who has long been England's leading Structuralist.

Wilkinson does not believe in personalities (he ditched his own years ago). He's a grafter too. Something as massive as The Structure doesn't just build itself and the former Leeds boss has been hammering away behind the scenes like Harrison Ford in the barn-raising scene in Witness.

All at the FA who have seen the result have pronounced it impressive. Indeed Crozier has said that The Structure is so marvellous that England can now realistically aim to win the World Cup in 2006.

The only problem is that, if the plans for the new Wembley are anything to go on, the FA's judgment of what represents an impressive structure may actually be a stunning combination of a dog's breakfast and a pig's ear.

webTitle: Political options for a burning issue

fields.headline: Political options for a burning issue
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Zero tolerance
fields.body:
Zero tolerance

Rigorously enforce the 1971 Misuse of Drugs Act with £100 fixed penalty fine for first offence for possession for personal use but straight to court for second offence, with penalty rising to prison sentence of up to 7 years for those who persistently flout the law. Abandon use of informal police warnings or cautions. Criminal record for possession.Testing positive for cannabis when under arrest can in certain parts of the US lead to compulsory detention and treatment courses.

Who backs it? Ann Widdecombe, Norman Tebbit and former Home Office minister David Maclean; Paul and Janet Betts.

Status quo

Prosecution for possession left to police discretion, with emphasis on statutory cautions to divert offenders from illicit drug use. Police have power of arrest and, mainly as a result of stop and search, arrested 77,000 people for cannabis possession in 1997. Half were fined and half formally cautioned; both attract a criminal record. Some 4,852 people were jailed for cannabis possession in 1997 but most faced other charges, and average sentence was four months.

Who backs it? Tony Blair, Jack Straw; Metropolitan police commissioner Sir John Stevens; drugs tsar Keith Hellawell.

Government has licensed trials to establish if cannabis has therapeutic benefits for people with multiple sclerosis. Doctors were able to prescribe tincture of cannabis for 100 years until it was banned in 1973. If it is licensed for medical use the drug will probably be stripped of its active recreational ingredient. Ministers say they will support conclusion reached from the trials.

Who backs it? House of Lords select committee on science and technology and British Medical Association.

Decriminalisation

Possession remains an offence but has lowest priority for police and prosecuting authorities. The cannabis is seized. Penalty becomes an informal warning or fixed penalty fine but no criminal record. Imprisonment not an option. This option can take many forms. In Holland there is an official written policy that simple possession is not prosecuted.

Who backs it? The Daily Telegraph (for a trial period); Charles Kennedy, Liberal Democrat leader; the Police Foundation inquiry, including two chief constables; Cleveland police authority; John Grieve, former head of Met's anti-terrorist branch.

Legalisation

The underground economy arising from illegal drug use is the main source of drug-related crime. If you put an end to drugs black market, the state can control supply of hard and soft drugs. Could lead to chemists selling Skunk or Colombian Gold, and a boom in self-help books such as How to Kick the Dope Habit and 101 Ways to Enjoy Cannabis Without Smoking.

Who backs it? Labour MPs Paul Flynn, Tony Banks and Brian Iddon; Francis Wilkinson, former chief constable of Gwent; Tory MP Alan Duncan; Ringo Starr, Harry Belafonte and Alan McGee, record mogul.

webTitle: Divided city is united by the common cause of legalisation

fields.headline: Divided city is united by the common cause of legalisation
fields.standfirst:
At college or on the estates, Oxford has no truck with Widdecombe's views
Special report: drugs in Britain
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: At college or on the estates, Oxford has no truck with Widdecombe's views.
fields.body:
It is all very well for the privileged, articulate middle classes who smoked dope at university to call for the decriminalisation of cannabis while ignoring the impact drugs have on deprived, inner-city estates. Or at least that is what Ann Widdecombe claimed at the weekend as she attempted to refine her argument in favour of spot fines for users.

However, a a trip to Oxford to sample attitudes at her alma mater and on one of Britain's most notorious council estates might reveal to her that the inhabitants of those two very different worlds share the same view: cannabis is not the problem she thinks it is.

From the outside, little about the austere brick quadrangle at Lady Margaret Hall college, Oxford, has changed since Ms Widdecombe spent seven clear-headed years studying at the college in the late 1960s and early 1970s for a BA in politics, philosophy and economics and then for an MA.

Inside the airy halls of residence, however, attitudes towards illegal drugs have moved on. It is fair to assume that if there are future shadow home secretaries currently studying at Miss Widdecombe's alma mater, they are unlikely to propose that cannabis users be further criminalised. Liberalisation, not criminalisation, will be the rallying call from a future conference platform.

Joanne Iremonger, 18, in the first year of a modern languages degree at the college, thinks cannabis should be legalised although she is not a great fan of it herself. "A zero tolerance attitude will just exacerbate existing drug problems," she said. "It just focuses attention on the drug, which I think makes younger teenagers more likely to try it. When there is a forbidden fruit it is more appealing."

Ms Iremonger's attitude is partly informed by her parents adopting a liberal approach. "My mother insisted that if I was going to smoke cannabis, I did it in the house, rather than going out, and I did. Once I had smoked it I felt a bit giggly, a bit hungry, and then I thought: Is that it? It was not a big deal."

Nick Kitchen, who like Miss Widdecombe is a PPE student but unlike her has smoked pot, was celebrating his 20th birthday yesterday. He condemned the policy. "It is ridiculous. I can see that a spot fine, like a parking ticket, might have supporters, but with a parking fine you don't get a criminal record. My parents' attitude is that they don't see it as a great damager. "

'Tell the truth'

Of Rachel, Hannah and Sophie, three trainee teachers at the college, two favoured legalisation, one decriminalisation. None thought their parents would back Miss Widdecombe's fines. "You can't tell people what to do with their own bodies, even kids. All you can do is tell them the truth about the consequences of their actions," said one.

It would be wrong to suggest that the cannabis debate rages at Lady Margaret Hall. All undergraduates are warned that the college does not lie outside the law and that they can be expelled for smoking dope. (The reality, say students, is that moderate use is tolerated by the authorities.)

It is not that students do not care about the issue, rather that cannabis use is so widespread generally as to be unremarkable."It is a farcical debate being carried out among the Daily Mail-reading classes," said one.

At the weekend Miss Widdecombe said: "It is all very well talking about what educated, articulate people did at university, but I'm talking about housing estates where drugs ruin people's lives."

On one such estate, the notorious Blackbird Leys, the scars of poverty and social exclusion are obvious, and the tranquil quad of Lady Margarets seems more than five miles away. But the kids hanging out on Blackbird Leys Road seem in little need of advice.

Bobby Ahmed, 21, and Delroy Thomas, 20, both unemployed, enjoy a smoke. "For me it's a mind soother," said Delroy. Pot helps them to beat the boredom of long days looking for work. The real scourges of the estate, they say, are crack cocaine and heroin.

"Pot doesn't make you mug people like the crackheads and brownheads [heroin users]," said Mr Thomas. "You see the addicts ducking past here with their hoods and caps pulled down real low. We call them 'cats' because they are always over fences and ducking round cars. The cats would rob their grannies for a fix," said Mr Ahmed.

"Police should be nicking them, not puff dealers. We know someone, he works five days a week, then sells a bit of gear to pay for the electric and cover the cost of a smoke - he got arrested, while the cats are looking forward to Christmas and easy pickings from people's houses. It's crazy."

webTitle: Dounreay 'could be off limits for 300 years'

fields.headline: Dounreay 'could be off limits for 300 years'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Britain's nuclear industry
fields.trailText: Some parts of the Dounreay nuclear site will have to remain off limits for up to 300 years, the UK Atomic Energy Authority said yesterday, amid reports from environmentalists that the plant has been "leaking like a sieve".
fields.body:
Some parts of the Dounreay nuclear site will have to remain off limits for up to 300 years, the UK Atomic Energy Authority said yesterday, amid reports from environmentalists that the plant has been "leaking like a sieve".

But the UK Atomic Energy Authority says all the major radiological hazards would be removed within 25 years, as details were unveiled yesterday of the 60-year, £4bn plan to decommission the Caithness reprocessing plant. More than 2,000 jobs will be guaranteed over the next 20 years by the clean-up. Environmentalists welcomed yesterday's announcement but said the costs involved could be nearer £10bn. And they said pressure must be kept up to have the facility made as safe as possible.

There have been a number of safety scares at the plant since it was built in 1945.

This year the UKAEA was fined a total of £101,000 for safety breaches at the plant after pleading guilty to three charges of contaminating workers with excessive doses of radiation in 1995.

It also admitted a separate charge relating to safety when a contractor accidentally dug through a main power cable, knocking out the electricity supply.

In 1998, an audit by the health and safety executive made 143 recommendations for improvements.

Most recently, a study that was not made public for six years found that levels of plutonium in the homes of Dounreay workers were significantly higher than in other homes in the areas.

And since 1984 hundreds of radioactive particles have been found near the facility.

In 1998 Donald Dewar, then Scottish secretary, announced the plant would close in 2004.

At a press conference in Inverness yesterday, Dounreay director Peter Welsh said the decommissioning plan was intended to return the site to its pre-nuclear condition. Mr Welsh said that the 50- to 60-year plan for the programme was twice as fast as had been previously envisaged.

The first stage will involve construction of up to 20 new facilities at the site for waste treatment and processing of nuclear materials, as well as the decommissioning of existing redundant facilities such as the prototype fast reactor. By the end of the second stage, some 25 years hence, all major radiological hazards should have been removed.

webTitle: BBC names 'Omagh bombers'

fields.headline: BBC names 'Omagh bombers'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of the BBC
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The BBC last night beat off an 11th hour legal attempt to block a programme naming four men in connection with the Omagh bombing which killed 29 people.
fields.body:
The BBC last night beat off an 11th hour legal attempt to block a programme naming four men in connection with the Omagh bombing which killed 29 people.

The demand by the Northern Ireland human rights commission for the Panorama programme to be injuncted was thrown out by the high court in Belfast, Mr Justice Kerr finding in the corporation's favour just 90 minutes ahead of transmission to end a dramatic day of legal argument.

Mr Justice Kerr said: "There is no reason to suppose that criminal proceedings against any of those taking part in the programme will be stayed."

He added that the relevant sections of the Human Rights Act, which the commission argued meant the court should err on the side of the person, showed that the "balance fell firmly in favour of the broadcaster".

The commission had argued that the programme's naming of suspects could prejudice any criminal trial, and thus breach the human rights of the bomb's victims and any defendants.

On Friday the high court in Belfast rejected another application from Lawrence Rush, who lost his wife in the worst attack of the Troubles.

Mr Rush had asked the attorney general to take up the case but yesterday Lord Williams refused because the law on contempt of court applies only once people are charged with a crime, and no one has been charged with the bombing.

In court Karen Quinliven, for the commission, argued that identification could damage police investigations and said there were implications "for the personal safety and right to life" of those named. She also argued the right of all people to be protected from "trial by media".

She produced a letter from the RUC chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, to the director general of the BBC. In it Sir Ronnie wrote that he would wish to ensure no material would be used which "would or might be likely to have an adverse affect on future prosecutions", Ms Quinliven said.

The BBC argued that since those named lived in the Irish Republic, they were beyond the jurisdiction of the court and the commission.

Ben Stephens QC, representing the corporation, said: "There is no chance of an upset to fair trial. The human rights commission has taken on itself to protect individuals outside its jurisdiction."

Panorama said that four men, all from the republic, were tied to the bombing by records from mobile phones they either used or supplied.

The records from the day of the bombing on August 15 1998 place those using the phones in the vicinity of the scene where the device exploded and in a timescale consistent with the explosion.

Panorama says that through the records the four can be tracked on their way to Omagh from the republic, staying in the town for 20 minutes and then leaving in the direction of the Irish border.

The BBC claimed eyewitnesses had given evidence to the police as to who was using the mobile phones, but were too frightened to testify in court. When challenged by the BBC, all four people named refused to explain their movements on the day.

On legal advice, the Guardian has decided not to name the four identified by the BBC.

The programme's reporter, John Ware, said the legal precedent that would have been set if the application had succeeded would have amounted to a "gagger's charter". Mr Ware said: "It would mean you can't publish evidence of criminal behaviour for fear of prejudicing any trials. It would mean that a programme identifying alleged corrupt police officers couldn't run, as that would jeopardise a fair trial."

After the verdict, a BBC spokesman said: "Many of the victims' relatives clearly wanted the programme to be broadcast including those who took part in the programme. They and many others hope that the transmission of this programme will help bring to justice those responsible for the Omagh atrocity."

Brice Dixon, head of the commission, said: "We're concerned that if no successful prosecution ensues because of the risk of an unfair trial, the victims are left without justice and that breaches their human rights."

The commission was set up under the Good Friday agreement and charged with defending human rights in the province.

webTitle: Dutch point to benefits of 'coffee shop' experiment

fields.headline: Dutch point to benefits of 'coffee shop' experiment
fields.standfirst:
Special report: drugs in Britain

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: For cannabis law reformers the proof that the 20-year-old Dutch "coffee shop" experiment has worked lies in the fact that fewer schoolchildren now experiment with marijuana in the Netherlands than in Britain.
fields.body:
For cannabis law reformers the proof that the 20-year-old Dutch "coffee shop" experiment has worked lies in the fact that fewer schoolchildren now experiment with marijuana in the Netherlands than in Britain.

They also point out that Holland now has the lowest drug-related death rate in Europe and that the number of problem heroin and other addicts has remained stable for years. The average age of a heroin addict in Amsterdam is now 36, some 12 years older than the average for the growing number of hard-drug abusers in Britain.

But its critics, including some in Holland, as well as the British and American governments, say that this "semi-legal" policy of toleration has turned the country into a major producer and exporter of amphetamines and ecstasy, and into an important transit point for drugs entering Europe.

The Americans complained last year that Dutch ecstasy exports had reached epidemic proportions, and not so long ago the French accused the Dutch of running a "narco-state" benefiting from drug tourism.

In fact all drugs are still illegal in the Netherlands. The 1976 Dutch Opium Act, however, distinguishes between hard drugs, such as heroin and cocaine, which have unacceptable risks, and soft drugs such as herbal cannabis and cannabis resin.

The intention of the law is to separate the hard and soft drug markets and is based on the belief that prosecuting and punishing cannabis smokers causes more harm than the drug itself.

For the Dutch the question of illegal drugs is more of a public health issue than a law and order one. Indeed their official health advice says the biggest danger from smoking dope comes from the tobacco.

The official advice is: "You can smoke cannabis off and on, just for fun. You can smoke every day, but you will permanently lose touch with reality. It is up to you."

The Dutch also say that it is mixing with drug dealers rather than the cannabis itself that leads young people to experiment with harder drugs.

So since 1980 the sale of a small quantity - 5 grams now; it used to be 30 but there was a backlash - of cannabis in "coffee shops" has been tolerated under strict conditions. Hard drugs are banned and sales to children are not allowed. Alcohol is not to be sold on the same premises.

Control of coffee shops has become stricter in the past few years, with the closure of 300 of the 1,500 shops for breaches of the guidelines or proving an annoyance to local residents.

Although technically cannabis remains illegal, the Dutch have a formal written policy of not prosecuting people found in possession of small amounts, on the grounds of "expediency in the public interest".

Critics of the Dutch say the "coffee shops" get their supplies illegally from major drug dealers, whether growers or importers. The Dutch say they can live with this fundamental contradiction as the benefits outweigh the disadvantages.

Perhaps the most compelling evidence pointing to the success of their experiment remains the fact that young people are far less likely to experiment with drugs in Holland than they are in Britain.

By removing the perceived glamour of illegality, they seemed to have removed one of the main motivations for experimenting with soft drugs.

The latest figures show that in 1998 only 27% of Dutch teenagers had tried cannabis, compared with 40% of British youngsters.

webTitle: Comment: Blair is moved by foreign misery but tougher at home

fields.headline: Blair is moved by foreign misery but tougher at home
fields.standfirst:
The Balkans have a lot to thank Tony Blair for, as does Sierra Leone
Special report: Kosovo
Special report: Tony Blair
fields.trailText: No Nato leader is more gratified by what has happened in Yugoslavia than Tony Blair. The deposing of Milosevic is the vindication of a strategy for which he risked more than anyone else in the west. He was the moral, if not the military, leader of what saved Kosovo, and has now led to the despatch of the tyrant. This is both stirring and alarming.
fields.body:
No Nato leader is more gratified by what has happened in Yugoslavia than Tony Blair. The deposing of Milosevic is the vindication of a strategy for which he risked more than anyone else in the west. He was the moral, if not the military, leader of what saved Kosovo, and has now led to the despatch of the tyrant. This is both stirring and alarming. Before we get to the alarm, though, we should mark an unusual moment of success for a foreign policy. The Nato intervention in Bosnia and Kosovo attracted immense and righteous attack, not least because it didn't seem to get anywhere. Now it has got somewhere, and the jibers still can't stand it.

Certain simple truths have always been self-evident, though often evaded. First, if Milosevic had carried ethnic slaughter through Kosovo without Nato's intervention, he would almost certainly still be in power in Belgrade. It's unlikely, after reclaiming Serbia's emotional heartland from the Kosovo Albanians, that he would even have been challenged. Second, if he had remained supreme, it is very probable that south-east Europe would have descended into destructive turmoil. Albania, Macedonia and Greece were the dominoes exposed to the repercussions of Milosevic's destabilising activities to the north. Those were two immensely serious contingencies. The Balkans, ablaze on Nato's southern flank, would have threatened the peace of the world.

So, as well as paving the way for a people's peaceful revolution, Nato did something for civilisation in Europe. The method was war, and it imposed indiscriminate brutalities on some innocent Serbs and Kosovo Albanians. It was in no way a pretty sight. Some terrible mistakes were made, so terrible that they have tended to overshadow the wider purpose. And this purpose was long in being achieved. Now that it has happened, we find critics straining to deny it. The truth is that however messy, however delayed, however costly, and however incalculable the outcome may be for Kosovo itself, the war was indispensable to the possibility of a genuine Balkan peace.

Mr Blair played a big part in that. Ask any American close to the scene at the time. At home, though he was shoulder to shoulder with Robin Cook, the cabinet was, as usual, not involved. In Nato, the doubts of the collective needed regularly purging by the nerveless lucidity of the British leader. In Washington, President Clinton's hesitations and domestic problems were put sternly to the question from London. On his own visit to the Balkans, Blair made clear that his impulses were as much prophetic as pragmatic. "Our promise to all of you is that you shall return in peace to the land that is yours," he told a massive audience of Kosovo Albanian refugees camped in Macedonia.

He was getting ready to commit 50,000 British fighting troops, if Serbia did not desist. Though Clinton remained in thrall to the modern US doctrine that only air wars are politically feasible, Blair today remains convinced that, if necessary, American soldiers too would have taken the field. Clinton, he thinks, was ultimately ready for it. But Milosevic spared them that, and pulled out of Kosovo. It was the beginning of the end of the dictator's invincibility, which was finally buried by the people last week.

This history is likely to reinforce a trend. Mr Blair proves to be a natural intervener. Intervention for humanitarian reasons, or to make good the incompetence of failed states that cannot protect their own people, or a mixture of both, is turning out to be a more conspicuous aspect of his moral personality than anything he does here. At home he is an indifferent spectator of the lives of the hopeless and deprived, wishing them only to brace up and work. Abroad, he sees zones of human crisis, far from Britain's interest but sometimes close to her historic legacy, where the benign hand of paternalistic friendship should expensively stretch out.

The current example is Sierra Leone, where Britain has now decided, having removed one lot of her soldiers, to send further reinforcements for those left behind. We seem to be there for the long haul, after all. There are defensible reasons for this, not least that Sierra Leone is keen on it. It's also the case that the United Nations, as Sierra Leone among other places shows, has been stretched to breaking point. The security council passes peacekeeping resolutions which its members then refuse to support with troops. Kofi Annan signalled not long ago that he favoured a more hard-headed approach, leaving an opening for the kind of selective, swift, competent, military operations Mr Blair seems to have assumed as a kind of bilateral British duty.

The secretary-general is gloomy about the traditional UN method, which has proved inadequate in Africa especially - though East Timor, against the odds, proved a more encouraging case. "The time has come," he told Jim Hoagland of the Washington Post recently, "for us to base our planning on worst-case scenarios. To be surprised by cooperation, if we get it. And to go in prepared for all eventualities, including full combat, if we don't".

The Nato intervention in Kosovo, the most blatant violation of the UN system ever authorised by Europe and the US, asserted that there were other ways to impose international standards. Its outcome, with the installation of President Kostunica, is far from final: it will, in some ways, complicate the future of Kosovo as any kind of informal Nato protectorate, for example. But the war, I think (as a supporter of it at the time), now receives its final justification. This also, however, increases the urgent need for a more systematic rulebook for intervention than can ever be supplied by the personal priorities of a well-motivated prime minister, surrounded by a cabinet that cannot raise its eyes from class sizes, waiting lists and the latest cannabis confessions.

Usefully, Paddy Ashdown has been recruited by the Foreign Policy Centre to think more deeply about the question than, once suspects, the Foreign Office has time to do. There are few better men to lead the inquiry. As foreign secretaries came and went, Sir Paddy took a more consistent and informed interest in the Balkans than anyone else in the House of Commons. He said the other day, "We need to address the new rules of conflict, in which intervention is no longer about sovereignty and state boundaries but about human suffering." What intervention? By whom? When? Especially why?

Bosnia and Kosovo are, from the viewpoint of the interveners, about more than suffering. They were and are about integrating the Balkans, above all Serbia, into a Europe that respects universal human values. The election of Kostunica was a first, triumphant step on a long road, and we can be glad the Nato system facilitated it. In the choice between internationalism that permits such moves, and isolationism that would always veto them, the destruction of Milosevic makes the right clear case. But every case is different. And piety is not enough.

webTitle: Online Classics off pitch by a fifth

fields.headline: Online Classics off pitch by a fifth
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Online Classics, the performing arts internet business, lost a fifth of its market value yesterday after announcing a heavily discounted £7.4m share placing.
fields.body:
Online Classics, the performing arts internet business, lost a fifth of its market value yesterday after announcing a heavily discounted £7.4m share placing.

Saying that new shares would be placed at 60p each sent the price of existing shares tumbling 17p to end the day at 67p.

Chief executive Christopher Hunt said the price had been set to ensure the placing's success. "We knew our share price would take a hit, but we wanted certainty. We are confident that the price will climb back in the near future."

The company, which is buying Mr Hunt's Iambic Produc tions for £5m in cash and shares, expects to announce further acquisitions and deals with other broadcasters soon.

Mr Hunt said the Aim-listed company would be looking for a full listing in "the longer term". He reported full year pre-tax losses of £986,294, against £14,738 profits the previous year.

The takeover of Iambic would take the company back into profitability and positive cashflow.

Online Classics provides performing arts content over the net. Iambic, a TV production company, will allow it to deliver content to other media.
