webTitle: Eidos takeover talks collapse

fields.headline: Eidos takeover talks collapse
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Eidos shareholders' worst fears were realised yesterday when the beleaguered computer games company confirmed that its long-running takeover talks had collapsed.
fields.body:
Eidos shareholders' worst fears were realised yesterday when the beleaguered computer games company confirmed that its long-running takeover talks had collapsed.

Infogrames of France had indicated in June that it had been prepared to make an offer for the firm best-known for its Lara Croft Tomb Raider franchise after successive profit warnings that had shattered the share price of the British firm.

Almost four months later, the directors of Eidos said it had found the level of the all-share offer unacceptable and that many of the leading City investors with shares in the company were not permitted to swap them for shares in overseas companies.

Eidos shares slumped 13% to 255p, their lowest level since March 1999.

Analysts believe that the state of the computer games market is so dire that Infogrames, Europe's largest computer games company, is under no pressure to strike a deal now but will probably return to the negotiating table in the first half of next year.

"The French don't need Eidos at the moment, they can just let the shares slip down further and then pick the company up at a bargain price," one analyst said.

Confirmation that the talks have ended came three days after Jeremy Lewis, Eidos's chief financial officer and one of its leading dealmakers, quit the firm to "pursue other interests". Yesterday's announcement compounds a miserable year on the market for Eidos. In 1999 its shares were some of the best-performing on the market, trading at a peak of around £12 that valued Eidos at more than £1bn. Based on last night's close, Eidos is now valued at £280m.

Mr McGarvey insisted that Eidos would be able to trade out of its trough thanks to a strong list of forthcoming releases and anticipation of the release of Sony's PlayStation 2 console.

"We never put this company up for sale, we were merely reacting to a bid from a third party", he said. "We will return to our strategy of managing the company's growth and our employees are committed to that."

Eidos is now expected to launch a charm offensive on the City in an effort to persuade it that the company can survive as an independent entity.

It has just released a game based on the TV show "Who wants to be a millionaire?" and in the next few months has products linked to the films Chicken Run and 102 Dalmations.

The collapse of talks will be a blow to both Eidos directors and shareholders. Chief executive Charles Cornwall is thought to have been looking for an exit from the firm to concentrate on his burgeoning media and internet interests in the US. He is expected to take a more back seat role as Mr McGarvey continues to run the company on a day-to-day basis. Institutional investors have made no secret of the fact that they would like the company to be sold.

US investment bank Morgan Stanley was brought in to kick-start the sale process but despite its efforts has been unable to find a bidder brave enough to buy the Wimbledon company.

Electronic Arts, Havas Entertainment, Microsoft and News Corporation were all rumoured as possible buyers for Eidos but declined to bid.

Analysts say that Eidos shares should recover after the introduction of PlayStation 2 and other new consoles. They say that the content Eidos owns is in demand from a growing and wealthy market.

webTitle: Crawford sets InterX on software path

fields.headline: Crawford sets InterX on software path
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Philip Crawford, one of the highest profile British software executives and the new boss of InterX, yesterday said that the former computer hardware business could be transformed into a world leading internet software firm.
fields.body:
Philip Crawford, one of the highest profile British software executives and the new boss of InterX, yesterday said that the former computer hardware business could be transformed into a world leading internet software firm.

Mr Crawford, who became chief executive of InterX in July after quitting as senior vice president of Oracle, said InterX's Bladerunner software would position the firm in front of established players such as Broadvision and Vignette in the race to sell e-commerce software to online businesses.

"We are in the right place at the right time and with the right product," Mr Crawford said of InterX's software that allows clients to learn more about their customers and more accurately target the services they deliver.

InterX is pinning its hopes on Bladerunner to such an extent that it has restructured the firm and sold its core computer hardware distribution division.

Mr Crawford believes the product is five years ahead of its rivals and by being platform independent has insured itself against the future development of any unseen devices.

InterX's business is virtually unrecognisable from the spring, when the shares traded at close to £40. The restructuring has seen the price fall sharply. Last night the shares closed down 25p at £10.62.

webTitle: Amazon chief looks to Europe's great untapped

fields.headline: Amazon chief looks to Europe's great untapped
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Europe could overtake the US as the world's most important online marketplace as it is regarded as a largely untapped audience by American firms, according to net retailer Amazon.com's founder, Jeff Bezos.
fields.body:
Europe could overtake the US as the world's most important online marketplace as it is regarded as a largely untapped audience by American firms, according to net retailer Amazon.com's founder, Jeff Bezos.

"The rate of growth for Amazon in Europe is dramatic, much more dramatic than it has been historically in the U.S ... people here believe e-commerce is not taking off, but that's not the maths that I see," he told an industry conference in Stockholm.

Amazon intends to roll out more local language websites following the recent launch of its French site, www.amazon.fr. "Long term we would like to have a local presence in every country, but that's going to take a long time," he said.

Mr Bezos defended his company's aggressive push into new markets as shares in his company continued to be hit by doubts that it would ever make money. He said that Amazon, which started life five years ago as a bookseller, intended to offer an increasingly wide range of products around the world.

Amazon's latest deal was last week's online photo service, launched in conjunction with Ofoto, a digital camera company. The deal prompted a further wave of criticism on Wall Street, where sentiment has become negative regarding the Amazon strategy of providing a "one stop" net shop.

Critics believe its strategy will lead to continuing losses. While the group's US books, music and video division made an operating profit in the second quarter, its total losses rose 40% to $115m, largely because of the cost of expansion.

Shares in Amazon were among the hardest hit of a poorly performing Nasdaq composite index yesterday. They were down almost 10% to just over $29 at noon in New York - sharply lower than an all time high of $119, reached last December.

Bill Curry, Amazon's director of media relations, said: "We plan to keep expanding both products, markets and services. We are committed to a long term vision of being the place people can find everything they want to buy online."

This view found some support in the investment community yesterday.

Tim Albright, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, the American investment bank, said that Amazon's strategy would benefit over time because it is still the market leader. Things may be bad for the leading e-commerce companies, he said, but they were even worse for their smaller rivals, who are facing closure. "If people want to buy something online there are fewer and fewer places to go now."

Mr Bezos said yesterday that Christmas would prove some of the doubters wrong.

"I think it's going to be a web Christmas," he told Reuters news agency.

Wall Street will expect to hear further details of the company's bid for profitability when it announces its quarterly results, later this month.

webTitle: How big money buys big votes in US race

fields.headline: How big money buys big votes in US race
fields.standfirst:
Gore's social agenda under assault as billions of dollars dominate 'hidden election'
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Flo seems such a nice old lady. She is feisty, good-humoured and worries about how other elderly Americans are getting on, especially with the high price of medicines these days. She is especially concerned that some new-fangled policy in Congress is going to put "big government in our medicine cabinet".
fields.byline: Julian Borger  and  Martin Kettle  in Washington
fields.body:
Flo seems such a nice old lady. She is feisty, good-humoured and worries about how other elderly Americans are getting on, especially with the high price of medicines these days. She is especially concerned that some new-fangled policy in Congress is going to put "big government in our medicine cabinet".

That remark, almost hidden among her lighthearted musings, gives away who she really works for. The series of public policy advertisements she appears in is paid for by an innocuously named group, Citizens for Better Medicare, which turns out to be the public relations arm of Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America.

The industry lobby is fighting a tooth and nail battle against a Democratic proposal to curb the ballooning price of prescription medicines. It has poured more than $11m (£7.8m) into the presidential campaign - mainly to George W Bush who opposes the scheme, but about a third to Al Gore in the hope he will feel beholden to the industry if elected and perhaps water down the plan. In a close race like this, it pays to hedge your bets. For that reason, the industry has ploughed many millions more into congressional races.

The gulf between Flo's kindly face and the hard-edged bottom-line war she is fighting in is a fitting illustration of the two parallel elections underway in the US. One is a contest of personalities and a menu of user-friendly policies that fills the airwaves and news bulletins. The other is practically invisible and pits two loose coalitions of corporations and interest groups against each other in a struggle to decide how money will be made and who will make it under the next administration.

The map of the visible election is familiar. It is the patchwork of states coloured in different shades to represent their allegiances. The other, largely invisible, electoral map shows how corporate America has lined up for contest - the most money-driven election in US history.

Larry Makinson, head of the Centre for Responsive Politics which monitors the role of money in the campaign, said the sheer amount of cash involved owed a lot to the closeness of the race. The corporations, he explained, "don't know who to lobby because they don't know who's going to be in control and both parties are trying to raise money like gangbusters. And so they're calling in chits."

But after the election, it is corporate America that will call in its chits, and - if recent political history is anything to go by - much of the new administration's policy will be guided by the bets placed by big business during the campaign.

In some cases, the policy issues are the same in both the visible and invisible elections. The future of Medicare has been exhaustively debated, even though the trade association, whose "public service" broadcasts are helping shape that debate, is rarely identified.

However, many of the key battles which determine the struggle over big money are not fought in the open. They concern issues such as tort reform and financial deregulation, which sound obscure and tedious, but which represent billions of dollars to both parties' financial backers.

The story is often told of how George W Bush came almost out of nowhere to win the Texas governorship in 1994 from a popular Democratic incumbent, Anne Richards. It is often explained in terms of Mr Bush's optimistic never-say-die nature and his easy manner with ordinary Texans.

But it had a lot to do with one campaign pledge. "Probably the first and most important thing I will do when I am governor of this state," he promised, "is to insist Texas changes the tort laws and insist we end the frivolous and junk lawsuits that threaten our producers and crowd our courts."

True to his word, he signed a string of tort reform bills in his first few weeks in office. Tort reform means making it harder for consumers to sue large corporations. If he becomes president, Bush and his backers mean to put industries such as tobacco, guns, oil and medicine far beyond the reach of the lawsuits which have had the corporations pinned down in the courts for years.

The Bush tort reform proposals would limit victims' rights of access to the court system and cap the amount of damages they could be awarded if they did manage to bring a case to court.

The effect in Texas was dramatic. When a San Antonio jury tried to award a widow $42.5m after lax oil company safety procedures had resulted in the death of her husband, an oil refinery worker, the Bush tort reform laws meant the company paid just $200,000.

Mr Bush's tort reform pledge flooded his 1994 campaign with corporate funds, and is doing the same now. It is bringing in cash from almost every corporate sector which feels vulnerable to the US people's litigious instincts - financial services, insurance, tobacco, pharmaceuticals and oil, the list is endless and explains the Republican candidate's extraordinary lead in the money stakes. The anti-corporate third party candidate, Ralph Nader, often refers to Mr Bush as a "corporation disguised as a human being".

Mr Bush had raised a record $170m by the end of August and must be heading towards $200m by the election on November 7. Over half his campaign funding is "hard money" - individual donations subject to a limit of $1,000 given directly to his campaign coffers. These donations are often "bundled" together by firms or interest groups in the names of their members or employees.

The rest is "soft money" which can be given to each party's national committee to promote "issues". These issues are not supposed to be directly related to the election campaign, and so are not subject to cash limits. But it is a transparent veil. The money and the advertising it funds almost always goes to support the presidential candidates.

Vice-president Gore has raised more soft money than hard but altogether he has little more than half the financial resources of his opponent. His key backers are the lawyers, who fear tort reform as much as Mr Bush's corporate sponsors crave it. In most class-action lawsuits - against gun manufacturers, tobacco, the construction industry or whomever - the lawyers keep a third of the financial award. Each year in US courts that accounts for a huge sum of money and the legal industry has invested nearly $12m in Mr Gore to make sure its members are not deprived of it.

Alienating industries

Mr Gore's and the Democrats' close association with the trial lawyers has, however, inflicted strategic costs elsewhere, alienating industries that might otherwise be sympathetic, such as the computer and dot.com industry.

Silicon Valley is this year's emerging big player on the election Monopoly-board, contributing $10m to the presidential campaigns alone. The Clinton Democrats have long held an edge here, as they have generally opposed initiatives to tax the internet. Furthermore, the relaxed liberal California lifestyle which is home to many in the industry is conducive to Democratic support. Democratic primacy is being challenged however, as the big computer and internet firms worry about the threat of shareholder lawsuits, by which individual owners of company stock have sued firms for sudden plunges in its value, a frequent occurrence in the volatile hi-tech sector.

The huge financial sector is also tilting away from Mr Gore. The banks and investment houses have traditionally been "double-givers", backing politicians on both sides, to make sure government stayed out of their business. Their payoff was the financial deregulation legislation of 1999.

But this year, there is another issue on the table. Mr Bush's proposal to allow Americans to invest part of their social security payments (the US version of national insurance payments) in the stock market has raised the possibility of billions of dollars of new investment funds for the securities industries. It represents a significant prize and has tilted this, the largest single corporate sector, decisively in Mr Bush's favour.

Mr Gore's environmental policies have cost him dearly in the race for big money. It has alienated the real estate brokers and construction industry, which are against environmental zoning, the transportation industry, which wants cheap fuel and less emission control, and the big oil companies.

Mr Bush and his running mate, Dick Cheney, spent much of their careers in the oil business, so the industry's backing comes as little surprise. But the oil companies will exact a price for a Republican victory. They want to explore the Arctic coastal plain in Alaska, beneath which they believe there are 16bn barrels of oil. Mr Gore has said he will not allow the area, a wildlife refuge, to be destroyed.

Mr Gore's environmental policy is generally more popular with voters, as is his support for Medicare and his opposition to tort reform (most Americans believe in the right to sue). But those positions have also lost him financial backing. This election may prove whether you can win the contest for votes without winning the contest for money first.

fields.headline: A study in failure
fields.standfirst:
Hard copy version of the Boo disaster
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: The founders of Boo.com have agreed to write a warts-and-all book detailing the collapse of Britain's highest profile internet start-up.
fields.body:
The founders of Boo.com have agreed to write a warts-and-all book detailing the collapse of Britain's highest profile internet start-up.

Ernst Malmsten and Kajsa Leander, the two 30-year-old Swedes who set up the online clothes retailer, are being paid a fee of £50,000-£80,000 to provide the inside story on how the company burned £80m in little more than a year.

The book is being co-written by a Wall Street Journal journalist and is being pitched as a book about popular culture as much as a standard business book.

The authors have been holding an auction among London publishers. It is thought that Random House, the Bertelsmann- owned publisher, has won.

An executive at a rival firm that has submitted a bid said: "Boo.com was such a turning point in the internet business that we were very keen to sign them up. It's not just an ordinary book about business."

Mr Malmsten and Ms Leander felt heavily let down by several of the blue-chip investors who poured money into the company; a fresh wave of revelations could prove an embarrassment. Bernard Arnault's LVMH and US investment bank JP Morgan came in for particularly heavy criticism when Boo.com called in liquidators in May.

The founders themselves were criticised for their failure to install proper financial controls and the champagne lifestyle many at the company enjoyed.

webTitle: Railtrack faces big fine as delays rise

fields.headline: Railtrack faces big fine as delays rise
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack could face a record fine of up to £35m after train delays were found to have increased by 10%.
fields.body:
Railtrack could face a record fine of up to £35m after train delays were found to have increased by 10%.

The company had been ordered by Tom Winsor, rail regulator, to reduce delays by 7.8% for the 12 months starting last April, but instead these have risen by 10%.

Railtrack yesterday blamed bad weather and track circuit failures, but said that it would do its best to improve its performance in the second half of the year.

Mr Winsor is not likely to take immediate action against the company. His intention is to give Railtrack the opportunity to improve its game. Any fine therefore will be held in abeyance until April next year.

The potential fine of £35m, which would be the largest in corporate history, is based on £2m levied by the regulator for every 1% of underperformance. So far Railtrack is more than 17.8% adrift of the regulator's guidelines.

Railtrack was fined £10m by the regulator earlier this year for failing to meet passenger targets. Following criticism that he was adopting a confrontational approach, Mr Winsor reviewed the position.

He has decided to give the company a "second chance'.' In future, financial penalties will be delayed, but the company will have to pay through lost bonuses.

These will be changed as part of the regulator's review of the reliability of the infrastructure, for the first time since they were set at the time of privatisation in 1993.

Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, last night apologised for the inconvenience caused to passengers by delays. "But our investment programme is vital to the long-term health of the railway, and passengers will ultimately benefit from the work," he said.

He warned that this autumn would present a big challenge, and to meet it, the company had a bigger autumn programme than ever before. This included train sanders, so called leaf-guards, and 1,000 people on stand-by to clear leaves off the line.

Mr Corbett said that the company was delivering record levels of investment, with an increase of 36% to £1.2bn in the first half of the year.

Incidents of trains passing signals at red have started to rise again, but Mr Corbett said that the overall record had been generally good.

Security alerts at Victoria and Paddington stations in central London, and serious delays through emergencies in other parts of the country, have led to considerable losses in time.

Fatalities and trespass caused a 30% increase in delays, while delays due to collisions with bridges rose by 16%.

Railtrack's poor performance has been underlined by figures from the shadow strategic rail authority showing that Railtrack and the 25 train companies have had a disastrous summer.

Apart from pressure from the regulator on Railrack, the rail companies could also face stricter financial penalties from the SSRA for failing to run trains on time or to operate them at all. Some companies could have their right to operate removed if they do not improve, because rail passenger groups are clamouring for tougher action.

 Virgin Trains is to ban all smoking from the middle of 2002 after complaints from passengers. The operator of west coast and cross-country routes will outlaw lighting up in corridors, toilets and buffets as well as carriages.

webTitle: UK News: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: New evidence in Lockerbie trial
fields.body:
New evidence in Lockerbie trial

The trial of two Libyans accused of causing the Lockerbie air disaster in which 270 people died was halted yesterday as prosecutors revealed they have new information but refused to disclose what it was.

Presiding judge Lord Sutherland said the court would sit today but would then adjourn until next Tuesday. Al Megrahi and Fhimah, alleged members of the Libyan intelligence services, deny planting a bomb on board Pan Am Flight 103.

Pierre-White is chef of decade

Marco Pierre-White was named as the chef of the decade yesterday in an AA survey of 1,800 British chefs. The shortlist included his mentors Pierre Koffman and Raymond Blanc.

Cannabis smell closes station

Billericay police station in Essex was closed for two days after officers were overcome by the smell of giant cannabis plants which had been seized from the home of a campaigner.

Low sex drive link to cancer

Men who have a low sex drive may be at increased risk of developing breast cancer, according to a report published yesterday in the British Journal of Cancer. Researchers said that lower testosterone levels may be linked to the cancer.

Man grabs knife in school

A school was evacuated yesterday when a psychiatric patient from a nearby hospital went into the canteen and grabbed a knife. The man was disarmed by police at Dalriada grammar school in Ballymoney, Co Antrim.

webTitle: Annan struggles to stall Middle East war

fields.headline: Annan struggles to stall Middle East war
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, yesterday led international efforts to haul Israel back from the brink of war on two fronts: against the Palestinians, and on its northern border in Lebanon.
fields.body:
The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, yesterday led international efforts to haul Israel back from the brink of war on two fronts: against the Palestinians, and on its northern border in Lebanon.

But hours after the expiry of an ultimatum set by the prime minister, Ehud Barak, for 12 days of violence to end, Israel and the Palestinians were locked in angry recriminations after a day of sporadic violence in the West Bank and Gaza.

Meanwhile, Egypt and the US backed efforts to defuse a crisis caused by the kidnapping of three Israeli soldiers by Lebanese-based Hizbullah militants at the weekend.

Russia's foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, visited Syria and Lebanon and a UN envoy said he had been told the three men were alive and safe.

But there were no assurances for Mr Annan last night, who met with Israel's foreign minister, Shlomo Ben Ami, before talks with the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, in Gaza. He will not meet Mr Barak until today. "I have not come up with any magic formula or solution," Mr Annan said on his arrival in Tel Aviv.

The rhetoric on both sides was unforgiving. "There are no signs in the field that there is a halt in the violence on the Palestinian side," Mr Ben Ami said. "Therefore I do not see any room at the moment for a change in the Israeli position."

The Palestinians have categorically rejected Mr Barak's ultimatum. They say the core of the crisis is the high casual ties inflicted by Israeli soldiers, with 89 dead, almost all Arabs. Mr Arafat, who met earlier yesterday with Egypt's president, Hosni Mubarak, said he would only discuss his demands for an international investigation into the violence with Mr Annan.

Although the deadline set by Mr Barak formally expired with the sunset that ended the most sombre day on the Jewish calendar, Yom Kippur, Israel appeared prepared to hold fire at least until today.

And beneath the rhetoric, so did the Palestinians. Although sporadic shooting erupted in the West Bank city of Ramallah when mourners streamed from a funeral to a barricade manned by Israeli troops on the outskirts of town, there were no fatalities. Fourteen people were reported injured.

However, the violence was descending into tribal hatreds, with Jew killing Arab and Arab killing Jew in the West Bank as well as in Israel proper. Overnight, soldiers reported the discovery of the brutally beaten body of a distant cousin of the US vice-presidential candidate, Joe Lieberman, who had been kidnapped by Palestinians near Nablus at the weekend.

In Nazareth, hundreds of Israeli Arabs, at a funeral for two men killed by Israeli riot police overnight, clashed with stone-throwing Jews.

On the street, the Palestinians were in no mood to yield to ultimatums. "The civilian uprising is continuing and I think many Palestinian leaders are doing their best to ensure there is not shooting," said Mustafa Barghouti, head of Palestinian ambulance services.

"But what started as an uprising for the al-Aqsa mosque in Jerusalem has become an uprising for independence, and against the Israeli occupation."

The widening nature of the protests, ignited by the visit to the holiest Muslim site in Jerusalem by a hardline Israeli leader, is being carefully charted in the Arab world. In Jordan and Egypt, there have been angry protests against the heavy toll suffered by the Palestinians.

The tensions building over the crisis in Lebanon were the most serious since Israel withdrew its troops last May. Mr Barak said he would hold the Lebanese - and Syria, the real power behind the throne there - responsible for the kidnapping of his troops.

That could complicate diplomatic efforts to arrange a prisoner exchange, trading the three soldiers for Lebanese detainees kidnapped by Israel and held illegally in its jails.

webTitle: Business: News analysis

fields.headline: Federal smoke delays merger
fields.standfirst: News Analysis: 'Glaxo SmithKline' struggle costs the two companies £27m a day
fields.trailText: The first question the receptionist asks visitors to Smith-Kline Beecham's Philadelphia nerve centre is: "Are you from Glaxo Wellcome?"
fields.body:
The first question the receptionist asks visitors to Smith-Kline Beecham's Philadelphia nerve centre is: "Are you from Glaxo Wellcome?"

Glaxo employees, once considered enemies, are infiltrating the building like a virus - they only need to show proof of their employment to get in.

Everything is ready for the long-delayed merger of the two firms. In SmithKline's reception hall, glass cabinets display products such as Aquafresh and Ribena. There are gaps inside, ready and waiting for Glaxo's contribution.

Signs bearing the name Glaxo SmithKline have been ordered, ready to adorn the outside of the building. The company has stocked up with new headed notepaper, the secretaries have been drilled on how to answer the phones post-merger and a video-link for staff with chief executive Jean-Pierre Garnier has been arranged, and postponed.

This is no ordinary deal. The merger will create Britain's largest drugs company, employing 107,000 people. But at the whim of the federal trade commission, the combination still hangs in the balance. The commission wants more information about the two companies' smoking cessation products, which may or may not command an unacceptably large market share.

The merger is intended to create annual cost savings of £1bn - which means that for every day of waiting, the two firms spend£27m more than they would as a combined entity. Yet the sticking point officially surrounds just Smith-Kline's Nicorette gum and Nicoderm patches, which have daily sales of less than £1m.

The FTC believes the two nicotine replacement products could clash with Glaxo's Zyban - a prescription drug which acts to reduce the craving for cigarettes. Lawyers in Washington are examining advertising material to see if they target the same customers or whether, as Glaxo claims, Zyban is mainly for last-gasp struggling quitters.

The official line is banal - a SmithKline spokeswoman says: "Of course there's disappointment about the hold-up, but on the whole people are just getting on with the job. Everybody is still focused on delivering results for Smith-Kline Beecham."

Yet there is increasing scepticism about whether all is what it seems. If the problem merely surrounds Nicorette and Nicoderm, critics are asking why SmithKline does not sell them. They are minor products, accounting for less than 4% of total sales, and battling to save them does not justify the cost of keeping the two companies running separately.

One leading pharmaceuticals analyst says: "The whole thing is kind of odd. I get the feeling there's more than meets the eye on this one."

Rumours are circulating that the American authorities feel little incentive to hurry, because they are irritated with SmithKline's uncooperative attitude on other matters. Last month, for example, the company upset a congressional committee investigating the alleged overpricing of cancer treatments by flatly refusing to hand over information about its anti-nausea drug for chemotherapy patients, Kytril. SmithKline maintained that its documents were sensitive and only supplied them in response to a subpoena and a threat of criminal charges.

The two firms' insistence on publishing precise target dates for the completion of the deal is said to have irritated the commission - which considers itself to be above deadlines.

More significantly, political observers wonder whether it is coincidence that the US authorities are taking a tough line on two drugs companies in the middle of a presidential election. Vice-president Al Gore has made much of his desire to get tough on the drugs industry. If the merger were cleared under the Clinton administration, Republican candidate George Bush could make political capital.

The official line is that the deal will be completed by the end of the year. Despite its confidence that things are still on track, SmithKline has frozen redundancies and is not telling employees whether they will have jobs in the merged firm. Thousands are left uncertain - the Manufacturing, Science and Finance union still believes 5,000 redundancies are possible.

Mr Garnier directs events from the group's Philadelphia office from where he can just about see down the street where the group's US predecessor, SmithKline & French, originated. The pressure is on Mr Garnier to ensure that SmithKline takes another step from being a local Pennsylvania endeavour to an international leader in the drugs industry.

webTitle: Milosevic's allies seek cover

fields.headline: Milosevic's allies seek cover
fields.standfirst:
Yugoslavia's new president consolidates his grip as defeated regime's big players change allegiance
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Yugoslavia's new president, Vojislav Kostunica, yesterday received two big boosts in his effort to weed out the vestiges of Slobodan Milosevic's regime when the leaders of the main parties in the Serbian parliament agreed on early elections and the hardline Serbian police minister, Vlajko Stojiljkovic, resigned.
fields.body:
Yugoslavia's new president, Vojislav Kostunica, yesterday received two big boosts in his effort to weed out the vestiges of Slobodan Milosevic's regime when the leaders of the main parties in the Serbian parliament agreed on early elections and the hardline Serbian police minister, Vlajko Stojiljkovic, resigned.

Riding the tide of victory as politicians who once opposed him rushed to gain favour with the new forces of democracy, Mr Kostunica was also buoyed by reports that another close Milosevic ally, President Milan Milutinovic of Serbia, will resign in the next few days.

He and the Serbian police minister are on the list of five Serbs including Mr Milosevic who have been indicted for war crimes in Kosovo by the international tribunal in the Hague.

Mr Kostunica was also bolstered by the news that a new Serbian parliament will be elected in December, six months before it was due. The suspicion still remains, however, that former Milosevic allies will cling to power. Last night hundreds of students gathered outside the Serb parliament amid reports that some such allies were hedging on the agreement to hold fresh elections.

After a stormy session, Vojislav Seselj, the leader of the Serb Radical party and a former ally of Mr Milosevic, was jostled by protesters and one of his bodyguards fired his pistol in the air.

Yugoslavia's near bloodless revolution could still turn ugly. In a sign that some of the worst members of the old regime are still active, Branko Djuric, the Belgrade police chief, was reported by his wife to have been abducted. It was he who allowed the police to put up only minimal resistance when demonstrators stormed the federal parliament, and Radio Television Serbia last week. Hardliners blamed him for triggering the collapse of the regime.

In Belgrade workers attacked Radoman Bozovic, a close Milosevic aide and the director of Genex, a major trading corporation. He tried to flee from his car but was caught and beaten.

His bodyguards snatched him into a nearby building for safety. Later he resigned as head of the company when staff, who suspect massive embezzlement of the company's earnings, invaded his office and told him he must quit.

In Nis workers stormed a state-run textile factory demanding the Socialist management be fired. Vladimir Stambuk, who was appointed by Mr Milosevic as dean of the school of political sciences at Belgrade University, was also fired. He had sacked dozens of professors since being put in place to purge the university of opposition supporters.

When he grudgingly accepted defeat last week, Mr Milosevic said he wanted to remain in politics as head of the Socialist party and to provide "strong opposition".

That now looks unlikely as his friends depart or switch sides. Elections for a new Serbian parliament will be held on December 17 and the Socialists are likely to lose a lot of their seats. This could lead to the collapse of the Socialist party as a serious force. JUL, the Yugoslav Left, the party founded by Mira Markovic, the former dictator's wife, is also likely to suffer crashing losses in December.

With elections imminent, Mr Kostunica has a free hand to nominate both the Serbian and Yugoslav governments and ensure they work closely together. Zoran Bjindjic, his campaign manager, said yesterday the new Serbian government would be a transitional administration of technocrats plus political representatives from the democratic Opposition of Serbia, the coalition of 19 parties which backed Mr Kostunica in last month's elections.

The Yugoslav government is expected to be a similar mixture, though it will probably also contain ministers from Montenegro. The ruling party of President Milo Djukanovic in Montenegro made what increasingly seems the major blunder when it boycotted last month's elections. As a result, Mr Kostunica may appoint ministers from the other main Montenegran party, the Socialist People's party. It used to support Mr Milosevic against the pro-western Mr Djukanovic. Its party leader, Momir Bulatovic, resigned yesterday as Yugoslav prime minister. This was a formality since the new president appoints the prime minister.

The thundering sound of loyalties being switched is a stunning triumph for Mr Kostunica. On the foreign front, he welcomed the news yesterday that the European Union was lifting oil sanctions and the ban on commercial flights.

The change of atmosphere was apparent when Mr Stojiljkovic, the police minister, told MPs in his resignation speech that "it was an honour to have been attacked by Nato" during last year's air strikes. MPs greeted the comments with derisive laughter.

Mr Stojiljkovic's days were numbered and he would almost certainly have been sacked had he not jumped first. Vojislav Seself, the leader of the Radical party, and Vuk Draskovic, leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement, both hold him responsible for ordering several assassination attempts on themselves and their closest advisers. They were proposing a motion to dismiss him.

Mr Kostunica was also bolstered by the news that a new Serbian parliament will be elected in December, six months before it was due. The suspicion still remains, however, that former Milosevic allies will cling to power. Last night hundreds of students gathered outside the Serb parliament amid reports that some such allies were hedging on the agreement to hold fresh elections. After a stormy session, Vojislav Seselj, the leader of the Serb Radical party and a former ally of Mr Milosevic, was jostled by protesters and one of his bodyguards fired his pistol in the air. Yugoslavia's near bloodless revolution could still turn ugly. In a sign that some of the worst members of the old regime are still active, Branko Djuric, the Belgrade police chief, was reported by his wife to have been abducted. It was he who allowed the police to put up only minimal resistance when demonstrators stormed the federal parliament, and Radio Television Serbia last week. Hardliners blamed him for triggering the collapse of the regime. In Belgrade workers attacked Radoman Bozovic, a close Milosevic aide and the director of Genex, a major trading corporation. He tried to flee from his car but was caught and beaten. His bodyguards snatched him into a nearby building for safety. Later he resigned as head of the company when staff, who suspect massive embezzlement of the company's earnings, invaded his office and told him he must quit. In Nis workers stormed a state-run textile factory demanding the Socialist management be fired. Vladimir Stambuk, who was appointed by Mr Milosevic as dean of the school of political sciences at Belgrade University, was also fired. He had sacked dozens of professors since being put in place to purge the university of opposition supporters. When he grudgingly accepted defeat last week, Mr Milosevic said he wanted to remain in politics as head of the Socialist party and to provide "strong opposition". That now looks unlikely as his friends depart or switch sides. Elections for a new Serbian parliament will be held on December 17 and the Socialists are likely to lose a lot of their seats. This could lead to the collapse of the Socialist party as a serious force. JUL, the Yugoslav Left, the party founded by Mira Markovic, the former dictator's wife, is also likely to suffer crashing losses in December. With elections imminent, Mr Kostunica has a free hand to nominate both the Serbian and Yugoslav governments and ensure they work closely together. Zoran Bjindjic, his campaign manager, said yesterday the new Serbian government would be a transitional administration of technocrats plus political representatives from the democratic Opposition of Serbia, the coalition of 19 parties which backed Mr Kostunica in last month's elections. The Yugoslav government is expected to be a similar mixture, though it will probably also contain ministers from Montenegro. The ruling party of President Milo Djukanovic in Montenegro made what increasingly seems the major blunder when it boycotted last month's elections. As a result, Mr Kostunica may appoint ministers from the other main Montenegran party, the Socialist People's party. It used to support Mr Milosevic against the pro-western Mr Djukanovic. Its party leader, Momir Bulatovic, resigned yesterday as Yugoslav prime minister. This was a formality since the new president appoints the prime minister. The thundering sound of loyalties being switched is a stunning triumph for Mr Kostunica. On the foreign front, he welcomed the news yesterday that the European Union was lifting oil sanctions and the ban on commercial flights. The change of atmosphere was apparent when Mr Stojiljkovic, the police minister, told MPs in his resignation speech that "it was an honour to have been attacked by Nato" during last year's air strikes. MPs greeted the comments with derisive laughter. Mr Stojiljkovic's days were numbered and he would almost certainly have been sacked had he not jumped first. Vojislav Seself, the leader of the Radical party, and Vuk Draskovic, leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement, both hold him responsible for ordering several assassination attempts on themselves and their closest advisers. They were proposing a motion to dismiss him.

webTitle: At this price?  British  Airways

fields.headline: At this price?  British  Airways
fields.trailText: British Airways has been ploughing through a prolonged patch of turbulence. Chief executive Bob Ayling has gone, replaced in May by Australian executive Rod Eddington. The planned merger with American Airlines appears to have been abandoned. The proposed takeover of the Dutch airline KLM collapsed.
fields.body:
British Airways has been ploughing through a prolonged patch of turbulence. Chief executive Bob Ayling has gone, replaced in May by Australian executive Rod Eddington. The planned merger with American Airlines appears to have been abandoned. The proposed takeover of the Dutch airline KLM collapsed.

Mr Ayling's plan to focus the airline's main business on premium passengers has yet to prove itself.

The "world's favourite airline" is rethinking its involvement at Gatwick, London's second terminal, and is about to embark on a restructuring of its loss-making short haul routes.

To cap it all, it has had to introduce random breath-testing of pilots and cabin crew after 11 pilots and three crew were suspended following claims they had been drinking alcohol before flying.

BA shares have been jumping up and down in a manner worthy of a flight on a bad day.

The company, which announced record profits six years ago, is now struggling to return to profitability.

The City is in no doubt about the task before Mr Eddington and his team. It is to return BA to profit with a strategy that will include linking up with a strong North American or European partner, or preferably both.

A prerequisite of such a strategy may be a reshaping of the management team, a pruning of some of those responsible for bringing BA to its present parlous position.

The group is fast running out of time. BA has already run into regulatory problems with international partnerships. Regulators in Brussels and Washington effectively scuppered the plans for code sharing arrangements between BA and American Airlines.

Mr Eddington will have to pull something credible out of the hat fast, for the institutions will not tolerate the recent renewed plunge in BA's share price for much longer.

One thing is certain. BA shareholders must be prepared for a continued bumpy ride. The shares - which closed yesterday at 291.25p, down 1.75p - are not for the faint-hearted.

webTitle: Nick Wood on Serbia's unsung heroine

fields.headline: Serbia's unsung heroine
fields.standfirst:
Amid the celebrations at last week's overthrow of Slobodan Milosevic, one woman's death passed almost unnoticed. Nick Wood reports from Belgrade

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Amid the celebrations at last week's overthrow of Slobodan Milosevic, one woman's death passed almost unnoticed.  Nick Wood reports from Belgrade.
fields.body:
When Jasmina Jovanovic died during the recent tumultuous events in Serbia, the common reaction among people in Belgrade was that it was a small price to pay for change. Others have described her as the final victim of Slobodan Milosevic, whose 13 years of tyranny ended surprisingly peacefully last week.

When Jovanovic died last Thursday, she became the only person to lose her life in the Serbian uprising. The 39-year-old law graduate was killed when she slipped from a trailer carrying a bulldozer to the demonstration outside the Federal Parliament building in the centre of the capital. Witnesses say it was a freak accident. Her rucksack slipped and pulled her under the wheels as pro-democracy protesters stormed the building. Staff at the Urgent Centar, Belgrade hospital's emergency clinic, say she was dead on arrival.

Jovanovic was buried on Saturday in a small cemetery in her home village of Milosevac. But five days after her death, she has been virtually forgotten. As the new president, Vojislav Kostunica, attempts to assert his control of the country, news of her death has been limited to a few paragraphs on the inside pages of Serbian newspapers.

Yet according to her friends and colleagues, Jovanovic was part of a group that was instrumental in helping to bring down the Milosevic regime. Her death, and more specifically the way it has been viewed since, is a reminder, according to some, that women have a very long way to go before they become an acceptable part of political life in Yugoslavia.

Jovanovic spent her childhood in Milosevac, a village 40 miles from Belgrade, in an area regarded as the heartland of Serbia. Belgraders refer to it simply as being on "the South track" - an allusion to its lack of sophistication.

The only daughter of two teachers, Jovanovic moved away from the village to study law in Belgrade where she remained until her death. In 1992 she became one of the first members of Vojislav Kostunica's Serbian Democratic Party. At a memorial service held for her on Sunday, the party's representative, Dragan Jocic, described her as being very active in all the opposition demonstrations since then. "All the time she was working for change in Yugoslavia," he recalled when paying tribute to her.

Jovanovic's friends say she had been looking forward to Thursday's demonstration for days. Thursday was the date the Democratic Opposition of Serbia had set as the deadline for Milosevic to step down from power. "She had no fear, she was very brave," one friend is quoted as saying in the opposition daily newspaper Blic.

One woman, however, can't help but think that coverage of Jasmina Jovanovic's death would have been very different if she had been a man. "If a man was killed, very quickly the importance of his role in the democratic opposition in Serbia would be clear," says Biljana Vuco, president of the Yugoslav Lawyers Committee for Human Rights. "There was no news about Jasmina's political involvement," she adds. "I didn't even know she was a member of a political party."

According to Vuco, most people's perception of politics in Yugoslavia is that it remains very much a man's domain. The country's three most dominant female politicians are identified as strong women - but none of them has a popular reputation. "They are called bitches," Vuco explains. "They are guilty of everything."

Mira Markovic, the wife of Slobodan Milosevic, is the most obvious example, characterised as the Lady Macbeth of Serbia. But successful women in the Democratic Opposition get the same treatment. Danica Draskovic, the wife of Vuk Draskovic, president of the Serbian Renewal Party, and one of his closest advisers, is subject to numerous rumours about her personal life. Vesna Pesic, head of the Centre for Anti War Action, is respected among intellectuals but is not very popular outside those circles, Vuco says.

"The view is that they are in politics because they have personal problems," she explains. "They are not good housewives or mothers. There is a common opinion that women have nothing to do with politics in Serbia."

Jasmina Jovanovic, she argues, is therefore seen simply as a "poor woman who died in a demonstration by accident" and not as somebody who genuinely struggled to overthrow the Milosevic regime.

Others are less critical. Goran Svilanovic is head of the Civic Alliance of Serbia, one of the many groups that made up the Democratic Opposition of Serbia. He believes that the failure of the press to give more coverage to Jovanovic's death has little to do with gender. "Two men died at the same time, one of a heart attack and one of a stroke, and there is nothing about them in the papers," he points out, adding that it is communism and state control that has prevented the rise of women within Serbian politics.

It is certainly the case that women did not fare well under the Milosevic regime. Since the Nato bombardment began in the spring of 1999, combined with the grinding effects of nearly a decade of economic sanctions, half the population has been living below the poverty line. Infant mortality has increased, as has prostitution and domestic violence. According to the UN, 25% of Serbian women felt it would be "irresponsible" to bear children in their nation while Milosevic remained in power.

Lately, however, there has been evidence of an upsurge in women's activism. In the past year, 70% of all new non-governmental groups have been created by women.

Svilanovic believes that the women of Serbia have yet to have their day. "Everything has been controlled by the state," he says. "Unions have been under state control or nonexistent. It is the same for the bar association and the medical profession. It will take time, but women will gradually emerge."

Back in Milosevac, Jovanovic's funeral was one of the biggest the area had seen in years. Death notices pasted to lamp-posts note that her death came on the day "when democracy and freedom descended".

Her aunt, Ljiljla Peresic, says she had warned Jovanovic not to go to the demonstration, but she was determined. "She wanted change and a normal life."

webTitle: Business: Brewer weighs break-up and takeover options

fields.headline: Brewer weighs break-up and takeover options
fields.trailText: Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries yesterday surrendered to pressure from unhappy shareholders and launched a "strategic review", which is likely to mean an end to its 110-year-old history as an independent public company.
fields.body:
Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries yesterday surrendered to pressure from unhappy shareholders and launched a "strategic review", which is likely to mean an end to its 110-year-old history as an independent public company.

The review will consider either a break-up of the firm or a takeover. Talks have reopened with venture capital group Botts & Co, which has made a tentative offer of £470m.

Advisers to the company, which brews Bank's, Cameron and Marston's bitter, said there would be "no sacred cows" in the review, and privately admitted that maintaining the status quo was not an option.

Wolves' managing director, David Thompson, said: "We've actually been trading reasonably satisfactorily, but the news from the industry has been dire, and that has unsettled shareholders generally."

Many institutional share holders want to reduce their exposure to local pubs, which have been through a torrid time due to poor summer weather and a trend towards branded bar chains. Wolves is also considered to have too much brewery capacity, with little prospect of growth in demand for traditional ales.

Talks with Botts were restarted in a phone conversation on Thursday night. Botts has agreed to reduce its demands to see confidential trading information - it orig inally requested detailed data including the number of times the emergency services had visited each of Wolves' 1,700 pubs. Advisers from the two sides will hold a face to face meeting this week.

Wolves stressed that a takeover by Botts was not the only option - it said its review "may or may not lead to an offer for all or part of the company".

Another possibility is a break-up, with the group's three breweries being sold in some form of management buyout. However, analysts said that the whole of the business would have to go private to satisfy shareholders.

James Wheatcroft of stockbroker WestLB Panmure said: "The institutions want cash now. A demerger is not an option."

Wolves' shares jumped 8.5p to 475p. Botts has said that it is willing to pay 500p in cash, with a possibility of up to 50p more if the company's internal accounts are better than it expects.

webTitle: New York expert to run London's tube

fields.headline: New York expert to run London's tube
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Livingstone's London
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The man credited with bringing the New York subway back from the brink of collapse in the 1980s has been appointed by Ken Livingstone to turn round London's crisis-ridden transport system on a performance-linked salary worth up to £2m over four years.
fields.body:
The man credited with bringing the New York subway back from the brink of collapse in the 1980s has been appointed by Ken Livingstone to turn round London's crisis-ridden transport system on a performance-linked salary worth up to £2m over four years.

Bob Kiley, former chief executive of New York's metropolitan transport authority, is to be the first commissioner of transport for London, over seeing tubes, buses, taxis and main roads, and the planned congestion charge.

Mr Livingstone's attraction of such a successful international management figure, with a proven record in rescuing a comparable public sector city transport system, is bound to intensify the pressure on John Prescott to rethink his part-privatisation scheme for the tube.

Speaking from New York yesterday, Mr Kiley warned that the government's "public-private partnership" plan for London Underground was problematic and a "prescription for real problems".

He hoped that people would "take a pause and figure out whether they're doing the right thing".

Under Mr Kiley's stewardship from 1984 to 1991, New York's subway, bus and commuter rail systems were transformed with cash raised by bonds, the method of finance advocated for the London Underground by Mr Livingstone.

Mr Kiley's financial package of a basic salary of £250,000 a year, plus the chance to double that through performance bonuses is unprecedented for a public official and likely to prove controversial.

But, announcing the appointment yesterday, Mr Livingstone said Londoners would consider him "cheap at the price" if Mr Kiley solved the capital's transport crisis. He was "one of the greatest transport experts in the world".

The appointment was welcomed by Simon Sperryn, chief executive of the London Chamber of Commerce, who said it was "necessary to offer a world-class salary in order to turn the tube into a world-class system".

Liberal Democrat Susan Kramer, who stood against Mr Livingstone for mayor, said London had got "the best".

She added that Mr Kiley's success in New York should "convince the government to hand the tube over to London and end the discredited public-private partnership scheme".

But a spokeswoman for Mr Prescott's department said it would press ahead with the scheme.

webTitle: Business: Notebook

fields.headline: Good governance equals good business
fields.standfirst: Notebook: Hutchings must face the music
fields.trailText: The resolute silence from Greg Hutchings, chief executive of Tomkins, screamed one thing yesterday: resign, now. The former Hanson executive may have built what at its peak amounted to a £4.5bn conglomerate, spanning everything from guns to Hovis bread rolls, making many of Tomkins' investors a tidy return in the process, but Mr Hutchings never seemed to show much interest in the niceties of corporate governance.
fields.body:
The resolute silence from Greg Hutchings, chief executive of Tomkins, screamed one thing yesterday: resign, now. The former Hanson executive may have built what at its peak amounted to a £4.5bn conglomerate, spanning everything from guns to Hovis bread rolls, making many of Tomkins' investors a tidy return in the process, but Mr Hutchings never seemed to show much interest in the niceties of corporate governance.

His tendency was to run the company as if it were private. And it was only under intense pressure, with a share price close to free fall, that he finally agreed to split the roles of chairman and chief executive and bring in non-executive directors who could be relied upon to stand up to him.

If Mr Hutchings himself cannot stand up now and state publicly that each and every one of the extraordinary allegations regarding his probity that appeared over the weekend are nonsense, then he is not fit to run a publicly listed company.

Speaking privately, his aides have come over all conspiratorial, convinced that some in the City are out to "get" Mr Hutchings.

But even their suspicions appear to be directed at the way in which the information suddenly appeared in the press rather than the substance of the allegations themselves.

At the same time, statements from David Newlands, installed in the wake of institutional pressure from the likes of Hermes, do not encourage the idea that this is all some terrible misunderstanding.

Having called in Arthur Andersen to investigate the claims - which range from Mr Hutchings having both his wife and housekeeper on the company's books to suspicions that Tomkins assets were used to support Lord Archer's bungled campaign to become London's mayor - Mr Newlands has also dropped a heavy hint to the Inland Revenue that it might also take a closer look at his chief executive's affairs.

Mr Hutchings liked to wear a Smith & Wesson gun belt under his suit. Let us hope that when the auditors finish their inquiry they find no other traces of the wild west.

If they do, it will prove a serious embarrassment for the host of investment banks which have taken some exceptionally tasty fees out of Tomkins over the years. At its prime, the level of deal-making was such that the process of due diligence must have been a full time affair at the company.

Private use of corporate jets, friends or family on the payroll, and suspect use of company apartments are all common enough vices among privately run businesses, where the boss typically owns most of the equity and has primarily built the company on his or her own sweat and blood.

Corporate financiers and auditors handling floats are trained to spot and reverse such abuses because they know they are not tolerated in the public arena. At a company which for years was a member of the FTSE 100, using the public's money to expand, such monitoring should have been routine.

Good corporate governance, it should always be remembered, is not a piece of corporate greenery. It is just good business sense.

Telecoms chasm

It must be serious. Even the European Central Bank, which might be thought to have other preoccupations - not least a bombed-out euro - has noticed. The latest bulletin for the ECB devotes part of a special section to the telecoms sector's appetite for money as the cost of acquiring third generation mobile phone licences mounts.

As the ECB notes, the spread between government and corporate bonds is widening fast. If the cost of future licences exceed market expectations that spread is likely to widen further, though government bonds yields are likely to continue to be overshadowed by the health of public finances across most of the European Union.

The ECB is hardly the first to notice the risks inherent in the current UTMS spending spree. Look no further than the fall in the market capitalisations of the big European telecoms players since the spring.

webTitle: Celltech falls as drug trial fails

fields.headline: Celltech falls as drug trial fails
fields.standfirst: Price paid for developer questioned
fields.trailText: Britain's biggest biotechnology company, Celltech, suffered a significant blow yesterday with news that one of its most advanced products, a drug for the skin disease scleroderma, had failed in clinical trials.
fields.body:
Britain's biggest biotechnology company, Celltech, suffered a significant blow yesterday with news that one of its most advanced products, a drug for the skin disease scleroderma, had failed in clinical trials.

The news sent Celltech shares down 46p to £13.11 and triggered renewed suggestions that the company overpaid last year in its £580m purchase of drugs company Medeva, which developed the failed product.

Celltech said the drug, Relaxin, had showed no statistically significant evidence of working in a large-scale study in the US. Scleroderma is a rare disease in which the body produces too much collagen, causing a thickening of the skin and of internal organs which kills 60% of sufferers within 10 years.

Celltech's chief executive Peter Fellner said: "We were disappointed by this but we weren't very surprised. We had no clear view within Celltech as to whether it would prove effective."

He said the company had considered axeing Relaxin earlier this year. Trials were only continued because otherwise Celltech would have had to pay compensation to its development partner in the US.

Celltech has now dropped nearly all the development projects it inherited from Medeva, including a hepatitis vaccine, Hepagene, and an investigation into the use of nicotine to treat bowel problems. The only significant on going work is on a new version of methylphenidate, Medeva's leading drug for attention deficit disorder.

When asked whether he felt Medeva's pipeline was poor quality, Mr Fellner said: "With hindsight, you might say that."

He stressed, however, that the group had bought Medeva for its sales and marketing network in the US and for its profitable operation selling older products: "At the time we announced the deal, the purchase was for £580m. The amount attributable to Medeva's so-called pipeline was no more than 10%."

Industry experts were divided. One analyst, who declined to be named, said: "The general view is that they overpaid fairly massively. They were pretty well stitched up by their investment banks."

However, Nick Woolf of ABN Amro disagreed. "I think it would be unfair to claim they overpaid. This setback is not serious - it's just a blow to sentiment," he said.

Celltech has launched two new products this year - Mylotarg, for leukaemia, and Chirocaine, an anaesthetic. The next most advanced were Relaxin and Humicade, a drug for the bowel disorder Crohn's disease.

Analyst Howard Miller of Teather & Greenwood said the loss of Relaxin would knock Celltech's projected earnings for the year 2005 by about 10%: "I don't think on the whole scale of things that this is a big catastrophe for them."

ReNeuron, a Guildford-based company using hi-tech stem cells to develop treatments for brain disorders, has announced plans to float on the Alternative Investment Market.

webTitle: Business: Blow for Losec

fields.headline: Blow for Losec
fields.trailText: A court in Australia has delivered a blow to drugs company AstraZeneca by ruling that there are flaws in its patent protection over ulcer treatment Losec, the world's best selling prescription medicine.
fields.body:
A court in Australia has delivered a blow to drugs company AstraZeneca by ruling that there are flaws in its patent protection over ulcer treatment Losec, the world's best selling prescription medicine.

The full federal court of Australia said in Sydney that AstraZeneca's formulation patent for omeprazole, Losec's active ingredient, was "obvious and lacked inventive step".

AstraZeneca said it would appeal against the judgment, which allows a domestic firm, Alphapharm, to sell a generic version of the product.

Worldwide sales of Losec were $5.9bn (£4bn) last year, accounting for a third of AstraZeneca's overall turnover.

The company is fighting hard to defend its position, as patents in countries around the world gradually lapse.

Australian sales of Losec were just $100m. Court battles by the firm are continuing in the United States, which is by far the biggest market for the drug.

webTitle: Business: £18bn collapse is Japan's biggest in 50 years

fields.headline: £18bn collapse is Japan's biggest in 50 years
fields.trailText: The government's attempt to save Japan's financial dinosaurs from extinction suffered a serious blow yesterday with the largest insurance company collapse since the second world war.
fields.body:
The government's attempt to save Japan's financial dinosaurs from extinction suffered a serious blow yesterday with the largest insurance company collapse since the second world war.

Chiyoda Mutual Insurance was forced to file for court protection after banks rejected a government-backed rescue. According to the financial services agency, Chiyoda - the nation's 12th biggest insurance company - had liabilities of 2.9 trillion yen (£18bn). This exceeded the company's assets by ¥34.3bn.

Chiyoda's problems are well known. It was brought to its knees by bad loans and property investments during the late 1980s bubble.

Like many Japanese insurance firms, its problems were exacerbated by falling income from premiums, poor returns on investments and a sharp decline in stock market values since the start of the year.

Despite the announcement of a restructuring plan to cut four-fifths of its branches and 800 jobs, Chiyoda's financial health has worsened. In recent months, its ability to cover potential claims has fallen to dangerously low levels.

"To our policyholders and many other supporters we deeply apologise for this outcome," said the company's president, Reiji Yoneyama, at a press conference to announce his resignation.

Analysts took the company's failure as a sign that market forces are starting to prevail in the financial sector. The government has for some years forced "strong" institutions to protect the weak. This was known as the "convoy system".

But it is becoming harder to find a willing "escort ship" because strong organisations are struggling to ensure even their own survival.

When the financial services agency asked Chiyoda's main lender, the Tokai Bank, to arrange a bail-out last week, it refused. Tokai insisted the insurer tie up with a foreign firm - which it was unable to do.

Other insurance firms could face a jittery few days. Chiyoda is the fifth to collapse since 1997 and investors may start wondering which will be the next to go.

The impact on Chiyoda's 1.5m policyholders will be closely watched. If an industry-run fund is unable to cover the shortfall, the government may be forced to step in.

webTitle: Business: £500m rebranding for Caradon

fields.headline: £500m rebranding for Caradon
fields.trailText: After yesterday's sale of its Twyford plumbing business, building materials group Caradon plans to go on a £500m spending spree to establish itself as a hi-tech company under the name Novar.
fields.body:
After yesterday's sale of its Twyford plumbing business, building materials group Caradon plans to go on a £500m spending spree to establish itself as a hi-tech company under the name Novar.

Chief executive Jurgen Hintz wants to expand in the so-called intelligent building services he believes will become a fast-growing market as homeowners opt for more gadgetry.

The former Proctor & Gamble main board director said he was looking at a range of targets but added "we will not be spending money unless there are good returns."

Caradon has sold its trademark business, which also includes Mira Showers and Stelrad Radioators, to HSBC Private Equity for £442m in cash, considerably more than expected. HSBC will retain the right to use the Caradon name.

Caradon's shares rose 4p to 187.5p as the City welcomed the latest step by Mr Hintz, who arrived at Caradon two and a half years ago with a brief to restructure it.

Around 70% of the post-sales business is based in the US. Mr Hintz said he would be considering a secondary listing in the US although Novar's head office would be in London.

The group is already active in the "intelligent" sector, providing control systems for Wal-Mart stores. The sale will be submitted for approval at an extraordinary shareholders' meeting next month.

webTitle: Drugs 'main pointer' to crime by boys

fields.headline: Drugs 'main pointer' to crime by boys
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Drug use is the strongest predictor of serious or persistent offending for boys aged 12-17, according to a Home Office survey of youth crime.
fields.body:
Drug use is the strongest predictor of serious or persistent offending for boys aged 12-17, according to a Home Office survey of youth crime.

The report, published yesterday, showed the odds of offending for drug-takers were nearly five times higher than for non-drug users.

Boys who were disaffected from school or were persistent truants also had a higher risk of serious offending.

For older males, drug use continued to be the key factor, while heavy drinking was also influential.

Leaving school without any qualifications was the second most important predictor of criminal behaviour for the 18 to 30-year-old age group.

The survey questioned nearly 5,000 young people in England and Wales. Almost a fifth of the group admitted committing one or more offences in the past 12 months. Nearly half of the 12 to 30-year-olds questioned had committed at least one criminal offence.

The most "prolific" 10% of juvenile offenders were responsible for nearly half the crimes admitted by the group - they represented 1% of the full sample.

Those aged 14 to 21 were the most likely to be offenders. The survey shows the average age when juvenile lawbreaking begins is 13 and a half for boys, and 14 for girls.

At 12 or 13, a similar number of boys and girls offended, as well as used drugs and drank regularly, but after 14, male offenders started to outstrip women. The study also found marked differences in the nature of crime committed by the different genders at different ages.

Girls under 16 were most likely to be involved in criminal damage, shoplifting, buying stolen goods and fighting, while over 16 they turned away from criminal damage to fraud and buying stolen goods. The highest levels of offending were among 18 to 21-year-old men, with fraud and workplace theft beginning at this age.

The survey showed an increase in offending among 14 to 17-year-old boys since 1992/93 when the last such study was carried out.

The report's authors attributed the rise mainly to increases in fighting and criminal damage.

Home Office minister Charles Clarke said yesterday: "Cutting juvenile crime, creating safer communities and restoring confidence in the youth justice system are at the top of the government's agenda."

webTitle: Did Lennon imagine he would be killed?

fields.headline: Did Lennon imagine he would be killed?
fields.trailText: A song by John Lennon, released for the first time yesterday on what would have been the former Beatle's 60th birthday, appears to contain a premonition of his death at the hands of "the angel of destruction".
fields.body:
A song by John Lennon, released for the first time yesterday on what would have been the former Beatle's 60th birthday, appears to contain a premonition of his death at the hands of "the angel of destruction".

Help Me To Help Myself, a piano-accompanied ballad, appears on a digitally remastered version of Double Fantasy, the last album he recorded before he was shot dead outside his New York apartment by Mark Chapman in 1980. The song includes the lines:

Well I tried hard to stay
alive,
But the angel of destruction
keeps on hounding me, all
around.

But I know in my heart that we
really never parted, oh no.

Lennon's widow Yoko Ono had kept the recording private for 20 years. "With Double Fantasy, I thought it would be an ideal opportunity to introduce one of John's still unheard tracks," she said yesterday.

"He was playing this on the piano at home, half-laughing and saying 'Wouldn't it be something if we ever put this out?'

"They say people start to think of God near death. It's possible that was the case here. Whatever he was thinking of doing, it is a beautiful song and I wanted to share it."

Double Fantasy, a copy of which Chapman was carrying on the night of the murder, also contains Walking On Thin Ice, the last song Lennon wrote with Ono.

The birthday was also marked by the reissue of Lennon's first solo album, John Lennon/Plastic Ono Band, with two extra tracks.

Yoko Ono was in Tokyo to open the first John Lennon museum. Other commemorative events included a huge ice sculpture of Lennon in Sydney and an aircraft writing "Remember love" in the New York skies. In Liverpool, Lennon's home city, his half-sister Julia Baird planted an oak tree in a peace garden.

webTitle: TV: Getting personal with... Jeff Goldblum

fields.headline: Answer me
fields.standfirst: Getting personal with... Jeff Goldblum
fields.trailText: Getting personal with... Jeff Goldblum
fields.body:
Have you ever adopted a psuedonym, and if so why?

Jim Dandy - for security reasons

Have you ever lied about your age, and if so why?

I added a year to get into The Neighbourhood Playhouse. They threatened to throw me out when they found out, but I begged them to reconsider. That was some of my best acting.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad?

Gee, I don't think I'd take one out.

What was the last illegal thing you did?

I tore one of those tags off a mattress. I kept my mouth shut until now. Maybe I've made a mistake. Can you do hard time for that?

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did?

My sister has a bull terrier, you know one of those funny looking dogs, called Louise. I bought her a little toy. I believe she liked it very much.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with?

Richard Attenborough. Well he was awfully nice. He smells nice too.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with?

ST

Has a critic ever made you cry?

I don't think so.

What would you advertise without a fee?

The Playhouse West school in North Hollywood.

What would you never advertise? Cigarettes.

What wakes you up screaming at 4am? Earthquakes.

What takes you to a happy place?

I was singing It's Only A Paper Moon to myself the other day. That took me to a happy place.

 Jeff Goldblum stars in Jurassic Park and The Lost World, for which the DVD Box Set is out now (Columbia Tristar).
