webTitle: Last night's TV:  Gareth McLean

fields.headline: Doctors in distress
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Gareth McLean
fields.trailText: Doctors/Heartbreak Homes
fields.body:
There was an eerie silence in the Riverside Surgery in Doctors (BBC1). There were hardly any patients. Bar Mrs Harriman (who was sitting at a very low table which can't have been good for her posture, especially at her age), there was a distinct lack of people coughing, spluttering and reading months-old magazines; there wasn't even someone strange harassing the receptionist for an appointment. Tumbleweed and a low whistling wind would have fitted the ambience perfectly.

It was probably just as well there were only a few patients, though, since the doctors of Doctors didn't seem keen on doing an awful lot of work. Instead, they argued amongst themselves, though strangely not about the decor of their environs. The surgery looked like it had been decorated by Rod, Jane and Freddie, evidently to complement the receptionist who had gone for that boho look, but in primary colours. As she never came out from behind her desk, reports of her dungarees remain unconfirmed but she was definitely wearing a spotty headscarf. It made her look like a particularly cheerful refugee. Which, perhaps, she is. On the run from Sylvia Young.

While not all doctors' surgeries are austere and Victorian ("Please Doctor! Not the leeches!"), Riverside looked like a nursery. And Mrs Harriman at that low table didn't help either. They should have had her doing potato prints and been done with it.

Anyway, there was a story to Doctors ("100 episodes", the Radio Times squealed excitedly), but not much of one. Mac - who, sadly, is nothing like his namesake from Knots Landing - had accidentally promised to make both Dr Caroline and Dr Steve partners in the practice, but only one of them could actually be promoted. It turned out to be Dr Steve so Dr Caroline threw a plastic bedpan thing at her door and took to polishing her cheekbones. Dr Steve, whose main character trait is his height, was very pleased with himself until he had to go to a "partners' meeting" and not out with Dr Caroline and Dr Rana, the surgery's person of ethnic minority and dubious sexuality. (Often in drama, as in life, overly cheerful men are homosexual.) Edge of your seat stuff, I'm sure you'll agree.

There was one patient, however. Bernard, an elderly gent, had a flashback to World War Two on his rideable lawnmower. Now, had this been Casualty, he would have lost control of the machine and mown down his wife in a splatterfest of blood, but as it was, he just sat there as we shared his visions of Lancaster bombers and his pal Johnny getting killed by some Jerry nightfighter. It was all too much for poor Bernard, who eventually decided to see a counsellor for post-traumatic stress disorder. That's what daytime television does to you.

And for those of you interested, The British Lawnmower Museum in Southport (motto: Don't Let The Grass Grow Under Your Feet) houses a large collection of restored garden machinery and memorabilia, dating back to the invention of the lawnmower in the 1830s. It also boasts the largest toy lawnmower collection in the world, lawnmowers once owned by Diana Princess of Wales, Nicholas Parsons and Vanessa Feltz and a mower dating from before the time of Custer's Last Stand. Good to know that at the Battle Of Little Big Horn the grass was nice and neat.

Heartbreak Homes (BBC1) were just that. A bizarre programme, it followed the sad stories of people who had bought houses on the coast only to see their gardens, then their houses - and probably their lawnmowers - slip into the sea because of coastal erosion. While it was easy to feel sorry for the likes of George and Jean, a pair of retired bus drivers whose little bungalow was swallowed by the North Sea, it was more difficult to empathise with Terry and Janet who, in a stroke of staggering genius, built a house on really boggy ground. To their great surprise, it sank, though not before "tell-tale signs" - which is to say, cracks - appeared on the walls. The cracks were so huge, they were more tell-epic signs and a lesson not to build your house on marshland. Undeterred, Terry and Janet built another house right behind the old, sunken one, only this time with reinforced foundations. "You can build a house in the middle of the bleeding ocean if you get everything right", Terry insisted, still not quite having got it. There's no telling some people.

webTitle: Today's TV

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Strangers On A Train/Hilary And Jackie/An Ideal Husband
fields.body:
Strangers On A Train

(Alfred Hitchcock, 1951)

12.20pm, 6.15pm, Sky Cinema

Black-hearted thriller, with Hitchcock's tongue even more firmly in cheek than usual. The story, part-written by Raymond Chandler from Patricia Highsmith's novel, has tennis player Guy (Farley Granger) meeting apparently sane Bruno (Robert Walker, who was to die, aged 33, later that year), who suggests a murder-swap: he will top Guy's troublesome wife if Guy will reciprocate in the case of his father, the logic being that the police will never trace the killers. Some wonderfully wry scenes, including one of Hitch's nastiest murders, at the fairground.

Hilary And Jackie

(Anand Tucker, 1998)

8pm, FilmFour

A moving and passionate account of the intense struggle that was the life of Jacqueline du Pré, based on the book by the great cellist's siblings, Hilary and Piers. Tucker cleverly plays out the sisters' love-hate relationship from both their perspectives, centering on what at first appears an unforgivable betrayal. Emily Watson gives a virtuoso performance as the tempestuous, flawed genius and is beautifully supported by Rachel Griffiths as Hilary, David Morrisey as Hilary's husband Kiffer Finzi.

An Ideal Husband

(Oliver Parker, 1998)

8pm, Sky Premier

Rupert Everett is in his element as Lord Goring, the witty and debonair hero of Parker's entertaining adaptation of the Oscar Wilde play. Goring's life of extreme leisure - all dinner parties and idle chatter - is interrupted when he has to come to the aid of his stuffy friend Chiltern (Jeremy Northam): a ghost from his shady past (Julianne Moore's sparky, malignant Mrs Cheveley) having returned to threaten his political career. Wilde's debate on public and private virtue is still pertinent today, and if the direction is at times a little stodgy, the cast - including Cate Blanchett and Minnie Driver - more than makes up for it.

webTitle: A Country Diary

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Cheshire
fields.body:
Cheshire

By the end of August the swifts in our village, who had been with us since early May, had started the long journey south to their wintering grounds in Africa, and the autumn migration of our summer visitors was well under way. Up to the third week of September the local swallows were gathering on the telephone wires, with young ones still being fed by parents, obviously preparing for their own departure. By the end of the month the nest sites had been deserted and the birds had gone, following the swifts, with the dangerous journey over the Sahara ahead of them.

As I write these notes, in the first week of October, the house martin colony on the village hall is still a scene of frantic activity, so they are going to be later than usual leaving this year. Yesterday I counted 25 birds swooping down under the eaves still feeding young in 6 nests, and while in most of them faces were peering out of the entrance holes, voices continually calling to parents, in at least two the adult birds would disappear into the nest to pass on food. This would seem to indicate that there were still some very young chicks in the colony that will need plenty of attention before they are able to join the migration.

As the swifts, swallows and house martins disappear until spring next year, they are leaving behind them a well-stocked larder for the next influx of visitors - the winter thrushes - because the hawthorns around the village are loaded with berries, and any day now I expect the new arrivals to appear. They will have had to contend with some atrocious weather on the trip from eastern Europe, and won't find things much better here, so the least they deserve is a good food supply when they arrive.

webTitle: Prestige colleges hesitant on web degrees

fields.headline: Prestige colleges hesitant on web degrees
fields.trailText: Plans for the first national e-university, drawing together the cream of expertise at British institutions, are being unveiled today. The higher education funding council for England (HEFCE) hopes the £200m scheme can be up and running by 2002.
fields.body:
Plans for the first national e-university, drawing together the cream of expertise at British institutions, are being unveiled today. The higher education funding council for England (HEFCE) hopes the £200m scheme can be up and running by 2002.

But last night it was clear David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, still has to convince top universities to take part and lend prestige to his pet project. It is intended to mount web-based courses competing with larger corporate and virtual universities emerging in the US.

Initially the e-university will target postgraduates and professionals wanting to update their skills, but undergraduate degrees will follow. Students will obtain qualifications from exisiting universities that take part via the internet.

But the London School of Economics, which is involved in its own international e-learning links, was unlikely to take part, said Neil Gregory, head of research and project development. He said the e-university was an "opportunity to waste an awful lot of taxpayers' money". Some university "brand names" would appeal to overseas students but many would not. LSE has ventures with prestigous American institutions.

Oxford and Cambridge were interested but have adopted a "wait and see" attitude.

Tim O'Shea, master of Birkbeck College, London and a member of the e-university steering group, predicted the big names would want to get involved and could retain their own distinctive identity while getting financial support.

Building the e-university will be an extremely expensive and risky enterprise, a report for the funding councils by PriceWaterhouseCoopers indicates. Costs were orginally estimated at £120m over two years and the funding councils are counting on the enthusiasm of Mr Blunkett to secure financial backing for an initial four years.

Prof O'Shea said leading institutions would benefit from the technology developed by new universities. The investment would be huge but doing nothing would be be riskier, argues the report. If British universities did not do it, someone else would and traditional markets would evaporate.

Reflecting the urgency of the situation, the report suggests the e-U should be operating in 2002 - breakneck speed in university terms. Fees income is potentially huge. UK universities expect to take £560m in overseas student fees this year.

webTitle: Passnotes: Robert Kiley

fields.headline: No: 1737
fields.standfirst: Robert Kiley
fields.trailText: Robert Kiley
fields.body:
Age: 63.

Occupation: Newly appointed commissioner of transport for London.

Appearance: Hard-workin', hard- tawkin' Noo Yoiker. Not to be messed with.

Ah, I know about these American tough guys. Beneath that rough exterior lies a mushy wad of inner angst and confusion. He don't scare me. He should. Not only is he notoriously fearsome, but he also formerly held the most feared, the most terrifying, the most unnatural job known to man - he was the chief executive and chairman of New York's Metropolitan Transport Authority.

Saints preserve us! So he's certain to terrorise any rogue leaves away from our train tracks, and heaven help the foolhardy commuter who drives his car in the bus lane. Quite. After revamping and rescuing both New York and Berlin's public transport systems, this wise-cracking little toughie looks set to give Ann Widdecombe a run for her money in the hard lines and zero tolerance stakes.

And what tempts him over to our green and pleasant land? Apparently, he just couldn't resist Ken Livingstone's seductive plea to help him look after London's overcrowded bus routes, jammed tube lines, clogged river crossings, and all the rest of London's celebrated public transportation system - and who can blame him?

Of course, the prospect of earning more than £2m over four years is a mere sweetener. New York sarcasm doesn't suit you, my dear.

Do say: "Mr Kiley is one of the greatest experts on transportation." (Ken Livingstone).

Don't say: " An upstart American in charge of London's black cabs and double-decker buses? It's just not cricket!"

Not to be confused with: Robert Kilroy Silk, Kylie Minogue, Richard Kiel.

webTitle: Air France flies in face of BA

fields.headline: Air France flies in face of BA
fields.standfirst: Rival hails 14% increase in British passengers
fields.trailText: Air France yesterday cocked a snook at British Airways by announcing a 14% annual increase in passengers from Britain to destinations in France, one of the largest increases throughout its world network.
fields.body:
Air France yesterday cocked a snook at British Airways by announcing a 14% annual increase in passengers from Britain to destinations in France, one of the largest increases throughout its world network.

British traveller numbers have risen from 1.7m to just under 2m this year, largely because of the strong pound and a policy by the French carrier of opening routes from regional airports within the UK.

BA would not break down figures for individual countries for commercial reasons. It said, however, that passenger traffic between Britain and Europe had risen 0.4% in September compared to the same period last year, but there had been a 3.7% drop in capacity.

Marc Benedetti, Air France's UK general manager, said its increase was remarkable. "We are very pleased with the results which show that we are attracting new business and leisure passengers who are staying with us."

Air France figures show that the passenger take-off has occurred over the past five years. Since 1995, when the number of passengers flying to France was 900,000, there has been an increase of more than 70%.

Mr Benedetti said Air France had gradually been opening new routes from regional airports. The latest will be a daily service from Manchester to Lyon starting next month. He said the new schedules would serve the growing business and ski trade at France's second largest centre.

The company has just opened a service from Birmingham to Toulouse and another from Humberside to Paris opened last year. It also plans to introduce services from Aberdeen, Belfast and Bristol to Paris as soon as possible. But the expansion depends on how soon the fourth runway at Charles de Gaulle airport in Paris is ready. It is due to open next summer, which would free new slots.

According to Mr Benedetti, some of these would be used to expand the airline's services into Britain as well as other parts of Europe.

But Mr Benedetti stressed that the company could not be complacent. It would continue to face increased competition from Eurostar.

webTitle: Quit or be toppled, Mugabe is told

fields.headline: Quit or be toppled, Mugabe is told
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe's opposition leader is in high spirits after dodging arrest for treason on his return from South African visit
Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: After returning from South Africa and evading police who planned to arrest him on treason charges at the airport, Zimbabwe's opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, yesterday called on President Robert Mugabe to hold early elections or resign.
fields.body:
After returning from South Africa and evading police who planned to arrest him on treason charges at the airport, Zimbabwe's opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, yesterday called on President Robert Mugabe to hold early elections or resign.

"Mugabe's term as president lasts until 2002, but he no longer has the mandate of the people or their support," said Mr Tsvangirai, leader of the Movement for Democratic Change shortly after his arrival. "He is no longer legitimate. He should go back to the people and seek an early election, or he should resign. Otherwise he risks a popular uprising against him."

While Mr Tsvangirai kept the pressure on Mr Mugabe, the government increased its pressure on the MDC. Earlier yesterday, police arrested three MDC members of parliament on charges of inciting violence. There were angry protests after the arrests and police used teargas to disperse two gatherings of MDC supporters in central Harare. About 10 arrests were made.

Police had expected Mr Tsvangirai to return to Zimbabwe on a scheduled flight from Johannesburg and waited for him at Harare airport. But he entered the country by some other means, presumably a charter flight to a smaller airport. Upon arrival at his home, Mr Tsvangirai spoke with MDC officials and journalists.

Within minutes, he telephoned the police to tell them he was at home and could be arrested there. By early evening the police had still not come to pick him up. He was in high spirits after successfully slipping through the security net that police and intelligence services threw up around the airport.

Mr Mugabe's government has said that it intends to arrest him on treason charges because of remarks he made at a September 30 rally to mark the first anniversary of the MDC's founding. "We say to Mugabe, 'Please go peacefully. If you don't we will overthrow you violently'," Mr Tsvangirai said to a deafening roar of approval from more than 20,000 supporters. He quickly clarified his remarks, saying that he did not mean that the MDC would use violence, but that the people of Zimbabwe would rise up against continued abuses by Mr Mugabe and his Zanu-PF party.

"I said something unpalatable to Mugabe and to Zanu- PF, but I don't think it was illegal," Mr Tsvangirai said yesterday. "If the authorities think I have committed a crime, then I must face the due legal procedures. The people must maintain their cool. Zanu-PF is trying to provoke the people, so it will have an excuse to unleash more violence and repression."

Mr Tsvangirai said the MDC was committed to the rule of law and change by peaceful, constitutional and democratic means. He said Mr Mugabe "should be happy that he has a credible opposition that can contain the anger of the people against his misrule".

While in South Africa, Mr Tsvangirai said he met former president Nelson Mandela. "He still has immense influence. I asked him to try and encourage Mugabe to retire."

Mr Tsvangirai repeated his remarks that Mr Mugabe was "the Milosevic of Africa." He charged that he had ruined the economy, involved Zimbabwe in a disastrous war in the Congo and had thwarted democracy by rigging the parliamentary elections in June.

"The only difference between Yugoslavia and Zimbawe is that they are white and we are black. Our situations are the same," Mr Tsvangirai added.

webTitle: Body of girl, 17, found at cottage

fields.headline: Body of girl, 17, found at cottage
fields.trailText: A murder hunt was launched yesterday after the decomposed body of a teenage girl was found at an isolated cottage in Cornwall.
fields.body:
A murder hunt was launched yesterday after the decomposed body of a teenage girl was found at an isolated cottage in Cornwall.

Police sources said the body was believed to be that of Patricia Berriman, 17, who lived at the cottage with her boyfriend, Stanley Matthews.

It is understood that police searched the whitewashed cottage near Hatt in east Cornwall .

The body was found on Sunday evening in a bedroom. Police appealed for help in finding Mr Matthews after his car was found abandoned nearby.

Miss Berriman, a cleaner at the Rod and Line public house in Tideford, had not been seen since September 27.

Yesterday her parents, Alan and Pat, were at their detached pebble-dash house in Pillaton with police family liaison officers.

Karen Rafferty, of the Rod and Line pub, said: "She was just a really lovely girl, really sound, and she will be sadly missed. We can't believe what has happened."

Jacky Henry, sub-postmistress, said: "It is terrible to think of something like that happening so close. It is a very close-knit place, where everyone knows each other.

"When she was still at school she always used to come in here. She was always very polite."

A local councillor, Matthew McTaggart, said: "It is a very rural and very quiet area. I am shocked to hear this has happened.

Mr McTaggart added: "They are lovely people up here, and the whole community will be shocked."

Miss Berriman and her boyfriend are thought to have met when they worked at the China Fleet country club in Saltash, where Mr Matthews was a kitchen porter. They had been living at the rented cottage for five months.

Sergeant Alan Mobbs, of Devon and Cornwall police, said: "Following a call from a member of the public, police called at this isolated cottage where we found the body of a young woman."

Home Office pathologist Guyan Fernando was examining the body yesterday, but a formal identification is not expected for some time because of the decomposition.

It is understood that Miss Berriman had suffered head injuries.

Yesterday afternoon police arrested a 44-year-old man. He was detained shortly before 6pm and was taken to Charles Cross police station in Plymouth, Devon, for questioning.

webTitle: Straw urged to extradite Asian tycoons

fields.headline: Straw urged to extradite Asian tycoons
fields.standfirst: British based billionaires charged in India with accepting huge bribes in return for influencing former prime minister in arms scandal
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, was last night urged to extradite Britain's wealthiest Asian family, the Hindujas, to India after prosecutors there charged them with accepting huge bribes in the country's most notorious and long-running corruption scandal.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, was last night urged to extradite Britain's wealthiest Asian family, the Hindujas, to India after prosecutors there charged them with accepting huge bribes in the country's most notorious and long-running corruption scandal.

The brothers - Gopichand, Srichand, and Prakesh - were accused of accepting $10m (£7.1m) in commission from a Swedish arms manufacturer, Bofors, in return for using their considerable influence with the late Indian prime minister, Rajiv Gandhi, to secure an arms contract.

The bribes were allegedly paid into secret Swiss bank accounts.

The Hindujas, who entertained prime minister Tony Blair and his wife, Cherie, at their annual party last year, and helped bail out the failing Millennium Dome in Greenwich, south-east London, were first named in connection with the Bofors saga more than a decade ago.

But in December last year after a long battle, a federal court in Switzerland ruled that crucial bank documents relat ing to the scandal could be divulged to India's central bureau of investigation (CBI). The CBI formally charged the Hindujas in Delhi yesterday.

Speaking outside court, the bureau's special prosecutor, N Natrajan, claimed that the Hindujas had engaged in a criminal conspiracy.

He added: "They took commission and paid it into their accounts. They had three or four accounts, in which they hid the money," he said.

Asked whether the case against them was strong, he added: "Without evidence the CBI would not press charges."

Mr Natrajan last night said that he would ask Britain to consider extraditing the billionaire industrialists once the charges had been approved by the judge hearing the case, Ajit Bharihoke.

"Since we have an extradition treaty with Britain, once they are included ... all this will follow," he said. The judge will rule on November 20 whether the CBI's application is allowed.

In a statement yesterday, the Hindujas said that there was no evidence linking them to the deal and documents sent from Switzerland confirmed their innocence. It said that the law-abiding brothers had been treated in an unfair and unjust manner despite cooperating fully with the authorities in what had become a "highly politicised case."

The statement added: "The three Hinduja brothers are relieved that they are no longer at the mercy of the political pressures that have ruled the case for the past 13 years. As in the past they shall abide by the legal process."

In June 1998 Mr Straw approved Gopichand P Hinduja's application for British nationality.

He granted the family's patriarch, Srichand P Hinduja, a British passport as recently as April 1999. The third accused, Prakesh Hinduja, lives in Geneva.

The British based brothers preside over a £1.3bn oil and banking empire and are Britain's eighth wealthiest individuals.

Like his predecessor but one, Margaret Thatcher, Mr Blair attended the Hinduja's inter-faith dinner last November. However the then Indian high commissioner in London, Lalit Mansingh, who is now his country's foreign minister, was instructed to stay away from the festivities.

The brothers also gave £6m to sponsor the spirit zone at the dome following talks with Peter Mandelson.

Since the saga burst into the public domain in the late eighties, the Hindujas have refused to cooperate with prosecutors investigating the Bofors deal, which saw the Swedish firm back in 1986 triumph in its battle with a rival French company to supply 400 howitzer 155mm field guns to the Indian army.

Two weeks ago - in the face of documentation - they ad mitted a business association with AB Bofors.

But they said that the $10m had nothing to do with the howitzer contract.

Detectives investigating the Hindujas' financial affairs travelled to Geneva in June to request more documents.

Last October Rajiv Gandhi was posthumously charged in connection with the scandal, with several key members of his inner circle.

They include an Italian businessman, Ottavio Quattrocchi, Bofors agent Win Chadha, and India's then defence secretary, S K Bhatnagar.

webTitle: Extremist settlers accused of torture

fields.headline: Extremist settlers accused of torture
fields.standfirst:
Primordial hatred leads to brutality between tribes
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: In life, Isaam Joda was a tall, strapping man, but when they lifted the sheet from his body at the morgue yesterday, doctors revealed a shocking sight.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in Ramallah, West Bank
fields.body:
In life, Isaam Joda was a tall, strapping man, but when they lifted the sheet from his body at the morgue yesterday, doctors revealed a shocking sight.

Amid a welter of blood, cuts and bruises, the soft skin of his inner arms and left thigh was scarred by pink ovals of seared flesh. A doctor peeled back his right eyelid, pointing to a black mark caused, he said, by a cigarette.

According to Bassem Rimawi, director of emergency services at Ramallah's main hospital, Joda was tortured and beaten to death. He believed the wounds on the dead man's arms were caused by a hot iron.

The account of torture is repeated by Joda's neighbours in the West Bank village of Um Safa, north-west of Ramallah, and by Palestinian human rights workers.

They say Joda was beaten to death by extremist Jews from the West Bank settlement of Halmish. They accuse Israeli security forces of handing Joda over to the settlers, knowing his life would be in danger.

Israel categorically rejects the charge. "This is a lie like so many lies. This is part of the cynical behaviour of the Palestinian side," said Colonel Gal Hirsh, who commands Israeli forces in the Ramallah area. "I asked the Palestinians to join us and to make a combined investigation, and to send the body to one of our pathologists to check whether their claims are right.

"But they did not allow us to see the body. They captured it and took it to Ramallah."

If the allegations are confirmed, then Joda's death is part of a disturbing new trend to emerge after nearly two weeks of violence in the West Bank and Gaza, as well as within the borders of Israel proper.

During the past few days, there has been a spate of ugly attacks: Jews stoning Palestinian motorists, Palestinians firing on isolated Jewish settlements in the West Bank, beatings and stabbings. This is hatred at its most primordial: Jew killing Arab and Arab killing Jew.

The Palestinian allegations go to the heart of the angry exchanges between the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat. Mr Barak has demanded an immediate end to the violence; Mr Arafat says such a request is insulting. Instead, he is asking for an international investigation into the deaths of nearly 90 people, almost all Palestinians, in the recent violence.

The body of Joda, a house painter in his late 30s, was discovered yesterday morning and taken to the morgue at Ramallah's main hospital.

He had last been seen driving near Halmish, on his way to a nearby cemetery where he had work painting the gates. But when he passed a jeep of Israeli soldiers on patrol, he sped away because his battered Fiat was carrying yellow Israeli plates, a serious security offence for a West Bank resident, witnesses reported.

Joda was detained. But after his capture, Palestinians say he was turned over to Jewish civilians living in Halmish. "I believe that after he was captured by soldiers he was put in the settlement and the settlers spent the whole night enjoying him," Dr Rimawi said.

Col Hirsh denied the account, saying that his troops had no contact with Joda and that they had been under orders to keep a low profile during the Yom Kippur holiday.

He said Joda died when his vehicle overturned. "The man was driving too fast and he was probably smashed up by the impact of the accident," he said. "As you know, it was Yom Kippur and no Jewish person or Israeli would have been on the roads at that time."

However, the doctor's account is given more credibility by the admission to the hospital of an injured teenager, Mohammed Tamimi from Nabi Salih village, who told medical staff he was captured by the settlers at Halmish and badly beaten.

Such attacks appear part of a new phase in the violence. Fired by their leaders' angry rhetoric and the horrific casualties of recent days, people are answering the call of ancient tribal loyalties.

"I live in the same area," Dr Rimawi said. "I never thought of the settlers as prejudiced, but since the beginning of this intifada their attitude is changing. They are stoning our cars every day when we cross the road."

In Nazareth, in the heart of Israel, hundreds of Jewish extremists attacked an Israeli Arab neighbourhood overnight. When the police arrived they fired rubber bullets at the local Arabs - not their assailants, killing two men.

"What is happening in Nazareth today is a pogrom, bearing all the hallmarks which were well known to Jews in tsarist Russia, that is collusion between the racist attackers and police," said Gush Shalom, from an Israeli peace organisation.

Apart from Joda, the Palestinian health ministry reported the death of another man last night, shot in the head, apparently by settlers near Ramallah. A 70-year-old Nablus man was also reported beaten by settlers.

A Palestinian human rights organisation yesterday accused the Israeli army of colluding with extremist Jews carrying out attacks on Palestinians and Israeli Arabs. Law, the Palestinian society for the protection of human rights and the environment, said three Palestinian men had been killed by settlers in the past two days. The murders were part of a wave of terror enveloping Palestinians, it said.

"For the past couple of days, settlers attacked Palestinian citizens and their property and their homes. They used firearms in their attacks while the occupation army turned a blind eye to their aggressive acts," Law said in a statement.

The attacks were carried out in the old city of Jerusalem and nearby villages and refugee camps, as well as near the West Bank city of Hebron, a regular point of friction because of the Jewish island that sits in the middle of a large and crowded Palestinian city.

They also occurred within sight of the Israeli army. "Law views the bloody homicides that the occupation army commits against Palestinian civilians as opening the doors for settlers and extreme racists to commit more crimes and cause more bloodshed," the organisation said.

webTitle: Wanted: one sleaze-buster

fields.headline: Wanted: one sleaze-buster
fields.trailText: Wanted by Whitehall: A man or woman of impeccable integrity with an honest record and definitely no sleazy secrets to advise Tony Blair on the best way of keeping government and politics clean in Britain for the next three years.
fields.body:
Wanted by Whitehall: A man or woman of impeccable integrity with an honest record and definitely no sleazy secrets to advise Tony Blair on the best way of keeping government and politics clean in Britain for the next three years.

The rewards: No government car, no lavish expense account, no expensive accommodation and no perks. A one-day fee of £500 for each day's work. Workload unlikely to be more than a couple of days a week.

The government is formulating its first advertisement to find the cleanest person in the United Kingdom to replace Lord Neill, the chairman of the committee on standards in public life. The post previously filled by a law lord, Lord Nolan, and a leading QC, Lord Neill, is to be thrown open as part of a Whitehall drive to open top jobs to competition.

The decision to advertise the post - originally in the gift of the prime minister of the day - comes after advice from Dame Rennie Fritchie, commissioner for public appointments. She recommended that advisory appointments - especially those independent of government - be advertised. As well as the chairman, the committee intend to advertise vacancies for two other members who are due to retire.

Whitehall was still working yesterday on the text of new advertisement to appear in the national press later this month - they also have to set up an appointments board equally full of the cleanest " great and good" to judge the character and probity of the applicants.

The committee, whose members except for MPs and people holding public jobs get £180 a day, was originally set up by John Major after the cash for questions scandal involving ex Tory minister Neil Hamilton and Harrods owner, Mohamed Al Fayed. The first appointee, Lord Nolan, created the tough rules aimed at preventing sleaze in parliament and forcing MPs to declare incomes and contracts from parliamentary consultancies.

His successor, Lord Neill, immediately ran into controversy when he advised Tony Blair to hand back the £1m donation from Formula One promoter Bernie Ecclestone after his business received an exemption from a ban on cigarette advertising and sponsorship.

Lord Neill himself became embroiled in a row over "conflict of interest" when it emerged he had been advising Dame Shirley Porter, the controversial Westminster council leader, on her appeal against a £31 million surcharge over the " homes for votes " scandal. He immediately ended advising her over arcane points of local government law - though she went on to win her appeal which is now being challenged in the House of Lords.

webTitle: Why motorised scooters may fail their road test

fields.headline: Why motorised scooters may fail their road test
fields.trailText: Some of Britain's finest legal minds were asked to ponder the status of motorised scooters yesterday thanks to a bizarre police chase likened to the Keystone Cops.
fields.body:
Some of Britain's finest legal minds were asked to ponder the status of motorised scooters yesterday thanks to a bizarre police chase likened to the Keystone Cops.

Sitting at the high court in London, Lord Justice Pill, with Mr Justice Bell, suggested the public may need more protection from the Go-Ped craze because a loophole in the law had allowed their uncontrolled use.

The case followed a chase through Harrogate, North Yorkshire, which ended in the arrest of 38-year-old restaurateur, Michael Saddington, on charges of driving while disqualified.

As he tried out a Go-Ped belonging to one of his staff - similar in style to the popular folding aluminium scooters, but larger and fitted with a small petrol engine - Mr Saddington heard police sirens.

"It was a bit like the Keystone Cops actually. When the siren was going I thought: 'I wonder where they are going,' expecting them to whoosh straight past. But it turned out they were chasing me," he said outside the court.

Yesterday's test case was brought by the chief constable of North Yorkshire against a Harrogate magistrates court decision last February that Go-Peds were not motor vehicles.

The magistrates had cleared Mr Saddington, from Middlesbrough, of driving a motor vehicle while disqualified and driving without insurance.

The judges said the court would need time to consider whether Go-Peds, which are capable of speeds up to 20mph, could be classified as motor vehicles as a possible answer to the difficulties they posed.

Geraldine Kelly, appearing for the police, said the status of the scooters, which are powered by a 22.5cc two-stroke direct drive engine, was causing confusion and guidance was being sought from the court.

She urged the judges to rule that they should be classified as motor vehicles so their use could be controlled in the interests of public safety.

Richard Reed, appearing for Mr Saddington, said: "This is not a motor vehicle and a clear message needs to be sent out that these are not to be used on the road - a message clearly spelt out by the manufacturer and retailer."

After the hearing, Mr Saddington, described how he had borrowed a Go-Ped. He said he was spotted by police after he failed to stop at traffic lights. He was chased by a police car until he picked up his machine and went into a pub, where he was questioned and officers discovered he was disqualified from driving.

When he appeared before magistrates, he pleaded guilty to failing to stop at the lights and failing to stop for the police.

He was found guilty of failing to wear protective headgear, but was cleared of driving a motor vehicle while disqualified and with no insurance. He was fined £275, including costs.

In court, Ms Kelly argued that both a driving licence and insurance should be required for Go-Ped drivers as they could properly be classified as motor vehicles under the provisions of the 1988 Road Traffic Act.

Lord Justice Pill said: "This all shows the dangers of putting a Go-Ped on a public road. That is the very kind of machine which the public needs protection against."

The case continues.

The magistrates had cleared Mr Saddington, from Middlesbrough, of driving a motor vehicle while disqualified and driving without insurance. The judges said the court would need time to consider whether Go-Peds, which are capable of speeds up to 20mph, could be classified as motor vehicles as a possible answer to the difficulties they posed. Geraldine Kelly, appearing for the police, said the status of the scooters, which are powered by a 22.5cc two-stroke direct drive engine, was causing confusion and guidance was being sought from the court. She urged the judges to rule that they should be classified as motor vehicles so their use could be controlled in the interests of public safety. Richard Reed, appearing for Mr Saddington, said: "This is not a motor vehicle and a clear message needs to be sent out that these are not to be used on the road - a message clearly spelt out by the manufacturer and retailer." After the hearing, Mr Saddington, described how he had borrowed a Go-Ped. He said he was spotted by police after he failed to stop at traffic lights. He was chased by a police car until he picked up his machine and went into a pub, where he was questioned and officers discovered he was disqualified from driving. When he appeared before magistrates, he pleaded guilty to failing to stop at the lights and failing to stop for the police. He was found guilty of failing to wear protective headgear, but was cleared of driving a motor vehicle while disqualified and with no insurance. He was fined £275, including costs. In court, Ms Kelly argued that both a driving licence and insurance should be required for Go-Ped drivers as they could properly be classified as motor vehicles under the provisions of the 1988 Road Traffic Act. Lord Justice Pill said: "This all shows the dangers of putting a Go-Ped on a public road. That is the very kind of machine which the public needs protection against." The case continues.

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Petrol pioneer changes hands
fields.body:
Petrol pioneer changes hands

Carless Refining and Marketing, the oil company founded in 1859 and credited with coining the word "petrol", is changing hands. Repsol-YPF, the Spanish oil group, yesterday announced it is selling Carless to Petrochem UK for an undisclosed sum.

Harwich-based Carless is one of the UK's biggest refiners of specialist hydrocarbons, with a turnover of about £100m. Its products include petrochemical feedstocks and speciality fuels.

New Asda line under scrutiny

Asda, owned by Wal-Mart, yesterday introduced a new line of budget products with some items to be sold below cost price.

The range of "SmartPrice" products, already available in Wal-Mart's German stores, caused a stir when the German cartel office threatened to fine the US retailer last month for each item sold at an artificially low price.

The German competition authority said the chain's aggressive low price tactics were driving out competition. A report from Britain's competition commission is similarly expected to criticise the practice of selling below cost.

Grid accepts Ofgem prices

Britain's monopoly bulk electricity carrier, National Grid, said yesterday that it had decided to accept the price regime proposals for the next five years by Ofgem, the electricity industry regulator.

Last month Ofgem relaxed its final proposals from provisional ones set out in June, a move which sent the group's share price surging.

It set out price rises for the asset side of the business which will be limited to inflation minus 1.5 percentage points (RPI-1.5) a year in 2002-2005, with no cut in the first year 2001-2002. In June it proposed a year one cut of 0-6%, and RPI-3 for each of the remaining four years.

Ebookers buys UK travel firm

European online travel company ebookers.com said yesterday that it planned to buy British travel company Flightbookers for $15m (£10m).

Ebookers said that the $15m price tag was set in a call option to acquire Flightbookers agreed at the time of its November 1999 initial public offering. The agreement is subject to approval by the shareholders.

Sportsworld Media excels

Sportsworld Media Group said its current year has started strongly and trading is in line with the board's expectations.

The firm reported results for the year to June 30 with full year pre-tax profit - before amortisation of goodwill and including minority contributions - of £5.59m, up from £1.77m.

BBC wins right to own name

The BBC has won the right to the web domain name www.bbcnews.com. An arbitrator acting for the World Intellectual Property Organisation ruled that the name must be transferred from its holder, a Belize-registered business.

webTitle: Vodafone eyes Irish market

fields.headline: Vodafone eyes Irish market
fields.trailText: Vodafone is in discussions which could see it taking a stake in the Irish mobile phone market, filling in another piece of its jigsaw of assets across Europe.
fields.body:
Vodafone is in discussions which could see it taking a stake in the Irish mobile phone market, filling in another piece of its jigsaw of assets across Europe.

The company has held initial talks with Eircom, the former state-owned telecoms business, about either taking a stake in, or buying outright, its mobile network, Eircell. Analysts have put a value on the business of about £2.4bn.

Eircell has 1.1m subscribers and is the largest operator in the country. Esat Digifone, owned by Telenor of Norway and BT, is the only other network - although a third licence has been awarded to a consortium of US company Western Wireless and Ireland's RD Communications.

The Irish market is relatively small but is one of the fastest growing in Europe. Negotiations are understood still to be at an early stage with a result unlikely to be reached for some weeks.

It is uncertain what shape the deal would take although Vodafone's stated position is to take controlling stakes in its various networks worldwide and, where possible, full ownership. Vodafone though is not thought to be the only potential bidder for the business.

Shares in Eircom, formally known as Telecom Eireann, yesterday climbed 12% to €2.75 (£1.65) on the chance of a deal materialising.

A partial sale would give Eircom a partner throughout Europe. Its ambitions to expand were made clear when it bid unsuccessfully for a third generation licence in Britain. Vodafone declined to comment.

webTitle: Carlton bids £400m for horseracing rights

fields.headline: Carlton bids £400m for horseracing rights
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Carlton Communications has made a £400m offer for the broadcasting rights to British horseracing.
fields.body:
Carlton Communications has made a £400m offer for the broadcasting rights to British horseracing.

The late bid tops the £320m offer from Arena Leisure, the quoted company which owns and operates six racecourses as well as an online betting business.

Carlton has written to all 59 tracks with details of its offer for the television, interactive and internet rights over 10 years. The offer includes a guaranteed payment of £350m and £50m set aside for marketing.

In addition, Carlton has offered to split all profits 50-50 with the racecourses, which the company has estimated would bring the total figure over the 10-year period closer to £530m.

The offer is expected to unsettle Arena's hopes that it would move into an exclusive period of negotiations this week.

Carlton is hoping to leverage its combination of free-to-air TV through its ownership of several ITV franchises and of pay-TV through its half share in ONdigital. It is also likely to sell some of the rights on to the BBC and Channel 4 as well as setting up a dedicated racing channel.

The racing channel would replace the existing subscription only service and is likely to be made available to other platforms including Sky.

In the letter to race tracks, Carlton chief executive Gerry Murphy has also sketched out plans for an additional free racing channel.

"There is no doubt that racing is a hugely valuable asset," said one insider close to Carlton. "Interactivity is where racing really comes into its own because people want to look at form and the going and, of course, to bet online."

webTitle: Snook shares his Orange

fields.headline: Snook shares his Orange
fields.standfirst: Friends deny chief executive is being elbowed aside by France Telecom
fields.trailText: Hans Snook, chief executive of mobile phone company Orange, is set to make way for a French executive installed by the group's new owner France Telecom.
fields.body:
Hans Snook, chief executive of mobile phone company Orange, is set to make way for a French executive installed by the group's new owner France Telecom.

Mr Snook, who is closely identified with the Orange brand in Britain, is to become executive chairman of the enlarged group with Jean-François Pontal taking over as chief executive. Mr Pontal is expected to take up day-to-day running of the business with Mr Snook concentrating on broader strategic issues.

Advisers to Mr Snook said it made sense to have someone from within France Telecom who could oversee the integration of the existing Orange business with the mobile assets of the parent company.

An adviser was keen to stress that Mr Snook was in no way being marginalised. "The fact of the matter is that Hans had put a very strong management team into Orange and spent more and more time standing back, putting across the story and thinking about things such as new alliances. That will continue."

Mr Snook, he added, had not expected the impending change in management but was comfortable with the moves.

Mr Pontal was previously in charge of marketing for France Telecom's mobile business.

The management reshuffle had been scheduled for announcement toward the end of the month although that may now be brought forward. France Telecom chairman and chief executive Michel Bon had become chairman of Orange after the acquisition.

France Telecom is hoping to list Orange back on the stock market by the end of the year and has mandated Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, Morgan Stanley and Société Générale to handle the flotation.

It will float up to 15% of the business, which is likely to be worth some £60bn.

In Britain, Orange now has 8.3m subscribers putting it close to the country's second largest network, BT Cellnet. The enlarged group includes France Telecom's mobile assets, chiefly Itineris, its domestic network.

It will be Europe's largest mobile phone group behind Vodafone, with 30m subscribers and other interests in Italy and Germany.

Mr Snook, one of Britain's more eccentric business figures, made it clear during the company's brief ownership by Vodafone that he would quit if he did not approve of the eventual buyer or if there were no guarantee of the business being floated back on the market.

Those wishes appeared to come true when France Telecom paid £31bn for the company in May and said at the time it was keen for Mr Snook and his team to retain management control.

The business was bought by German telecoms and engineering business Mannesmann last year which was in turn bought by Vodafone in a bitterly hostile takeover.

It remains uncertain whether the changes to the management structure will affect Graham Howe, deputy chief executive and finance director of Orange whom the group had been keen to portray as part of a double act with Mr Snook.

webTitle: Pressure mounts on troubled Tomkins boss

fields.headline: Pressure mounts on troubled Tomkins boss
fields.trailText: A leading shareholder at engineering group Tomkins last night said investigations into alleged financial irregularities needed to be "dealt with" and vindicated its moves to shake up the company's boardroom.
fields.body:
A leading shareholder at engineering group Tomkins last night said investigations into alleged financial irregularities needed to be "dealt with" and vindicated its moves to shake up the company's boardroom.

Hermes Pension Management, which controls 5% of Tomkins, believes its campaign for Greg Hutchings to split the role of chairman and chief executive and bring in new independent non-executive directors such as Sir Brian Pitman has been justified.

Peter Butler, a director at Hermes, said: "This highlights the importance of strong non-executive directors. With those in place we can be confident that any statement [on board irregularities] will be final and any appropriate action needed will be taken."

Shares in Tomkins fell 3p to 166p yesterday after the company put out a formal notice confirming an inquiry into the perks and expenses of chief executive Mr Hutchings, who was paid £1.45m last year.

Mr Hutchings' future now looks precarious with one well-placed source saying only: "He has a better chance of survival than Milosovic."

The company said: "Follow ing recent press speculation and allegations relating to certain board practices at Tomkins, the chairman, David Newlands, can confirm that a full review of both historic and current practices is now underway."

The statement added: "This review will be completed as soon as possible."

Arthur Andersen, the company's auditor has been asked to look at allegations which include accusations that Mr Hutchings' wife and housekeeper both appeared on the company payroll in the past.

The auditor is also understood to be looking into donations - £40,000 annually - to a charity, United Response, run by a friend, and the use of four jets owned by Tomkins but leased to a Farnborough-based operator.

Hermes said it was anxious the investigation was dealt with as soon as possible. "None of this is doing any good for shareholder value but it clearly needs to be dealt with," said Mr Butler.

In the 1980s and 1990s, Hutchings was the driving force behind the growth of Tomkins, whose businesses include making windscreen wipers, handcuffs, handguns and shoes.

webTitle: Yom Kippur memories create sombre mood

fields.headline: Yom Kippur memories create sombre mood
fields.standfirst:
Israeli Jews Fears for future as present unravels
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Twenty-seven years after the last real war for Israel's survival, Jews marked the Day of Atonement, or Yom Kippur, in especially sombre mood yesterday, contemplating the death of the peace process and the prospect of 52 years of co-existence with Israeli Arabs unravelling.
fields.body:
Twenty-seven years after the last real war for Israel's survival, Jews marked the Day of Atonement, or Yom Kippur, in especially sombre mood yesterday, contemplating the death of the peace process and the prospect of 52 years of co-existence with Israeli Arabs unravelling.

Throughout yesterday, the trauma of those memories sat uncomfortably close, recalled with the order by the army chaplain for serving soldiers to forgo the obligatory fast to keep their strength up for battle, and by the decision of Is rael radio to broadcast bulletins on a day normally dedicated to silence and contemplation. The streets were deserted, with cars under a customary Yom Kippur ban.

It seemed unimaginable that just two weeks ago Israeli Jews were gambling at the casino in Palestinian-ruled Jericho or spending their sabbaths on shopping trips to the West Bank. Their frustration at the rapid change of events, and their feelings of powerlessness, came bubbling to the surface.

"What is going on here?" Sever Plotzer wrote in the newspaper Yediot Ahronot. "How does all that sit with the outburst of the horrible hatred that flooded the territories and the Arab sector?

"Where did we make the wrong assumption? Where was this concealed so that we did not see it?"

At a relatively liberal synagogue in Jerusalem, patronised by English-speaking Jews, one rabbi ushered in Yom Kippur on Sunday night by declaring: "All ideologies from Naziism to Islamism [sic] are the same." He then went on to disparage Palestinians, adding: "They focus on God too much."

Elsewhere in Jerusalem, wall placards proclaimed: "Kahane was right." The late extremist rabbi Meir Kahane called for the expulsion of all Arabs from the biblical promised land.

At a service at the Hebrew Union College, the flagship of the reform movement, the rabbi was more conciliatory. "Israel cannot call itself a Jewish state until all Arabs are treated equally," he said. "No matter what your political views, we can all agree what has happened is terrible."

However, many Israelis are beginning to believe that terrible or not, there is no way they can return to their earlier lives. In a poll in Yediot Ahronot, 74% of respondents said they saw Israeli Arabs as traitors.

webTitle: Mbeki accused of hypocrisy over Aids

fields.headline: Mbeki accused of hypocrisy over Aids
fields.standfirst: MPs given the anti-HIV drugs denied to South African poor
fields.trailText: South Africa's health minister, Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, has admitted that while her government refuses to prescribe anti-Aids drugs to people infected with HIV, members of parliament receive the treatments at public expense.
fields.body:
South Africa's health minister, Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, has admitted that while her government refuses to prescribe anti-Aids drugs to people infected with HIV, members of parliament receive the treatments at public expense.

The opposition has accused President Thabo Mbeki of gross hypocrisy because the government has told doctors that it it is illegal to provide anti-retroviral drugs to rape victims and pregnant women as a preventative measure, but the parliamentary health scheme specifically offers treatment in both cases.

Last week, the health authorities ordered one charity to stop providing AZT and other drugs to rape victims on the grounds that they have not been approved for such use.

The revelations will add to the surge of criticism Mr Mbeki has brought on himself by his Aids policies and his controversial questioning of the bulk of scientific opinion that HIV causes the disease.

The president has been attacked by South Africa's medical establishment, the trade union movement and the Anglican church, which recently called his Aids policy a crime against humanity comparable to apartheid.

The parliamentary medical scheme - which serves 2,000 MPs and judges - includes an option called the "aid for Aids" plan, which provides anti-HIV drugs up to the value of £4,000 for, among others, rape victims and pregnant women. The hope is to prevent mother to child transmission. So far, 68 MPs have signed up for the option.

The South African government has repeatedly justified its refusal to provide similar treatment in public hospitals, on the grounds that there is no evidence that the drug works in those cases, and because of the cost. Although AZT and other anti-Aids drugs are registered in South Africa, they have not been officially approved for use in preventing the transmission of HIV after a rape or by pregnant women.

Mr Mbeki has previously written to the leader of the official opposition, Tony Leon, accusing him of "blatant defiance of the law" for advocating that doctors prescribe anti-retroviral drugs in such cases. The president said that if this were to happen, the government would have to "take the necessary action to stop what would have been illegal behaviour".

Mr Leon said in a statement that while Mr Mbeki "plays with the lives of South Africans" by casting doubt on the causes of Aids, he and his fellow members of government enjoy "Rolls-Royce" Aids treatments.

"This government is clearly willing to take action on Aids only when the crisis has direct implications for its own members," Mr Leon said. "The needs of the rest of the country are averted with appeals to mythical African solutions, while members of government enjoy the best treatments the world has to offer."

Mrs Tshabalala-Msimang has defended the apparent discrepancy in policy by saying that the parliamentary health scheme is a matter for the private sector.

"MPs are members of the medical aid scheme, no different from people who belong to other medical aid schemes," she said. "AZT is available out there in the private sector. In the public sector it is not, because we cannot afford it. That is the truth of the matter." But she was immediately accused of misleading the public, because last week the authorities ordered a charity , the Greater Nelspruit Rape Intervention Project, to stop providing AZT and another drug, 3TC, to rape victims because "it was not in accordance with government policy". The project supplies anti-retroviral drugs to 50 women and children each month.

Its coordinator, Barbara Kenyon, denounced the order. "It's an outrage. If you are rich and sitting in government you can get life-saving medication, but if you are poor and living in rural Mpumalanga, then you are denied it," she said.

Mr Mbeki has previously written to the leader of the official opposition, Tony Leon, accusing him of "blatant defiance of the law" for advocating that doctors prescribe anti-retroviral drugs in such cases. The president said that if this were to happen, the government would have to "take the necessary action to stop what would have been illegal behaviour". Mr Leon said in a statement that while Mr Mbeki "plays with the lives of South Africans" by casting doubt on the causes of Aids, he and his fellow members of government enjoy "Rolls-Royce" Aids treatments. "This government is clearly willing to take action on Aids only when the crisis has direct implications for its own members," Mr Leon said. "The needs of the rest of the country are averted with appeals to mythical African solutions, while members of government enjoy the best treatments the world has to offer." Mrs Tshabalala-Msimang has defended the apparent discrepancy in policy by saying that the parliamentary health scheme is a matter for the private sector. "MPs are members of the medical aid scheme, no different from people who belong to other medical aid schemes," she said. "AZT is available out there in the private sector. In the public sector it is not, because we cannot afford it. That is the truth of the matter." But she was immediately accused of misleading the public, because last week the authorities ordered a charity , the Greater Nelspruit Rape Intervention Project, to stop providing AZT and another drug, 3TC, to rape victims because "it was not in accordance with government policy". The project supplies anti-retroviral drugs to 50 women and children each month. Its coordinator, Barbara Kenyon, denounced the order. "It's an outrage. If you are rich and sitting in government you can get life-saving medication, but if you are poor and living in rural Mpumalanga, then you are denied it," she said.

webTitle: New advice for women and youth

fields.headline: New advice for women and youth
fields.trailText: The government was last night embroiled in fresh controversy over a series of initiatives designed to help young people and women.
fields.body:
The government was last night embroiled in fresh controversy over a series of initiatives designed to help young people and women.

Within hours of Baroness Jay, the minister for women, unveiling an advice magazine, Yvette Cooper, minister for public health, was forced to correct misleading media accounts of an initiative aimed at curbing teenage pregnancies.

Baroness Jay's project, a 64-page publication called Voices, is aimed at "combining information and inspirational stories women can use to make the most of their lives". About 190,000 copies will be distributed via libraries, local authorities, the internet and with copies of Good Housekeeping.

The magazine will cover issues as diverse as health screening, setting up small businesses, handling money and learning to manage IT systems. The useful, often technical, information sits uneasily with its breezy style. The Mums Matter page starts: "Of all the jobs a woman takes on in her life, motherhood is considered by many to be by far the most important and rewarding." It goes on to explain the importance of self-esteem when staying at home to care for children before suggesting that, if they enjoy it, they might think about moving into child care as a career.

Coincidentally, yesterday there were reports that health ministers are spending £2m on a Just Say No or an It's OK to be a Virgin campaign. It forced Ms Cooper to say she had rejected that tack as counter-productive.

"Just Say No just does not work. It is patronising and ineffective and the wrong thing to do," she said. "That is why this will be a straight-forward campaign which gives teenagers the facts and is aimed as much at boys as at girls."

Labour's concern to tackle social exclusion has made ministers aware that teenage boys are as vulnerable and often less well informed than girls. Under the slogan Sex, Are you Thinking About It Enough? they will be told about everything from contraception, unprotected sex, awkward situations and peer pressure.

The perils of offering government advice on personal conduct were underlined yesterday by reaction to the advice against giving money to beggars. Shelter, Centrepoint, Crisis and the National Homeless Alliance warned that "over-simplifying the issue could backfire on the most vulnerable".

The government faces a third defeat on its efforts to equalise the age of consent for gay teenagers at 16, the former Tory cabinet member, Baroness Young warned last night.

webTitle: Forbidden film pierces Serbs' fog of denial

fields.headline: Forbidden film pierces Serbs' fog of denial
fields.standfirst:
Less room to hide for men who committed atrocities
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The guards outside 119 Blagoja Parovica were edgier than usual yesterday. Only the yelping of dogs broke the stillness. The cul-de-sac of fancy houses in the west Belgrade suburb of Banovo Brdo is home to General Ratko Mladic who since retiring has kept a surprisingly low profile for someone with such a high estimate of his own prowess.
fields.body:
The guards outside 119 Blagoja Parovica were edgier than usual yesterday. Only the yelping of dogs broke the stillness. The cul-de-sac of fancy houses in the west Belgrade suburb of Banovo Brdo is home to General Ratko Mladic who since retiring has kept a surprisingly low profile for someone with such a high estimate of his own prowess.

"He is not here. He doesn't want to see you. Leave," said one of the plainclothes armed guards. A Belgrade television station has just given Gen Mladic a new reason to find a bolthole. For the past two days it has broadcast a documentary showing shooting, shelling and heaps of executed Muslim civilians.

In silence the camera pans over twisted limbs and contorted, frozen faces. Little commentary is provided, but little is needed: all Serbia knows that Gen Mladic, now 57, was in command of Serb forces during their ethnic cleansing of Bosnia in the early 1990s.

The film is a rush job, the editing patchy, the pictures often grainy. Charting the rise of Serbia's political leader Slobodan Milosevic and his Balkan adventures, it uses archive material long familiar to western viewers.

But in Serbia, never before have such images been seen. According to the state media that dominated the airwaves for the past decade, Serbs were not aggressors but victims in the wars in Croatia, Bosnia and Kosovo. Those indicted for war crimes by the international criminal tribunal in the Hague were falsely accused by a partisan west.

The decision by the independent television station Studio B to compile and broadcast the montage of news footage has electrified the country. Four days after the fall of Mr Milosevic, the blanket of denial has been ripped away.

Serbia's four dozen suspected war criminals suddenly feel exposed and vulnerable. If the nation finds time among its other concerns to start soul searching, they are in trouble.

Whether they flee could depend on the outcome of the debate sparked the documentary. President Vojislav Kostunica opposes extraditing citizens to the Hague but momentum is picking up for trials to be held in Serbia.

The No 41 bus from Banjica to downtown Belgrade was packed when two pensioners started discussing the documentary: a travesty, lies and propaganda to demonise patriots, they agreed.

It took a few seconds for the three teenagers sitting opposite to pipe up in the film's defence: "It's true, we all know it's true. Terrible things were done in our name," said Stanislav, 17, a music student. Backed up his friends Jelena and Miryana, he said it was time to confront the past.

Other passengers pitched in and the arguments raged until the final stop. "It's always old people who deny what happened," said Jelena.

The two smartly dressed women in the Sports Cafe were not old. Journalists in their late 20s, they too had seen the programme. "Garbage. Just the sort of pukey stuff the west would like," said one.

"Wars are about people killing each other. Dead Muslims are something we knew already. There's nothing new in that. Serbs fought to defend their homes." Neither woman would give her name.

Behind them a wall of televisions flickered with motor racing, football and models striding down a catwalk. Showing Studio B was bad for business, said the barman. "People come here to forget all that stuff."

Not so Marina Antic and Radovan Radivojevic, both 21. Hunched over espressos, they agreed that what happened in Bosnia was attempted genocide. "We didn't have to see the bodies to know it." But it was too soon to sift fact from myth. "Right now we're preoccupied with the economic situation. That and the fear Milosevic might return," Ms Antic said.

Mirko Lukovic, an estate agent, reckoned he knew all about the wars until the documentary showed the pounding of the beautiful Croatian town of Dubrovnik in 1991. "They used ships. Can you believe it?"

As awareness spreads in the Serb heartland, war crimes investigators go on forensically combing grave sites in Croatia, Bosnia and Kosovo.

Each grim discovery makes it more likely that those indicted will sooner or later sit behind bulletproof glass in the bland courthouse on the edge of the North sea where the war crimes tribunal expects to continue working for at least another decade.

Yugoslavia's new government, desperate for aid and trade, may find it difficult ultimately to resist pressure to pursue these men.

"They are very, very worried. It is getting more dangerous for the small fry as well as the big boys. They would like to leave but have no place to go," said a confidant of Mladic.

By December the tribunal's chief prosecutor, Carla del Ponte, wants Mr Milosevic indicted on charges of genocide in Bosnia and Croatia, in addition to the existing charge of crimes against humanity in Belgrade's drive against the ethnic Albanians of Kosovo.

She is in the Balkans and has asked to meet Mr Kostunica. She says she will give him details about 100 frozen Swiss bank accounts belonging to Milosevic associates.

For Ljubodrag Stojadinovic it all comes as a late but welcome vindication. A former colonel in the Yugoslav army who served in Bosnia, he became a journalist and spent the past 10 years exposing Serb atrocities in the daily newspaper Glas. It wasn't easy.

He was threatened by the secret police, denounced by politicians, disowned by friends who would not believe him. "Ninety per cent of the soldiers were honourable but the others were dogs of war, criminals. People didn't want to talk about them. I joked that only pensioners and blondes continued to deny it. Now maybe even they will believe."

webTitle: EU pledges aid and lifts key sanctions

fields.headline: EU pledges aid and lifts key sanctions
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Serbia was showered with warm praise and promises of aid and friendship yesterday by the EU, which lifted the key sanctions imposed after Belgrade's attempt to subjugate Kosovo.
fields.body:
Serbia was showered with warm praise and promises of aid and friendship yesterday by the EU, which lifted the key sanctions imposed after Belgrade's attempt to subjugate Kosovo.

Rewarding Serbians for enforcing their democratic vote to oust Slobodan Milosevic as Yugoslav president, EU foreign ministers agreed at a meeting in Luxembourg to remove all sanctions except those affecting the Milosevic family and its business cronies.

Yugoslav assets abroad, for example, will stay frozen for now, because the EU says that releasing the assets would help the Milosevic clique. A ban on visas for EU countries also remains in place.

But the ministers indicated that they would not be demanding Mr Milosevic's immediate surrender to the UN criminal tribunal at the Hague, where he and four of his subordinates are wanted on war crimes charges. The EU says it is ready to wait.

"Without justice there can be no reconciliation in Yugoslavia, and without reconciliation there can be no peace," the German foreign minster, Joschka Fischer, insisted.

"But Milosevic is not our first priority. First they [the Yugoslavs] have to consolidate democracy, but justice will prevail, I have no doubt."

Robin Cook, Britain's foreign secretary, insisted that there was no disagreement with the US on this crucial issue, which is likely to loom large in the months to come.

Hubert Védrine, foreign minister of France, the current holder of the EU's rotating presidency, flies to Belgrade today to invite Yugoslavia's new president, Vojislav Kostunica, to join the stabilisation process leading eventually to status as an EU associate.

"This lays out the prospect of federal Yugoslavia's integration to the European Union," said Mr Védrine. "I will be telling him what our desires and expectations are, and telling him we wish him every success. We are looking for partnership."

Mr Kostunica is expected in turn to attend the weekend EU summit at Biarritz, not least so that government leaders can better get the measure of him.

No aid sums were mentioned in yesterday's communique, but the European commission already has a six-year plan to spend 2.3bn euros (£1.4bn) on Serbia if Belgrade shows it is fully working as a democracy.

EU experts will visit Belgrade later this week to determine what is needed, and some time later a World Bank mission will go too, said Chris Patten, the EU's external relations commissioner.

Mr Cook said the EU was showing that it wanted "to bring down barriers between the Serb people and the European Union". But with difficulties likely over Mr Milosevic, Kosovo and Montenegro, he conceded that there was a "long haul" ahead.

"If we waited for Serbia to do everything it needs to do, on Milosevic, on corruption, on the difficulties facing foreign investment, then we'd have to wait five years, and that would be ridiculous," one diplomat said. "We have to press that Milosevic be brought to the Hague, but there's no point in erecting a brick wall."

Ministers said the EU would study ways to quickly reopen the Danube, blocked by debris from Nato's bombing last year. Lifting sanctions would mean that oil deliveries could resume in a few days.

webTitle: Money dealers in limbo as dinar endures a wild ride

fields.headline: Money dealers in limbo as dinar endures a wild ride
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The value of people's money was fluctuating wildly, the mobile phone network was in meltdown, and money dealers stood confused: Yugoslavia's revolution has hit the currency black market.
fields.body:
The value of people's money was fluctuating wildly, the mobile phone network was in meltdown, and money dealers stood confused: Yugoslavia's revolution has hit the currency black market.

Reports flew across the country that the currency, the dinar, was exchanging for the deutschmark at hugely different rates. "Democratic change in Belgrade makes mess on the street currency market," read Vecerni Novosti's headline yesterday.

In the central Serbian city of Cacak, the dinar fell from 43 to the mark to 25 and yet prices remained the same. In nearby Kraljevo, it later rose from 25 to 32. Money dealers stopped working and peasants and black market traders stopped selling because they couldn't price their goods.

"On Saturday, we were selling 38 dinars to the mark. On Sunday the rate was 22. Now we are selling at 25 and buying at 30," said one money dealer, Zoran Mitrovic. "But everybody likes it and is cheering about what's happening.

"A stable situation is more important to them than prices," he said, adding that the disparity in buy and sell rates would narrow.

Dr Milan Kovacevic, founder of the G17 independent economic thinktank, which is close to the new president, Vojislav Kostunica, explained why the dinar is gaining strength: "Representatives from G17 met Yugoslav National Bank governor Dusan Vlatkovic on Saturday and he promised he would not sell foreign currency, and that he would stop printing dinars."

Dr Kovacevic also explained that, psychologically, the mood across Serbia has changed. People are now counting on an influx of foreign capital, so they are not selling dinars.

Mr Kostunica has improved the trade environment within the federation by lifting trade barriers between Serbia and Montenegro.

The Yugoslav National Bank holds $285m (£197m) in hard currency. But, faced with economic difficulties, Slobodan Milosevic's regime resorted to printing money to repay debts.

The national bank has been massively increasing the money supply over the past year - reducing the dinar's value. Prices subsequently rose to keep apace. Now both dealer and economist expect the rate to steady. "I think the rate will stabilise - and probably go down," said Dr Kovacevic.

webTitle: Corrections and clarifications

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: The figures we gave for the showing of Ken Loach's film Land and Freedom in the UK and France, pages 10 and 11, Friday Review, October 6, understated its performance. Although we correctly said it did better in France than in the UK, it was seen in the UK in 263 cinemas (rather than 59) and in France probably in more than 500 (rather than 150).
fields.body: The figures we gave for the showing of Ken Loach's film Land and Freedom in the UK and France, pages 10 and 11, Friday Review, October 6, understated its performance. Although we correctly said it did better in France than in the UK, it was seen in the UK in 263 cinemas (rather than 59) and in France probably in more than 500 (rather than 150). It was Ken Loach's most successful release in the period between Kes and My Name is Joe (which took about £900,000 as opposed to Land and Freedom, which took £800,000). Margaret Rutherford was unforgettable as Miss Prism. It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number.
