webTitle: Arts: Justin Adams

fields.headline: The Arabian knight
fields.standfirst: Justin Adams's solo album was made for just £600. Now he's being hailed as a Britain's answer to Ry Cooder. By  Robin Denselow
fields.trailText: Justin Adams's solo album was made for just £600. Now he's being hailed as a Britain's answer to Ry Cooder. By Robin Denselow
fields.body:
Justin Adams wanted to make a record that had "the rough spirit of all the things that excite me - old Lee Perry recordings, the verve of street singers in Morocco, those delta blues singers back in the 30s who were always precise but never tight-arsed". So he sat alone in his DIY studio, singing and playing guitars, percussion and his new favourite, the n'goni, or African lute. The result was one of the most original albums of the year.

Desert Road is a moody, evocative blend of Anglo-Arabic blues. It cost a mere £600 to make, and was released earlier this year on Adams's own label. He followed up by getting his own band together to play the new songs. The Wayward Sheikhs received a rousing reception at Womad this summer, Adams being hailed as an unlikely blend of Ali Farka Toure, JJ Cale, Ry Cooder and Mark Knopfler. Tomorrow the Sheikhs are back in London for a show to mark the "official re-release" of the album, now that it is finally gaining some notice.

Arabic and African styles may be in fashion, but this is music that has has obsessed Adams for years. He spent much of his childhood in the Middle East, in Jordan and then Egypt, where his father was British ambassador. He began playing guitar at that unlikely rock academy, Eton, studied art history at the Courtauld Institute, and got a degree despite taking a term off to open for Kid Creole while appearing with an outfit called The Impossible Dreamers.

At first, his Arabic influences did not go down too well with other musicians. "If I played anything with an Arabic scale, the band would joke, 'We're all off for a kebab now, are we?' " The old Etonian finally met up with an unlikely musical ally - a Stepney tearaway and former colleague of Johnny Rotten. Jah Wobble brought Adams and his influences into his new band, the wildly experimental Invaders of the Heart. Wobble, says Adams, was "tough and loved to shock, but he was broadminded enough not to be put off by my background."

Adams spent "eight good years with Wobble that got crazed towards the end", and in the process worked with the likes of Sinead O'Connor and Natacha Atlas. Since then, he's been a session guitarist, played with the classical cellist Caroline Dale in the Ghostland project (a mixture of strings, Celtic and dance themes, and), and worked as producer for that brilliant French band Lo'Jo, who mix French chanson with Arabic and African influences. Last year Lo'Jo took him down to Mali, where he bought his n'goni and decided to go solo at last, putting into effect the lessons he had learned in Africa and the Middle East. "I was frustrated by the world music tendency to use pristine drum loops, and then put an ethnic voice over that. You have to start with a rhythm that has a sense of swing. And I'm not mad about piano or complicated chords."

Adams sees the low-budget, low-key approach of his solo work as part of a trend. "It's either very cottage industry, like this, or it has to be big budget and enormous." He's keeping a foot in both camps. While promoting his songs with the Sheikhs, he's continuing to play with Ghostland, who are in the process of recording what sounds as if it will be a lush, glossy new album with elaborate use of strings on every track. I bet it won't be half as fun as the DIY Anglo-Arab-African desert blues of Adams and the Sheikhs in full swing.

Justin Adams's Desert Road is out on Wayward. The Wayward Sheikhs play Borderline, London W1 (020-7734 2095), tomorrow.

webTitle: An American opera on the death penalty

fields.headline: Dead man singing
fields.standfirst: The death penalty may not be an election issue in the US, but at least someone has had the guts to write an opera about it.  Martin Kettle on a historical musical achievement
fields.trailText: The death penalty may not be an election issue in the US, but at least someone has had the guts to write an opera about it. Martin Kettle on a historical musical achievement.
fields.body:
A month from now, George W Bush, the governor of the state that executes far more people than any other, may be elected the next US president. Yet in this year's election, the death penalty is barely mentioned or discussed. Like Bush, his opponent Al Gore is a capital punishment man, as all but a handful of US politicians are too. As a result, a system of punishment that helps to define modern America for many people in Europe - and that puts the penal system of the world's greatest democracy on a par with those of Iraq, Pakistan and China - has not even rated a mention in the presidential debates.

But, extraordinarily, the issue of the death penalty has produced a new, full-length American opera, which had its premiere at the San Francisco Opera House this weekend. At the close, members of the audience wept, and the emotion was almost as strong outside the opera house as within. As a torchlit vigil reminded the opera-goers, California alone currently has no fewer than 572 prisoners awaiting execution on death row.

It is hard to imagine that any composer can ever have written a more directly topical opera than the American composer Jake Heggie. Heggie's Dead Man Walking, his first opera, with a libretto by the currently ubiquitous dramatist Terrence McNally, is an adaptation of Sister Helen Prejean's account of her work with Louisiana's death row inmates. And, although Heggie's opera is universal in its themes and moral scope, it is also aesthetically and culturally a distinctively American opera. To see it in an American theatre, performed by American artists, with an American audience is to experience a special collective intensity.

As the critic and writer Peter Conrad has said, almost all opera is in some sense a song about love and death. But Conrad's description applies with special force to Dead Man Walking. Death dominates and pervades the whole evening, from the savage opening murder scene, which leaves no question about Joseph De Rocher's guilt, to his final execution by legal injection, enacted in a terrible silence that goes beyond even the ability of music to express.

But song is there too, and so is love. Just as in Sister Helen's book, and just as in Tim Robbins's Oscar-winning 1996 movie, the central subject of the opera is not death so much as love. "I love you," sings De Rocher in his final words as he is strapped to the execution table. "I love you, too," Sister Helen responds. Then there is silence, broken only by the sounds of the death machinery, and then silence again. Finally, unaccompanied, Susan Graham as Sister Helen sings a spiritual: rich, southern and affirmative.

It is a tribute to Heggie's score and to his handling of such an unremittingly serious subject that he manages to move occasionally into lighter vein without it seeming inappropriate. Like many contemporary American composers, Heggie can slip easily in and out of various styles. In this case, hymns and rock'n'roll vary the musical mood and pace at key moments. McNally's text helps enormously too, darting into brief exchanges between the characters that help to establish theatrical contours and real relationships.

Dead Man Walking is not an "anti-death penalty" opera in an agitprop sense. It works as a drama precisely because it catches subtleties and nuances. De Rocher is not a nice man or even a martyr. The death row prisoners are scary not noble. The prison governor is caught between keeping order and wanting to behave decently. And the most immediately accessible characters in the drama are the victims' parents, who continually confront Sister Helen with their own terrible losses.

If the most overwhelming scene in the opera is, appropriately, the execution, the runner-up is the sextet between the victims' parents, Sister Helen and De Rocher's hapless mother, sung with huge emotional directness by Frederica von Stade. "You don't know what it's like," the parents sing in a series of heartbreaking overlapping lines. They are right. Sister Helen doesn't know, though she is learning. Moments like this make the opera truly dramatic. By any conceivable standards, Dead Man Walking is a big opera emotionally. That's part of what one instantly respects about it. Many modern operas avoid emotionally big subjects in favour of attitude and obscurity. There is not an ounce of those things here. Seriousness, on its own, may not be enough, but it is a very useful start.

Heggie is an unabashed melodist, as he said himself at a symposium on the eve of the premiere. His music is rich and emotionally charged, betraying varied influences from Mussorgsky to Britten and Ravel, and carries enormous atmospheric power. The orchestral writing is full of interest and subtlety, and with Patrick Summers in the pit to bring the score to life, Heggie manages to build musical tension in a way that shows astonishing maturity for someone writing his first large- scale dramatic work. There is a sweep to this work which can only be called inspired.

Oddly, however, given Heggie's growing reputation as a writer for the voice - his more than 50 published songs have been recorded by some of the most lustrous names in the singing world - the one nagging uncertainty concerned his handling of the vocal line. Heggie's characteristic phrases almost always turn downwards, closing in on themselves, rather than expanding to more ambitious directions. After a while, this risks becoming predictable.

But such reservations must be put in perspective. Heggie's achievement is simply immense. There was scarcely a moment in the evening when one was not aware of the high purposes of great art. Graham was at the core of the evening, rarely off the stage, singing her heart out in rich-toned directness. Joe Mantello's production is unerring, with studied and effective simplicity (and a few good gags) the hallmark. Dead Man Walking makes the most concentrated impact of any piece of American music theatre since West Side Story more than 40 years ago. San Francisco, one of the great patron houses of contemporary opera, has a historic achievement on its hands.

webTitle: Letters: Homeless problem

fields.headline: We beg to differ
fields.trailText: I was surprised to see the response of the Big Issue to the government's campaign urging the public not to give to beggars (Report, October 9), given its philosophy of "a hand up, not a hand out".
fields.body:
I was surprised to see the response of the Big Issue to the government's campaign urging the public not to give to beggars (Report, October 9), given its philosophy of "a hand up, not a hand out". Our outreach workers are in no doubt that many of those begging on the street do not sleep rough and that money is often spent on drugs. Charities have an obligation to provide the public with the real picture. If they still decide to give to people holding a "hungry and homeless" sign, at least they are making an informed choice.
Jeremy Swain
Thames Reach

Giving homeless people money cannot solve their long-term problems. The government, working with charities including St Giles Trust, is redoubling efforts to help rough sleepers to leave the streets for good. Extra housing has been set aside and more help is being given to sort out problems which are the root cause - mental illness, addiction, poor coping skills. Supporting homeless charities by donating time, skills or money is more likely to produce long-term results.
Daniel Currie
St Giles Trust

When I hand over change to someone in need, at least I know that 100% of it is to be used by that person, not going to a bank for service charge, to an advertising campaign or to keeping a well-housed director of some project in post. Cutting out the middle person?
Ray Sirotkin
London ray.sirotkin@cwcom.net

Whenever my little daughter and I see a beggar, I let her do the giving. I remember how she went up to a young woman, sitting in an Edinburgh doorway and, handing her a coin, said brightly: "There you go!" The young woman's face cracked into a grin; she still seemed to be chuckling when I looked back. Perhaps money given to beggars like her is most often spent on drugs, but you never know whether an act of kindness will change someone's life.
Paul Thompson
Scone, Perths

The government's plan to spend £250,000 on a Christmas campaign against giving to beggars is cruel, embarrassing and a disgraceful waste of taxpayers' money. Surely these resources could be better allocated helping to alleviate homelessness and providing warmth and food to those on the streets? To prevent yet another government-inspired public relations disaster, ministers should scrap this misguided idea at once.
Alex Belardinelli
Leeds

webTitle: Letters: Your maths is rubbish

fields.headline: Your maths is rubbish
fields.trailText: I was delighted to see the privileged place of maths in the school curriculum discussed, following the publication of the study Why Learn Maths, (Academics query compulsory maths, October 3).
fields.body:
I was delighted to see the privileged place of maths in the school curriculum discussed, following the publication of the study Why Learn Maths, (Academics query compulsory maths, October 3). However, the article takes quotes from my chapter of the study out of context. I did write, "the utility of academic and school mathematics in the modern world is greatly overestimated" but I continued "and the utilitarian argument provides a poor justification for the universal teaching of the subject".

I go on to describe the "relevance paradox", according to which society is increasingly mathematised but at a level invisible to most of its members. I argue that maths is also undervalued because most justifications are based on utility and instrumental value.

But maths is rich in intellectually challenging and exciting concepts and I therefore conclude by proposing that all learners should be entitled to develop mathematical skills, including a critical apprecia tion of the social applications and uses of mathematics. Far from saying that school maths can be dispensed with, I argue that we need more intellectually ambitious aims for teaching it. I will post the chapter, on www.ex.ac.uk/~PErnest/ for people interested in reading it for themselves. Perhaps this will reassure those who sent me angry messages about rubbishing maths in school.
Paul Ernest
Professor of maths education, University of Exeter p.ernest@ex.ac.uk

At present salary levels, where does the government expect to find maths teachers? (Four-day week at fresh start school, October 6.) As a mathematician with a PhD and two years university research and teaching experience, I would be happy to fill one of the three vacant maths teacher posts at Corby Community College. My minimum salary requirement is £40,000 plus bonuses.
Dr Jonathan Butler
Glasgow jbutler@mth.kcl.ac.uk

fields.headline: Victims of the drugs war
fields.trailText: In his excellent article (The joint is jumping, October 9), Alan Travis says that "last year", Norman Tebbit responded to my "call ... for the Church of England to back cannabis legalisation". I have never made such a call - though I have supported legalisation since 1966 - nor was I aware that Tebbit had responded to anything I had said or written last year.

On June 14 1998, however, he did attack my report on drugs to the Church of England in the Mail on Sunday, saying that I had called "for an end to the ban on drugs - including heroin and crack cocaine". This "call" does not appear anywhere in the report, and I took the article to the press complaints commission. While the Daily Telegraph, which made a similar mistake, apologised for its inaccuracy, I never received any apology from Tebbit or The Mail on Sunday.

St Botolph's Church, London KenLeech@aol.com

Your feature (Where there's smoke, October 6) makes the smoking of cannabis seem common and harmless. But it's not - because it's illegal. Our 16-year-old has been cautioned and had a final warning for possession of tiny pieces of cannabis. He also spent hours in the police station, was photographed, finger-printed and DNA-tested. Now he's afraid that he will end up with a criminal record. I don't think there's much wrong with smoking cannabis but as long as it's illegal it will warp and damage young (and not-so-young) lives.

webTitle: Letter: Baby police

fields.headline: Baby police
fields.trailText: For some 200,000 years humans have been conceived for no better reason than that the parents were overwhelmed by a sexual urge. Since contraception became more widely available, many babies have been conceived because the device failed, or the parents were too drunk to use it.
fields.body:
For some 200,000 years humans have been conceived for no better reason than that the parents were overwhelmed by a sexual urge. Since contraception became more widely available, many babies have been conceived because the device failed, or the parents were too drunk to use it.

Now, we can decide to have a baby to save an ailing marriage or because the older child needs someone to play with. But is there really a distinction to be made between "good" and "bad" reasons for having a child? Does it only become an issue when in vitro fertilisation is involved (Letters, October 6)? It seems strange that the opinion of "society" is enjoined when a baby like the Nashes' is conceived for a good reason, into a family where the elder sister is more likely to love him than resent him. Nobody's life is perfect. Such a child's problems may be different from, but no worse than, anyone else's.
Muriel Hirsch
Crawley, West Sussex

webTitle: Leader: Foreign football

fields.headline: Foreign football
fields.standfirst: Don't spread the net too wide, by George
fields.trailText: The flag of St George - so reports said yesterday - flies forlornly at the Keegan family home on Teeside, but there are few signs of the man who precipitated a national crisis. For this is a lot bigger than a bouncing ball. Kevin's departure prompts a question this sceptr'd isle has been puzzling over for centuries (including the man who coined the phrase, who knew full well how many non-English the "isle" contains). Why is it so difficult to grasp Englishness?
fields.body:
The flag of St George - so reports said yesterday - flies forlornly at the Keegan family home on Teeside, but there are few signs of the man who precipitated a national crisis. For this is a lot bigger than a bouncing ball. Kevin's departure prompts a question this sceptr'd isle has been puzzling over for centuries (including the man who coined the phrase, who knew full well how many non-English the "isle" contains). Why is it so difficult to grasp Englishness?

There they stood in the streets of Charleroi their beer bellies stretching their George cross tee-shirts. There they were again on Saturday, their sole reference in a game with Germans was how we won the war. But now they are piling into William Hill's book on the Keegan succession in favour of foreigners.

Objectively, the most successful manager in the isles is of course Sir Alex Ferguson. In a world without loyalty, the transplanted Scot might well fancy the challenge. But they would burn him in effigy on Sauciehall Street if he dared. However badly Scotland plays (things have been looking up a bit of late), even the most blown-away Scot could not contemplate such treachery. As for Arsène Wenger, no légion d'honneur for him if he were ever to coach England for a contest with les bleus. Liberal internationalists might like the idea of an English national side being managed by an Italian or even a German, though none are in sight at the moment as Christoph Daum pulls out his hair for drug testing. The openness of English life to foreign participation is wide and creditable (even if foreigners have undue influence in the media). But it would be a rum do in football. For if a manager, why not a goalkeeper or a striker. You would soon dispense with national competitions altogether and be left with mega club sides as cosmopolitan as Arsenal's. The Football Association have to find an English... no, a truly open-minded search would consider able women, too.

webTitle: Leader: Yugoslavian revolution

fields.headline: Revolution, Act 2
fields.standfirst:
Milosevic's henchmen get the chop

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Yugoslavia entered the second stage of its revolution yesterday as Vojislav Kostunica, the people's power president, took a chainsaw to the dead wood of Slobodan Milosevic's regime. Among those felled were the Yugoslav federal prime minister, Momir Bulatovic and his entire cabinet, Serbia's interior minister and, prospectively, Serbia's president, Milan Milutinovic, an indicted war criminal who is under intense pressure to quit. All are long-standing Milosevic allies.
fields.body:
Yugoslavia entered the second stage of its revolution yesterday as Vojislav Kostunica, the people's power president, took a chainsaw to the dead wood of Slobodan Milosevic's regime. Among those felled were the Yugoslav federal prime minister, Momir Bulatovic and his entire cabinet, Serbia's interior minister and, prospectively, Serbia's president, Milan Milutinovic, an indicted war criminal who is under intense pressure to quit. All are long-standing Milosevic allies. Despite furious protests from ultra-nationalists, the Serbian parliament also agreed to hold early elections. A political novice he may be, but Mr Kostunica appears to have a sure instinct for power. Although he and his allies remain (for now) in the minority in the federal parliament, this concerted push to win control of Serbia's institutions is a crucial precursor to the national social and economic regeneration that is the new president's biggest task. By this determined attempt to purge the body politic, Mr Kostunica further undermines sad, bad Milosevic's deluded hopes of a comeback and increases the chances that he will soon face justice at home, if not in The Hague.

Although it is still very early days, Mr Kostunica has also moved deftly in respect of the breakaway republics of Montenegro and Kosovo. While offering no concessions on sovereignty, he has made clear that he is ready to sit down and talk about future federal relationships - in sharp contrast with the brutal, bullying tactics employed by his predecessor. It is far from certain that the Kosovo Albanians are prepared to talk to Mr Kostunica about anything other than a date for secession. But after last year's international intervention, that is as much Nato's and the UN's problem as it is his. Montenegro's president Milo Djukanovic, on the other hand, has indicated that he might accept a deal that gives Montenegro equal status with Serbia and leads to a withdrawal of Yugoslav military police and some army units. According to Zoran Djindjic, a leading Kostunica ally, such an agreement may be facilitated by Mr Kostunica's next purge, of top army generals appointed by Milosevic.

The EU's rightly unconditional decision to relax sanctions and pledge $2bn in aid will help Mr Kostunica further consolidate his position. If the EU ever delivers the cash, it will reward ordinary Serbs for their courage in backing him. But he should keep his chainsaw to hand, for he is not out of the woods yet.

webTitle: Letters: Drama of theatre's crisis

fields.headline: Drama of theatre's crisis
fields.trailText: As a resignation letter, performing arts lecturer John Freeman's diatribe against live "mainstream" theatre performance (I accuse... G2, October 4) would be splendid stuff. He could then take full advantage of his new-found leisure time to discover just how wrong he is.
fields.body:
 As a resignation letter, performing arts lecturer John Freeman's diatribe against live "mainstream" theatre performance (I accuse... G2, October 4) would be splendid stuff. He could then take full advantage of his new-found leisure time to discover just how wrong he is. Theatre has never been more relevant, wherever performed and in front of whatever audience. It excites and empowers the young, teases and stimulates the older and entertains us all. That it also requires attention and commitment is surely, in this isolated age of computer screen and TV handset, something to be celebrated.

In Scotland, with its widely drawn groundswell of enthusiasm for a national theatre, we have been able to show how a strong theatrical infrastructure can get to and bring on the main component parts in a re-emergent nation. Can I give Mr Freeman a few pointers?

The Glasgow Citizens, with as diverse a programme as one could dream of, survived the old Gorbals and is the trailblazer for the new. Its core audience of local people of all ages takes enormous pride in the company's work. At Dundee Rep an ensemble of actors feels so much part of the community that they volunteer to help in local projects. In Edinburgh the Royal Lyceum's quality work on stage is more than matched by inspirational work in schools that is making children want to come to the theatre and to create theatre for themselves. Meanwhile the Traverse is so vibrant a laboratory for the creative and expressive arts it ensures that theatre never gets anywhere near the alien territory of Mr Freeman's strange scenario.

In the hope his employers have still to see his piece, I urge Mr Freeman to give himself one more chance of salvation and head for the Cottesloe in London, where the Tron Theatre (Glasgow) and RNT's coproduction of Zinnie Harris's wonderful Further From the Furthest Thing is starting a short run. Should that fail, I fear its King Lear's company for him.
John Scott Moncrieff
Chair, drama committee, Scottish Arts Council

The good kicking John Freeman gives contemporary theatre no doubt causes squeals of outrage amongst decent, Guardian-reading folk. It is, however, very much deserved. Postwar cultural policy has delivered theatre into the hands of self-important, upper-middle class professionals who have proceeded to serve up their anaemic, bum-numbing fare to dwindling numbersof like-minded cultural cliques and undergraduates. Theatre can still be a uniquely powerful medium, but it has slowly suffocated by being placed either within the high-art museum or the confines of soulless, elitist citadels.

A living, vibrant theatre must be created and experienced at a community level. This form of theatre has all but disappeared thanks to an arts policy that favours high profile, grandiose schemes aimed at impressing bankers, politicians and Melvyn Bragg.
Tim Dawtry
Pandemonium Theatre, Leeds.

Since John Freeman clearly dislikes the theatre it is logical he doesn't go and so knows nothing about it. His claim that "theatre dialogue bears no relation to contemporary language" is belied by the work of Nick Grosso, Rebecca Prichard, Roy Williams and a host of others who are streets ahead of anything he'll hear on his beloved EastEnders.
Stephen Jeffreys
London

Perhaps Arnold Wesker (Letters, October 7) would like to apply to our undergraduate programme here at De Montfort University (we welcome applications from mature entrants). As part of his studies, I'd be happy to discuss with him the meaning of terms such as "marginal" and "subversive".
John Freeman
De Montfort University

webTitle: Leader: Deglamorising cannabis

fields.headline: Deglamorising cannabis
fields.standfirst:
The UK should follow the Dutch lead

Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Forget the acute embarrassment of the Conservative party over an internal revolt against its new hardline policy on cannabis - enjoyable though its squirming might be. Forget the increasingly shrill responses of the Conservative leader, who descended yesterday to issuing the emptiest political response on the issue: "We have to step up the war against drugs." Britain already has the toughest laws in Europe, which is one reason why its policies are so ineffective.
fields.body:
Forget the acute embarrassment of the Conservative party over an internal revolt against its new hardline policy on cannabis - enjoyable though its squirming might be. Forget the increasingly shrill responses of the Conservative leader, who descended yesterday to issuing the emptiest political response on the issue: "We have to step up the war against drugs." Britain already has the toughest laws in Europe, which is one reason why its policies are so ineffective. The Police Foundation's national commission on drug legislation - on which two chief constables served - rightly concluded in March that our current laws do more harm than good. Forget the disarray in the Conservative party, because it is Labour which is in power. When parliament reassembles, ministers will be summoned before the home affairs select committee to give their considered response to the 81 recommendations in the Police Foundation's report.

Never has there been a better chance to reform our current system. Ministers should reflect on three fundamental shifts in attitudes - by politicians, public and police - that have occurred in the last week. In a mature society, the readiness of seven Tory shadow ministers to admit they have taken cannabis, should not cause a ripple. But until now, immature debate has predominated. An earlier admission by Mo Mowlam over taking pot, produced shock and horror on both front benches. Similarly, the public backlash against Ann Widdecombe's proposed abolition of the police caution for cannabis, breaks a long trend. Public backlashes are supposed to be associated with over-permissive policies, not the shamelessly regressive. Finally this week has not just seen the police superintendents, who would have to manage Miss Widdecombe's policy, openly declare it was unworkable, but a former chief constable, Francis Wilkinson, became the first to have held his rank to call for the legalisation of cannabis.

If ministers are surprised by these responses, they should not be. A Mori poll, commissioned by the Police Foundation, found Middle England at odds with the government's hardline stance on drugs. Some 80% wanted a more relaxed approach to cannabis. Media attitudes have also shifted. The tabloids - not just the Mirror and Express, but the Mail too - said the Foundation's report deserved a serious debate. The Telegraph even played with a legalisation experiment. Ministers should seize the opportunity these shifts in attitude create.

The foundation's report was too cautious, but its proposals - which would reclassify drugs according to the harm they cause - would be a logical first step to decriminalisation. So would its proposal to make cannabis an unimprisonable offence. These columns have long preferred decriminalisation to legalisation. Decriminalisation retains the offence but does not pursue prosecution. It has been supremely successful in Holland in separating soft drugs from hard drugs. It still has fewer young people than the UK taking cannabis despite its availability. And, unlike the UK, has stabilised or even reduced heroin use. Legalisation would either let the tobacco barons take part, or at least (because pot is mixed with tobacco) revive sales. The Dutch are no longer alone. Portugal and Switzerland are preparing to liberalise. A war against drugs is a war against our children. Seven shadow cabinet ministers recognise this truth. Surely Labour can follow suit. They should stop issuing the most dangerous message of all: that all drugs are equally harmful. They are not and young people already know it.

webTitle: For 17 years a guerrilla group and a commune lived in harmony. Then came a brutal killing

fields.headline: For 17 years a guerrilla group and a commune lived in harmony. Then came a brutal killing
fields.trailText: They may have different philosophies but for the last 17 years a band of heavily-armed Marxist guerrillas and a radical commune founded in London have managed to live in harmony in a remote area of Colombia.
fields.body:
They may have different philosophies but for the last 17 years a band of heavily-armed Marxist guerrillas and a radical commune founded in London have managed to live in harmony in a remote area of Colombia.

While the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Columbia (Farc) has grown in strength and influence thanks to drugs money, Atlantis has been promoting organic farming and primal scream therapy. Farc has tolerated - even helped - the commune.

But the two are now at loggerheads after Tristan James, the 18-year-old grandson of the Atlantis founder, Jenny James, and his Colombian friend were stabbed and decapitated, and their bodies set on fire after being accused of spying for pro-government paramilitaries.

Atlantis was founded in London as a "radical primal commune" based on the principles of Reichian, or "Primal Scream", therapy in 1970. Four years later the group moved to Burtonport, Co Donegal, but their alternative lifestyle earned them suspicion and notoriety.

Newspaper headlines dubbed them the Screamers and Irish MPs called for their deportation. In 1976, the group received a series of bomb threats when they were accused them of abducting a woman.

Back to nature

In 1978 the founder, Ms James, set out for South America with three daughters in tow. "I thought it was time to cut the umbilical cord with all western civilisation. My goal was to go back, and back to a more natural way of life," she said.

Her plan was to reach Bolivia, in homage to Che Guevara, but in 1983, after travelling throughout Latin America and the Caribbean, Ms James settled in Icononzo in the central Tolima state of Colombia. "I was completely seduced. Colombia has something so vibrant. It's a country which has everything," she said.

Although most of their 200-hectare farm was left for reforestation, the commune was largely self-sufficient. As well as growing organic crops, the group toured schools with theatre productions, and taught ecological farming techniques and vegetarian cookery to local schoolchildren and women's groups. Another farm was founded and they prospered.

Commune member Anne Barr said: "We lived in tranquillity for a long time. People came out of curiosity to see what these crazy gringos were doing, be cause we are in areas where there shouldn't be foreigners."

One good reason that there were no other foreigners in Icononzo was that it was a traditional guerrilla stronghold. Farc began as a peasant movement under Manuel "Tiro Fijo" (sure-shot) Marulanda in July 1964 but is now considered one of the biggest and best-armed guerrilla forces in history.

Its stated aims sound benevolent. Farc wants more social investment in rural areas, political reform, a redefinition of the country's natural resources policy - particularly with regard to oil exploration and the role of foreign multinationals in Colombia - and a scaling down of the country's armed forces.

But its methods are sometimes brutal. Much of its funding comes from the cocaine and heroin trade. It says it simply "taxes" growers and traffickers but the US government claims it is directly involved in the trade. It also raises money from kidnappings and extortion. Earlier this year the US government sent in more than £1bn-worth (about £700m) of military aid to Colombia officially to help its government wipe out drug trafficking but essentially to help it destroy Farc.

Women commanders

Around one in three of Farc's 15,000 members are women. Some units are headed by women commanders and most of its roadblocks in its heartland of San Vicente, known unofficially as Farclandia, are organised by women. It effectively controls about two-fifths of Colombia, an area the size of France.

For Atlantis, living in the region meant living alongside the rebels. Ms James said: "If there is a robbery you can go to the police if you want, but the police don't dare come up to you. So you go to Farc, and they sort it out."

When armed robbers stole 1m pesos (worth around £700 at the time) from the commune in 1991, the guerrillas made the thieves return the cash, with interest. "We had very good relations for a while ... It never entered our heads that there would be physical danger."

But then in February 1998 the rebels told them the commune would have to leave the second farm. "They were afraid that paramilitary spies would be among the visitors, and it seemed like a real fear to us, so we accepted it," said Ms Barr. In August last year, a new commander in Icononzo ordered the 15 commune members to leave that farm as well. Under the rule of "Commandante Gonzalo" the region fell prey to the intrigues of the local militia.

On July 8 he and Javier Nova, 18, arrived in Icononzo where they visited Brendan. The following evening, despite warnings that they were risking their lives, the two men set out on the two-hour walk to the home of Mr Nova's family.

webTitle: Puzzle under foot Trompe l'oeil art floors Somerset House

fields.headline: Puzzle under foot Trompe l'oeil art floors Somerset House
fields.trailText: The entrance to the seamen's waiting hall in Somerset House in central London has acquired a painting on the floor. It is a 30 sq m trompe l'oeil floor cloth coated with 12 layers of varnish and appears to be a continuation of the stone of the hall itself.
fields.body:
The entrance to the seamen's waiting hall in Somerset House in central London has acquired a painting on the floor. It is a 30 sq m trompe l'oeil floor cloth coated with 12 layers of varnish and appears to be a continuation of the stone of the hall itself.

"It is a puzzle, but you have to look closely to find the clues," said the artist, Sophie Sarin yesterday as the result of three months' work was laid in the palace, once the domain of civil servants but now converted to a museum with national lottery money.

Somerset House is the masterpiece of Sir William Chambers, George III's favourite architect. He was born in Sweden of Scottish parents. With the Swedish cultural attache and the Sir John Soane's museum in London, Ms Sarin, who is Swedish, traced documents relating to Chambers' life, career and designs for Somerset House, built in the late 18th century, which she has silk screened into the floor design.

It is called The Polar Star floor cloth. Ms Sarin said King Gustavus III of Sweden made the architect a Knight of the Order of the Polar Star.

webTitle: Youth jailed for inventing race attack

fields.headline: Youth jailed for inventing race attack
fields.trailText: A youth who falsely claimed he was attacked by a racist gang, doused in petrol and set on fire, was yesterday sent to a young offenders' institution for three months.
fields.body:
A youth who falsely claimed he was attacked by a racist gang, doused in petrol and set on fire, was yesterday sent to a young offenders' institution for three months.

Chris Barton, 18, admitted wasting police time at an earlier hearing and was being sentenced at Oxford magistrates court.

Thames Valley police launched a hunt for a gang of white teenagers alleged to have screamed racist abuse before hurling petrol over Barton and igniting it during the late night attack in the village of Berinsfield, Oxon, last April.

Barton, of West Indian origin, claimed the men then walked away laughing. He had stolen a car from Abingdon college the previous night and had burnt himself while torching the vehicle, leaving scars to his face and arms, the court heard. To cover up, he made up the "racist attack", even selling his story and photographs to a local news agency for £400.

Credit cards and a driving licence belonging to the car owner were later discovered in his bedroom by police.

Jennifer Jonckheer, prosecuting, said his actions led to hundreds of hours of police time being wasted.

Stipendiary magistrate David Simpson ordered Barton to pay £400 compensation to the police.

webTitle: Deportation case goes to the Lords

fields.headline: Deportation case goes to the Lords
fields.trailText: A Pakistani cleric, accused of recruiting British Muslims to fight a holy war in Kashmir, yesterday won permission to take his battle against deportation to the Lords.
fields.body:
A Pakistani cleric, accused of recruiting British Muslims to fight a holy war in Kashmir, yesterday won permission to take his battle against deportation to the Lords.

Three law lords, Lords Steyn, Hope and Millett, gave Shafiq Ur Rehman, 29, of Oldham, Greater Manchester, permission to challenge a court of appeal decision.

The appeal court ordered the special immigration appeals commission to reconsider its ruling that there was not enough evidence on which to base the deportation order.

The court, headed by Lord Justice Woolf, ruled that the approach of the commission had been too narrow. Lord Woolf said: "The promotion of terrorism against any state is capable of being a threat to our own national security."

Mr Rehman's lawyer, Amjad Malik, said: "A threat to national security should mean a direct or indirect threat to the UK, not to other countries. My client has has raised concerns about Kashmiri people in his role as a minister of religion."

Mr Malik wanted the Lords to define the standard of proof needed to show his client was involved in terrorist activities.

webTitle: Depression link to heart disease

fields.headline: Depression link to heart disease
fields.trailText: Scientists yesterday provided the strongest evidence so far linking depression and heart disease.
fields.body:
Scientists yesterday provided the strongest evidence so far linking depression and heart disease.

A study of 4,493 pensioners showed that those most often depressed were 40% more likely to develop heart disease than those less troubled by depression. None of the participants, all aged 65 and over, had any heart disease when the the six-year study began in the United States.

Their mood status was assessed each year using a system to rate depression symptoms. Participants were also asked about their health, medication, and feelings. Every five-unit increase in the average depression score was associated with a 15% increased risk of developing heart disease.

Investigator Curt Furberg, from Wake Forest University, North Carolina, said: "This study has established that symptoms of depression are an independent risk factor for coronary heart disease in older individuals. This doesn't mean that depressive symptoms are a cause of coronary heart disease, but that the presence of depressive symptoms predicts the development of disease."

webTitle: You had better believe it

fields.headline: You had better believe it
fields.trailText: Richard Wilson, alias Victor Meldrew, is so sick of his catchphrase, "I don't believe it", that he is charging fans who ask him to repeat it, he reveals today.
fields.body:
Richard Wilson, alias Victor Meldrew, is so sick of his catchphrase, "I don't believe it", that he is charging fans who ask him to repeat it, he reveals today.

The star of One Foot in the Grave has raised cash for charity for his renditions. In an interview with Radio Times, Wilson, 64, says passers-by repeat his line to him "three or four times a day sometimes, and they all think they are the first".

Now when fans ask him to repeat it, he tells them he will only do it for charity.

"In Scotland recently, I made £500. I had asked for £2,000 and one woman said she couldn't afford that, but would £250 be any good? So I took her to one side and did it. Then another woman came up and said 'Could I have it as well, please'."

webTitle: Activists extinguish incinerator

fields.headline: Activists extinguish incinerator
fields.trailText: Edmonton incinerator which burns 550,000 tonnes of rubbish for seven London boroughs was put out yesterday after Greenpeace volunteers capped a chimney and occupied the loading cranes. Nine volunteers remained chained to the building last night.
fields.body:
Edmonton incinerator which burns 550,000 tonnes of rubbish for seven London boroughs was put out yesterday after Greenpeace volunteers capped a chimney and occupied the loading cranes. Nine volunteers remained chained to the building last night.

Greenpeace is trying to prevent an increase of the waste burning incinerators from 15 to more than 80 as part of the government's plan to make energy from waste rather than more environmentally acceptable recycling and composting. There is new evidence that dioxins caused by burning rubbish are associated with cancer clusters. Greenpeace claims incineration can cause birth defects and asthma.

There is a planning application to increase the Edmonton incinerator's capacity to 830,000 tonnes a year - in boroughs where the average recycling rate is 1% compared with Edmonton in Canada which has a 50% recycling rate.

The Conservative and Liberal Democrat parties have criticised the building of new plants and Ken Livingstone, London's mayor, has discouraged further incinerators while a waste strategy is developed for London.

Greenpeace claims that closing off the incineration option while landfill is being restricted to comply with a new European directive would force authorities to develop alternatives to landfill. Manufacturers would have to plan for recyclability of materials.

But local authorities in long- term contracts with incinerator operators have an incentive to keep waste levels high in order to provide the promised tonnage.

fields.standfirst: PSHE
fields.trailText: PSHE
fields.body:
Teaching Pages

****

Aimed at: teachers

Assess your own attitude to PSHE and access some of the resources used by Exeter University's PGCE course on this site of the Schools Health Education Unit.

Brain Pop - Health

****

Aimed at: KS3

Engaging US movie shorts about health concerns for adolescents (inc acne and periods) as well as more general aspects of human biology.

Samaritans

***

Aimed at: everyone

Includes the Samaritans Youth Pack for schools, statistics on suicide, and an engrossing survey of young men's attitudes towards their own distress. The latter is free but available only by post. Some material is also in Welsh.

Generation Sex

***

Aimed at: teenagers

Flashy new site from Channel 4 with a question-and-answer service that visitors can browse: some are quite explicit and might worry more conservative teachers and parents. The ABC of Sex is a good reference for queries about particular words, and there is a strong section for girls who have had unprotected sex. See also the government's MindBodySoul website for PSHE.

DrugScope

****

Aimed at: everyone

Formerly the Institute for the Study of Drugs Dependence and the Standing Conference on Drug Abuse, DrugScope has a large education section and an online drugs encyclopaedia of considerable depth.

The Red Spot

*****

Aimed at: everyone

Subtitled Menstrual Culture, this site examines the physiological, historical and emotional aspects of the subject in an entertaining, intelligent way. Very helpful for anyone giving a talk.

Police Services UK

***

Aimed at: everyone

Every police force has its own website, and those of the Met and West Yorkshire Police are particularly interesting.They could prove useful if you want to engage pupils' interest by looking at the role of the local police.

Smoking and Health

****

Aimed at: everyone

ASH has a dedicated schools section. It does not patronise its audience and nor condemn smokers outright. Could be easier to use with KS4 students?

AIDSmap

***

Aimed at: everyone

Links to a variety of research and resources on Aids.

Alcohol Concern

www.alcoholconcern.org.uk

***

Aimed at: everyone

Probably its most useful feature are the factsheets on alcohol covering, among other topics, women's drinking and the scale of consumption.

Euthanasia links

No star rating; it's a Guardian site

Aimed at: everyone

This page links to campaigning organisations such as the Society for the Protection of the Unborn Child, the Voluntary Euthanasia Society and the Catholic position on abortion.

See more PSHE sites and a back catalogue of all subjects covered so far at Guardian netclass or contact Ros Taylor at ros.taylor@theguardian.com

webTitle: Resources: It is now possible to produce a "designer baby". But it is right?

fields.headline: From here to maternity
fields.standfirst: It is now possible to produce a "designer baby". But it is right? asks  John Crace
fields.trailText: It is now possible to produce a "designer baby". But it is right? asks John Crace
fields.body:
Last week it was reported that an American couple with no fertility problems had used in-vitro fertilisation (IVF), a medical intervention used by couples who have had difficulties conceiving, to produce a "designer baby".

The couple's six-year-old daughter, Molly, suffers from a fatal blood disorder known as Fanconi's anaemia. Her only hope is a transplant of non-diseased cells - most likely from a sibling. Even though the parents could conceive naturally, there was a high risk that another baby would have the condition.

Doctors said the only way to be certain that their next child would be free of the disease - and a suitable donor for Molly, too - would be to have IVF and for the embryos to be screened for genetic disorders before being put back into the womb. Doctors therefore genetically screened 12 embryos using Pre-implantation Genetic Diagnosis (PGD) until they found one that was disease-free and a perfect match for Molly. When the baby, Adam, was born, blood cells from his umbilical cord were injected into his sister. Her survival chances have improved from 30% to 90%.

Ethics

There has been a great deal of sympathy for the parents' position, but opinion is strongly divided. Some argue that Molly would have died without the intervention, that the blood cells from the umbilical cord are usually just thrown away and that the parents have only done what all loving parents would do. Others argue that much as they feel for Molly, producing a "designer baby" sets a dangerous precedent of seeing children as a commodity. They also say that baby Adam may grow to resent both his sisters and parents when he discovers how - and why - he was conceived.

Scientific developments often advance more quickly than our ability to think through all the consequences. We can now select the sex of a baby, and this is a small step from choosing hair and eye colour, IQ, size and physical ability. This has a lot in common with the "eugenics" campaigns of the Nazis. It is feared that PGD could promote an intolerant society.

webTitle: Internet know-how: choosing a school

fields.headline: Internet know-how
fields.standfirst: Choosing a school
fields.trailText: Choosing a school
fields.body:
Although there's no substitute for going along to an open evening yourself, the task of choosing a school is made much easier if you can do the research online. That's particularly true if you have faith in Ofsted inspection reports and performance tables, but those aren't the only criteria.

The government's performance tables, Ofsted reports and a school's own site are now accessible from the same search page at www.parents.dfee.gov.uk/. Take care with the Ofsted reports: schools without major problems are only inspected once every four years, and much can change in that time. Weaknesses identified at the end of 1996 may well have been resolved by the turn of the century.

Beacon schools - those identified by the government as an inspiration to others in their area - are listed at www.standards.dfee.

The Guardian published its own primary performance tables, based on a number of different factors - such as the level of improvement between 1996 and 1999 and the number of pupils with special needs - at the end of 1999. Data is also available for secondary schools. You can find the tables in a special report

If a school's sixth form interests you, have a look at our more recent analyses of A-level results, which are linked from alevels2000. This lists the top 100 schools and private institutions and the top 50 FE colleges based on this year's figures.

www.upmystreet.com locates the top-performing school in each area, but since the winner is likely to come from the private sector, this will concern only a minority of parents.

The Independent Schools Information Service offers basic information on over 1,300 private schools. The redoubtable Harrogate Ladies' College is making a special effort this year: would-be pupils can attend a taster weekend www.hlc.org.uk.
Hobson's boarding school profiles are slightly more detailed and better illustrated.

The annual Good Schools Guide (£18 + postage) has long been available in a printed version. Only purchasers can read the contents online, you can read a sample entry (for Eton College). The links section at www.goodschools is very useful, particularly for those looking for schools with a particular religious affiliation.

webTitle: Resources: Israel and Palestine

fields.headline: An unholy row
fields.trailText: Last week witnessed some of the worst violence for years between Israeli troops and Palestinian protesters.
fields.body:
Last week witnessed some of the worst violence for years between Israeli troops and Palestinian protesters. At least 69 people have died (mostly Palestinians) and around 2,000 have been injured. What sparked this violence?

What sparked this violence?

On September 28, Ariel Sharon, the leader of Israel's main opposition party (Likud) made a visit to the holy sites in East Jerusalem. This infuriated the local Palestinians and the rioting began. During his visit, Sharon inspected The Temple Mount - a small area containing the Dome of the Rock. This is the third most holy Muslim site, from where Mohammed is believed to have ascended into heaven. The adjacent Western or Wailing Wall of the ancient Temple is also a Jewish holy site

For Sharon to go there was seen as very insensitive by the Palestinians. He is hated because in 1982 he had the power to stop the massacre of Palestinian refugees in neighbouring Lebanon but did nothing.

Why is Jerusalem the source of such conflict?

Jerusalem is not just any city. It is where many Jewish Israelis and the Palestinians would like their capital to be. The Temple Mount is thought by Jews to be the site of the Second Temple. Its destruction by the Romans in 70AD began nearly 2,000 years of Jewish exile from the Holy Land. Jews began returning to what was then Palestine in the 1880s, but Israel came into existence only in 1948.

In 1967, in the Six Day War, Israel attacked and defeated its neighbours Jordan, Syria and Egypt, which had threatened war. As part of that victory it conquered the eastern part of Jerusalem (the city was already divided) and a large area of land up to the River Jordan. This has become known as the West Bank. The Israelis have been told to give this land back by the United Nations.

Why are Palestinians and Israelis in conflict?

Just as the Israelis regard these lands as home, so too do the Palestinians. They hoped that after the first world war, when the Middle East was freed from Turkish control, they would be given space to create a Palestinian state. This never happened. Instead the British, who were in charge of the region, tried to get them to accept splitting the land into Jewish and Palestinian sections, with Jerusalem an "international city" looked after by the United Nations.

The Palestinians rejected this and joined with their Arab neighbours in trying to destroy Israel in 1948. This war also resulted in Arab defeat. Over one million Palestinians were driven from their homes, ending up in refugee camps all over the Middle East.

Israel's victory in the 1967 Six Day War meant that those Palestinians living on the West Bank, taken from Jordan, found themselves under Israeli occupation. This tense situation has not been improved by the arrival of more than 161,000 Jewish settlers who have taken land since then on the West Bank and in another occupied area called Gaza (now controlled by the Palestinian Authority).

What efforts have been made to sort out all these problems?

Negotiating peace in the Middle East has been painfully slow. The first breakthrough came in 1979 when Egypt recognised Israel's right to exist. The Israeli leader who did most to promote peace was Yitzhak Rabin, but his willingness to talk to the Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO) at Oslo was unacceptable to some extremists and led to his assassination. Progress was being made in talks between the current Israeli leader, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat (overseen by President Clinton), until these troubles began.

What are the key issues in these negotiations?

Agreement is needed about those Palestinian refugees wishing to return home, the Jewish settlers and control of West Bank water resources. These may be complicated matters but are simple compared to the issue of Jerusalem, though even there there have recently been signs of a possible compromise.

Is the fighting in anyone's interest?

The conflict is clearly putting pressure on the Israeli leader, Barak, and focusing world attention on the Palestinian cause. Some experts have suggested that is why the Palestinian authorities have been slow to halt their people's street protests. But Barak has elections coming up and does not want to appear weak. That may explain the ferocious response of the Israeli army.

The Palestinians want an independent inquiry into the violence. It is unlikely that Israel will accept this. And while these discussions carry on, the main peace talks are paused.

Curriculum links: history, RE, geography and citizenship.

Useful websites:

BBC and CNN for background to the Middle East conflict.

See also: the Palestinian refugee site: www.arts.mcgill.ca
Israeli government site: www.info.gov.il

webTitle: So you want to learn about... nutritionists

fields.headline: So you want to learn about...
fields.standfirst: Nutritionists
fields.trailText: Nutritionists
fields.body:
Yuk! Pardon?

You're surely not going to consume that thing. Dead right I am

You're really going to eat it? Well, I'm not going to sit here and stroke it.

But it's sheer poison. Rubbish! It's a chocolate éclair.

Precisely. Think of the damage it'll do. Nothing to what I'll do if I'm not left in peace to enjoy it.

Well, really. Haven't you heard of healthy eating? I hear nothing else all day, madam. I'm a nutritionist.

Never! And I'm a hungry one at that, so ...

But that's fascinating. What do you do exactly? We nutritionists promote the understanding of the effects of diet on the health of animals and humans by applying scientific knowledge, or dietetics.

I thought that was scientology. Certainly not.

So what is it? It's simply the interpretation and communication of the science of nutrition to enable people to make informed and practical choices about food and lifestyle.

You mean like telling them not to eat chocolate éclairs? Give it a rest.

What's the difference between dietetics and nutrition? All dietetics courses include nutrition but all nutrition courses do not lead to a qualification in dietetics.

Er, right. What qualities are needed? We require a basic interest and ability in science. And obviously an interest in diet and food, beyond the usual liking for the stuff, that is.

Anything else? Good communication skills and team-working skills would be preferred. And you mustn't be judgmental.

Perish the thought. Are there different specialities? Yes. There's animal nutrition, the study and promotion of the health of all animals: livestock, pets, wild animals and so forth. And public health nutrition, where nutrition is applied to benefit the general population, for example, in the relationship between diet and health and heart disease, cancer, weight issues etc. And sports nutrition, the promotion of public health, nutrition and physical activity in sports and exercise sciences.

What about career opportunities? These range widely for graduates and postgraduates. They exist in food and animal feed manufacture and retail, marketing, public relations, media, health promotion, community development, charities, health services, freelance and consultancy work, and research.

Wow! How do I get some of this action? A degree is advisable for a career as a nutritionist. There are degrees in nutritional science or combinations with food science, agriculture, dietetics, or sports science. The entry qualifications for a degree are usually five GCSEs (A-C), two or three A-levels, including chemistry and another science subject. Other qualifications are accepted, especially from mature applicants.

What about non-degree courses? These range from short courses to gain specific skills, which can last from a few days to a few months, to an HND in Nutrition Science. And now I'm going to eat this in peace.

 The Nutrition Society 10 Cambridge Court, 210 Shepherds Bush Road, London W6 7NJ www.nutsoc.org.uk

British Dietetic Association 7th Floor, Elizabeth House, 22 Suffolk Street, Birmingham B1 1LS Telephone 0120 6164900

 learndirect 0800 100900 may be able to give further information and advice on courses

webTitle: Furthermore: flying pigs in college

fields.headline: Pigs might fly
fields.standfirst: Janet Jones reflects on the everyday airborne porkers of college life
fields.trailText: Janet Jones reflects on the everyday airborne porkers of college life
fields.body:
"There's a pig flying past the window!" None of us looked. All of us laughed. We knew there was no pig. We knew the flying pig was the metaphor chosen to decorate the latest improbability here at the whiteboard in further education.

Improbabilities are legion in further education. Any one of these could have given rise to the flying pig:

1 No building works.

2 No members of staff being moved from one room to another.

3 No wires or cables trailing anywhere.

4 No toilets with "TEMPORARILY CLOSED - PLEASE USE AN ALTERNATIVE TOILET" written on the door.

5 No duplication - or other multiplication - of paperwork.

6 No assessment, moderation, validation, appraisal, inspection, verification, screening, observation.

7 No trouble with The Boiler.

8 No high-tech equipment that nobody can work.

9 No low-tech equipment that doesn't work.

10 No students on the wrong course.

11 No students on the wrong site.

12 No wrong courses.

13 No staff locked out of staffrooms.

14 Nobody locked out of classrooms.

15 Nobody locked in - the story goes she managed to break out as far as a telephone from where she dialled 999.

16 No disputes among staff.

17 No disputes among students.

18 No disputes among students and staff.

19 No doubts among anybody that we should all have the biggest pay rise ever ...

The Boiler (at number seven) deserves a few paragraphs to itself - it has the capacity to make a flying pig appear as a relatively reasonable phenomenon.

The Boiler has its own clause in our managers' contracts of employment and all new managers ought to be forewarned. The heart of the problem with The Boiler is, according to rumour, that it is not ours. It is next-door's. And not only does it belong to next-door - it is next-door, too.

Our relationship with next-door has a history of sensitivity and uncertainty, touching on wider issues than The Boiler. Next-door is not sure it wants to have anything to do with us. Next-door is not sure it is cool to have anything to do with further education at all. For next-door is another educational institution which regards itself as higher rather than further education.

Unfortunately for us we will be very cool indeed if we fail to preserve contact with next-door. We used to share a canteen along with The Boiler, but our relationship broke down over the way we were alleged to behave in the canteen. The corridor leading from further to higher was blocked off. If the same thing happens to the pipes leading from higher to further we will have a long holiday.

Maybe things are changing and next-door does not feel demeaned by its connection with us these days. We appreciate the warmth and the water. We have to live in hope of the occasional flying pig and sometimes look out of the window.

webTitle: If you ask me...how to encourage reading

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: My teenage son only reads the odd football magazine. He used to be such a voracious reader, but now he seems to have no interest in it at all. I'm concerned that this will hold him back in the future. Are my fears justified? What can I do to persuade him to read more?
fields.trailText: My teenage son only reads the odd football magazine. He used to be such a voracious reader, but now he seems to have no interest in it at all. I'm concerned that this will hold him back in the future. Are my fears justified? What can I do to persuade him to read more?
fields.body:
Dr Julie Davies, a lecturer in education at Sheffield University

Value what your son is reading. Boys are often put off reading at a young age because of the emphasis placed on fiction.

Your son is reading texts that are by no means evil. An important literacy skill is to read a range of genres - including the music press or fanzines. These give a link to popular culture, and often include critical and political articles, thus raising awareness of wider issues.

Discuss your son's reading with him and develop this critical awareness further. Fiction reading is important in developing the imagination and offers a richness of experience. Help your son by reading (and enjoying) teenage fiction yourself; discuss and recommend books with him. Excellent writers appealing to boys include David Almond, John Brindley, Melvin Burgess, Philip Pullman, or Robert Westall.

Look for TV tie-ins, sci-fi, thrillers, books that have a supernatural theme, are funny, or reflect your son's specific interests. Your local librarian can help, but nothing beats a trip with your son to mooch round bookshops together. Research suggests membership of male culture in schools is not necessarily a "given", but must be publicly earned, for example by rejecting academic "bookishness".

Remember it's tough for your son to please you and his teachers, as this threatens his membership of this "boys' club". Be sensitive.

Trevor Millum, from the National Association for the Teaching of English

While your concern is understandable, anxiety is counter-productive and attempts to encourage your son to read books will backfire. As parents, we tend to look back to when our children were younger, and imagine they were reading more than they were. We can also underestimate just how much our teenagers are reading. Boys will read what and when they want to.

Boys' interest in the Harry Potter books - by no means easy or short - is proof of this. Fiction can develop understanding about plot, character, emotion but so, too, do TV, films and some computer games. There's still a tendency to rank reading - from "classic fiction" at the top to magazines/computer screen at the bottom.

But reading has changed. Young people have far more material to pick from and deal with. Ensure your son has access to a variety of non-fiction texts around the home that he can dip into as and when he chooses.

Don't forget your son is reading a huge amount of prescribed texts at school, and take heart that he's still reading for relaxation.

 The Book Trust publishes reading lists at: www.booktrust.org.uk or tel: 0906 516 1193 (calls charged at £1.50 per minute) between 10am-1pm weekdays.

Colin Noble, Raising Boys' Achievement project manager at Kirklees LEA

As well as developing literacy and language skills, fiction gives insights and expressions to emotions and values which teenage boys often find difficult to express, or even deny.

If we're concerned about developing a caring masculinity within young men, we need to encourage them to understand and own such emotions. Many teenage boys respond well to a male mentor, who's invariably not their father. Younger teenage boys often see older teenage boys as smokers, drinkers, money-earners, risk-takers and generally unacademic.

Older brothers and friends could be encouraged to enthuse about books they've read. Many boys respond well to short-term challenges - "Bet you can't read that chapter by teatime" - and some enjoy interactive books where they can help decide the outcome.

Some find books with lively covers featuring boys far more attractive than those which are bland or feature girls. Similarly, boys from minority ethnic groups are often more attracted to books about boys from their ethnic group or culture.

Many boys respond to tasks which appear to have a purpose. If boys can see that reading will help them in the future, they may view it as a task worth undertaking. The trick is to turn the task into a pleasure.

webTitle: The Mary Ward Centre - hope for all

fields.headline: Pure learning
fields.standfirst: Chris Arnot visits a Bloomsbury group that's still going strong
fields.trailText: Chris Arnot visits a Bloomsbury group that's still going strong - the Mary Ward Centre
fields.body:
Rob Munro left school with just a swimming certificate and eventually found a dead-end job in a London hotel.

Six years ago, strolling past the Mary Ward Centre for adult education in Queen Square, he stopped and went in.

"Immediately, I felt it was a warm place, nobody was coming on heavy," says Munro, who is now 31 and has just started his second year of a fine art degree at Chelsea College of Art.

Mary Ward would have liked Monro's story. It would have confirmed her commitment to education as a means of "equalisation" in society, her belief that "the hundred pleasures and opportunities that fall mainly to the rich" should become more widely available.

She was the top-selling novelist Mrs Humphry Ward, who in the 1890s used some of her considerable earnings to found a "settlement" in Bloomsbury where ordinary people could enjoy concerts, debates and lectures. Gustav Holst was musical director for a time. Other lecturers were George Bernard Shaw, Sidney Webb and Keir Hardie.

Her legacy lives on in Bloomsbury, a name which invites images of rarefied intellectual jousting. But appearances can be deceptive.

"Behind those Portland-stone facades is a hinterland of poverty," says the centre's principal and warden Patrick Freestone. Poky bedsits lurk behind imposing hotels and expensive restaurants.

"The postcode is WC1, but a large proportion of names on the letters delivered around here are Bengali."

A typical daytime English course for beginners might include a 15-year-old Kosovan, a 70-year-old Bangladeshi and some migrant Portuguese working in nearby hotels and hospitals. For some of these students, learning to fill in a form in English is a major achievement.

Nobody is turned away. Freestone, 52, is an East Ender who went to one of the 1960s-built universities which expanded opportunities for those from working-class backgrounds. He retains a passionate belief in concepts that are current government buzzwords.

Social exclusion? "Apart from anything else, we run courses in Pentonville Prison and the offices of the Big Issue."

Lifelong learning? "We have more students over 90 than under 19."

Blanche d'Arbeloff was 93 when she joined an art class in 1986.

"She wouldn't stay with the over-60s class because she felt it wasn't stretching her enough," beams head of art Suzanna Jackson.

Like any college principal, Freestone worries about funding. Course fees cover less than 35% of his £1.3m budget.

"The Further Education Funding Council has been wonderful for this institution," Freestone says. But it is to be abolished and replaced by the Learning and Skills Council.

"There's a lot of rhetoric about lifelong learning and social capital, but funding may only come with leverage to meet national targets."

fields.bodyText: Rob Munro left school with just a swimming certificate and eventually found a dead-end job in a London hotel. Six years ago, strolling past the Mary Ward Centre for adult education in Queen Square, he stopped and went in. "Immediately, I felt it was a warm place, nobody was coming on heavy," says Munro, who is now 31 and has just started his second year of a fine art degree at Chelsea College of Art. Mary Ward would have liked Monro's story. It would have confirmed her commitment to education as a means of "equalisation" in society, her belief that "the hundred pleasures and opportunities that fall mainly to the rich" should become more widely available. She was the top-selling novelist Mrs Humphry Ward, who in the 1890s used some of her considerable earnings to found a "settlement" in Bloomsbury where ordinary people could enjoy concerts, debates and lectures. Gustav Holst was musical director for a time. Other lecturers were George Bernard Shaw, Sidney Webb and Keir Hardie. Her legacy lives on in Bloomsbury, a name which invites images of rarefied intellectual jousting. But appearances can be deceptive. "Behind those Portland-stone facades is a hinterland of poverty," says the centre's principal and warden Patrick Freestone. Poky bedsits lurk behind imposing hotels and expensive restaurants. "The postcode is WC1, but a large proportion of names on the letters delivered around here are Bengali." A typical daytime English course for beginners might include a 15-year-old Kosovan, a 70-year-old Bangladeshi and some migrant Portuguese working in nearby hotels and hospitals. For some of these students, learning to fill in a form in English is a major achievement. Nobody is turned away. Freestone, 52, is an East Ender who went to one of the 1960s-built universities which expanded opportunities for those from working-class backgrounds. He retains a passionate belief in concepts that are current government buzzwords. Social exclusion? "Apart from anything else, we run courses in Pentonville Prison and the offices of the Big Issue." Lifelong learning? "We have more students over 90 than under 19." Blanche d'Arbeloff was 93 when she joined an art class in 1986. "She wouldn't stay with the over-60s class because she felt it wasn't stretching her enough," beams head of art Suzanna Jackson. Like any college principal, Freestone worries about funding. Course fees cover less than 35% of his £1.3m budget. "The Further Education Funding Council has been wonderful for this institution," Freestone says. webTitle: The army is fighting for those post-16 students

fields.headline: Catch 'em young
fields.standfirst: Simon Midgley  on how the army is fighting for those post-16 students
fields.trailText: Simon Midgley on how the army is fighting for those post-16 students
fields.body:
Drenched by a steady drizzle, pairs of 17-year-old trainee soldiers negotiate their way warily through the deep twisting gorge coordinating their fire at sprung targets which rear unpredictably from the trees and bracken.

With the adrenaline pumping - live ammunition is being used for the first time - young men and women are learning to fire and manoeuvre together in a close quarter battle exercise.

Some 600 youngsters from the Army Foundation College near Harrogate took part in an end-of-course, two-week outdoor exercise on Otterburn moor in Northumberland. They learned to shoot, collaborate and hone their leadership skills in supervised exercises on austerely beautiful ranges flanked by the Pennines and the Cheviot Hills.

Two companies of young soldiers - Waterloo and Cambria - spent one week in a training camp and a second week living in the field.

Back in Harrogate, meanwhile, two fellow companies - Burma and Alamein - were continuing their classroom-based training.

The college, which has over 1,000 students housed in the former premises of the Royal Signals Army Apprentice College, was opened in 1998 to train the non-commissioned officers - corporals, sergeants and sergeant majors - of the future for service in the army's front line fighting forces - the Royal Armoured Corps, the Royal Artillery and the Infantry.

The college opened when the army was under-recruiting in order to persuade 16- and 17-year-olds to join before the army's formal recruitment age of 16 years nine months.

The idea is to attract recruits before they are lured into post-16 education and training or jobs in civvy street. In the past, junior entrants have tended to stay in the army longer and succeed better because they were well motivated.

Today the Army Foundation College, which is being re-built via a private finance initiative, offers a year-long course of military skills and vocational education.

As well as getting basic military training, students also work towards gaining a National Traineeship which comprises a core NVQ level 2 in IT and qualifications in communication skills, application of number, working with others, improving your own learning and problem solving at NVQ levels 2 or 3. Trainees also take part in a leadership and initiative programme.

Military training includes operating the standard infantry issue SA80 assault rifle, using grenades, fieldcraft, drill, map reading, air photography, first aid and nuclear, biological and chemical defence. As well as undertaking physical education, games and sports, students also climb, cave, kayak and mountaineer.

An intensive six-week period acclimatises new entrants to military life and discipline. The training is then divided into three, 14-week terms. Every seven weeks outstanding students are promoted to corporal, sergeant or sergeant major and students are paid up to £135.80 a week.

Students can discharge themselves at any time between two weeks' and six months' service. After six months, trainees are committed to at least three years service.

Last year some 85% of students achieved an NVQ at level 2. Overall some 20% of trainees drop out because of unsuitability or homesickness.

John Lyell, aged 17 from Hull, has enjoyed the course's leadership and initiative training. "It gives you the opportunity to take control of the situation," he said. "You are given command and problem-solving tasks.

"The physical side is challenging but nothing that you cannot handle."

He hopes to join the Prince of Wales own infantry regiment which will offer opportunities for postings to Jamaica, Oman and Northern Ireland.

Attea Houghton, aged 17, from Liverpool is Cambria company sergeant. She said: "I always wanted to join the army. The lifestyle was more appealing - travel and adventure."

Initially, she added, female students had to work very hard to prove to the males that they were up to it.

Lt Col Jonathan Garnett, commanding officer of the college, said that the field army is very impressed by the first generations of graduates from the college. "They are bright, well motivated, pick things up quickly," he said. "They've made a good start."

 For further information call 08457 300111 or visit the Army's website at www.army.mod.uk
