webTitle: Rostrum: what next for the Learning and Skills Council

fields.headline: Lifelong learning looms
fields.standfirst: The new post-16 landscape is here, but watch out for the locals, warns  Bryan Davies
fields.trailText: The new post-16 landscape is here, but watch out for the locals, warns Bryan Davies
fields.body:
The search for bridges over troubled waters was much in evidence at the Labour Conference in Brighton. At further education fringe meetings, including the Association of Colleges dinner, this was clearly the mood - the sector expressing anxieties rather than confidence about the immediate future. Ministers, of course, have carried the legislation creating the new Learning and Skills Council. The national chair, chief executive, chief inspectors, the chairs and executive directors of local learning and skills councils have all been appointed. Further education can readily appreciate the scale of the change, but it is many months away from receiving any of the benefits.

As the Further Education Funding Council winds down, several of its key figures have not made the transition to the Learning and Skills Council. Colleges are waking up to the fact that old relationships are in decline. Not that such links were necessarily cosy, but "better the devil you know". Moreover funding council officers and inspectors have prided themselves on their open relationships with colleges, who overwhelmingly formed their client group. In addition the funding council enjoyed the confidence that its performance was appreciated in the area which counted most, central government.

The quinquennial review gave the funding council a cleaner bill of health than any comparable quango. Moreover its low administrative costs and slim staff budget, only 2% of the total further education spend, won ministerial approval. Its regional structure applied a light touch, emphasising advice and support. Of course, on occasions it provided the evidence of college failings and formed rigorous judgments, but colleges could tap support without being enmeshed in the toils of excessive bureaucracy. The inspectorate in particular earned high marks for rigour yet accessibility.

A different world awaits. The Learning and Skills Council was never a rebadging exercise for the funding council or the Training Standards Council or the TECs, though clearly some of their features and many of their people have their full part to play in the new body. The Learning and Skills Council is charged by government with a massive responsibility. A society in which far too many have limited educational achievements and skills is to be transformed into the lifelong learning culture fitting for the age of rapid technological and societal change. Colleges bask in the knowledge that they are its biggest client group and are crucial to its success and much of the central funding structure will remain in place certainly in the early years.

Anxieties however mount, particularly as the local learning and skills councils take shape. Key appointments at local level emphasise that further education is only part of a much wider picture. In place of the regional structure of a national quango overwhelmingly dedicated to their role, there now rises the very different perspective of the local learning and skills councils. These bodies will enjoy much greater local input, not least by local authorities with their responsibilities in the post-16 and adult learning areas. Local employers and private training providers join the forum of decision takers in which the colleges participate.

Opportunities, of course, abound. The colleges will eventually see the comparative costs and advantages of their provision against school sixth forms become subject to keen local scrutiny, although local communities will inevitably tread with care in this most controversial of areas. The inspectorate will ensure that the quality enhancement imposed with increasing rigour upon the colleges will obtain for the private training providers too.

The price, however, will be the need for further education to argue its case in a much more intensive local forum in which it will be a minority interest in terms of representation, though the major provider. Further education is destined to come in from the cold. Yet for many in further education it may not be the problems of global, but of local, warming with which they will be wrestling. The level of disturbance means troubled waters. Further education needs to play its full part in ensuring that the local learning and skills councils are secure bridges of opportunity for the sector.

 Lord Bryan Davies is chair of the Further Education Funding Council

webTitle: A college that wants to be a department store

fields.headline: Are you being served?
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston visits a college that wants to be a department store
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston visits a college that wants to be a department store
fields.body:
Does any hawk-eyed John Lewis store detective recall a dapper middle-aged gent wandering around the chain's Kingston upon Thames branch? He would have been gazing keenly at the huge open spaces, at the seamless merging of lighting into leather goods into soft furnishings, at the winding escalators, at the never-ceasing buzz.

In one sense he was casing the joint. But don't fret, JL. The principal of South East Essex college of arts and technology wasn't planning some haberdashery heist.

Tony Pitcher was seeking inspiration. He was about to ask a firm of architects to design new premises for his college, and he was going to issue probably the oddest request in the history of further education construction.

"Build me a department store."

The architects, KSS, of Savile Row, took it on the chin. "If we'd asked them to build us a new college, they would have had all sorts of preconceptions of what a college should look like," explains Pitcher, who prefers the title chief executive. "So we said we wanted it to be like a department store.

"They were absolutely enthusiastic. They thought it was a really interesting architectural challenge, and not just another boring old technical college."

Now the Further Education Funding Council has given its blessing to the "relocation" and, provided a couple of minor planning issues can be sorted, work should begin on this £40m project next year.

Sometime in 2003, it will open. And the punters will be forgiven for thinking they've strayed into Grace Brothers because, apart from the proposed college's design, it will share the new complex in the centre of Southend with some real shops in a brand new mall. Any shopper taking the wrong escalator from the atrium floor will miss Boots and fetch up in the college foyer.

For a biggish chunk of the population, who get dragged under protest from Saturday sport on the telly, the typical department store is a foretaste of hell. So why would a college want to ape one? It's clearly no sudden whim. Over the past decade, since Pitcher took over as principal in 1991 of the then Southend college of technology, it has developed a style of operation that is radically different from the traditional model.

As in a big store, there are no internal divisions. Learning is not done in classrooms, Pitcher says. It takes place in 20 "learning centres" - big rooms of up to 500 square metres.

In each of these up to half a dozen groups of students learn. They're likely to be doing different courses, or at least different levels of the same course. The groups are served by teachers and "learning advisers" who assist students with particular problems.

"Teachers don't lecture except to give very short explanations of a concept when necessary," Pitcher explains. "And students don't waste time copying down material which the teacher has taken from a book and copied out on the whiteboard."

"We're trying to avoid inefficient ways of communicating information," chips in David Howe, director of quality assurance.

So where do students get their stuff?

"They get their material from worksheets and our intranet," says Pitcher.

The college certainly bristles with computers. This is apparent when the principal, Howe and David Latham, director of resource development, take the Guardian on a tour of the current premises near Southend Victoria station, and half a mile from the new site in the town centre.

This five-floor steel-framed and glass building was designed in the late 1950s along standard technical college lines. But now there are no walls, or very few. The television and sound recording studios, for instance, are enclosed, and for obvious reasons.

"Students get the feeling of working for a large purposeful organisation, not as an isolated group with one teacher," says Pitcher. "It's the sort of busy beehive feeling or of being in a modern department store. We're preparing students for a modern working environment."

Howe recalls one visitor remarking that it was more like a building society than a college. "I think they were being damning. I saw it as a compliment."

Removing walls boosts student performance and improves behaviour, the trio firmly believe. "It has been shown that students' behaviour is moderated by the size of the space they're in and the presence of people doing other activities ," says Howe. "An NVQ student might be energised by seeing people doing an HND in the same subject," says Latham.

The transition to the new style caused student recruitment to double from 1992 to 1995, says Pitcher. The college now has 3,550 full-time and 6,000 part-time students.

And how do teaching staff feel, exposed to such open display rather than safe in their own enclosed domains?

The revolution required gradual introduction and thorough explanation. Quite a few staff back in the early 1990s were apprehensive and there was a significant dash for early retirement, says Pitcher. "But after a while the nervous staff were those whose departments we hadn't yet introduced this method to."

The open-plan, learning-centre mode benefits teachers in many ways, he says. They pick up skills from their colleagues, who learn from them in return. And any problems they have are quickly spotted.

"The old method depends heavily on the skills of each teacher, who alone had to manage the learning of 25 to 30 people."

In the traditional classroom, even the most promising rookie teacher takes a few years to find out what works. In their own capsules they get little or no help from colleagues. Meanwhile, their students don't get the best.

The openness extends to the learning materials which staff produce. It's all the intellectual property of the college and has to be entered onto the intranet to be available to the next teachers needing it.

The college gets an increasing number of visitors from colleges here and overseas. Recently a delegation from Benenden, Princess Anne's old school, came calling and showed great interest in the learning centre method. Other colleges have adopted part of the method. Some had tried it and concluded it doesn't work.

It is a "student-centred" approach, says Pitcher. And like the "child-centred" methods so reviled as trendy nonsense by rightwing newspapers over the past decade it attracts suspicion.

"It shouldn't be underestimated," says Howe. "It's complex and only works if the whole jigsaw is in place.

"When critics say it doesn't work, it's because they haven't fitted in all the pieces of the jigsaw."

webTitle: Learning and Skills Council's equal opportunities  tested

fields.headline: 1 out of 47 - try harder
fields.standfirst: The government's equality pledge falters at the first hurdle, reports  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: The commission investigating the shortages of black staff in colleges wants to know why only one of the 47 chairs of the new bodies to run post-16 education is from an ethnic minority.
fields.body:
The commission investigating the shortages of black staff in colleges wants to know why only one of the 47 chairs of the new bodies to run post-16 education is from an ethnic minority.

This situation apparently contradicts the stated mission of the Learning and Skills Council, the national organisation which recruited the chairs, to strive ceaselessly for equal opportunities.

"We will expect the Learning and Skills Council to build equality of opportunity into all its policies ..." declares the council's prospectus.

To emphasise this commitment, it adds that one of the first tasks of the council will be to draw up a strategy to tackle under-representation from ethnic minorities.

And yet virtually its first act has been to appoint only one person from an ethnic minority among the chairs of the so-called local learning and skills councils, its subsidiary bodies around the country. These councils will play a key role in distributing resources for post-16 education.

The chairwoman of the Central London local learning and skills council will be Yvonne Thompson, who is black, runs her own public relations agency and is on the board of the London Development Agency. She is also one of just seven women appointed.

Mike Peters, chair of the Commission for Black Staff in Further Education, said: "It doesn't give me much confidence that the new Learning and Skills Council will of itself take equality issues really seriously, because on the surface it doesn't appear to have done so."

The Commission is inviting the Learning and Skill's chief executive John Harwood to explain.

"I don't want to condemn the organisation without them having the opportunity to respond properly," said Peters, who becomes director of education in Lambeth on November 1.

His sentiments were echoed by the Commission for Racial Equality and by the lecturers' union, Natfhe.

"We are disappointed with this result but we're not unappreciative of the efforts that have been made to encourage applications from ethnic minority people for those places," said Joe Charlesworth, a senior policy officer at the Commission for Racial Equality.

"We would back some careful scrutiny by the DfEE of the selection process."

There is disappointment within the Learning and Skills Council at this under-representation of people from ethnic minorities on the organisations which will play key roles in post-16 education, a spokesman said.

"It's fair to say we would have liked to have seen more representation from people from the ethnic minorities and people with disabilities," he said. "But we are quite confident that the procedure was open and fair."

This situation apparently contradicts the stated mission of the Learning and Skills Council, the national organisation which recruited the chairs, to strive ceaselessly for equal opportunities. "We will expect the Learning and Skills Council to build equality of opportunity into all its policies ..." declares the council's prospectus. To emphasise this commitment, it adds that one of the first tasks of the council will be to draw up a strategy to tackle under-representation from ethnic minorities. And yet virtually its first act has been to appoint only one person from an ethnic minority among the chairs of the so-called local learning and skills councils, its subsidiary bodies around the country. These councils will play a key role in distributing resources for post-16 education. The chairwoman of the Central London local learning and skills council will be Yvonne Thompson, who is black, runs her own public relations agency and is on the board of the London Development Agency. She is also one of just seven women appointed. Mike Peters, chair of the Commission for Black Staff in Further Education, said: "It doesn't give me much confidence that the new Learning and Skills Council will of itself take equality issues really seriously, because on the surface it doesn't appear to have done so." webTitle: How US university league tables work

fields.headline: Pay up or 'die'
fields.standfirst: US universities go to great lengths to gain a high league table ranking. But the system stinks, says  Geoffrey Alderman
fields.trailText: US universities go to great lengths to gain a high league table ranking. But the system stinks, says Geoffrey Alderman
fields.body:
The September issue of the Washington Monthly carries an exposé of the most prestigious university ranking tables in the US. It was in 1983 that US News first published its rankings of American universities. The early rankings were based on the personal perceptions of the presidents of what were termed "the best" higher education institutions in the States. Later, a small team of statisticians was put together to produce more "scientific" rankings. And now the rankings enjoy a cult following at home and abroad.

But as Nicholas Thompson, author of the exposé, explains, the US News rankings "are opaque enough that no one outside the magazine can figure out exactly how they work, yet clear enough to imply legitimacy".

His views have implications for the growing international obsession with league tables in higher education. Newspapers publish league tables to increase circulation. Compilers of these rankings are no doubt conscientious after a fashion, but they want to squeeze as much as they can from easily available data, preferably that published by institutions and which backroom data-processors can feed effortlessly into a spreadsheet. This entails some astonishing assumptions on their part - astonishing, that is, to those who bother to question them.

To take one example, newspaper rankings in the UK almost invariably take account of teaching inspection results. In the first few such inspections (1993-5), a literal grading was given, later to be replaced by a set of numerical scores. There is no way in which the early literal gradings can be legitimately translated into numerical scores, and yet this is what the Times and the Daily Telegraph newspapers do routinely.

The rankings published by US News are not based on measurements of what Thompson calls "actual education". This may be because in the US such data would be too expensive to gather, and too difficult to quantify. But the data does exist, in student-satisfaction and teacher-quality surveys which every university and college carries out. US News, it seems, just cannot be bothered to access the data and process it.

"The rankings," Thompson argues, "grease the skids for changes in specific directions." An investigation carried out last year by Professor Mantz Yorke and myself suggested that a preoccupation with teaching inspection outcomes, and with their impact on rankings, was resulting in a downward pressure on academic standards: the more firsts and upper seconds awarded, the better the league table position.

In the US the rankings industry has also affected university management. One measurement used by US News is the "alumni giving rate" - the per centage of alumni who give to their universities and colleges. This is argued to be "an indirect measure of alumni satisfaction". Thompson cites the case of Cornell University, which at one stage focused on soliciting a large number of small donations. At Stanford, students paid $25 an hour to solicit donations were specifically told to mention to alumni that "any donation" would improve Stanford's ranking. Elsewhere, it seems, alumni thought unlikely to donate are removed from the institution's database, or simply reclassified as dead.

In the US and UK, higher education is beset by rankings, and partly driven by them. This is unhealthy. In 1996 the president of Stanford University, Dr Gerhard Casper, wrote the editor of US News a stinging personal rebuke. Stanford is consistently one of the top-ranked US universities. Nonetheless he felt able to refer to the "specious formulas and spurious precision" of the US News rankings.

He added he was extremely sceptical that the quality of a university could be measured statistically. I agree. It is a great pity that other university heads, both here and in the US, have not given him the public support he deserves.

 Professor Geoffrey Alderman is vice-president of Touro College, New York, and former pro vice-chancellor of Middlesex University, London.

webTitle: Disabled students need more rights

fields.headline: Lesser of two equals
fields.standfirst: If you are a disabled lecturer, you don't have many rights. If you are a disabled student, you have even fewer. Not fair, says student and amputee  Lisa Miller
fields.trailText: If you are a disabled lecturer, you don't have many rights. If you are a disabled student, you have even fewer. Not fair, says student and amputee Lisa Miller
fields.body:
There I was ticking the multiple disability box on my Ucas form, while feeling no different from anyone else. I am a dyslexic, a diabetic and an amputee. I see the amputation as a problem but not the rest of it. So ticking that box left me feeling nervous: what on earth did university hold for me?

Now, two years on and just starting my second year at Newcastle University at 20, I realise why my disabilities were of such interest. As much as people would like to believe otherwise, disabled students still do not have a fair time in higher education. In fact, there are so many obstacles that are overlooked that it's ridiculous - not only on the learning front, but in everything else associated with student life, such as the social scene.

As a disabled student I don't feel different from anyone else, but the fact is that I am different, and because of this, improvements need to be made. Everyday things other people would find easy I am unable to do. This I am used to, but it would be made easier for me if people were more understanding of my needs.

Better facilities are needed. There is the usual situation of negotiating buildings. For example, when I started university last September I discovered that the specific accommodation for disabled students was designed for wheelchair users. However, my particular needs mean I need en suite accommodation - which these rooms did not have. En suite rooms were available in halls of residence and this is where I moved.

However, these halls are three miles outside the city centre, which leads to problems with transport. After the first year, students have to find their own accommodation. Ironically, finding somewhere for next year is relatively easy, as landlords ensure their property meets the specific requirements of the tenant - but there are obvious cost complications here.

Disabled students are under-represented in higher education: just 3.4% of the nation's students last year were registered disabled, as compared to 14% of the population. The Disability Discrimination Act (DDA) of 1982 should have helped redress the balance, but it is fatally flawed.

The problem is this. The act is only concerned with four core issues: employment; access to goods, services and facilities; the sale and letting of property; and access to transport. It excludes educational services from the main provisions. In other words, universities have to improve their facilities for their staff (protected under the employment provisions of the act) but not for their students.

Fair? I don't think so. I control my diabetes and have learned how to deal with my dyslexia, but my other disability is another story. Although most of the time I can lead a relatively "normal" life, there are differences that I come across that most people do not encounter.

At the beginning of this year, for instance, I was on crutches for four weeks. I was unable to attend lectures, which of course meant that I had a lot of catching up to do. In addition I was unable to carry anything for myself, could not get around with ease and had to rely on friends for help.

I enjoy university very much, but being so far away from the city centre I end up spending a small fortune on taxis due to my difficulties using public transport. And it is difficult to have a full social life, too - if I want to go to a nightclub and I am using crutches or a walking stick, entry is denied because they can be used as weapons.

At Newcastle University, people have been good to me and very understanding of my needs. But the number of disabled students here is low: 2.5% this year, nearly 1% below the national average. To pull these figures up, the university has applied to Hefce for funding to create a disability unit to support for disabled students. This is a great step forward.

And it is a step Newcastle and other universities are under increasing pressure to take. The recent decision by the Quality Assurance Agency to report on provision for the disabled in their assessments, has made sure of that, while the establishment of the Disability Rights Commission last April added to the pressure. More than ever, universities have no real option but to improve their provisions.

But giving disabled students equal opportunities is a long process. It will take time not only to deal with access but also to provide a sense of support for disabled students. Thought needs to go into both.

At the moment a vicious circle exists. In order to encourage more disabled students, universities need to improve their facilities and support. On the other hand, there is no need to do so while so few disabled people are entering higher education. It is time the circle was broken.

webTitle: Campus olympians

fields.headline: Target 2008
fields.standfirst: Government plans to regalvanise Olympic sports on UK campuses are only now being realised, yet the future looks great. By  Phil Revell
fields.trailText: Government plans to regalvanise Olympic sports on UK campuses are only now being realised, yet the future looks great. By Phil Revell
fields.body:
Great Britain picked up 11 golds, 10 silvers and seven bronze medals in the most successful Olympics for 70 years. But how much credit can our universities take? Only one on-campus programme produced medal success - Bath - with a gold and a bronze for pentathletes Stephanie Cook and Kate Allenby, and a judo silver for current student Kate Howey.

Bath's director of sport, Ged Roddy, has just been appointed director of a new regional sports institute. It's part of the UK Sports Institute, a John Major vision which was expected to achieve just the kind of Olympic success British athletes have just delivered. But the institute is three years behind schedule. Sport England's spending approval for the infrastructure investment envisaged by Major came through just a few days before athletes left for Sydney.

"The facilities developed here over the last few years are a result of the investment for the last Youth Olympics in 1995," says Roddy. "We were training Kate Howey in a converted squash court."

Bath plans to spend £23m of lottery money on new facilities. This is part of a £120m lottery-funded investment in sport, much of which will be spent on university-based facilities at the nine regional centres of the UK Sports Institute. Loughborough, Manchester Met, Sheffield, East Anglia, Southampton and Birmingham will also receive infrastructure investment, with separate funding for projects in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland.

But why the delay? Conservative plans for the institute involved massive spending on one national centre to be based in Sheffield. Sports governing bodies would move to the city to be alongside world-class facilities in over a dozen sports.

But the sporting bodies were never persuaded. Athletics, based in Birmingham, showed no inclination to move north, while cycling was just establishing itself at the velodrome in Manchester. Universities like Bath and Loughborough felt they had been left out of a scheme which ignored the need for regional centres of excellence.

In 1997 the incoming Labour administration came under fierce lobbying pressure. Sports minister Tony Banks soon announced a change of policy. The UK Institute would consist of regional centres based on existing centres of excellence.

Finally, in October last year, the funding was announced, but universities still had to submit detailed plans for approval and another 10 months slipped by before the first funding announcement was cleared, allowing Bath to put contracts out to tender.

Roddy doesn't want to get into recriminations: "British Sport has suffered from lack of investment for the past 40 years. I would travel from the centre of Sydney out to the swimming centre and I would pass four 50m pools on the way. Australia has 1,500 such pools. We have six, and only one - here at Bath - has been built since the last games in Atlanta."

At Loughborough, Rod Thorpe is waiting for final clearance for nearly £25m of investment on campus. The university will have one of those 50-metre pools, along with new indoor track and field facilities, new artificial pitches, centres for badminton and netball and a gymnastics analysis centre.

Both universities see the funding as a chance to open up higher education to more young people. Bath has introduced a HND specifically designed for young athletes, while Loughborough have worked on strategies which allow sports development and university level study to co-exist.

"We try to take a flexible approach," says Thorpe. "But you have to be careful - some laboratory-based courses are difficult to take time out from."

So when might we expect a return on the current investment? "Logic would say 2008," says Thorpe. "Results from investment in infrastructure are bound to take a little longer. What we will see is more young people coming through the system."

One way to achieve that is to bring athletes onto campus when still at school. At Bath, junior and senior players train together, with all the benefits that accrue when top-class role models are on hand to aid the development of younger players. Some of these are based on campus, hundreds of miles away from their parents, staying at local schools and juggling their education and their sport.

"I moved here in September last year," said 17-year-old Anne Murdoch. "My judo coach coaches the women's Olympic team. At the moment I'm training with people who are my heroes, people like Kate Howey. So it was the best place for me, it's a much higher level."

"People, facilities, athletes - it's not rocket science," says Roddy. "Put them together and you'll begin to see success coming out of the programme."

webTitle: Proposed British e-university

fields.headline: e-asy does it
fields.standfirst: Thanks to a proposal published today, the British e-university could be up and running by 2002.  Tim O'Shea, who helped with the plans, reports
fields.trailText: Thanks to a proposal published today, the British e-university could be up and running by 2002. Tim O'Shea, who helped with the plans, reports
fields.body:
The British e-university is suddenly looking very real. The proposal published today by the Higher Education Funding Council for England combines an exciting vision of the potential of a UK electronic university with remarkably sensible suggestions for the technological platforms and pedagogical models that would be deployed.

Instead of an institution run by a consortium of leading universities, it has emerged as a shop window to the world for the whole of UK higher education. It will take course materials from any university or college in the country - provided they are excellent - and feed them to learners anywhere in the world (or indeed in Britain).

The entire sector would own the e-university, which would have a "committee for academic quality" made up of respected academics from across the sector who would evaluate course proposals. This approach will be more like that used in the Research Assessment Exercise than the more contentious methods associated with Teaching Quality Assessment.

It is likely to be acceptable to universities, who will be able to use the e-university to greatly increase the audience they can reach for their awards.

The model will provide a strong incentive for universities to collaborate to offer the e-university courses, particularly postgraduate courses with a professional dimension. Universities working in consortia to produce new courses will need to identify quality assurance processes that fit their current practices and to propose which of them will function as the awarding body.

The key pedagogic ideas are to incorporate self-assessment material in each constituent module of any course and to provide navigation support for potential and active students as they move through and between courses and modules. This is a very learner-centred model which, if successfully implemented, could distinguish the e-university from its competitors by providing a much higher quality of student experience and lower levels of attrition.

The technological approach is to attempt to deal with the speed with which manufacturers' software and hardware platforms enter and vanish from the market by sticking to open web-based internet technologies and building on the success of UK academic networks such as SuperJANET. Course designers will be supported by templates which will ensure that the material they produce is capable of being delivered by the e-university and that key pedagogic issues such as learner navigation and self-assessment are always addressed.

I believe that the e-university could be operational in 2002, but there is a lot of work to be done before then. The current models of assessment used in universities are already a bad fit to technology-based courses. If a student uses a personal computer as a routine tool for much of their studying and practical work in a topic like computer-aided diagnosis; and if professionals always use computer-based tools; then it is stupid to forbid the use of a computer during exams. Eventually it will be taken as normal that students use personal computers for assessment, including three-hour exams. Some of the universities that work through the e-university will have to find the courage to radically extend the range of assessment models they offer for students registered directly with them and for their e-university awards.

Great universities have extensive libraries. The e-university must be able to offer an e-library that is the union rather than the intersection of the online digital information services offered by the participating universities. This e-library must yield a "sense of place" and of being part of the e-university community; and it must in itself be a key attraction for international students.

The e-university will have to overcome very difficult copyright and intellectual rights problems so that it can claim ownership of one of the world's important e-libraries.

The e-university must be able to support sustained student communities that continue beyond the temporal boundaries of courses, and its library will be a natural locus for them. The e-library should also be a base for groupings of academics, especially those concerned with disciplines like classics that need support or emerging interdisciplinary subjects such as bioinformatics that need clearer definition.

The "navigator" to counsel prospective students, discuss their prior qualifications and perhaps test them before they embark on a course, and advise them on what they would need for particular qualifications, is a central concept for the e-university. But as ubiquitous and omniscient advisers cannot be found in ordinary-sized real universities or out in internet space, designing effective navigation services will be a challenge. The suggestion proposed of offering learners a choice of competitive navigators is loopy. Multiple navigators would require the creation of meta-navigators to help the learners choose between them. Then we would need to choose between them. So we need to avoid this infinite regress and aim for the "seamless service" rightly espoused by the report. Tackling this design challenge we can draw on the work already done in the creation of the more successful portals on the web.

The e-university proposal makes much play of the need for "interactive tutorial support". This term covers a heterogeneous set of activities. It can be synchronous or asynchronous, delivered by humans or machines, and if humans are involved they could include peer students, tutors, navigators, courses designers or subject-matter experts.

This takes us into a complex educational design space. A machine agent can offer automated tutorial advice and some students may find it helpful and relevant. But the struggling student may find the advice meaningless and a mature student may find it pointless or patronising.

The design of interactive support depends crucially on the grain-size of the smallest learning module. The proposal that the smallest module be a half-semester course will make the design of support practical. The suggestion that much smaller "reusable learning objects" be indexed and stored is fraught with potential difficulty. There is an unresolved ten sion and trade-off in the current proposals between the desire for economies of scale that might be delivered through the reuse of tiny fragments of content and the need to design coherent student learning routes which will depend on reasonably sized modules and courses.

A very valuable idea that we owe to past work on teaching quality is "parity of provision". The e-university will have to address the digital divide. It divides those who have modern personal computers and those who do not, those who have access to cheap or free wireless network bandwidth and those who do not and those who are comfortable pointing and clicking and those for whom dots and slashes are a black mystery. The e-university must secure the necessary resources and backing so that it is seen to be increasing access to knowledge via new technology both in Britain and abroad.

The e-university will have to be clear on its values and the source of its competitive advantage. This will rest in part on the quality of UK academic awards and in part on effective navigation support for learners. It could also be built on a convincing e-library and on a repertoire of ways of using new technology to enhance the quality of student learning. The e-university could use technology to support the acquisition of higher-order learning skills relating to working collaboratively in groups, developing autonomy while surfing the web and manipulating visualisations of abstract concepts.

The e-university proposal is workable and it could thrive in competition against the current set of private virtual universities and other online providers. I hope it can successfully adopt the values associated with academic community, parity of provision, major university libraries and the use of technology to promote autonomy in learners and researchers. If it can do this then it has the potential to grow into a great new institution that past educational visionaries such as Sir Thomas Gresham, Cardinal Newman, George Birkbeck or Thomas Dewey would recognise as a real university.

webTitle: America's desire for British students

fields.headline: The hungry giant
fields.standfirst: Since Laura Spence, the Ivy League has found an appetite for Brits, says  Lee Elliot Major
fields.trailText: Since Laura Spence, the Ivy League has found an appetite for Brits, says Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
Hundreds of UK students are set to follow in the footsteps of Laura Spence and study in the US, as the top Ivy League schools intensify their recruitment drives in the UK this year.

Leading the charge of US admissions officers across the Atlantic is Dartmouth College, which is targeting talented state school pupils failing to get into Oxbridge and may even poach students already on UK degree courses. Dartmouth has already secured at least one application from another pupil at Laura Spence's former school.

Harvard admissions staff, meanwhile, say they are experiencing much more interest from UK students this year, particularly from the north of the country. Many believe the controversy over Spence's rejection by Oxford has made other state pupils much more aware of the opportunities available in the US.

This has exaggerated an existing trend. Since tuition fees were introduced for UK universities two years ago the Fulbright Commission, which supports Anglo-American educational exchanges, has witnessed a sharp rise in inquiries from UK students.The latest official figures show that 7,765 UK citizens were studying in the US in 1998-99, while the 90 US colleges represented at last weekend's undergraduate US education fair are expected to register record levels of interest from students this year.

However, relatively few UK students have up to now applied to Ivy league institutions. Dartmouth College, for example, had 20 applications last year, while the Harvard UK alumni team interviewed about 100 UK students. This is something the colleges are out to change.

"Dartmouth is trying hard to hire the best students from the UK. We perceive the lack of funding [in UK universities] to be a unique opportunity for us," said Professor David Blanchflower, a senior Dartmouth official. "We are prepared to consider transfers from high-quality students from UK universities. We have scholarships to offer. We are particularly interested in those from state schools who can't get into Oxford or Cambridge.

Ironically, a new marketing drive to promote British education abroad, launched by Tony Blair earlier in the year, has been one of the catalysts stirring the US universities into action.

"US universities are starting to wake up to the need to be much more proactive in the recruitment of international students as they have become aware of the increasing competition from Britain, Australia and other countries," said Joan Yamada Dawson, educational adviser for the Fulbright Commission. Meanwhile, the US government's reply to Blair's initiative is to mirror it: a "brand image" to market US education abroad is now being developed.

One of the most popular ways of securing US places is through prestigious athletic scholarships. Sean Reed, for example, won a $20,000 soccer scholarship to Rawlins College in Florida five years ago. He says it was an amazing experience that helped to broaden his horizons: "In Britain people are much more reserved, but in the US they are much more willing to take a chance with you." Reed, though, stressed that most students in US institutions were from very privileged backgrounds.

Some American students at the Ivy league universities, meanwhile, seem unable to recognise the rosy picture some British ministers have painted of Harvard and other Ivy League institutions.

In an article in Harvard University's student newspaper, a young journalist writes: "One of the peculiar aspects of the debate is the way Harvard is cited for utilising a progressive and inclusive admissions system that blindly finds the best talent rather than supporting an existing hierarchy."

He continues: "Admissions director Marlyn McGrath-Lewis denied that the entire Spence affair was a PR setup designed to draw attention away from the fact that Harvard admissions are decided by an elite cabal of Swiss bankers and the CIA."

webTitle: Grapevine: family learning initiative  in schools

fields.headline: A family business
fields.trailText: Family learning initiative in schools
fields.body:
It's not unusual for siblings to make music together - from the Jacksons in the 70s to the warring Gallagher brothers of Oasis fame.

But three members of the band at West Walton CP school in Norfolk have taken things even further. Matthew Jakeman, aged eight, plays keyboards, mum Fiona plays the clarinet and grandad Ron plays the drums. "He is very important," says Matthew. "He gives us the beat."

The importance of Ron's sense of rhythm is confirmed by Maggie Barwell, head of music and the inspiration behind the school's hugely successful family learning initiative, which seeks to break down barriers between parent and school.

The impetus for the initiative was the fact that upon entering the school, over 70% of reception children scored below the national average in their baseline assessment, due principally to the lack of pre-school provision in this rural area. In response to this, the school invited parents to take a more active part in their child's learning.

But, as headteacher Mick Robinson recognises, this isn't always easy. "Some parents have bad memories of school or feel threatened and suspicious of it," he says, "so they have to be encouraged to cross the threshold. By getting parents involved, this strengthens the partnership between home and school, which in turn increases the likelihood of children succeeding in their primary years."

Michelle Wake, marketing director of the Campaign for Learning, the national charity that champions lifelong learning, wholeheartedly agrees. "Research shows that children learn more effectively when they have family support, particularly in the early years."

At West Walton, the family learning project started with the parents from the word go. "We asked them for ideas, and having seen the school's chamber choir perform, they wanted to be a part of it," remembers Barwell. From this, a range of activities grew, which parents can attend with their children after school three nights a week. "The family French club began as a response to what the children wanted," says Barwell. "The whole nature of the clubs has changed as a result of the participants' influence."

The crèche held at the school is crucial, ensuring that all parents have the opportunity to attend such things as the "drop-in club", held every Wednesday. "Some just come along to play with their children, some bring games to share with others, and we occasionally invite specialists, such as an adviser from the Citizens' Advice Bureau or the school nurse - the parents set the agenda," says Barwell.

Jocelyn Bays, a learning assistant at West Walton, runs the family cookery classes. "In some cases, both mum and dad come along, and in other families elder siblings who now attend the high school come back to cook with their families," she says. Bays benefited personally from the initiative when she got married this summer - the family choir sang for the occasion.

Both Bays and her colleague, Cheryl Webb, enthuse about the very positive effects of families working together and the major improvements that result from the warm and open relationship between parents and teachers - a relationship that is fostered at an early age.

"Baby Joseph first came along to the weekly music sessions we hold for pre-school children with the reception class when he was two weeks old. At 10 months he was joining in. At first I thought it was coincidence, but then I realised that he was actually bowing in time with the music," Barwell laughs. Apart from a clear improvement in listening skills amongst those toddlers who have attended these sessions, once they enter the reception class any fears about going to school are largely banished.

Fiona Jakeman cannot praise the school enough. "We really feel a part of it, instead of walking in to the school and thinking, oh, I shouldn't really be here." She enjoys interacting with other children in the family band and choir, and thinks it's good for them to see that parents want to learn, too.

And it's not only the parents who have shown that you're never too old to learn. Leading by example, Robinson has started to learn to play the guitar. "I've always meant to, but have never got round to it."

Now if Ron Jakeman needs extra drumming practice, Fiona and Matthew can happily oblige, proving that learning in Norfolk really is a family affair.

 The Campaign for Learning publishes ideas for family learning on its website, www.campaign-for-learning.org.uk or phone Learn Direct on 0800 100 900 for advice and suggestions.

webTitle: When teachers return to their roots - their old school

fields.headline: Return to sender
fields.standfirst: Why can't teachers keep away from their old school, asks  Susannah Conway
fields.trailText: Why can't teachers keep away from their old school, asks Susannah Conway
fields.body:
There are probably very few of us who would relish going back to our old school, bumping into teachers we thought we'd seen the back of, but for some former pupils from Bridley Moor High School in Redditch, this is exactly what they wanted. At Bridley Moor, more than 10% of the teaching staff are ex-pupils. Acting head Val Duffy-Cross thinks this is because "there's a spirit here ... a warmth and a community. The students feel safe and secure." So safe, apparently, that some can't bear to leave.

A mixed comprehensive for children aged 13-18, the school currently has 894 pupils. Nine out of the school's 79 teaching staff studied here. They can be found in most departments - from maths and English to science and humanities - and their ages span generations, from the eldest, Roy Hooper, 57, who returned to the school in 1966, to the youngest, new recruit Kate Jones, 19, a special needs classroom assistant.

So what is it that compels students to come back and teach there? When Kate Jones took time out from her degree the school offered her a temporary position as a classroom assistant. "I loved it here so I didn't think twice about returning," she says.

Jones finds that being so close in age to the pupils means she can relate to their problems in class. "Some of my friends are still in the sixth form, but we now have to act in a different way because there are boundaries. If I meet a friend in the corridor, I would normally give them a hug but as a member of staff that's unthinkable."

Melanie Bullivant, 22 and also a classroom assistant, has returned to Bridley Moor for a year before starting a social work course. "I used to get on with the staff really well so it's been great to come back knowing everyone." Bullivant was the head student tutor in her sixth form. "The strangest thing is having to call the staff by their first names. I can't get used to that at all."

Steve Dunton, 28, now head of religious education, sent his CV to the school six years ago when he was between jobs. "At Bridley Moor I had felt more a part of a family than a school, so when I returned to teaching I wanted to give something back."

And like a family, the relationships between staff can be complicated. Kate Jones was taught by Sally Smith, 42, now an English teacher, who herself was taught by Roy Hooper. "The students I've taught, such as Sally and Melanie, have their own reasons for coming back of course," says Hooper. "But if they want to teach here, their relationships with the staff have already been built." The family atmosphere could also be attributed to members of staff knowing each for a long time, as Smith knows well: "I think back to times when I taught two or three of the other members of staff, and it's quite sobering because it makes you feel old."

The staff at Bridley Moor are adamant that the high proportion of "returners" is a good sign, and, on the whole, the experts agree. "They understand the culture, the standards and the values of the school and will be able to contribute usefully because they've already bought in to that," says Ben Williams, a chartered corporate psychologist based in Edinburgh. "These teachers recognise they gained a lot from the school and want to 'pay back' something."

But, Williams warns, if teachers return to their former school without teaching elsewhere, like Bridley Moor's younger members of staff have done, they risk losing the essential life experience that will inform their teaching. "My concern is if they are going out of academia having qualified as teachers, and don't go to other schools first, it can create a very blinkered attitude to life in general."

Bridley Moor's Ofsted inspection report is impressive, reporting GCSE results above the national norm, and sixth-form attainment that is "overwhelmingly satisfactory". The report also mentions the successful relationships between staff and students. "The teachers don't talk down to you, they talk to you and school feels so friendly," says 18-year-old head girl Claire Harris. "I must like it here because I come back every night - my part-time job is cleaning the school."

Sadly, Bridley Moor will close its doors to pupils in August 2001 after a local authority review decided that three of the five secondary schools in Redditch should close. Emotion has run high: "I would have loved to have sent my children here," laments Kate Jones. Ben Williams thinks it's a shame, too: "It sounds like there is a lot of love in that school, and we need more of that."

Steve Dunton, 28, now head of religious education, sent his CV to the school six years ago when he was between jobs. "At Bridley Moor I had felt more a part of a family than a school, so when I returned to teaching I wanted to give something back." And like a family, the relationships between staff can be complicated. Kate Jones was taught by Sally Smith, 42, now an English teacher, who herself was taught by Roy Hooper. "The students I've taught, such as Sally and Melanie, have their own reasons for coming back of course," says Hooper. "But if they want to teach here, their relationships with the staff have already been built." The family atmosphere could also be attributed to members of staff knowing each for a long time, as Smith knows well: "I think back to times when I taught two or three of the other members of staff, and it's quite sobering because it makes you feel old." The staff at Bridley Moor are adamant that the high proportion of "returners" is a good sign, and, on the whole, the experts agree. "They understand the culture, the standards and the values of the school and will be able to contribute usefully because they've already bought in to that," says Ben Williams, a chartered corporate psychologist based in Edinburgh. "These teachers recognise they gained a lot from the school and want to 'pay back' something." But, Williams warns, if teachers return to their former school without teaching elsewhere, like Bridley Moor's younger members of staff have done, they risk losing the essential life experience that will inform their teaching. "My concern is if they are going out of academia having qualified as teachers, and don't go to other schools first, it can create a very blinkered attitude to life in general." Bridley Moor's Ofsted inspection report is impressive, reporting GCSE results above the national norm, and sixth-form attainment that is "overwhelmingly satisfactory". The report also mentions the successful relationships between staff and students. "The teachers don't talk down to you, they talk to you and school feels so friendly," says 18-year-old head girl Claire Harris. "I must like it here because I come back every night - my part-time job is cleaning the school." Sadly, Bridley Moor will close its doors to pupils in August 2001 after a local authority review decided that three of the five secondary schools in Redditch should close. Emotion has run high: "I would have loved to have sent my children here," laments Kate Jones. Ben Williams thinks it's a shame, too: "It sounds like there is a lot of love in that school, and we need more of that."

webTitle: Getting the quiet pupils to speak up

fields.headline: Hey you, be noisy!
fields.standfirst: While disruptive children get all the attention, it is the quiet ones who may be the real problem.  Jerome Monahan reports
fields.trailText: While disruptive children get all the attention, it is the quiet ones who may be the real problem. Jerome Monahan reports
fields.body:
There are invisible children in our schools. Ask teachers and they immediately recall examples - the excruciatingly shy pupils who seemed to melt into the background, visibly shrinking when questions were asked or averting their eyes when addressed.

At break they were the forlorn figures standing apart from the hurly-burly. They were the troubled ones who never gave any trouble.

Kim Gregory is worried about her nine-year-old, Gary: "He is very lonely but he tries to dismiss his problems. He says, 'Oh, I don't mind, don't worry'. He's so ultra considerate - always at the back of the line, the one who gets the last sweet when they are being handed out. I fear one day he will explode."

A Hampshire mother, unwilling to reveal her identity, tells a similar tale of her 12-year-old: "He is completely lacking in self-confidence and is becoming very isolated. He is unnaturally well behaved. The teachers say he is so 'nice and polite', but they don't see how sad he is at home. His behaviour is convenient for them."

It's a view shared by health campaigners and professionals. "Children who act out will get the most notice," says Juliet Buckley of the charity Young Minds. Jeanette Newton of the Dudley Counselling Service feels that concern and funding is flowing predominantly to disruptive children.

But for children whose instinct it is to internalise their worries, the consequences of having their troubles overlooked can have profound consequences. Last year's "Bright Futures" report from The Mental Health Foundation identified communication difficulties and low self-esteem as key risk factors likely to contribute to children developing a mental health problem.

One organisation that focuses on the plight of the withdrawn child is the charity The Pyramid Trust. Since 1992, it has promoted a programme aimed at children of seven to nine - an age, according to the American psychologist Mortimer Schiffer, in which their main "social hunger" is for peer-acceptance. "In our view this is the ideal time to intervene," says the trust's chief executive, Alan Watson. "Every child deserves to have early signs of failure noticed and nipped in the bud."

The trust has developed an approach which it "franchises" out to local education or health authorities. "They contact us and we set them up as the local 'lead agency', responsible for promoting the idea among schools and then co-ordinating things once they get started," explains Watson.

The trust provides a blueprint for running the three-stage scheme. First, teachers are invited to assess their classes using checklists. Next, their "nominations" are discussed at a special "multi-service" meeting of teachers, psychologists, school nurses and representatives from educational welfare. From this gathering emerges a shortlist of 10. These pupils are invited to join a special after-school club that runs for 10 weeks and is co-ordinated by an outside volunteer, trained by The Pyramid Trust and employed by the lead organisation.

Once parents agree their children can attend, the club meetings begin. "Often this is the first time they have ever been selected for anything," says Alan Watson. "The clubs are designed to offer six key ingredients - love, security, praise, recognition, responsibility and new experiences - the children select a club name, design badges, cook, play games and there is always an outing. At the end there is a big farewell party."

The rationale for this approach is the seeming long-term boost in confidence. Among many success stories one stands out. "He started as a desperately alone child," says volunteer Jacqui Wood. "He never played and his anorak was 'fuzzy' on one side because he spent his breaks circling the playground alone, leaning on the walls as he went." His headteacher, Sue Murry-Wicks, takes up the tale: "After the club finished he had changed, now he can be seen playing football with the others."

Alan Watson regards the positive experiences gained in the clubs as a kind of "slow-release fertiliser" in these children's lives. "It builds their resilience to cope with subsequent buffets and, according to recent follow-up research, seemingly boosts their literacy skills, too."

For Zarrina Kurtz, one of the authors of an as yet unpublished review for the National Health Service Executive of the outcomes of treatments of psychiatric disorders in childhood, the court is still out on the long-term benefits of this kind of intervention. "But," she concedes, "if something can be done to help a child overcome a difficult stage in their life, enabling them to succeed when they appear to be failing, then it may be giving them access to a whole raft of other positives."

To date the National Pyramid Trust has run clubs in 86 schools for 930 children and has trained 280 volunteers. There are always more candidates than can be accommodated. What then for the thousands of "invisible" children slipping through the net, passing on to the even more daunting secondary school environment? Alan Watson is clear about the benefit of early intervention, but says it is never too late.

At Cator Park School For Girls in Bromley, Helen Palmer is definitely of this view. She and her special educational needs team are developing a programme for children in years 8-10 based on the social skills training method devised by the clinical psychologist Susan Spence.

The initiative also relies on teachers nominating pupils who give them cause for concern, eight of whom are offered the chance to meet together once a week for 16 weeks. The sessions explicitly target their social skills, with special questionnaires being used to prompt discussion about their feelings and experiences.

Palmer's colleague Charlotte Thomas is delivering the sessions and already sees improvements only six weeks down the line: "One girl was always covering her face - now she's making eye contact."

Services such as Young Minds have to help pick up the pieces when things for anxious or withdrawn children reach crisis point. "The isolation children experience at school can often be the raw material for much more serious difficulties later on," says Juliet Buckley. "Of all the problems we receive calls about, depression ranks the highest. The invisible child today often becomes the adolescent hiding in their bedroom of tomorrow."

 Bright Futures can be ordered from The Mental Health Foundation: 020-7535 7400. The National Pyramid Trust: 020-8579 5108.

Susan H. Spence's Social Skills Training programme is available from NFER-Nelson: 01753 827249.

Young Minds run a telephone service providing information and advice for anyone with concerns about the mental health of a child or young person: 0800 018 2138.

webTitle: A new study highlights the importance the arts in schools

fields.headline: Art & soul
fields.standfirst: For years, we've pushed children to do well in maths, in science, in this test and that. But now a new study highlights the importance of an area long overlooked: the arts
fields.trailText: For years, we've pushed children to do well in maths, in science, in this test and that. But now a new study highlights the importance of an area long overlooked: the arts
fields.body:
In a north London school a group of 15-year-olds is busy improvising. Ten minutes earlier when they entered the class, they were loud and rowdy, but now their concentration is rapt and they are working as a team. There is a quiet buzz about the room as if something exciting is taking place. It is. Before the session is over these children have turned some of their feelings about their daily lives, and the pressures they experience at school, at home and on the streets into a rough and ready but tender and true piece of theatre.

You may think this kind of scene is going on in secondary schools up and done the country, but you would be wrong. There is much talk of the arts being for all, but for secondary school children in England and Wales, access to a broad range of well-taught arts education covering art, music, drama and dance is a lottery.

A new study published today by the National Foundation for Educational Research shows that large numbers of pupils have little or no opportunity to take part in drama and dance, both of which lack status within the national curriculum, and many are leaving school feeling that their arts experience at school has had almost no impact on them. Most damagingly, almost two-thirds of a sample of more than 2,000 school leavers indicated that despite the importance music plays in most teenagers' lives, they had learnt very little from music while at secondary school. Many perceived music lessons as being elitist and equated them with a classical or music tradition that they felt was not relevant to them.

That's the bad news. However, the report also found that young people who are exposed to good and effective arts teaching experience remarkable benefits. The biggest study into arts education in secondary school ever undertaken, Arts Education in Secondary Schools: Effects and Effectiveness*, found that pupils studying art, music, drama and dance accrued heightened enjoyment and fulfilment, an increase in skill and knowledge, advances in personal and social development, development of creativity and thinking skills and the enrichment of communication and expressive skills. As one drama teacher put it: "It is another dimension to their lives, which isn't just a factual, mechanical dimension. It is something that is a life inside their head; it's an imaginative life; a creative life."

But shifts in educational policy over the last 15 years and the introduction of a national curriculum suggest that the push to produce more literate and numerate school-leavers may also mean that we are producing school-leavers with less rich imaginative lives and fewer creative skills. The late eighties saw the decimation of school music services as the national curriculum began to take shape and headteachers started to prioritise buying computers over musical instruments. Most children who want to learn a musical instrument must pay to do so. Activities such as drama and dance have been absorbed into English and PE or have become entirely extracurricular.

Tony Fegan, educational director of the London International Festival of Theatre, which has pioneered artist-led arts education in schools, points out :"the generation of artists in this country who are now in their 30s were the recipients of very good arts education". But where will the next generation of artists come from? The government may like to bask in the reflected glory of Brit art and Brit pop, but they have been slow to recognise that creative and cultural education is as important as literacy and numeracy.

The National Foundation report should help to persuade them rather more quickly, providing as it does firm evidence that good-quality teaching of the arts in schools clearly has a beneficial impact on children and young people. From the point of view of one 13-year-old, arts educa tion means "we get a lot of work done faster, we get more people co-operating and more people feeling happy". Put it another way, as the authors of the report do: "A school strong in the arts can better engage its pupils and counter disaffection and the need for exclusion." Now that should make the government sit up and listen.

The research findings that early exposure to the arts greatly improves future achievement should, in an ideal world, also have an impact on current primary school policy that can condemn four- and five-year-olds in reception classes to spend more time wielding a pen than a paint brush.

But the report's authors are very clear that it is not enough for schools to provide pupils with experience of just one or two art forms. Even in those schools with the strongest arts provision it is rare to find art, music, dance and drama all on offer. But the evidence is so clear that each of the art forms generates such distinctive benefits that the authors warn against policies which assume that the learning gains associated with one art form are broadly the same as those of the others. Dance offers increased awareness of the body and movement; art promotes expressive skills; drama nurtures empathy, and music extends active learning skills. All are necessary to create rounded individuals capable of fulfilling their potential in personal relationships, wider society and the workplace.

The report also adds to the growing body of research that casts doubt over beliefs that participation in the arts boosts academic achievement generally. This may dismay some arts education lobbyists who have put forward claims for the so-called "Mozart effect" that suggests that studying music will aid pupils' maths. But as Dr John Harland, the co-author of the report, points out, the evidence for the benefits of a good arts education are now so strong that the "Mozart effect" is irrelevant. "After all," he says "no other subject has to justify itself by its impact on other parts of the curriculum."

So how can good arts education for all be achieved? Harland argues strongly that "if the beneficial outcomes that the arts can stimulate are to be available to all pupils, there is a pressing case for reversing the trend towards selective policies that extend inequalities between schools and which result largely in the best schools for the arts becoming better." Clearly specialist arts schools along the lines of design and technology col leges are not the best way forward.

The current non-curricular status of dance and drama means that they are particularly vulnerable. As one teacher, quoted in the report, puts it: "Heads rule OK. It's as simple as that. At the end of the day if the head wants something in the school it will happen."

But if they don't, it won't. This could be countered if the contribution of dance and drama beyond that of PE and English were recognised and they were given comparable status in the national curriculum to that of art and music. Even so this has its dangers, as one teacher expresses: "Arts is dead if there is no scope for individual creativity. You might as well not bother in my opinion. We can't encourage creativity amongst kids and expect it to thrive, if we are in a curricular straitjacket." Timetables to match the needs of individual art forms are essential.

But the single most crucial factor in the success of arts education appears to be the employment of effective specialist teachers who are passionate about their subjects. The report found that individual teacher factors were more important determinants of effectiveness than whole-school factors. Children were quick to pick up the differences between the value of a PE teacher attempting to teach dance and a specialist dance teacher. They also had a clear preference for those able to demonstrate practical skill. Just as we need well-trained maths teachers, we need well-trained arts specialists with a real passion for their subject. If they are practising artists, so much the better.

The difference good teaching can make was demonstrated by one of the schools studied, where the music department had worked very hard at showing that music at school could incorporate pupils' own musical preferences. "We seem to have broken the barrier in school and showed that music is a cool thing to do, music is a cool place to hang out." If one school can do it, so can others.

As Harland says: "What we have to ask is how can we achieve equality of arts education for all children, not by dumbing down the best schools but by lifting the others." He adds: "With this report and previous research there is now enough evidence to offer an adequate argument for politicians." But are they ready to listen?

webTitle: US internet news firms win parity

fields.headline: US internet news firms win parity with wires as US ditches 15-minute rule
fields.trailText: 8am Internet news services in the US will be able to compete on a level playing field with financial news wires after the PR industry decided to end its practice of sending releases early to wire services. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Internet news services in the US will be able to compete on a level playing field with financial news wires after the PR industry decided to end its practice of sending releases early to wire services.

In the past financial wire services in the US always received corporate press releases 15 minutes before everyone else. This gave companies such as Reuters, Bloomberg and Dow Jones a monopoly on crucial information about company results and mergers and acquisitions, enabling them to charge professional traders large fees to access the service.

But the arrival of the internet meant the practice had become outdated and PR Newswire and Businesswire, the two main disseminators of corporate press releases, have now begun sending them to websites and other news providers at the same time.

This means that anyone looking for news on Yahoo or MSN will now see a release at the same time as a news wire will. The only condition is that sites carrying the press releases will have to ensure they are clearly labelled to enable readers to differentiate between a press release and a news article.

Charles H Morin, PR Newswire's president and chief executive, said: "After careful consideration and discussion with the media and other organisations involved, we have decided that the 15 minutes we give journalists to spread material news is no longer necessary.

"Once, the delay helped to level the playing field but technology and the overall effects of the internet have altered the landscape dramatically. We are now able to reach millions of investors, whether they are using the internet, cell phones, pagers or any other wireless device."

The 15-minute delay began in the 1960s as a way of ensuring that market-sensitive information could be widely disseminated before anyone could act on it.

The move does not affect the UK, where all news releases are controlled by the London Stock Exchange and the 15-minute delay will continue.

We are now able to reach millions of investors, whether they are using the internet, cell phones, pagers or any other wireless device." The 15-minute delay began in the 1960s as a way of ensuring that market-sensitive information could be widely disseminated before anyone could act on it. The move does not affect the UK, where all news releases are controlled by the London Stock Exchange and the 15-minute delay will continue.

webTitle: True North opens digital marketing arm

fields.headline: True North opens digital marketing arm
fields.trailText: 8am: True North is to launch a new digital marketing company, e-drive, to provide marketing solutions on the web, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
True North is to launch a new digital marketing company, e-drive, to provide marketing solutions on the web.

E-drive will be a division of Marketing Drive Worldwide, True North's below-the-line agency. It will be headed up worldwide by Mickey Goodman, the former president of customer relationship marketing at Marketing Drive, and in Europe by Alan Lawson, the current marketing director of Marketing Drive.

True North is setting up offices of e-drive in London, Paris and Hamburg. The London office will have about 20 staff.

E-drive will offer database and digital marketing services to new clients as well as existing Marketing Drive customers. These include United Biscuits, IPC and Daimler-Chrysler.

webTitle: D'Arcy picks up £1.5m disability task

fields.headline: D'Arcy picks up £1.5m disability task
fields.trailText: 8am: The government is ploughing an extra £1.5m into fighting discrimination on grounds of disability with the launch of a national press and poster campaign through D'Arcy. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
The government is ploughing an extra £1.5m into fighting discrimination on grounds of disability with the launch of a national press and poster campaign through D'Arcy.

The campaign kicks off next week targeting small business service providers to encourage them to think about how potentially restrictive their service might be for a disabled customer.

The work aims to show that making changes to customer services required by the Disability Discrimination Act helps disabled customers access goods and services as easily as anyone else.

Five ads, written by Angus Macadam and Paul Jordan, feature real business people showing what changes they've made to the way they deliver their service. Across the executions, different disabilities are shown to demonstrate that there are many disabilities that make access to goods and service sometimes tricky - reinforcing the idea that it's not just an issue for those in wheelchairs.

Kate Hopkins, account director at D'Arcy, said: "This campaign is more focused on getting service providers to act differently, not just think differently. Rresearch showed us that the best way of encouraging the behavioural change we want is to give people in business examples of what they could actually do."

webTitle: US TV ratings

fields.headline: Fugitive fails to run away with US audiences
fields.trailText: 8am US ratings:Warner Bros' remake of The Fugitive, one of the most hotly anticipated new shows of the US 2000-2001 season, made a strong but not spectacular debut on CBS on Friday night, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Warner Bros' remake of The Fugitive, one of the most hotly anticipated new shows of the US 2000-2001 season, made a strong but - given the hype surrounding it - not spectacular debut on CBS on Friday night.

The Fugitive drew an average audience of 13m (9.1 rating/16 share) on CBS from 8pm, dominating its 60-minute slot, according to preliminary Nielsen figures. But new 9pm CBS detective drama CSI - which is being made by a team including blockbuster film producer Jerry Bruckheimer (The Rock, Enemy of the State) - did even better, opening with 17m, 9.1/16.

A third new 60-minute CBS drama, The District, also debuted strongly on Saturday night. The show, which focuses on the efforts of a Washington DC police chief to clean up the city's streets, was the highest rating of the evening on any network, with 10.2/18 from 10pm.

On Friday night new Gabriel Byrne comedy vehicle Madigen Men premiered respectably on ABC, pulling in 8.5m viewers (6/10) from 9.30pm against the all-conquering CSI.

webTitle: ExxonMobil calls global media pitch

fields.headline: ExxonMobil names global media shortlist
fields.trailText: 8am: ExxonMobil has shortlisted five agencies as it seeks to consolidate its combined $100m global media buying account, Jade Garrett reports.
fields.body:
ExxonMobil has shortlisted five agencies as it seeks to consolidate its combined $100m (£75m) global media buying account.

Carat, Optimum Media Direction, Starcom MediaVest, Universal McCann and Zenith Media will pitch for the business in a review that is being handled from the US. The contract will take effect from next year.

Media buying for the company's range of products is currently shared among a wide range of agencies around the world. ExxonMobil may settle on more than one agency to handle the business, in which case the account could be divided by regions.

The Exxon Corp./Mobil Corp. merger was approved in November 1999. DDB has handled the creative account for Mobil since 1949. McCann-Erickson Worldwide has handled Exxon since 1912.

A decision is not expected for several weeks.

webTitle: The best candy scene: Dancer In The Dark

fields.headline: The best candy scene: Dancer In The Dark
fields.trailText: Selma (Björk) and her son Gene are visiting the well-appointed home of police officer Bill (David Morse) and his wife Linda (Cara Seymour). Bill puts some light classical music on the record player, while Linda enters carrying a tin of candy. Selma turns to her hosts.
fields.body:
Selma (Björk) and her son Gene are visiting the well-appointed home of police officer Bill (David Morse) and his wife Linda (Cara Seymour). Bill puts some light classical music on the record player, while Linda enters carrying a tin of candy. Selma turns to her hosts.

"You have such a beautiful home!"

Bill turns to Selma.

"Oh, it's nothing really."

"Sure it is," insists Linda. "I don't reckon anybody would expect your average police officer to have a place like this."

Bill grins coyly.

"Linda's great at making things look spiffy."

Selma looks up at Bill.

"Yes, and of course there's all that money you inherited, Bill..."

Linda smiles and nods. Bill says nothing.

"Where do you keep it?" Selma asks. "In the bank?"

"In a safe deposit box," Linda replies. "Bill thinks it's for the best."

Selma smiles gently.

"Oh, a safe deposit box. Good thing you don't keep it here. It wouldn't be very safe. Although it might be kind of nice too, 'cause then you could look at it once in a while."

"Sometimes Bill brings the box home, to check on things. You do, don't you Bill? But I guess nobody'd mess with a police officer."

Linda offers Selma a sweet.

"You always give us such fine and expensive things when we come and see you."

Bill catches Selma's eye.

"Oh, Linda always appreciated the good things."

See also: Willy Wonka And The Chocolate Factory, The French Connection

Don't see also: Reality Bites.

Pointless trivia: Dancer In The Dark director Lars von Trier added the "von" to his surname while studying at the Danish Film Academy.
